EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A noreaster moved up the coast southeast of Cape Cod and spread snow across much of Massachusetts, northern Connecticut, Rhode Island, and southern New Hampshire.
Strong southwest flow behind a warm front allowed for strong winds at the surface along the east coast of Massachusetts and southern New Hampshire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An amateur radio operator recorded a wind gust of 60 mph on a home weather station.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from the Great Lakes across central New England spreading snow across much of Southern New England.

Low pressure moved up the Atlantic coast and spread snow across southern New England.  Heavy snow fell across much of southern New Hampshire, downing trees and power lines.  At Manchester-Boston Regional Airport, more than a dozen flights were cancelled.

An intensifying coastal low spread heavy snow across southern New England. Snow began in the early afternoon across Connecticut and southwestern Massachusetts, spreading quickly across Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and southern New Hampshire. Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to eight inches of snow fell across eastern Hillsborough County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold frontal boundary dropped south of New England on the evening of the 10th. Low pressure developed along the frontal boundary across the southeastern states late on the night of the 10th into the 11th.  The low then tracked rapidly to the northeast, spreading a significant amount of precipitation into New England. A deep layer of warm air aloft and sub-freezing air at the surface resulted in a major ice storm across interior Massachusetts and southern New Hampshire as well as much of northern New England. ||The hardest hit areas in southern New England were the Monadnock region of southwest New Hampshire, the Worcester Hills in central Massachusetts, and the east slopes of the Berkshires in western Massachusetts. Anywhere from half an inch to an inch of ice accreted on many exposed surfaces. Especially when combined with breezy conditions, the ice downed numerous trees, branches, and power lines which resulted in widespread power outages. More than 300,000 customers were reportedly without power in Massachusetts and an additional 300,000 were without power in the state of New Hampshire. Because of the breadth of this storm (from Pennsylvania to Maine), extra crews to reinstate power were harder to come by.  Power crews from states as far away as South Carolina, as well as local National Guard teams, were called out to help with power restoration and clean up.  While most people had their power restored within a week, others were still without power at Christmas (nearly 2 weeks later). During this period, temperatures were mostly below normal and at least one major snowstorm affected the same area.  At the time of the December 19th snowstorm, over 100,000 customers were still without power in the two states combined.  Most communities had opened shelters to provide a warm, safe place for residents.  According to the numbers reported in local newspapers, most did not take advantage of this opportunity and chose to remain in their homes, using wood stoves or generators for heat.  Many schools, a week and a half from the winter holiday break at the time of the storm, cancelled school for the remainder of the month because of a lack of electricity and clear routes for transporting students.  ||A public works employee, supervising storm clean up in Marlborough, went missing during his shift and was found dead two days later in a reservoir.  Because this occurred as a part of his job, following the storm, it was considered an indirect fatality.  Damage to the infrastructure in Massachusetts and New Hampshire amounted to roughly eighty million dollars.  This amount does not include damage to private property, which was unavailable at the time of this report.  The extent of the damage and number of people affected prompted the governors of both Massachusetts and New Hampshire to request federal assistance.  FEMA approved both requests.  President Bush issued a Major Disaster Declaration for Public Assistance for seven Massachusetts counties and all of New Hampshire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half an inch of ice accumulated on exposed surfaces across eastern Hillsborough County.  Numerous wires down in Merrimack and Manchester.  Trees, wires, and utility poles downed in Pelham.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm moved southeast of Nantucket immediately following another coastal storm that affected southern New England on the 19th and 20th of December. This storm spread snow across all of southern New England then switched over to rain across northern Connecticut, Rhode Island and portions of Massachusetts south of the Massachusetts Turnpike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to twelve inches of snow fell across eastern Hillsborough County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early on the 5th, a strong storm system approached from the Plains. Ahead of the system, breezy southerly winds provided well above normal temperatures and abundant moisture. Warmth and moisture destabilized the atmosphere and fueled developing thunderstorms. A cold front moved across the state causing numerous severe storms and several tornadoes. One of the tornadoes tracked from Yell County to Sharp County, staying on the ground for 121.84 miles. This track length set a record for the longest tornado path ever recorded in Arkansas. The continuous track was confirmed by two National Weather Service meteorologists who flew the track with the Civil Air Patrol. The final track was based on ground surveys, the Civil Air Patrol flight, and an aerial mapping flight performed for the Arkansas Forestry Commission.
Severe thunderstorms affected a large part of Arkansas on the 8th.  There were a number of reports of wind damage and an isolated tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure off the Western U.S. coast helped transport abundant moisture into Southeast Arizona. Heavy rainfall occurred in the mountains causing flooding in the Catalinas and stream flooding in Greenlee County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swift water rescue occurred about 4 am at the Canada Del Oro Wash near West Overton Road and North La Cholla Blvd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rare and widespread snowfall occurred across much of southeast and east central Louisiana, beginning early in the morning of December 11th and continuing until around the noon hour, as an unusually strong and cold upper level storm system moved across the region. The snow, which was occasionally heavy, affected all but some of the immediate coastal areas. The heaviest snow occurred over the Florida parishes of east central and southeast Louisiana from east of Baton Rouge to the Pearl River, and along and to the north of Interstate 12. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 6 inches were common in this area with 6 to 8 inch totals occurring in sections of Tangipahoa Parish. The weight of the snow resulted in widespread power outages and tree damage in areas that received the heavier snowfall amounts. Snowfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common across areas to the south and southwest of Lake Pontchartrain including the New Orleans metropolitan area.

Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A farmer reported buildings and vehicles moved on his property by strong winds near Ashkum.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong thunderstorms moved across parts of far southern Lake Michigan during the afternoon hours of December 27th.

Heavy rain fell across northwest Indiana during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northwest Indiana during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures dropped to 5 to 10 degrees above zero during the morning of December 15th.  One woman died due to cold exposure.
Low temperatures dropped into the lower 20s on December 2nd.  One woman died due to cold exposure after suffering spinal injuries from a fall.
Low temperatures dropped into the lower teens on December 4th and to 5 to 10 degrees above zero on December 5th.  Three people died from cold exposure in Chicago.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: SKYWARN spotter reported trees and signs down on Old Brickyard road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff reported small sheds destroyed and the gazebo damaged in Ward and trees down on hwy 178 near Batesburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of pulse storms moved through the Midlands and Pee Dee region producing hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was reported near the Cheraw municipal airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Highway Patrol reported golf ball size hail on highway 378 on the Wateree bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of storms as well as several discrete supercells affected north Texas.  Hail as large as softballs was reported as well as a brief tornado touchdown.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golfball-size hail was reported between Belton and Little River Academy.

Snow and freezing rain in the late afternoon became all snow during the evening, with snow accumulations ranging from 2 to 5 inches. The freezing rain was generally brief and icing was light, except for more significant icing affecting travel in the Sioux City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow, mixed briefly with freezing rain at the beginning, accumulated 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm frontal boundry draped across Central Minnesota was the focus for scattered severe thunderstorms on this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Occurred behind the strong thunderstorms as high pressure moved into thea area.

CZ_NAME: EDISTO BEACH SC TO SAVANNAH GA OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line developed in advance of a cold front and tracked through the southeast United States, resulting in several strong to severe thunderstorms across the Atlantic Coastal Waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 39 mph was measured by the Salty Dog Cafe mesonet site on Hilton Head Island, South Carolina.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow showers developed during the early morning hours and continued through much of the day across the Tennessee border counties. Snow showers, heavy at times, continued near the Tennessee border, with heavy snowfall accumulations reported by early evening. The snow tapered off to flurries during the early morning hours. Total snowfall amounts ranged from an inch or 2 along the Blue Ridge, to as much as 6-7 inches in the higher elevations near the state line.

Snow showers, heavy at times, continued near the Tennessee border, with heavy snowfall accumulations reported by early evening. The snow tapered off to flurries during the early morning hours. Total snowfall amounts ranged from an inch or 2 along the Blue Ridge, to as much as 6-7 inches in the higher elevations near the state line.

Total snowfall amounts ranged from an inch or 2 along the Blue Ridge, to as much as 6-7 inches in the higher elevations near the state line.

Snow showers developed overnight and continued through much of the day across the higher elevations of the Tennessee border counties. Heavy snowfall accumulations were reported in the higher elevations along the Tennessee border by noon. The snow continued off and on through the day, with total snowfall accumulations of 2-7 inches reported by late in the evening. Meanwhile, valley locations in these areas received little more than a dusting.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.

A complex winter storm brought high winds and snow to northern and central Nevada. The high winds caused blowing and drifting of the snow which reduced visibilities to less than 1/4 mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought strong winds and snow to northern Nye county. Frequent wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph occurred with this storm with occasional gusts of 45 to 55 mph. This reduced visibility to less than 1/4 mile at times in snow and blowing snow. Three inches of new snow fell in Tonopah.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm brought strong winds and snow to northern Lander and northern Eureka counties. Winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting snow making travel conditions very difficult and hazardous. Battle Mountain picked up 2 inches of new snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought strong winds and snow to northern Nye county. Winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph caused blowing and drifting snow making travel difficult and hazardous. A spotter in Reese River reported 3 inches of new snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure located over the eastern Great Lakes on Tuesday morning, January 1st, tracked east across central New York Tuesday afternoon, and off the New England coast by Wednesday morning on January 2nd. ||As this low pressure tracked east, a swath of light to moderate snow fell across much of eastern New York and western New England from early Tuesday morning into Wednesday morning. ||This storm system produced 3 to 7 inches of snow accumulation across the Berkshires of western Massachusetts, with the greatest amounts across the higher elevations of northern Berkshire county.||This light to moderate snowfall created hazardous travel conditions for the Wednesday morning commute, and also led to the delayed openings of some schools and businesses Wednesday morning.

As cold air poured over the relatively warmer waters of the Great Lakes, bands of moderate to locally heavy snow developed and affected northern portions of Herkimer County. ||The snowbands developed Friday morning on January 25th, and persisted until early Saturday morning on January 26th. Localized snowfall amounts of 6 to 10 inches fell, mainly for areas near and north of Route 28.

A strong low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region.  Snow developed out of this system late in the day on November 30th, and continued through a good part of December 1st.  Snowfall totals of around a foot were common in a band arcing from just west of Traverse City, northeastward into Eastern Upper Michigan.  Trout Lake picked up 17 inches of snow, East Jordan had around 15 inches, and Interlochen right around a foot.

A strong upper level low dropped southward across New Mexico and brought heavy snow to the southern Sacramento Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From 6 to 8 inches of snow was measured between Cloudcroft and Sunspot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large, strong upper level trough approached far west Texas from the west. In response, a deep surface trough developed in the southern plains to the northeast of the area. The tight surface pressure gradient and mixing down of strong winds aloft resulted in high winds at the surface.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were measured from 59 mph to 73 mph across the northeast and east portions of El Paso from the evening of the 13th through the noon hour of the 14th. A roof was blown off of a house in northeast El Paso. Also, several power lines blown down resulting in power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level trough moved eastward across the desert southwest and induced a deep surface low in the Texas panhandle. A tight surface gradient and the mixing down of strong winds aloft resulted in high winds at the surface.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust of 60 mph was measured 15 miles south of Hachita.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As steady precipitation associated with a warm front moved back into Sussex County on the evening of the 29th, temperatures were still around freezing over some of the higher terrain. It was still warm enough aloft for precipitation to fall as rain. At the ground it froze on contact on some exposed surfaces, roadways and bridges and made for slippery travel on untreated surfaces. As southeast to south winds continued through the night, temperatures rose above freezing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense Pacific storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to all of southeast Idaho.  One to three feet of snow fell in the Central Mountains with 4 to 8 inches in the Snake River Plain with blizzard conditions.  One to two feet were common in the southern and southeast highlands with up to 32 inches in the Upper Snake Highlands.  Interstates 84 and 86 were closed east of Declo.  State Highways 39,32,37,46,21, 81, and 77 were all closed.  US Highways 20 and 26 were closed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained 40 mph winds with gusts over 60 mph at the Pocatello Regional Airport caused blizzard conditions for several hours on Christmas morning.  Interstate 86 was closed from Pocatello west to the Interstate 84 intersection due to the strong winds and drifting snow.   Snow amounts were 7 inches in Chubbuck, Pocatello, and Blackfoot with  6.5 inches at the Pocatello Regional Airport.  3 to 4 foot drifts were common in the Pocatello area.  State Highway 37 from American Falls to the Oneida/Power County line was closed due to drifting snow.  State Highway 39 from American Falls to 12 miles east of Aberdeen was closed.  Power lines were downed due to the winds 6 miles northeast of American Falls.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in the Caribou Highlands with spotters reporting 16 inches 7 miles east of Pocatello, and 18 inches in Bone.  Heavy SNOTEL amounts were 21 inches at Sedgwick Peak, and 9 inches at Sheep Mountain and Somsen Ranch.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow amounts reported by spotters were 11 inches in Preston and 18 inches in Weston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts knocked over a power pole and blew tin off of a barn near Wasola.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm wind gusts damaged a roof of a church south of Wasola along Highway 5.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 37 knots (43 mph) was measured at the Sand Key Light C-MAN station.

CZ_NAME: BIG AND LITTLE WOOD RIVER REGION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of Pacific storms the last week of December brought heavy snow to the Central Mountains and Upper Snake and South Central Highlands.  Whiteout conditions occurred in the Snake River Plain with road closures in the South Central Highlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snow fell at the Lost Wood Divide SNOTEL site.  Other heavy SNOTEL amounts were: 13 inches at Dollarhide, 10 inches at Galena Summit, 14 inches at Galena Lodge, 17 inches at Vienna Mine, and 9 inches at Bald Mountain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of Pacific storms the last week of December brought heavy snow to the Central Mountains and Upper Snake and South Central Highlands.  Whiteout conditions occurred in the Snake River Plain with road closures in the South Central Highlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drifting snow and strong winds caused interstate 86 east bound to be closed east of American Falls.  The winds caused whiteout conditions near American Falls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of Pacific storms the last week of December brought heavy snow to the Central Mountains and Upper Snake and South Central Highlands.  Whiteout conditions occurred in the Snake River Plain with road closures in the South Central Highlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US Highway 20 closed from Ashton to the Montana state line on the 29th.  14 inches of snow reported by a spotter in Island Park.  Snow amounts at SNOTEL sites were 10 inches at Island Park, 9 inches at White Elephant, and 12 inches at Black Bear.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system lifted out of the Midwest and tracked just west of Buffalo to near Ottawa and Montreal. This is a very favorable track for high winds across much of Western New York as strong gusty winds are further enhanced by the funneling effects of Lakes Erie and Ontario. The strong winds developed during the evening hours and continued until early morning of the 25th. The highest gusts exceeded 60 miles per hour. The winds downed trees and power lines with tens of thousands left without power. Specific reported wind gusts included: 62 m.p.h. at Watertown Airport and Rochester Airport; 61 m.p.h. at Eden and Oswego; 60 m.p.h. at Java Center; 59 m.p.h. at Oswego Coast Guard; 58 m.p.h. at Dunkirk, Alden and Hamburg; 55 m.p.h. at Buffalo Airport and Canandaigua; 54 m.p.h. at Fulton; and 52 m.p.h. at Wellsville.

A rare and widespread snowfall occurred across much of southeast and east central Louisiana, beginning early in the morning of December 11th and continuing until around the noon hour, as an unusually strong and cold upper level storm system moved across the region. The snow, which was occasionally heavy, affected all but some of the immediate coastal areas. The heaviest snow occurred over the Florida parishes of east central and southeast Louisiana from east of Baton Rouge to the Pearl River, and along and to the north of Interstate 12. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 6 inches were common in this area with 6 to 8 inch totals occurring in sections of Tangipahoa Parish. The weight of the snow resulted in widespread power outages and tree damage in areas that received the heavier snowfall amounts. Snowfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common across areas to the south and southwest of Lake Pontchartrain including the New Orleans metropolitan area.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures dropped into the teens on the morning of December 8th.  One man died in Chicago due to cold exposure.

Very cold air spread across northern Illinois starting on December 21st and continuing through December 25th.  Low temperatures dropped to 5 below to 10 below zero on the 21st and 22nd, and were in the low single digits on the 23rd, 24th and 25th.  Five people died due to cold exposure, two in Chicago, one in Des Plaines, one in Western Springs and one in Addison.

Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood water was reported up to the foundations of several homes and was flowing over several roads.  A tributary was one foot above the Adams Road bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were down around the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less. The dense fog occurred along and just ahead of a warm front. Light east to southeast winds brought moist air over cold, icy ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow and freezing rain in the late afternoon became all snow during the evening, with snow accumulations ranging from 2 to 5 inches. The freezing rain was generally brief and icing was light, except for more significant icing affecting travel in the Sioux City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow and freezing rain became all snow by early evening, with snow accumulating 2 to 5 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain caused icy roads before changing to snow in the early evening. Snow then accumulated 2 to 4 inches. The icy roads contributed to several accidents, but no reported injuries, in the Sioux City area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure over the Northern Plains dropped southeast across Illinois and generated light snow amounts of 0.5 to 2.5 inches over south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  However, freezing rain and sleet accumulations of 1/10 to 2/10 of an inch occurred before colder air changed the precipitation to snow.  Road surfaces became slippery and dozens of vehicle accidents were reported by the media.  The greatest accumulations of 2 to 2.5 inches occurred from Marquette County east to Fond du Lac County.  Amounts tapered off to less than a half inch near the Illinois border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved across Southern Canada during the early morning hours of the 5th. The low pressure combined with high pressure over Eastern Idaho created a tight pressure gradient across Western Montana. This strong surface pressure gradient resulted in strong southwest winds across the valleys of South Central Montana.
Strong low pressure that moved across Southern Canada caused a brief period of very strong winds across the Livingston and Nye areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 50 mph were reported at the Livingston Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure that moved across Southern Canada caused a brief period of very strong winds across the Livingston and Nye areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 50 mph were reported in the Nye area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist Pacific storm system produced heavy snow accumulations across the Beartooth and Absaroka Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fisher Creek Snotel reported 9 inches of new snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong pressure falls across Northern Montana resulted in strong pressure gradients across portions of Northern Wyoming. This resulted in high winds across the Sheridan Foothills area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 mph was reported at the Sheridan Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong pressure falls across Northern Montana resulted in strong pressure gradients across the Eastern Foothills of the Rocky Mountain Front Range. As a result, high winds were reported across the western portions of the Billings Forecast Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 40 mph were reported in Harlowton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of up to an inch and a quarter combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the 60s  to melt a snowpack of four to eight inches which resulted in flooding on the creeks and streams of Western New York.|Cazenovia Creek at Ebenezer crested above its 10 flood stage at 13.0 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in West Seneca and near Cazenovia Park in South Buffalo.|Buffalo Creek at Gardenville crested above its 7 flood stage at 8.71 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding occurred in Elma and Gardenville.|Cayuga Creek at Lancaster crested above its 8 flood stage at 9.23 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in Marilla, Alden and Lancaster.|Tonawanda Creek at Batavia crested above its 9 flood stage at 11.71 feet at 10 a.m. on the 28th.|Tonawanda Creek at Rapids crested above its 12 flood stage at 14.56 feet at 9 a.m. on the 30th. Widespread flooding occurred from Batavia through Alabama, Clarence, Newstead, Akron and Amherst. Backwater flooding occurred on Ransom, Black, Beeman and Mud Creeks.|Black Creet at Churchville crested above its 6 flood stage at 7.87 feet at 7 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding extended from Chili to Churchville.|Oatka Creek at Garbutt crested above its 6 flood stage at 6.85 feet at 1 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding was reported in Garbutt and Scottsville.|Ellicott Creek at Williamsville crested above its 8 flood stage at 10.35 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding was reported along the creek in Bowmansville, Cheektowaga, Williamsville and Amherst.|Road, low-lying and basement flooding was reported along these creeks and some evacuations were ordered.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system tracked northeast from the eastern Great Lakes into eastern Canada during Wednesday, January 30th. A strong cold front associated with this low swept across east central New York State during the late morning and early afternoon hours of Wednesday, accompanied by locally damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down due to strong winds. One tree fell in Greenfield, while another fell within the Town of Ballston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intensifying low pressure tracking northeast along the Atlantic coast crossed the Gulf of Maine during the 14th...before exiting through the maritimes during the 15th. Heavy snow developed during the morning of the 14th...continued overnight...then ended during the morning of the 15th. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were reported at times across central and Downeast Maine. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 15 inches across Downeast Maine...with 7 to 12 inches across central areas. Winds of 15 to 25 mph contributed to significant blowing and drifting snow...with near whiteout conditions at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow accumulations ranged from 5 to 9 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level trough moved eastward across the desert southwest and induced a deep surface low in the Texas panhandle. A tight surface gradient and the mixing down of strong winds aloft resulted in high winds at the surface.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 60 to 67 mph were measured at White Sands Missle Range Headquarters. A gust of 97 mph was measured near San Augustine Pass. Windows were blown out of vehicles at the WSMR main post.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust of 71 mph was measured just southwest of High Rolls.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred at the Kingman airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 2 miles SSE of Independence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained at near 30 mph with gusts around 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 1 to 3 inches to produce areas of blowing snow, with brief visibilities near a quarter mile in places. The strong winds and temperatures falling to around zero produced wind chill readings of 20 to 25 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained near 30 mph with gusts around 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 1 to 3 inches to produce blowing snow, with brief visibilities around a quarter mile in places. Temperatures falling to near zero combined with the strong winds to produce wind chill readings of 20 to 25 below zero.

Low pressure moved out of the central Plains and moved across Pennsylvania. The low brought an eight to twelve inch blanket of snow to the entire region on the 19th. Across the western southern tier, snowfall amounts were slightly lower however, the snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet across that area. Some of the highest snowfall amounts included: 16 inches at Fairport; 15 inches at Youngstown; 14 inches at LaSalle; 13 inches at Medina; 12 inches at Getzville, Lockport, and North Tonawanda; 11 inches at Montezuma, Charlotte, Perinton, and Warsaw; 10 inches at Kenmore, Buffalo, Stafford, Pavilion, Lowville, Harrisville, Rochester, Niagara Falls, Wilson, Oswego, Walworth and Akron; 9 inches at West Seneca, Black River, Calcium, Hooker, Gorham, Phelps, and Palmyra. Innumerable automobile accidents were reported throughout the region as the roads became hard to navigate in the heavy snow and reduced visibilities. Schools shut down across the region and many municipalities suggested avoiding unnecessary travel if possible.

An intense Pacific storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to all of southeast Idaho.  One to three feet of snow fell in the Central Mountains with 4 to 8 inches in the Snake River Plain with blizzard conditions.  One to two feet were common in the southern and southeast highlands with up to 32 inches in the Upper Snake Highlands.  Interstates 84 and 86 were closed east of Declo.  State Highways 39,32,37,46,21, 81, and 77 were all closed.  US Highways 20 and 26 were closed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported 24 inches of snow 3 miles west-northwest of Arco. 12 inches fell at the Hilts Creek SNOTEL.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of temperatures falling to 5 below to 10 below zero and winds of 20 to 30 mph caused wind chill readings to drop to 35 below zero across much of northern Illinois during the morning hours of December 21st.

A combination of temperatures falling to 5 below to 10 below zero and winds of 20 to 30 mph caused wind chill readings to drop to 35 below zero across much of northern Illinois during the morning hours of December 21st.

A deepening storm system lifted out of the Midwest and tracked just west of Buffalo to near Ottawa and Montreal. This is a very favorable track for high winds across much of Western New York as strong gusty winds are further enhanced by the funneling effects of Lakes Erie and Ontario. The strong winds developed during the evening hours and continued until early morning of the 25th. The highest gusts exceeded 60 miles per hour. The winds downed trees and power lines with tens of thousands left without power. Specific reported wind gusts included: 62 m.p.h. at Watertown Airport and Rochester Airport; 61 m.p.h. at Eden and Oswego; 60 m.p.h. at Java Center; 59 m.p.h. at Oswego Coast Guard; 58 m.p.h. at Dunkirk, Alden and Hamburg; 55 m.p.h. at Buffalo Airport and Canandaigua; 54 m.p.h. at Fulton; and 52 m.p.h. at Wellsville.

A strong cold front crossed the region during the morning hours. Winds shifted to the southwest and increased rapidly. The combination of the wind shift, rapid strengthening of the wind speed and the long fetch up the length of Lake Erie produced a seiche on the lake. Water levels rose over six and a half feet in about three hours time. The Lake Erie water level crested at Buffalo at 8.1 feet, just above its eight foot flood stage. Flooding was reported along the lake shore from Angola to Buffalo.

A deepening area of low pressure moved across the Ohio valley and Pennsylvania before moving off the southern New England Coast during the afternoon of the 31st. Steady snow developed over the region and was accompanied by increasing northerly winds. Widespread snowfall amounts ranged from eight to fourteen inches during the eight hour event. The strong winds produced areas of blowing and drifting snow and resulted in significantly reduced visibilities. Some of the highest snowfall reports included: 14 inches at Walworth; 12 inches at Fairport; 11 inches at Lockport; 10 inches at Alden, Colden, Kenmore, Livonia, Penfield, and Warsaw; 9 inches at Sinclairville, Buffalo, Amherst, Clarence, Elma, Pavilion, Greece and Niagara Falls; and 8 inches at South Dayton, Montezuma, Avon, Mount Morris and Newark.

Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were reported to be flooded and closed across eastern Ogle County, including Route 72 near Davis Junction, Route 251 south of Route 64 and Route 2 north of Bryon.  Stormtotal rainfall amounts included 1.48 inches 3 miles north of Bryon and 1.18 inches near Rochelle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads across eastern Lee County were flooded, some were closed.  Ditches and creeks were also flooded.  Stormtotal rainfall amounts included 1.88 inches near Dixon and 1.44 inches near Paw Paw.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inch diameter tree limbs were blown down near Route 18 and East 9th Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of up to an inch and a quarter combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the 60s  to melt a snowpack of four to eight inches which resulted in flooding on the creeks and streams of Western New York.|Cazenovia Creek at Ebenezer crested above its 10 flood stage at 13.0 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in West Seneca and near Cazenovia Park in South Buffalo.|Buffalo Creek at Gardenville crested above its 7 flood stage at 8.71 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding occurred in Elma and Gardenville.|Cayuga Creek at Lancaster crested above its 8 flood stage at 9.23 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in Marilla, Alden and Lancaster.|Tonawanda Creek at Batavia crested above its 9 flood stage at 11.71 feet at 10 a.m. on the 28th.|Tonawanda Creek at Rapids crested above its 12 flood stage at 14.56 feet at 9 a.m. on the 30th. Widespread flooding occurred from Batavia through Alabama, Clarence, Newstead, Akron and Amherst. Backwater flooding occurred on Ransom, Black, Beeman and Mud Creeks.|Black Creet at Churchville crested above its 6 flood stage at 7.87 feet at 7 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding extended from Chili to Churchville.|Oatka Creek at Garbutt crested above its 6 flood stage at 6.85 feet at 1 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding was reported in Garbutt and Scottsville.|Ellicott Creek at Williamsville crested above its 8 flood stage at 10.35 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding was reported along the creek in Bowmansville, Cheektowaga, Williamsville and Amherst.|Road, low-lying and basement flooding was reported along these creeks and some evacuations were ordered.

On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were down around the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved across parts of northwest and west central Illinois during the mid evening hours of June 8 producing widespread tree damage, a few large hail stones, and heavy rain resulting in some isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds estimated to be 65 mph blew down numerous large trees along Stagecoach Trail (W Galena Road) near Waddams Grove, IL at 8:35 pm June 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent supercell developed during the afternoon and moved eastward along a cold front.  This storm was responsible for hail as large as baseballs as it moved across Jack, Stephens, Palo Pinto, Parker, and Tarrant Counties.  A squall line developed along the southward moving cold front later that evening, producing a few reports of thunderstorm winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car stalled out in high water along Cooper Street and Randol Mill Road.

A low pressure over the Northern Plains dropped southeast across Illinois and generated light snow amounts of 0.5 to 2.5 inches over south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  However, freezing rain and sleet accumulations of 1/10 to 2/10 of an inch occurred before colder air changed the precipitation to snow.  Road surfaces became slippery and dozens of vehicle accidents were reported by the media.  The greatest accumulations of 2 to 2.5 inches occurred from Marquette County east to Fond du Lac County.  Amounts tapered off to less than a half inch near the Illinois border.

A strong cold front crossed the Ohio Valley on Monday, December 15th. On Tuesday the 16th, an upper level low pressure system tracked to the northeast, bringing a quick shot of snow to northern Kentucky and south central Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A half inch of snow was measured in Anderson Park, with 1.3 inches falling in Barnesburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold snap claimed the life of a Greene county woman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A woman was found outside of her home late Sunday night. She died after being taken to an area hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The active lake effect season continued with the seventh event in less than a month getting underway immediately following a cold frontal passage on Thursday December 4th. A well aligned westerly flow set off lake effect snows off Lake Ontario Thursday afternoon which intensified and continued Thursday night into early Friday, mainly from northern Oswego County into the western Tug Hill. Later in the day, a single intense band lifted north to the Watertown area during the evening and remained until about 2 am when it lifted north and weakened. Off Lake Ontario, specific reports included: 17 inches at Pulaski; 13 inches at Lacona and Harrisville; and 9 to 13 inches at Watertown.|After some diminishing of the activity Friday morning, a deep westerly flow set up again during the day with a band of intense snow setting up off Lake Erie over the lakeshore area near Dunkirk-Silver Creek. This band remained intense as it drifted north up the lake into the Buffalo South Towns by dark, then lifted quickly across the Buffalo metro area during the evening and then stalled in a weakened form up over Niagara county and Niagara Peninsula before dissipating Saturday morning. Specific snowfall reports included: 11 inches at Dunkirk; 10 inches at Mayville; 8 inches at Derby and Blasdell; and 7 inches in East Aurora.

Low pressure moved out of the central Plains and moved across Pennsylvania. The low brought an eight to twelve inch blanket of snow to the entire region on the 19th. Across the western southern tier, snowfall amounts were slightly lower however, the snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet across that area. Some of the highest snowfall amounts included: 16 inches at Fairport; 15 inches at Youngstown; 14 inches at LaSalle; 13 inches at Medina; 12 inches at Getzville, Lockport, and North Tonawanda; 11 inches at Montezuma, Charlotte, Perinton, and Warsaw; 10 inches at Kenmore, Buffalo, Stafford, Pavilion, Lowville, Harrisville, Rochester, Niagara Falls, Wilson, Oswego, Walworth and Akron; 9 inches at West Seneca, Black River, Calcium, Hooker, Gorham, Phelps, and Palmyra. Innumerable automobile accidents were reported throughout the region as the roads became hard to navigate in the heavy snow and reduced visibilities. Schools shut down across the region and many municipalities suggested avoiding unnecessary travel if possible.

A persistent upper low/trough system continued to cause problems for the residents of the Aloha State.  The feature induced more heavy rain and thunderstorms as a moist trade flow moved beneath the cold air aloft.  However, there were no significant injuries or property damage.
A winter storm brought heavy snow and high winds to portions of central and northern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of new snow was reported at Great Basin National Park. Gusty winds caused blowing and drifting of the snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought heavy snow to portions of southern Elko County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of new snow was reported in Spring Creek and 8 inches in Lamoille.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across portions of Elko County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of new snow was reported in Elko and Ryndon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex winter storm brought high winds and snow to northern and central Nevada. The high winds caused blowing and drifting of the snow which reduced visibilities to less than 1/4 mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought strong winds and snow to northern Elko county. Frequent wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph occurred with this storm with occasional gusts of 50 to 60 mph. This reduced visibility to less than 1/4 mile at times in snow and blowing snow. Wildhorse Reservoir reported 5 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought strong winds and snow to southwest and south central Elko county. Frequent wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph occurred with this storm with occasional gusts of 45 to 55 mph. This reduced visibility to less than 1/4 mile at times in snow and blowing snow. A peak gust of 78 mph was reported at the Ruby Valley RAWS station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms became better organized and formed a coastal county squall line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pine trees were reported down on County Road 105.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong southwest winds in advance of a cold front were sustained from 30 to 35 mph for a few hours. Peak wind gusts were from 40 to 45 mph. At Evansville, sustained winds reached 33 mph with gusts to 43 mph.

Early morning thunderstorms were caused by a cold front that extended from northeast Illinois to the southeast part of Oklahoma.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a large tree at a farming complex. The lightning traveled down through the roots to a fence, which caught on fire. A propane line on the fence blew out part of an electrical box inside and outside the home on the property.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front was accompanied by a squall line of thunderstorms with strong winds. Widespread wind gusts in the 50 to 60 mph range were observed, with isolated higher gusts around 70 mph. The storms were not prolific lightning producers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some trees were blown down near Zalma and Patton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front was accompanied by a squall line of thunderstorms with strong winds. Widespread wind gusts in the 50 to 60 mph range were observed, with isolated higher gusts around 70 mph. The storms were not prolific lightning producers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A shed was heavily damaged on Route AA east of Poplar Bluff. The 18-foot wide shed roof was blown up to 200 feet away, with pieces hitting a nearby house. A car inside the shed was damaged. At a church on Highway 51 between Fisk and Broseley, wind blew down the covered area over the front door and damaged a sign. In Poplar Bluff, tree limbs were down on a couple streets. A large tree was down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intensifying low pressure tracking northeast along the Atlantic coast crossed the Gulf of Maine during the 14th...before exiting through the maritimes during the 15th. Heavy snow developed during the morning of the 14th...continued overnight...then ended during the morning of the 15th. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were reported at times across central and Downeast Maine. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 15 inches across Downeast Maine...with 7 to 12 inches across central areas. Winds of 15 to 25 mph contributed to significant blowing and drifting snow...with near whiteout conditions at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow accumulations ranged from 10 to 15 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure weakened as it crossed the Great Lakes on the morning of the 21st as a second area of low pressure developed off the North Carolina coast.  The coastal low intensified rapidly as it moved northeast along the East Coast to Nova Scotia by the morning of the 22nd. The coastal low brought heavy snow to the entire state with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 15 inches in coastal areas to 20 to 30 inches in the mountains.  Eustis reported a total of 41 inches of snow from the storm.

A shallow arctic airmass moved into the region a few days earlier resulting in near to slightly below freezing temperatures across much of northern Louisiana.  A warm...moist layer of air overran the shallower, colder air at the surface with patchy light drizzle and light rain falling across the region.  The drizzle and light rain became freezing drizzle and light freezing rain across much of northern Louisiana during the predawn hours of December 23rd.  The ice froze to elevated bridges and overpasses which in turn, resulted in several vehicle accidents.

A strong low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region.  Snow developed out of this system late in the day on November 30th, and continued through a good part of December 1st.  Snowfall totals of around a foot were common in a band arcing from just west of Traverse City, northeastward into Eastern Upper Michigan.  Trout Lake picked up 17 inches of snow, East Jordan had around 15 inches, and Interlochen right around a foot.

Westerly winds behind a departing low pressure system kicked up locally heavy lake effect snow.  In Eastern Upper Michigan, the Paradise and Tahquamenon Falls area picked up around 10 inches of snow during the afternoon and night of the 4th.  Very heavy snow impacted parts of Northern Lower Michigan, with isolated snowfall rates of 4 to 5 inches per hour at times on the evening of the 4th, just west of Gaylord.  Places from Gaylord to Alba had between 10 and 15 inches of new snow my morning on the 5th.  A bit to the north, places just south of Indian River also picked up just over a foot of snow.

A deepening storm system lifted out of the Midwest and tracked just west of Buffalo to near Ottawa and Montreal. This is a very favorable track for high winds across much of Western New York as strong gusty winds are further enhanced by the funneling effects of Lakes Erie and Ontario. The strong winds developed during the evening hours and continued until early morning of the 25th. The highest gusts exceeded 60 miles per hour. The winds downed trees and power lines with tens of thousands left without power. Specific reported wind gusts included: 62 m.p.h. at Watertown Airport and Rochester Airport; 61 m.p.h. at Eden and Oswego; 60 m.p.h. at Java Center; 59 m.p.h. at Oswego Coast Guard; 58 m.p.h. at Dunkirk, Alden and Hamburg; 55 m.p.h. at Buffalo Airport and Canandaigua; 54 m.p.h. at Fulton; and 52 m.p.h. at Wellsville.

Rainfall of up to an inch and a quarter combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the 60s  to melt a snowpack of four to eight inches which resulted in flooding on the creeks and streams of Western New York.|Cazenovia Creek at Ebenezer crested above its 10 flood stage at 13.0 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in West Seneca and near Cazenovia Park in South Buffalo.|Buffalo Creek at Gardenville crested above its 7 flood stage at 8.71 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding occurred in Elma and Gardenville.|Cayuga Creek at Lancaster crested above its 8 flood stage at 9.23 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in Marilla, Alden and Lancaster.|Tonawanda Creek at Batavia crested above its 9 flood stage at 11.71 feet at 10 a.m. on the 28th.|Tonawanda Creek at Rapids crested above its 12 flood stage at 14.56 feet at 9 a.m. on the 30th. Widespread flooding occurred from Batavia through Alabama, Clarence, Newstead, Akron and Amherst. Backwater flooding occurred on Ransom, Black, Beeman and Mud Creeks.|Black Creet at Churchville crested above its 6 flood stage at 7.87 feet at 7 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding extended from Chili to Churchville.|Oatka Creek at Garbutt crested above its 6 flood stage at 6.85 feet at 1 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding was reported in Garbutt and Scottsville.|Ellicott Creek at Williamsville crested above its 8 flood stage at 10.35 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding was reported along the creek in Bowmansville, Cheektowaga, Williamsville and Amherst.|Road, low-lying and basement flooding was reported along these creeks and some evacuations were ordered.

A coastal storm moved southeast of Nantucket immediately following another coastal storm that affected southern New England on the 19th and 20th of December.  This storm spread snow across all of southern New England then switched over to rain across northern Connecticut, Rhode Island and portions of Massachusetts south of the Massachusetts Turnpike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to twelve inches of snow fell across interior Essex County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches in southeast South Dakota east of the James River, and also in the area that is both west of the James River and north of Interstate 90. The snow was preceded by a little freezing rain in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow and freezing rain fell during the late afternoon. causing icy roads mainly in the southern part of Union County. The precipitation became all snow by early evening, and the snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow and freezing rain in the late afternoon became all snow during the evening, with snow accumulations ranging from 2 to 5 inches. The freezing rain was generally brief and icing was light, except for more significant icing affecting travel in the Sioux City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow, mixed briefly with freezing rain at the beginning, accumulated 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.

Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damage occurred at 72599 240th St. One tree felled over main entrance public access road. Many branches severed from area trees. Both dugouts at baseball field were damaged. Several trees felled near baseball field. Large branch felled over Western road leading to park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to West Central Wisconsin, by the late evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees felled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance tracking across the northern plains brought a period of snow to eastern Nebraska and western Iowa followed by an Arctic cold front which brought plunging temperatures and gusty winds.  New snowfall was only an inch or two, but it was on top of 2 to 5 inches of snow that fell a few days prior.  As northwest winds picked up to 20 to 35 mph with higher gusts during the morning of 12/20, areas of blowing and drifting snow developed.  Visibilities frequently fell to a mile or two in west central Iowa.  However, the main story from this event for this area was the dangerously cold wind chill values that were observed from the evening of 12/20 into and through much of 12/21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures which fell a little below zero by the evening of 12/20 combined with northwest winds of 15 to 30 mph and produced dangerously cold wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero. These cold wind chill values persisted into the early evening hours of 12/21, but by that time the winds had subsided to mainly less than 10 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line developed in advance of a cold front and tracked through the southeast United States, resulting in several severe thunderstorms across southern South Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported a tree down on Middle Road in Beaufort, South Carolina.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A progressive upper atmospheric storm system quickly passed over the southern Rockies during the afternoon hours of the 18th. A deepening surface low pressure area over southeastern Colorado and southwestern Kansas in advance of this system and a strong lower level wind maximum resulted in widespread sustained winds in the 25 to 35 mph range over the western Texas Panhandle and South Plains. A localized severe gust of 62 mph was measured by the KVII-TV Schoolnet at Friona (Parmer County) shortly after 14:30 CST. No damage was reported.

A localized area of intense winds developed across the Piedmont during the early evening in association with a small area of low pressure. Numerous trees and power lines were blown across the southern part of Union County in North Carolina, with the wind damage extending southward into the northwest Piedmont of South Carolina.

A localized area of intense winds developed across the Piedmont during the early evening in association with a small area of low pressure. Numerous trees and power lines were blown down over eastern Chester County in South Carolina through the southern part of the North Carolina Piedmont.

High winds developed near the Blue Ridge around sunrise, peaking in the mid to late morning, before tapering off during the afternoon. Numerous trees and power lines were blown down, with some scattered power outages.

High winds developed near the Blue Ridge around sunrise, peaking in the mid to late morning, before tapering off during the afternoon. Numerous trees and power lines were blown down, with some scattered power outages.

High winds developed near the Blue Ridge around sunrise, peaking in the mid to late morning, before tapering off during the afternoon. Numerous trees and power lines were blown down, with some scattered power outages.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.

A complex winter storm brought high winds and snow to northern and central Nevada. The high winds caused blowing and drifting of the snow which reduced visibilities to less than 1/4 mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought strong winds and snow to northern Lander and northern Eureka counties. Frequent wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph occurred with this storm with occasional gusts of 45 to 55 mph. This reduced visibility to less than 1/4 mile at times in snow and blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was roof damage and shingles torn off the front and rear of roof of home located at 6040 Saundersville Rd. An eight inch diameter tree was uprooted. There was damage to a covered pontoon boat involving pole and canvas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees and power lines were blown down around the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low with cold temperatures aloft caused instability resulting in thunderstorms with small hail across Southeast Arizona.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small hail resulted in numerous accidents on Highway 90 south of Benson. One of these accidents resulted in the fatality as a truck slid off the road into a concrete culvert.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region.  Snow developed out of this system late in the day on November 30th, and continued through a good part of December 1st.  Snowfall totals of around a foot were common in a band arcing from just west of Traverse City, northeastward into Eastern Upper Michigan.  Trout Lake picked up 17 inches of snow, East Jordan had around 15 inches, and Interlochen right around a foot.

An area of low pressure weakened as it crossed the Great Lakes on the morning of the 21st as a second area of low pressure developed off the North Carolina coast.  The coastal low intensified rapidly as it moved northeast along the East Coast to Nova Scotia by the morning of the 22nd. The coastal low brought heavy snow to the entire state with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 15 inches in coastal areas to 20 to 30 inches in the mountains.  Eustis reported a total of 41 inches of snow from the storm.

Snow showers developed during the early morning hours and continued through much of the day across the higher elevations of the Blue Ridge mountains. By late afternoon, accumulations ranged from around an inch to as much as 4 inches. Meanwhile, the valleys saw only occasional flurries or light snow, with just a dusting reported here and there.

Westerly winds behind a departing low pressure system kicked up locally heavy lake effect snow.  In Eastern Upper Michigan, the Paradise and Tahquamenon Falls area picked up around 10 inches of snow during the afternoon and night of the 4th.  Very heavy snow impacted parts of Northern Lower Michigan, with isolated snowfall rates of 4 to 5 inches per hour at times on the evening of the 4th, just west of Gaylord.  Places from Gaylord to Alba had between 10 and 15 inches of new snow my morning on the 5th.  A bit to the north, places just south of Indian River also picked up just over a foot of snow.

An intensifying coastal low spread heavy snow across southern New England. Snow began in the early afternoon across Connecticut and southwestern Massachusetts, spreading quickly across Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and southern New Hampshire. Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine to eleven inches of snow fell across eastern Kent County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A coastal storm moved southeast of Nantucket immediately following another coastal storm that affected southern New England on the 19th and 20th of December.  This storm spread snow across all of southern New England then switched over to rain across northern Connecticut, Rhode Island and portions of Massachusetts south of the Massachusetts Turnpike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow fell across western Franklin County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff's office reported numerous trees and power lines down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While a major ice storm affected Massachusetts and Southern New Hampshire, three to five inches of rain fell in Rhode Island resulting in small stream and some street flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 10 and Wellington Road in Cranston were flooded.  The Woonasquatucket River at Centerdale overflowed its banks flooding Atwells Avenue in Providence.  Benjamin Road in North Providence was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While a major ice storm affected Massachusetts and Southern New Hampshire, three to five inches of rain fell in Rhode Island resulting in small stream and some street flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 117 in Coventry was flooded with two feet of water.  Also in Coventry, Turkey Meadow Brook overflowed its banks flooding Meadow Road.  Small stream flooding inundated a portion of Maple Valley Road in Coventry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While a major ice storm affected Massachusetts and Southern New Hampshire, three to five inches of rain fell in Rhode Island resulting in small stream and some street flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Branch River overflowed its banks damaging the bridge on the Victory Highway Bridge on Route 107.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent supercell developed during the afternoon and moved eastward along a cold front.  This storm was responsible for hail as large as baseballs as it moved across Jack, Stephens, Palo Pinto, Parker, and Tarrant Counties.  A squall line developed along the southward moving cold front later that evening, producing a few reports of thunderstorm winds and large hail.
Thunderstorms produced a couple of small tornadoes in the Columbia CWA and a squall line also moved through and took down trees and powerlines across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Electric company reported trees and powerlines down in Eastover.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media and storm survey found that a strong downburst took down many trees at the Columbia Country club and did minor damage to the clubhouse.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow, mixed briefly with freezing rain at the beginning, accumulated 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure over the Northern Plains dropped southeast across Illinois and generated light snow amounts of 0.5 to 2.5 inches over south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  However, freezing rain and sleet accumulations of 1/10 to 2/10 of an inch occurred before colder air changed the precipitation to snow.  Road surfaces became slippery and dozens of vehicle accidents were reported by the media.  The greatest accumulations of 2 to 2.5 inches occurred from Marquette County east to Fond du Lac County.  Amounts tapered off to less than a half inch near the Illinois border.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported two trees down in Walterboro, South Carolina. One was reported to be blocking the road at 2500 Ritter Road, and the other was blocking the road at 100 Lambert Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The active lake effect season continued with the seventh event in less than a month getting underway immediately following a cold frontal passage on Thursday December 4th. A well aligned westerly flow set off lake effect snows off Lake Ontario Thursday afternoon which intensified and continued Thursday night into early Friday, mainly from northern Oswego County into the western Tug Hill. Later in the day, a single intense band lifted north to the Watertown area during the evening and remained until about 2 am when it lifted north and weakened. Off Lake Ontario, specific reports included: 17 inches at Pulaski; 13 inches at Lacona and Harrisville; and 9 to 13 inches at Watertown.|After some diminishing of the activity Friday morning, a deep westerly flow set up again during the day with a band of intense snow setting up off Lake Erie over the lakeshore area near Dunkirk-Silver Creek. This band remained intense as it drifted north up the lake into the Buffalo South Towns by dark, then lifted quickly across the Buffalo metro area during the evening and then stalled in a weakened form up over Niagara county and Niagara Peninsula before dissipating Saturday morning. Specific snowfall reports included: 11 inches at Dunkirk; 10 inches at Mayville; 8 inches at Derby and Blasdell; and 7 inches in East Aurora.

A rare and widespread snowfall occurred across much of southeast and east central Louisiana, beginning early in the morning of December 11th and continuing until around the noon hour, as an unusually strong and cold upper level storm system moved across the region. The snow, which was occasionally heavy, affected all but some of the immediate coastal areas. The heaviest snow occurred over the Florida parishes of east central and southeast Louisiana from east of Baton Rouge to the Pearl River, and along and to the north of Interstate 12. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 6 inches were common in this area with 6 to 8 inch totals occurring in sections of Tangipahoa Parish. The weight of the snow resulted in widespread power outages and tree damage in areas that received the heavier snowfall amounts. Snowfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common across areas to the south and southwest of Lake Pontchartrain including the New Orleans metropolitan area.

Rainfall of up to an inch and a quarter combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the 60s  to melt a snowpack of four to eight inches which resulted in flooding on the creeks and streams of Western New York.|Cazenovia Creek at Ebenezer crested above its 10 flood stage at 13.0 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in West Seneca and near Cazenovia Park in South Buffalo.|Buffalo Creek at Gardenville crested above its 7 flood stage at 8.71 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding occurred in Elma and Gardenville.|Cayuga Creek at Lancaster crested above its 8 flood stage at 9.23 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in Marilla, Alden and Lancaster.|Tonawanda Creek at Batavia crested above its 9 flood stage at 11.71 feet at 10 a.m. on the 28th.|Tonawanda Creek at Rapids crested above its 12 flood stage at 14.56 feet at 9 a.m. on the 30th. Widespread flooding occurred from Batavia through Alabama, Clarence, Newstead, Akron and Amherst. Backwater flooding occurred on Ransom, Black, Beeman and Mud Creeks.|Black Creet at Churchville crested above its 6 flood stage at 7.87 feet at 7 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding extended from Chili to Churchville.|Oatka Creek at Garbutt crested above its 6 flood stage at 6.85 feet at 1 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding was reported in Garbutt and Scottsville.|Ellicott Creek at Williamsville crested above its 8 flood stage at 10.35 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding was reported along the creek in Bowmansville, Cheektowaga, Williamsville and Amherst.|Road, low-lying and basement flooding was reported along these creeks and some evacuations were ordered.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees fell on a mobile home owned by Ms. Dorothy Whitley on North Springs Rd. The home was completely destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tightening pressure gradient ahead of a powerful Pacific storm system produced strong winds in central Wyoming and in the Absaroka Range.  A sensor on Chief Joseph Pass commonly recorded sustained wind of 60 to 80 mph with a peak of 81 mph.  An anemometer along U.S. Highway 287 near Sweetwater Station measured sustained wind of 56 mph.  A peak gust of 73 mph was measured by NWS personnel traveling Wyoming Boulevard on the south side of Casper.

Hurricane force wind was recorded in the Absaroka Mountains over Chief Joseph Pass.  Sustained wind of 50 mph or more was common for more than 24 hours over the pass along State Highway 296.  During the early morning of Saturday, February 9, sustained wind on the pass routinely registered 80 to 100 mph with a peak of 102 mph.  Strong westerly flow across central Wyoming also contributed to a brief period of high wind.  The Camp Creek RAWS in southern Fremont County measured a gust of 60 mph.

A strong low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region.  Snow developed out of this system late in the day on November 30th, and continued through a good part of December 1st.  Snowfall totals of around a foot were common in a band arcing from just west of Traverse City, northeastward into Eastern Upper Michigan.  Trout Lake picked up 17 inches of snow, East Jordan had around 15 inches, and Interlochen right around a foot.

Strong winds in Estes Park caused a roof under construction at the YMCA of the Rockies to collapse.  The wind caught the end section of the roof truss, and in a domino effect, blew it into the second and thirds trusses, on down the line of the roof.

CZ_NAME: S & E JACKSON / LARIMER / N & NE GRAND / NW BOULDER COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two snowmobilers were killed on the side of Gravel Mountain near Grand Lake.  The avalanche occurred when one of the men tried to assist the other, after his snowmobile had become stuck in the snow.  Both men were buried by the slide and died at the scene of the accident.  Another snowmobiler was partially buried in the avalanche, but was not injured.

Another brief period of high winds occurred in and near the foothills of Boulder and Jefferson Counties.  In Nederland, the strong wind snapped a blue spruce which landed on a nearby propane tank.  Some roofs in the immediate area were damaged.  Power lines were also downed; which left 126 residence without electricity for about 6 hours. Peak wind gusts included 90 mph at the National Wind Technology Center, and 89 mph, 6 miles northwest of Boulder.

Six to nearly 15 inches of snow fell across northwest Wisconsin, including 12 inches at Yellow Lake and 8 inches at Grantsburg. The heaviest snow fell during the late morning and early afternoon.

An abnormally warm and humid air mass spread across Kansas and Missouri on Friday, thanks in part to a large and powerful storm system which developed across the Great Basin.  Temperatures Friday afternoon soared to records levels in the upper 60s.  In fact, daily high temperature records were set in Kansas City, St. Joseph, Concordia, Joplin, Springfield, Vichy-Rolla, and Des Moines.  This spring-like air mass set the stage for a rapid swing in weather conditions across the area, with extensive snow melt in Iowa creating ice jams and river flooding.||By the evening hours of the 26th, the powerful upper level storm system was beginning to bear down on the Central Plains.  A potent cold front was swinging through Nebraska and Iowa, with the development of thunderstorm activity across much of eastern Kansas and west central Missouri by 9 pm.  This thunderstorm activity, while strong to severe, caused litte in the way of damage, however did produce flash flooding in areas from Warrensburg, MO to Moberly, MO.||After midnight however, a large line of thunderstorms began to develop further to the west along the aforementioned cold front stretching from central Kansas into northwestern Missouri.  Additional stronger thunderstorms developed in areas near Emporia, KS and further southward along Interstate 35 by 3 am.  These thunderstorms would go on to produce widespread wind damage as they lifted northward into the Kansas City Metro and areas to the south and east.  Composite radar imagery below indicates the regional progression of this line of storms and their track across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows were broken out by high winds, at a residence located at 159TH and Outlook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level trough crossed New Mexico on the 5th, bringing isolated reports of high winds across central and eastern portions of the state.
A sharp dry line helped focus a few thunderstorms over southeast New Mexico during the late afternoon hours. One severe storm over extreme eastern Chaves county produced penny size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to penny size hail reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A sharp dry line over eastern New Mexico on the 10th helped focus the development of isolated severe thunderstorms over De Baca and Roosevelt counties. Hail around one inch in diameter was reported.
A sharp dry line over eastern New Mexico on the 10th helped focus the development of isolated severe thunderstorms over De Baca and Roosevelt counties. Hail around one inch in diameter was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was at the Melrose Bombing Range.

By late afternoon, accumulations ranged from around an inch to as much as 4 inches. Meanwhile, the valleys saw only occasional flurries or light snow, with just a dusting reported here and there.

Freezing drizzle and very light freezing rain developed near the Tennessee border during the late afternoon, causing slick spots to develop on roads, mainly in areas north of I-26. Numerous traffic accidents occurred.
