Strong south winds associated with an approaching front helped produce surf of 6 to 10 feet along the south-facing shores Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Lanai, Maui, and Kahoolawe. There were no reports of significant injuries or property damage.

Low pressure moved out of the central Plains and moved across Pennsylvania. The low brought an eight to twelve inch blanket of snow to the entire region on the 19th. Across the western southern tier, snowfall amounts were slightly lower however, the snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet across that area. Some of the highest snowfall amounts included: 16 inches at Fairport; 15 inches at Youngstown; 14 inches at LaSalle; 13 inches at Medina; 12 inches at Getzville, Lockport, and North Tonawanda; 11 inches at Montezuma, Charlotte, Perinton, and Warsaw; 10 inches at Kenmore, Buffalo, Stafford, Pavilion, Lowville, Harrisville, Rochester, Niagara Falls, Wilson, Oswego, Walworth and Akron; 9 inches at West Seneca, Black River, Calcium, Hooker, Gorham, Phelps, and Palmyra. Innumerable automobile accidents were reported throughout the region as the roads became hard to navigate in the heavy snow and reduced visibilities. Schools shut down across the region and many municipalities suggested avoiding unnecessary travel if possible.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.

A fast moving low pressure system moved through Southern New England bringing 4-10 inches of snow to the region. In addition, strong cold advection and pressure rises resulted in very cold temperatures, strong winds, and bitterly cold wind chills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An amateur radio operator recorded a wind gust of 59 mph on his home weather station.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying coastal low spread heavy snow across southern New England. Snow began in the early afternoon across Connecticut and southwestern Massachusetts, spreading quickly across Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and southern New Hampshire. Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to twelve inches of snow fell across northwestern Providence County.

A coastal storm moved southeast of Nantucket immediately following another coastal storm that affected southern New England on the 19th and 20th of December.  This storm spread snow across all of southern New England then switched over to rain across northern Connecticut, Rhode Island and portions of Massachusetts south of the Massachusetts Turnpike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow fell across eastern Franklin County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent supercell developed during the afternoon and moved eastward along a cold front.  This storm was responsible for hail as large as baseballs as it moved across Jack, Stephens, Palo Pinto, Parker, and Tarrant Counties.  A squall line developed along the southward moving cold front later that evening, producing a few reports of thunderstorm winds and large hail.

On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Dispatch reported trees and power lines were down around the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches in southeast South Dakota east of the James River, and also in the area that is both west of the James River and north of Interstate 90. The snow was preceded by a little freezing rain in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure over the Northern Plains dropped southeast across Illinois and generated light snow amounts of 0.5 to 2.5 inches over south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  However, freezing rain and sleet accumulations of 1/10 to 2/10 of an inch occurred before colder air changed the precipitation to snow.  Road surfaces became slippery and dozens of vehicle accidents were reported by the media.  The greatest accumulations of 2 to 2.5 inches occurred from Marquette County east to Fond du Lac County.  Amounts tapered off to less than a half inch near the Illinois border.

A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several creeks and small streams flooded low lying areas within the city of Springfield.

Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A section of Highway 32 was flooded due to excessive rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The active lake effect season continued with the seventh event in less than a month getting underway immediately following a cold frontal passage on Thursday December 4th. A well aligned westerly flow set off lake effect snows off Lake Ontario Thursday afternoon which intensified and continued Thursday night into early Friday, mainly from northern Oswego County into the western Tug Hill. Later in the day, a single intense band lifted north to the Watertown area during the evening and remained until about 2 am when it lifted north and weakened. Off Lake Ontario, specific reports included: 17 inches at Pulaski; 13 inches at Lacona and Harrisville; and 9 to 13 inches at Watertown.|After some diminishing of the activity Friday morning, a deep westerly flow set up again during the day with a band of intense snow setting up off Lake Erie over the lakeshore area near Dunkirk-Silver Creek. This band remained intense as it drifted north up the lake into the Buffalo South Towns by dark, then lifted quickly across the Buffalo metro area during the evening and then stalled in a weakened form up over Niagara county and Niagara Peninsula before dissipating Saturday morning. Specific snowfall reports included: 11 inches at Dunkirk; 10 inches at Mayville; 8 inches at Derby and Blasdell; and 7 inches in East Aurora.

The season's most severe lake effect event to date followed the passage of a sharp front early on Sunday the 21st. Winds turned southwest and increased to 30 to 40 mph with higher gusts by early afternoon over the west and almost as strong by late Sunday afternoon east of Lake Ontario. The strong winds inhibited single band formation, but resulted in a broad 20-30 mile wide area of lake snows northeast of Lake Erie right across the Buffalo metro area during the afternoon, which gradually settled south across the city and nearby southern suburbs in the evening. The winds created whiteouts and near blizzard conditions at times, with drifts commonly three feet across the entire Buffalo metro area. An upper air disturbance crossed around 3 a.m. on Monday the 22nd and bands shifted south where they remained in a weakened form across southern Erie and northern Chautauqua and Cattaraugus counties during the day Monday before drifting north and weakening Monday night.  Off Lake Ontario, a similar scenario ensued, but about 4 to 6 hours later. The main activity was over Jefferson and northern Lewis counties Sunday afternoon and night, gradually shifting south across Oswego county Monday and settling across the Syracuse area later Monday before shifting north and weakening Tuesday morning.  Snowfall amounts were close to a foot across metro Buffalo with a bit more in a strip from Hamburg to West Seneca to Elma to Batavia. Six inches fell up into far southern Niagara County, and even Rochester caught three inches as the band extended that far east for a time Sunday evening. Off Ontario the heaviest amounts fell from central Jefferson to northern Lewis counties, although a narrow area of a foot also was recorded in the Syracuse area and far southern Oswego County as the band stalled Monday.  The strong winds and frigid temperatures combined with the heavy snow to create the worst whiteout conditions and drifting in the Buffalo area in several years. Activities were ground to a halt with several major highways closed, including the I-90 NYS Thruway. Numerous automobile accidents were reported, including a fatal crash in Cambria.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.

A rare and widespread snowfall occurred across much of south Mississippi, beginning early in the morning of December 11th and continuing until around the noon hour, as an unusually strong and cold upper level storm system moved across the region. The snow, which was occasionally heavy, affected all but the coastal areas of south Mississippi. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches were common in this area; however, up to 6 inches of snow was reported in western Pearl River County.

Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous basements were flooded in Highland Park.  Several roads were also flooded including Trailway Street, Green Bay Road and Park Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds gusting as high as 45 mph blew down numerous tree limbs and power lines.  A tree was blown down at 83rd and Yates in Chicago.  The tree fell onto an SUV and injured five people inside the SUV.  Another tree was completely uprooted at Scott and Astor Roads.  The tree fell onto two cars.
A strong storm system approaching the area brought high winds to central and northern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Long Hollow RAWS site had a wind gust to 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system approaching the area brought high winds to central and northern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 84 mph was recorded at the Warm Springs Summit Mesonet |site. The high winds blew down power lines in Tonopah and the entire town was without power for over 1 hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system approaching the area brought high winds to central and northern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 63 mph was recorded at the Austin RAWS site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system approaching the area brought high winds to central and northern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 66 mph was recorded at the National Weather Service Forecast office 2 miles northeast of downtown Elko. The high winds blew over a semi-truck on Interstate 80 near Ryndon. Power lines were also blown down causing a widespread power outage over the southern portion of Elko.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less. The dense fog occurred along and just ahead of a warm front. Light east to southeast winds brought moist air over cold, icy ground.

Strong southwest winds in advance of a cold front were sustained from 30 to 35 mph for a few hours. Peak wind gusts were from 40 to 45 mph. At Evansville, sustained winds reached 33 mph with gusts to 43 mph.

Thunderstorms moved across parts of northwest and west central Illinois during the mid evening hours of June 8 producing widespread tree damage, a few large hail stones, and heavy rain resulting in some isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 9:10 pm June 8, the automated surface observing system at the Quad City International Airport in Moline, IL measured a wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of heavy rain and snow melt brought numerous streams and creeks out of there banks across Fayette, Westmoreland, and Indiana counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Butler Run and Spruce Run out of there banks and flooding near Route 982.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of heavy rain and snow melt brought numerous streams and creeks out of there banks across Fayette, Westmoreland, and Indiana counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Two Lick Creek flooding near Josephine and Grafton along route 119.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two skiers were injured, one extensively, when an avalanche triggered in a bowl they were skiing through on Casper Mountain.  The slide was 100 yards wide and at least 50-100 yards long.  One skier received only minor injuries after hitting a tree and having his skis ripped from his feet.  The second skier was buried under a foot of snow after getting one of his skis caught in the branch of a tree.  He received a deep cut to his shin and a broken foot as a result of the slide.

Low pressure located over the eastern Great Lakes on Tuesday morning, January 1st, tracked east across central New York Tuesday afternoon, and off the New England coast by Wednesday morning on January 2nd. ||As this low pressure tracked east, a swath of light to moderate snow fell across much of eastern New York and western New England from early Tuesday morning into Wednesday morning. ||This storm system produced 3 to 7 inches of snow accumulation across the Berkshires of western Massachusetts, with the greatest amounts across the higher elevations of northern Berkshire county.||This light to moderate snowfall created hazardous travel conditions for the Wednesday morning commute, and also led to the delayed openings of some schools and businesses Wednesday morning.

Intensifying low pressure tracking northeast along the Atlantic coast crossed the Gulf of Maine during the 14th...before exiting through the maritimes during the 15th. Heavy snow developed during the morning of the 14th...continued overnight...then ended during the morning of the 15th. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were reported at times across central and Downeast Maine. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 15 inches across Downeast Maine...with 7 to 12 inches across central areas. Winds of 15 to 25 mph contributed to significant blowing and drifting snow...with near whiteout conditions at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow accumulations ranged from 8 to 12 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Six to nearly 15 inches of snow fell across northwest Wisconsin, including 12 inches at Yellow Lake and 8 inches at Grantsburg. The heaviest snow fell during the late morning and early afternoon.
Rainfall from several storm systems was enough to finally bring an end to the Severe (D2) Drought that had begun in March of 2007.

Strong winds caused blizzard conditions over southwest Minnesota, mainly away from the southern border of the state. The strong winds combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall. The new snowfall varied mostly from 2 to 4 inches. Zero visibilities and drifting snow made travel virtually impossible. Wind chill readings were driver to as low as 40 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained around 30 mph with gusts over 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 2 inches or less to produce blowing snow, with brief visibilities around a quarter mile in places. Temperatures falling to near or a little below zero combined with the strong winds to produce wind chill readings of 20 to 35 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A sharp dry line over eastern New Mexico helped focus thunderstorm development on the evening of the 10th. One thunderstorm near Melrose turned severe and produced strong wind gusts at the Melrose Bombing Range.

The dry line over eastern New Mexico become active on the afternoon and evening of the 11th as scattered thunderstorms formed. A few of these storms turned severe, producing large hail, mainly over the south central mountains and northeast plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail along highway 456 and 406.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The dry line over eastern New Mexico become active on the afternoon and evening of the 11th as scattered thunderstorms formed. A few of these storms turned severe, producing large hail, mainly over the south central mountains and northeast plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail at the Lincoln State Monument.

Low pressure moved out of the central Plains and moved across Pennsylvania. The low brought an eight to twelve inch blanket of snow to the entire region on the 19th. Across the western southern tier, snowfall amounts were slightly lower however, the snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet across that area. Some of the highest snowfall amounts included: 16 inches at Fairport; 15 inches at Youngstown; 14 inches at LaSalle; 13 inches at Medina; 12 inches at Getzville, Lockport, and North Tonawanda; 11 inches at Montezuma, Charlotte, Perinton, and Warsaw; 10 inches at Kenmore, Buffalo, Stafford, Pavilion, Lowville, Harrisville, Rochester, Niagara Falls, Wilson, Oswego, Walworth and Akron; 9 inches at West Seneca, Black River, Calcium, Hooker, Gorham, Phelps, and Palmyra. Innumerable automobile accidents were reported throughout the region as the roads became hard to navigate in the heavy snow and reduced visibilities. Schools shut down across the region and many municipalities suggested avoiding unnecessary travel if possible.

Strong south winds associated with an approaching front helped produce surf of 6 to 10 feet along the south-facing shores Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Lanai, Maui, and Kahoolawe. There were no reports of significant injuries or property damage.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.
A cold front traveling through southeast Texas coastal waters created strong thunderstorm winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was measured by PORTS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying coastal low spread heavy snow across southern New England. Snow began in the early afternoon across Connecticut and southwestern Massachusetts, spreading quickly across Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and southern New Hampshire. Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across much of southern New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eleven to twelve inches of snow fell across western Kent County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent supercell developed during the afternoon and moved eastward along a cold front.  This storm was responsible for hail as large as baseballs as it moved across Jack, Stephens, Palo Pinto, Parker, and Tarrant Counties.  A squall line developed along the southward moving cold front later that evening, producing a few reports of thunderstorm winds and large hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha/Council Bluffs areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of freezing rain and sleet accumulated around 1/2 inch over most of the county.  A period of snow followed the mix precipitation with upwards of 3 to 5 inches of snow reported over the northwest half of the county.|Although the mixed precipitation created hazardous driving conditions,|accumulation on trees and power lines was somewhat limited.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha/Council Bluffs areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of freezing rain and sleet accumulated around 1/2 inch over most of the county.  An inch or two of snow then fell on the mixture before the precipitation ended late Thursday night.  Although the mixture created hazardous driving conditions and stuck to vehicle windshields, accumulation on trees and power lines was somewhat limited.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive rain caused several areas of Neosho to flood.  Roads were closed off in the north and central sections of Neosho.

Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.

A strong cold front crossed the Ohio Valley on Monday, December 15th. On Tuesday the 16th, an upper level low pressure system tracked to the northeast, bringing a quick shot of snow to northern Kentucky and south central Ohio.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three and a half inches of snow was measured in West Union, with a swath of snow 3-4 inches deep across the southern half of the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inches of snow was measured in Portsmouth.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Point Pleasant, seven tenths of an inch of snow fell.

Rainfall of up to an inch and a quarter combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the 60s  to melt a snowpack of four to eight inches which resulted in flooding on the creeks and streams of Western New York.|Cazenovia Creek at Ebenezer crested above its 10 flood stage at 13.0 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in West Seneca and near Cazenovia Park in South Buffalo.|Buffalo Creek at Gardenville crested above its 7 flood stage at 8.71 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding occurred in Elma and Gardenville.|Cayuga Creek at Lancaster crested above its 8 flood stage at 9.23 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in Marilla, Alden and Lancaster.|Tonawanda Creek at Batavia crested above its 9 flood stage at 11.71 feet at 10 a.m. on the 28th.|Tonawanda Creek at Rapids crested above its 12 flood stage at 14.56 feet at 9 a.m. on the 30th. Widespread flooding occurred from Batavia through Alabama, Clarence, Newstead, Akron and Amherst. Backwater flooding occurred on Ransom, Black, Beeman and Mud Creeks.|Black Creet at Churchville crested above its 6 flood stage at 7.87 feet at 7 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding extended from Chili to Churchville.|Oatka Creek at Garbutt crested above its 6 flood stage at 6.85 feet at 1 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding was reported in Garbutt and Scottsville.|Ellicott Creek at Williamsville crested above its 8 flood stage at 10.35 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding was reported along the creek in Bowmansville, Cheektowaga, Williamsville and Amherst.|Road, low-lying and basement flooding was reported along these creeks and some evacuations were ordered.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 68 mph was recorded by the Ruby Valley RAWS site.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of new snow was reported in Spring Creek and the Ruby Lake National Wildlife Refuge and 8 inches in Lamoille. In addition gusty winds caused blowing and drifting of the snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of new snow fell in Diamond Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region.  Snow developed out of this system late in the day on November 30th, and continued through a good part of December 1st.  Snowfall totals of around a foot were common in a band arcing from just west of Traverse City, northeastward into Eastern Upper Michigan.  Trout Lake picked up 17 inches of snow, East Jordan had around 15 inches, and Interlochen right around a foot.

Intensifying low pressure tracking northeast along the Atlantic coast crossed the Gulf of Maine during the 14th...before exiting through the maritimes during the 15th. Heavy snow developed during the morning of the 14th...continued overnight...then ended during the morning of the 15th. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were reported at times across central and Downeast Maine. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 15 inches across Downeast Maine...with 7 to 12 inches across central areas. Winds of 15 to 25 mph contributed to significant blowing and drifting snow...with near whiteout conditions at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow accumulations ranged from 10 to 15 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm frontal boundry draped across Central Minnesota was the focus for scattered severe thunderstorms on this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gradient created by high pressure behind thunderstorms caused the strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to West Central Wisconsin, by the late evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees broken or toppled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds caused blizzard conditions over southwest Minnesota, mainly away from the southern border of the state. The strong winds combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall. The new snowfall varied mostly from 2 to 4 inches. Zero visibilities and drifting snow made travel virtually impossible. Wind chill readings were driver to as low as 40 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained around 30 mph with gusts over 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 2 inches or less to produce blowing snow, with brief visibilities around a quarter mile in places. Temperatures falling to near or a little below zero combined with the strong winds to produce wind chill readings of 20 to 35 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure weakened as it crossed the Great Lakes on the morning of the 21st as a second area of low pressure developed off the North Carolina coast.  The coastal low intensified rapidly as it moved northeast along the East Coast to Nova Scotia by the morning of the 22nd. The coastal low brought heavy snow to the entire state with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 15 inches in coastal areas to 20 to 30 inches in the mountains.  Eustis reported a total of 41 inches of snow from the storm.

Low pressure moved out of the central Plains and moved across Pennsylvania. The low brought an eight to twelve inch blanket of snow to the entire region on the 19th. Across the western southern tier, snowfall amounts were slightly lower however, the snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet across that area. Some of the highest snowfall amounts included: 16 inches at Fairport; 15 inches at Youngstown; 14 inches at LaSalle; 13 inches at Medina; 12 inches at Getzville, Lockport, and North Tonawanda; 11 inches at Montezuma, Charlotte, Perinton, and Warsaw; 10 inches at Kenmore, Buffalo, Stafford, Pavilion, Lowville, Harrisville, Rochester, Niagara Falls, Wilson, Oswego, Walworth and Akron; 9 inches at West Seneca, Black River, Calcium, Hooker, Gorham, Phelps, and Palmyra. Innumerable automobile accidents were reported throughout the region as the roads became hard to navigate in the heavy snow and reduced visibilities. Schools shut down across the region and many municipalities suggested avoiding unnecessary travel if possible.

Another strong winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought strong winds and heavy snow to White Pine county. Winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused blowing and drifting snow making travel difficult and hazardous. Lund picked up 7 inches of new snow. Ruth and the Great Basin National Park headquarters received 5 inches of new snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought strong winds and snow to extreme eastern Elko county. Winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused blowing and drifting snow making travel difficult and hazardous. One to three inches of snow fell across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across northern Nye and southern White Pine |counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of new snow was reported at Tonopah.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across northern Nye and southern White Pine |counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across the southern portion of White Pine county. Lund picked up 6 inches of new snow and Ely reported 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 10 and 11, a strong Pacific storm system moved southeast across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall amounts in the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Idaho road department reported that Lost Trail Pass received 12 inches of new snowfall accumulations from this event. Also, the Moose Creek weather station received 9 inches of new snowfall accumulations from this event as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 10 and 11, a strong Pacific storm system moved southeast across Western Montana and produced heavy snowfall amounts in the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Idaho and Montana road departments reported 11.7 and 12 inches of snow at Lolo and Lost Trail Passes, respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 13, a large avalanche was triggered near the Big Mountain Ski Resort.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flathead County Search and Rescue personnel reported a large avalanche on the back side of Big Mountain Ski Resort. Two skiers were killed and one was injured. The avalanche was initiated by another skier who was skiing out of bounds in an area closed to skiing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of thunderstorms moved southward over the local area waters which generated strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was measured at the Jamaica Beach Weather Observatory.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three homes sustained roof damage at the intersection of Grand Park and Honeysuckle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of southwestern-moving thunderstorms created severe weather across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail occurred in the city of Pearland.

CZ_NAME: HIGH IS TO FREEPORT TX OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southwest moving thunderstorms produced wind gusts while moving across the coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind gust was measured at Scholes International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The storm that had been parked along the California coast finally moved inland on the 18th and created isolated high winds over the Central High Plains.

A shallow arctic airmass moved into the region a few days earlier resulting in near to slightly below freezing temperatures across much of northern Louisiana.  A warm...moist layer of air overran the shallower, colder air at the surface with patchy light drizzle and light rain falling across the region.  The drizzle and light rain became freezing drizzle and light freezing rain across much of northern Louisiana during the predawn hours of December 23rd.  The ice froze to elevated bridges and overpasses which in turn, resulted in several vehicle accidents.

A shallow arctic airmass moved into the region a few days earlier resulting in near to slightly below freezing temperatures across much of McCurtain County.  A warm...moist layer of air overran the shallower, colder air at the surface with patchy light drizzle and light rain falling across the region. The drizzle and light rain became freezing drizzle and light freezing rain across much of McCurtain County during the predawn hours of December 23rd. The ice froze to elevated bridges and overpasses which in turn, resulted in several vehicle accidents.

A potent supercell developed during the afternoon and moved eastward along a cold front.  This storm was responsible for hail as large as baseballs as it moved across Jack, Stephens, Palo Pinto, Parker, and Tarrant Counties.  A squall line developed along the southward moving cold front later that evening, producing a few reports of thunderstorm winds and large hail.

A vigorous storm system brought heavy snow and gusty winds to portions of North Central Montana. Snow amounts of 5 inches or more were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inces of new snow along with visibilities less than one-quarter mile was reported at Chinook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous storm system brought heavy snow and gusty winds to portions of North Central Montana. Snow amounts of 5 inches or more were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 40 mph along with visibilities less than one-quarter mile was reported at Hilger.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture from a Pacific weather system overrode cold air along the Northern Rocky Mountain front and produced heavy snow. Snow amounts in excess of 6 inches was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of snow was reported at Babb 18WSW (the Flattop Mountain SNOTEL site - elevation 6229 feet).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep surface low pressure moving across southern Canada along with a strong westerly flow aloft combined to produce high winds along the Northern Rocky Mountain Front. Wind gusts in excess of 60 mph were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 78 mph was reported at the Two Medicine DOT site. Additionally, a gust to 70 mph was reported at Heart Butte and at Browning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep surface low pressure moving across southern Canada along with a strong westerly flow aloft combined to produce high winds along the Northern Rocky Mountain Front. Wind gusts in excess of 60 mph were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust to 66 mph was reported at the Cut Bank ASOS site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter measured a 64 mph wind gust on his weather station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level trough of low pressure was the catalyst for scattered severe thunderstorms across Central Minnesota on this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five inch diameter branches down at Kettle River in Columbus Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong jet stream pattern and mid level atmospheric trough combined to produce isolated severe weather on this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail occurred at County Road V and Pioneer Road, or about 3 miles North of Sheldon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm frontal boundary stretched across West Central Wisconsin...was the main ingredient for the development of scattered severe thunderstorms on this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Deputy reports a brief sighting of a funnel cloud at County Road A and |Daly Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches in part of southeast South Dakota north of Interstate 90 during the afternoon and evening of December 2nd. The snow continued to a little past midnight near the eastern border of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches in part of southeast South Dakota north of Interstate 90 during the afternoon and evening of December 2nd. The snow continued to a little past midnight near the eastern border of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches over Lincoln and Lyon counties of southwest Minnesota from the mid afternoon of December 2nd, to a few hours past midnight on December 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches over Lincoln and Lyon counties of southwest Minnesota from the mid afternoon of December 2nd, to a few hours past midnight on December 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches in southeast South Dakota east of the James River, and also in the area that is both west of the James River and north of Interstate 90. The snow was preceded by a little freezing rain in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of light snow and freezing rain became all snow during the afternoon, with snow accumulating 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches in southeast South Dakota east of the James River, and also in the area that is both west of the James River and north of Interstate 90. The snow was preceded by a little freezing rain in some areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of light snow and freezing rain became all snow during the afternoon, with snow accumulating 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the 3rd major winter storm of the 2008-09 winter season for south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  It dumped 8 to around 14 inches, but the impact on society was significant since there was a lot of blowing and drifting of the snow.  Bands of heavy convective snow had snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour.  The winds were generally east becoming northeast and then north at 13 to 22 knots (15 to 25 mph) with gusts to 26 knots (30 mph).  However, along the Lake Michigan shoreline, a few winds gusts peaked at 30 to 35 knots (35 to 40 mph), which resulted in near-blizzard conditions in that area.  Snow drifts were reported to be 2 to 4 feet in height across southern Wisconsin.  In the middle of the night a small plane skidded of a runway at Milwaukee Mitchell Field, but there were no injuries.  Mitchell Field was closed for a couple hours due to the incident.  Additionally, many airplane flights were delayed or cancelled at the airports in Madison and Milwaukee.  Numerous schools and civic functions were cancelled.  Media reports indicated that dozens of vehicle accidents occurred.  A 2-car accident in the Town of Bristol in Dane County claimed the life of a 16-year old girl (indirect death) on December 18th.  ||Specific snowfall measurements include 14.3 inches in West Allis (Milwaukee Co.); 13.3 inches in Brookfield (Waukesha Co.); 13 inches in Argyle (Lafayette Co.); 12.5 inches near Richland (Washington Co.); 12 inches near Sheboygan (Sheboygan Co.) and far northwestern Ozaukee County; Union Grove (Racine Co.); 12.3 inches in Paddock Lake (Kenosha Co.); 11.5 inches in Middleton (Dane Co.); 11.2 inches in Jefferson (Jefferson Co.); 11 to 12 inches in far northwestern Iowa County and far west-central Green County; 11 inches in far south-central Columbia County and in Beaver Dam (Dodge Co.); 10.9 inches in East Troy (Walworth Co.); 10.8 inches in Afton (Rock Co.); 10.2 inches in Reedsburg (Sauk Co.); 10 inches near Campbellsport (Fond du Lac Co.); 8.6 inches in Markesan (Green Lake Co.), and 8 to 8.5 inches in southern Marquette County.  Synoptically, a strong low pressure moved from southeast Colorado to eastern Kansas to northeast Missouri to Indiana. Surface dewpoints were in the 55 to 60 range on the southeast side of the low pressure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha/Council Bluffs areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated around a quarter of an inch over most of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure over the Northern Plains dropped southeast across Illinois and generated light snow amounts of 0.5 to 2.5 inches over south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  However, freezing rain and sleet accumulations of 1/10 to 2/10 of an inch occurred before colder air changed the precipitation to snow.  Road surfaces became slippery and dozens of vehicle accidents were reported by the media.  The greatest accumulations of 2 to 2.5 inches occurred from Marquette County east to Fond du Lac County.  Amounts tapered off to less than a half inch near the Illinois border.

An upper level disturbance tracking across the northern plains brought a period of snow to eastern Nebraska and western Iowa followed by an Arctic cold front which brought plunging temperatures and gusty winds.  New snowfall was only an inch or two, but it was on top of 2 to 5 inches of snow that fell a few days prior.  As northwest winds picked up to 20 to 35 mph with higher gusts during the morning of 12/20, areas of blowing and drifting snow developed.  Visibilities frequently fell to a mile or two in west central Iowa.  However, the main story from this event for this area was the dangerously cold wind chill values that were observed from the evening of 12/20 into and through much of 12/21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures which fell a little below zero by the evening of 12/20 combined with northwest winds of 15 to 30 mph and produced dangerously cold wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero. These cold wind chill values persisted into the early evening hours of 12/21, but by that time the winds had subsided to mainly less than 10 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The active lake effect season continued with the seventh event in less than a month getting underway immediately following a cold frontal passage on Thursday December 4th. A well aligned westerly flow set off lake effect snows off Lake Ontario Thursday afternoon which intensified and continued Thursday night into early Friday, mainly from northern Oswego County into the western Tug Hill. Later in the day, a single intense band lifted north to the Watertown area during the evening and remained until about 2 am when it lifted north and weakened. Off Lake Ontario, specific reports included: 17 inches at Pulaski; 13 inches at Lacona and Harrisville; and 9 to 13 inches at Watertown.|After some diminishing of the activity Friday morning, a deep westerly flow set up again during the day with a band of intense snow setting up off Lake Erie over the lakeshore area near Dunkirk-Silver Creek. This band remained intense as it drifted north up the lake into the Buffalo South Towns by dark, then lifted quickly across the Buffalo metro area during the evening and then stalled in a weakened form up over Niagara county and Niagara Peninsula before dissipating Saturday morning. Specific snowfall reports included: 11 inches at Dunkirk; 10 inches at Mayville; 8 inches at Derby and Blasdell; and 7 inches in East Aurora.

A rare and widespread snowfall occurred across much of southeast and east central Louisiana, beginning early in the morning of December 11th and continuing until around the noon hour, as an unusually strong and cold upper level storm system moved across the region. The snow, which was occasionally heavy, affected all but some of the immediate coastal areas. The heaviest snow occurred over the Florida parishes of east central and southeast Louisiana from east of Baton Rouge to the Pearl River, and along and to the north of Interstate 12. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 6 inches were common in this area with 6 to 8 inch totals occurring in sections of Tangipahoa Parish. The weight of the snow resulted in widespread power outages and tree damage in areas that received the heavier snowfall amounts. Snowfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common across areas to the south and southwest of Lake Pontchartrain including the New Orleans metropolitan area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 Dispatch reported numerous trees and power lines were down around the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of storms as well as several discrete supercells affected north Texas.  Hail as large as softballs was reported as well as a brief tornado touchdown.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Baseball-size hail fell in Rockdale breaking windows and damaging cars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of storms as well as several discrete supercells affected north Texas.  Hail as large as softballs was reported as well as a brief tornado touchdown.

A potent supercell developed during the afternoon and moved eastward along a cold front.  This storm was responsible for hail as large as baseballs as it moved across Jack, Stephens, Palo Pinto, Parker, and Tarrant Counties.  A squall line developed along the southward moving cold front later that evening, producing a few reports of thunderstorm winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tractor-trailers and trucks were blown over on Justice Lane.  Trees were also blown down across roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of storms as well as several discrete supercells affected north Texas.  Hail as large as softballs was reported as well as a brief tornado touchdown.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A television meteorologist observed a brief tornado west of Holland.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain occurred across northern portions of Stewart County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain made road conditions treacherous primarily in the northern half of the county.  A number of one-vehicle accidents occurred in Dover and out in the county, according to Stewart County Sheriff's Office.  Some of those included several accidents on Tenn. 120 and on Bumpus Mills Road.  The Dover Police Department worked a couple on the Dover Bridge and three in front of the Dollar Store.  At one point, at about 0800CST, city and county officials were stationed at either end of the Dover Bridge to caution motorists.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain in extreme northeast Nebraska in the afternoon changed to snow in the early evening, with snow accumulating 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain in the late afternoon changed to snow in the early evening, with the snow accumulating 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain in extreme northeast Nebraska in the afternoon changed to snow in the early evening, with snow accumulating 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain in the late afternoon changed to snow in the early evening, with the snow accumulating 2 to 4 inches. Icy roads from the freezing rain resulted in several accidents with no reported injuries in the South Sioux City area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An abnormally warm and humid air mass spread across Kansas and Missouri on Friday, thanks in part to a large and powerful storm system which developed across the Great Basin.  Temperatures Friday afternoon soared to records levels in the upper 60s.  In fact, daily high temperature records were set in Kansas City, St. Joseph, Concordia, Joplin, Springfield, Vichy-Rolla, and Des Moines.  This spring-like air mass set the stage for a rapid swing in weather conditions across the area, with extensive snow melt in Iowa creating ice jams and river flooding.||By the evening hours of the 26th, the powerful upper level storm system was beginning to bear down on the Central Plains.  A potent cold front was swinging through Nebraska and Iowa, with the development of thunderstorm activity across much of eastern Kansas and west central Missouri by 9 pm.  This thunderstorm activity, while strong to severe, caused litte in the way of damage, however did produce flash flooding in areas from Warrensburg, MO to Moberly, MO.||After midnight however, a large line of thunderstorms began to develop further to the west along the aforementioned cold front stretching from central Kansas into northwestern Missouri.  Additional stronger thunderstorms developed in areas near Emporia, KS and further southward along Interstate 35 by 3 am.  These thunderstorms would go on to produce widespread wind damage as they lifted northward into the Kansas City Metro and areas to the south and east.  Composite radar imagery below indicates the regional progression of this line of storms and their track across the region.

An Arctic cold front pushed across eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa during the early morning hours of December 14th.  Temperatures fell 50 to 60 degrees within 24 hours after the front passed through...from 40s and 50s during the early morning hours of the 14th to around zero by midnight on the 15th.  The cold air was ushered in on northwest winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts of 40 mph. The strong winds dropped wind chill values down to 20 below to 25 below zero.  Snow showers also accompanied the cold air...and visibilities were occasionally lowered to less than 1 mile in snow and blowing snow in west central Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Falling temperatures and strong northwest winds brought dangerously cold wind chill values to the area during the morning hours of December 15th.  Winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph and temperatures falling to the single digits above and then below zero produced wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong pressure falls across Northern Montana resulted in strong pressure gradients across the Eastern Foothills of the Rocky Mountain Front Range. As a result, high winds were reported across the western portions of the Billings Forecast Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 60 mph were reported in Livingston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure weakened as it crossed the Great Lakes on the morning of the 21st as a second area of low pressure developed off the North Carolina coast.  The coastal low intensified rapidly as it moved northeast along the East Coast to Nova Scotia by the morning of the 22nd. The coastal low brought heavy snow to the entire state with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 15 inches in coastal areas to 20 to 30 inches in the mountains.  Eustis reported a total of 41 inches of snow from the storm.

Snow showers developed overnight and continued through much of the day across the higher elevations of the Tennessee border counties. Heavy snowfall accumulations were reported in the higher elevations along the Tennessee border by noon. The snow continued off and on through the day, with total snowfall accumulations of 2-7 inches reported by late in the evening. Meanwhile, valley locations in these areas received little more than a dusting.

Snow showers developed overnight and continued through much of the day across the higher elevations of the Tennessee border counties. Heavy snowfall accumulations were reported in the higher elevations along the Tennessee border by noon. The snow continued off and on through the day, with total snowfall accumulations of 2-7 inches reported by late in the evening. Meanwhile, valley locations in these areas received little more than a dusting.

Snow showers developed during the early morning hours and continued through much of the day across the higher elevations of the Blue Ridge mountains. By late afternoon, accumulations ranged from around an inch to as much as 4 inches. Meanwhile, the valleys saw only occasional flurries or light snow, with just a dusting reported here and there.

By late afternoon, accumulations ranged from around an inch to as much as 4 inches. Meanwhile, the valleys saw only occasional flurries or light snow, with just a dusting reported here and there.

Snow showers developed during the early morning hours and continued through much of the day across the higher elevations of the Blue Ridge mountains. By late afternoon, accumulations ranged from around an inch to as much as 4 inches. Meanwhile, the valleys saw only occasional flurries or light snow, with just a dusting reported here and there.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.
Scattered thunderstorms became better organized and formed a coastal county squall line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of residential home damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds blew over a large tree at a Livingston apartment complex, damaging a vehicle. There were also four apartment units that suffered minor damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 26 through 28, a very moist Pacific storm system moved across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall amounts in the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Idaho Department of Transportation reported 10 inches of new snowfall accumulations between the Elk River and the Clearwater County line. Headquarters received 6 inches of new snowfall accumulations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fast moving low pressure lifting across Maine brought heavy snow to northeast Aroostook county during the morning and early afternoon hours of the 18th. Snowfall rates of around 2 inches per hour occurred from the late morning through early afternoon. Storm total snow accumulations ranged from 7 to 9 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow accumulations ranged from 7 to 9 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chills of 35 to 40 below zero occurred across northern Maine from the evening of the 20th through the early moring hours of the 21st before winds diminished.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 35 to 40 below zero occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chills of 35 to 40 below zero occurred across northern Maine from the evening of the 20th through the early moring hours of the 21st before winds diminished.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 35 to 40 below zero occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 3rd, a persistent gale force northwest flow down Delaware Bay caused blow-out tides to occur during the early morning low tide along the Delaware River and tidal sections of its tributaries in Delaware and Philadelphia Counties. Low tide at Marcus Hook (Delaware County) reached -2.20 feet below mean lower low water, in Philadelphia at Pier 11 -1.97 feet below mean lower low water and at the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge (Philadelphia County) -1.96 feet below mean lower low water. Blowout tides at all places start at -1.80 feet below mean lower low water.

Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifteen foot tall tree toppled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines and multiple trees downed.

Deep surface low pressure moving across southern Canada along with a strong westerly flow aloft combined to produce high winds along the Northern Rocky Mountain Front. Wind gusts in excess of 60 mph were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust to 72 mph was reported at Whitlash 8WNW.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep surface low pressure moving across southern Canada along with a strong westerly flow aloft combined to produce high winds along the Northern Rocky Mountain Front. Wind gusts in excess of 60 mph were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust to 59 mph was reported at Bynum 18WSW (the Gleason RAWS site).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system brought heavy snow to the Rocky Mountain Front. Snow amounts in excess of 10 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thirteen inches of snow was reported at Dupuyer 20WSW (the Badger Pass SNOTEL site).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 5 inches in part of southeast South Dakota north of Interstate 90 during the afternoon and evening of December 2nd. The snow continued to a little past midnight near the eastern border of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post cold-frontal wind chill values dropped to -20 to -30 across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  These bitter-cold wind chills were generated by west winds at 17 to 26 knots (20 to 30 mph) with gusts to 26 to 36 knots (30 to 41 mph).  Actual air temperatures were in the single digits above zero, or fell into that temperature range during this event.

Post cold-frontal wind chill values dropped to -20 to -30 across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  These bitter-cold wind chills were generated by west winds at 17 to 26 knots (20 to 30 mph) with gusts to 26 to 36 knots (30 to 41 mph).  Actual air temperatures were in the single digits above zero, or fell into that temperature range during this event.

Post cold-frontal wind chill values dropped to -20 to -30 across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  These bitter-cold wind chills were generated by west winds at 17 to 26 knots (20 to 30 mph) with gusts to 26 to 36 knots (30 to 41 mph).  Actual air temperatures were in the single digits above zero, or fell into that temperature range during this event.
A warm frontal boundary stretched across West Central Wisconsin...was the main ingredient for the development of scattered severe thunderstorms on this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inch diameter tree limbs downed at Highway 29 and 4th Street at River Falls University.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm frontal boundary stretched across West Central Wisconsin...was the main ingredient for the development of scattered severe thunderstorms on this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree felled across road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell...with 6 to 11 inches of snow reported along and northeast of a Dodge to Norfolk to Neligh line.  Some of the heavier snow totals included around 11 inches at Walthill and near Battle Creek and around 10 inches near Norfolk and Wayne.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow spread across Wayne county during the evening hours of 12/18.  Snowfall of an inch or two per hour fell for a few hours during the evening and early overnight hours, and much of the county likely recorded 8 to 10 inches of snow.  Wayne measured 10 inches from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the 3rd major winter storm of the 2008-09 winter season for south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  It dumped 8 to around 14 inches, but the impact on society was significant since there was a lot of blowing and drifting of the snow.  Bands of heavy convective snow had snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour.  The winds were generally east becoming northeast and then north at 13 to 22 knots (15 to 25 mph) with gusts to 26 knots (30 mph).  However, along the Lake Michigan shoreline, a few winds gusts peaked at 30 to 35 knots (35 to 40 mph), which resulted in near-blizzard conditions in that area.  Snow drifts were reported to be 2 to 4 feet in height across southern Wisconsin.  In the middle of the night a small plane skidded of a runway at Milwaukee Mitchell Field, but there were no injuries.  Mitchell Field was closed for a couple hours due to the incident.  Additionally, many airplane flights were delayed or cancelled at the airports in Madison and Milwaukee.  Numerous schools and civic functions were cancelled.  Media reports indicated that dozens of vehicle accidents occurred.  A 2-car accident in the Town of Bristol in Dane County claimed the life of a 16-year old girl (indirect death) on December 18th.  ||Specific snowfall measurements include 14.3 inches in West Allis (Milwaukee Co.); 13.3 inches in Brookfield (Waukesha Co.); 13 inches in Argyle (Lafayette Co.); 12.5 inches near Richland (Washington Co.); 12 inches near Sheboygan (Sheboygan Co.) and far northwestern Ozaukee County; Union Grove (Racine Co.); 12.3 inches in Paddock Lake (Kenosha Co.); 11.5 inches in Middleton (Dane Co.); 11.2 inches in Jefferson (Jefferson Co.); 11 to 12 inches in far northwestern Iowa County and far west-central Green County; 11 inches in far south-central Columbia County and in Beaver Dam (Dodge Co.); 10.9 inches in East Troy (Walworth Co.); 10.8 inches in Afton (Rock Co.); 10.2 inches in Reedsburg (Sauk Co.); 10 inches near Campbellsport (Fond du Lac Co.); 8.6 inches in Markesan (Green Lake Co.), and 8 to 8.5 inches in southern Marquette County.  Synoptically, a strong low pressure moved from southeast Colorado to eastern Kansas to northeast Missouri to Indiana. Surface dewpoints were in the 55 to 60 range on the southeast side of the low pressure.

A low pressure over the Northern Plains dropped southeast across Illinois and generated light snow amounts of 0.5 to 2.5 inches over south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  However, freezing rain and sleet accumulations of 1/10 to 2/10 of an inch occurred before colder air changed the precipitation to snow.  Road surfaces became slippery and dozens of vehicle accidents were reported by the media.  The greatest accumulations of 2 to 2.5 inches occurred from Marquette County east to Fond du Lac County.  Amounts tapered off to less than a half inch near the Illinois border.

A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha/Council Bluffs areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of freezing rain and sleet accumulated around 1/2 inch over most of the county.  Although the mixture created hazardous driving conditions and stuck to vehicle windshields, accumulation on trees and power lines was somewhat limited.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of Pacific storms the last week of December brought heavy snow to the Central Mountains and Upper Snake and South Central Highlands.  Whiteout conditions occurred in the Snake River Plain with road closures in the South Central Highlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Highway 37 closed due to heavy snow and high winds from mile post 37.4 to mile post 68.7.  13 inches of snow fell at the Howell Canyon SNOTEL with 12 inches at the Bostetter Ranger Station.

Amounts tapered off to less than a half inch near the Illinois border.

A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive rain caused widespread flooding across portions of Miller County.  Two bridges were washed out from swift moving flood water.

Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded near Highway 60 at the Dunn Exit.

Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several low water crossings became flooded and impassable to motorists due to excessive rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive rainfall caused several city streets to flood.  This urban flooding led to water running into one home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The active lake effect season continued with the seventh event in less than a month getting underway immediately following a cold frontal passage on Thursday December 4th. A well aligned westerly flow set off lake effect snows off Lake Ontario Thursday afternoon which intensified and continued Thursday night into early Friday, mainly from northern Oswego County into the western Tug Hill. Later in the day, a single intense band lifted north to the Watertown area during the evening and remained until about 2 am when it lifted north and weakened. Off Lake Ontario, specific reports included: 17 inches at Pulaski; 13 inches at Lacona and Harrisville; and 9 to 13 inches at Watertown.|After some diminishing of the activity Friday morning, a deep westerly flow set up again during the day with a band of intense snow setting up off Lake Erie over the lakeshore area near Dunkirk-Silver Creek. This band remained intense as it drifted north up the lake into the Buffalo South Towns by dark, then lifted quickly across the Buffalo metro area during the evening and then stalled in a weakened form up over Niagara county and Niagara Peninsula before dissipating Saturday morning. Specific snowfall reports included: 11 inches at Dunkirk; 10 inches at Mayville; 8 inches at Derby and Blasdell; and 7 inches in East Aurora.

A cold front crossed the region during the afternoon hours. Thunderstorms accompanied the front and one of the thunderstorms produced a damaging wind gust estimated near 60 mph. The media reported that wind downed trees near Alden in Erie County.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.

Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding was reported in Rockford with ditches and culverts full.  Stormtotal rainfall amounts included 1.50 inches at Rockford Airport, 1.39 inches about 3 miles northeast of Rockford and 1.24 inches near Roscoe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six feet of water was reported on 135th Street between Central and Harlem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After heavy rain and melting snow caused widespread flooding and flash flooding across Dupage County on December 27th, flooding continued on December 28th as flood waters slowly receded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and melting snow caused flooding of some roads, creeks and low lying areas across southern Cook County on December 27th.  The flood waters slowly receded on December 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and melting snow caused flooding of some roads, creeks and low lying areas across central and northern Cook County on December 27th.  The flood waters slowly receded on December 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved across parts of northwest and west central Illinois during the mid evening hours of June 8 producing widespread tree damage, a few large hail stones, and heavy rain resulting in some isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds estimated to be 65 mph blew down numerous trees throughout Stephenson County, IL around 8:35 pm June 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved across parts of northwest and west central Illinois during the mid evening hours of June 8 producing widespread tree damage, a few large hail stones, and heavy rain resulting in some isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in flash flooding of Spring Street in Galena, IL around 8:40 pm June 8.  The street was closed by law enforcement officials until flood waters receded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds estimated to be 65 mph blew down some power lines in Oquawka, IL at 8:50 pm June 8.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds estimated to be 60 mph blew down some tree limbs in Gladstone, IL at 8:52 pm June 8.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds estimated to be 65 mph blew down a tree across a highway near Biggsville, IL at 9:00 pm June 8.
