EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were down in Chapel Hill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were down over western Fentress County and in Jamestown. Some of these trees fell on houses and cars. Power was out in Jamestown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 29, 2008, severe thunderstorms occurred ahead of an approaching cold front. Once the thunderstorms moved out of the area, strong gradient winds took hold and produced some non-thunderstorm wind damage across Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down. Some trees fell on homes and cars. There was wind damage to a home at 3743 Dover Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense North Pacific storm produced strong wind and snow across the Eastern Aleutians an Pribilof Island resulting in a blizzard.
An intense North Pacific storm produced strong wind and snow across the Eastern Aleutians an Pribilof Island resulting in a blizzard.
A storm and its associated front moved into the Gulf of Alaska Friday. Strong wind combined with snow in advance of the front produced blizzard conditions across Kodiak Island.
Strong east wind and snow combined to produce a blizzard across the Pribilof Islands.
A storm moved into eastern Cook Inlet producing strong wind and snow resulting in a blizzard over the southern Peninsula.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter from Nikiski reported wind speeds of 39-57 mph along with 2 to 3 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds caused blizzard conditions over southwest Minnesota, mainly away from the southern border of the state. The strong winds combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall. The new snowfall varied mostly from 2 to 4 inches. Zero visibilities and drifting snow made travel virtually impossible. Wind chill readings were driver to as low as 40 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds over 30 mph with gusts to over 45 mph, existing snow cover, and 2 to 5 inches of new snow combined to produce widespread visibilities below a quarter mile in blowing snow, with drifting of the snow blocking roads. Temperatures falling to several degrees below zero combined with the strong winds to produce wind chill readings of 25 to 40 below zero.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained around 30 mph with gusts over 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 2 inches or less to produce blowing snow, with brief visibilities around a quarter mile in places. Temperatures falling to near or a little below zero combined with the strong winds to produce wind chill readings of 20 to 35 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure over the Northern Plains dropped southeast across Illinois and generated light snow amounts of 0.5 to 2.5 inches over south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  However, freezing rain and sleet accumulations of 1/10 to 2/10 of an inch occurred before colder air changed the precipitation to snow.  Road surfaces became slippery and dozens of vehicle accidents were reported by the media.  The greatest accumulations of 2 to 2.5 inches occurred from Marquette County east to Fond du Lac County.  Amounts tapered off to less than a half inch near the Illinois border.

Strong pressure falls across Northern Montana resulted in strong pressure gradients across the Eastern Foothills of the Rocky Mountain Front Range. As a result, high winds were reported across the western portions of the Billings Forecast Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 78 mph was reported at the Stillwater Mine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rain shower over Miles City produced a wind gust of 60 mph.
Strong pressure gradients along the Eastern Foothills of the Rocky Mountain Front Range resulted in high winds across these areas, as well as the favored gap flow areas of Wheatland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 40 mph were observed in Big Timber.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow showers developed during the early morning hours and continued through much of the day across the higher elevations of the Blue Ridge mountains. By late afternoon, accumulations ranged from around an inch to as much as 4 inches. Meanwhile, the valleys saw only occasional flurries or light snow, with just a dusting reported here and there.

A persistent upper low/trough system continued to cause problems for the residents of the Aloha State.  The feature induced more heavy rain and thunderstorms as a moist trade flow moved beneath the cold air aloft.  However, there were no significant injuries or property damage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rapidly developing severe thunderstorm produced penny-sized hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was sighted off of SH 59 and FM 102.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported along SR 7 east of the town of Crockett.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong gradient winds associated with an approaching surface low and cold front were enhanced and brought to the surface by shower activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lexington Airport ASOS reported a gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low level wind shear accompanied a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms across portions of northwest and north central Louisiana the morning of December 9th.  These thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging thunderstorm wind gusts and a few tornadoes across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF0 tornado briefly touched down on the east side of the Red River west of U.S. Hwy. 71 in a field.  A small tin outbuilding and some trees along the levee were damaged.  The tornado was on the ground for approximately one minute.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low level wind shear accompanied a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms across portions of northwest and north central Louisiana the morning of December 9th.  These thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging thunderstorm wind gusts and a few tornadoes across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was reported at East Bert Kouns Loop and Millicent Way.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On January 3rd, a persistent gale force northwest flow down Delaware Bay caused blow-out tides to occur during the early morning low tide along the Delaware River and tidal sections of its tributaries in Delaware and Philadelphia Counties. Low tide at Marcus Hook (Delaware County) reached -2.20 feet below mean lower low water, in Philadelphia at Pier 11 -1.97 feet below mean lower low water and at the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge (Philadelphia County) -1.96 feet below mean lower low water. Blowout tides at all places start at -1.80 feet below mean lower low water.

As rain associated with a warm front moved north into the Poconos just after Midnight EST on the 11th, surface temperatures dropped to below freezing. Light freezing rain accrued on exposed surfaces in some of the higher terrain locations. Ice accretions were less than one tenth of an inch. The recent weather in the Poconos was unseasonably warm and roadways remained wet. Temperatures rose above freezing by 5 a.m. EST that morning. No weather related accidents were reported.

A band of precipitation associated with a warm front moved across New Jersey during the late morning and early afternoon of the 29th. While it was warm enough above the ground for precipitation to fall as rain, temperatures at the surface did not have enough of a chance to recover to above freezing after a clear start to the night. Pockets of light freezing rain or sleet occurred, especially in valley locations. Ice accretions were less than one twentieth of an inch. Untreated roadways, bridges and overpasses were slippery. Farther to the east and southeast, temperatures rose above freezing before the precipitation arrived.

An abnormally warm and humid air mass spread across Kansas and Missouri on Friday, thanks in part to a large and powerful storm system which developed across the Great Basin.  Temperatures Friday afternoon soared to records levels in the upper 60s.  In fact, daily high temperature records were set in Kansas City, St. Joseph, Concordia, Joplin, Springfield, Vichy-Rolla, and Des Moines.  This spring-like air mass set the stage for a rapid swing in weather conditions across the area, with extensive snow melt in Iowa creating ice jams and river flooding.||By the evening hours of the 26th, the powerful upper level storm system was beginning to bear down on the Central Plains.  A potent cold front was swinging through Nebraska and Iowa, with the development of thunderstorm activity across much of eastern Kansas and west central Missouri by 9 pm.  This thunderstorm activity, while strong to severe, caused litte in the way of damage, however did produce flash flooding in areas from Warrensburg, MO to Moberly, MO.||After midnight however, a large line of thunderstorms began to develop further to the west along the aforementioned cold front stretching from central Kansas into northwestern Missouri.  Additional stronger thunderstorms developed in areas near Emporia, KS and further southward along Interstate 35 by 3 am.  These thunderstorms would go on to produce widespread wind damage as they lifted northward into the Kansas City Metro and areas to the south and east.  Composite radar imagery below indicates the regional progression of this line of storms and their track across the region.

Post cold-frontal wind chill values dropped to -20 to -30 across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  These bitter-cold wind chills were generated by west winds at 17 to 26 knots (20 to 30 mph) with gusts to 26 to 36 knots (30 to 41 mph).  Actual air temperatures were in the single digits above zero, or fell into that temperature range during this event.

This was the 3rd major winter storm of the 2008-09 winter season for south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  It dumped 8 to around 14 inches, but the impact on society was significant since there was a lot of blowing and drifting of the snow.  Bands of heavy convective snow had snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour.  The winds were generally east becoming northeast and then north at 13 to 22 knots (15 to 25 mph) with gusts to 26 knots (30 mph).  However, along the Lake Michigan shoreline, a few winds gusts peaked at 30 to 35 knots (35 to 40 mph), which resulted in near-blizzard conditions in that area.  Snow drifts were reported to be 2 to 4 feet in height across southern Wisconsin.  In the middle of the night a small plane skidded of a runway at Milwaukee Mitchell Field, but there were no injuries.  Mitchell Field was closed for a couple hours due to the incident.  Additionally, many airplane flights were delayed or cancelled at the airports in Madison and Milwaukee.  Numerous schools and civic functions were cancelled.  Media reports indicated that dozens of vehicle accidents occurred.  A 2-car accident in the Town of Bristol in Dane County claimed the life of a 16-year old girl (indirect death) on December 18th.  ||Specific snowfall measurements include 14.3 inches in West Allis (Milwaukee Co.); 13.3 inches in Brookfield (Waukesha Co.); 13 inches in Argyle (Lafayette Co.); 12.5 inches near Richland (Washington Co.); 12 inches near Sheboygan (Sheboygan Co.) and far northwestern Ozaukee County; Union Grove (Racine Co.); 12.3 inches in Paddock Lake (Kenosha Co.); 11.5 inches in Middleton (Dane Co.); 11.2 inches in Jefferson (Jefferson Co.); 11 to 12 inches in far northwestern Iowa County and far west-central Green County; 11 inches in far south-central Columbia County and in Beaver Dam (Dodge Co.); 10.9 inches in East Troy (Walworth Co.); 10.8 inches in Afton (Rock Co.); 10.2 inches in Reedsburg (Sauk Co.); 10 inches near Campbellsport (Fond du Lac Co.); 8.6 inches in Markesan (Green Lake Co.), and 8 to 8.5 inches in southern Marquette County.  Synoptically, a strong low pressure moved from southeast Colorado to eastern Kansas to northeast Missouri to Indiana. Surface dewpoints were in the 55 to 60 range on the southeast side of the low pressure.

A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell...with 6 to 11 inches of snow reported along and northeast of a Dodge to Norfolk to Neligh line.  Some of the heavier snow totals included around 11 inches at Walthill and near Battle Creek and around 10 inches near Norfolk and Wayne.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow spread across Cedar county during the evening hours of 12/18.  Snowfall of an inch or two per hour fell for a few hours during the evening and early overnight hours, and much of the county likely recorded 6 to 10 inches of snow.  Randolph measured 10 inches and Coleridge 8 inches for a few of the heavier totals reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense Pacific storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to all of southeast Idaho.  One to three feet of snow fell in the Central Mountains with 4 to 8 inches in the Snake River Plain with blizzard conditions.  One to two feet were common in the southern and southeast highlands with up to 32 inches in the Upper Snake Highlands.  Interstates 84 and 86 were closed east of Declo.  State Highways 39,32,37,46,21, 81, and 77 were all closed.  US Highways 20 and 26 were closed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eleven inches of snow fell at Slug Creek Divide SNOTEL.  12 inches fell at the Franklin Basin SNOTEL with 20 inches at Emigrant Summit SNOTEL.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the area during the evening of the 1st, with a mix of rain and wet snow across the Niagara frontier, which evolved into a lake effect snowband as the winds shifted to westerly behind the front. Snowfall reached 3 to 10 inches over higher elevations from southern Erie County down across the Chautauqua ridge, mainly between 1 and 9 am on the 2nd. The event ended during the evening of the 2nd as warmer air aloft cut off the activity. Specific reports included 10 inches at Perrysburg; 9 inches at Forestville, and 7 inches at South Dayton.

A cold front moved across the area during the evening of the 1st, with a mix of rain and wet snow across the Niagara frontier, which evolved into a lake effect snowband as the winds shifted to westerly behind the front. Snowfall reached 3 to 10 inches over higher elevations from southern Erie County down across the Chautauqua ridge, mainly between 1 and 9 am on the 2nd. The event ended during the evening of the 2nd as warmer air aloft cut off the activity. Specific reports included 10 inches at Perrysburg; 9 inches at Forestville, and 7 inches at South Dayton.

The active lake effect season continued with the seventh event in less than a month getting underway immediately following a cold frontal passage on Thursday December 4th. A well aligned westerly flow set off lake effect snows off Lake Ontario Thursday afternoon which intensified and continued Thursday night into early Friday, mainly from northern Oswego County into the western Tug Hill. Later in the day, a single intense band lifted north to the Watertown area during the evening and remained until about 2 am when it lifted north and weakened. Off Lake Ontario, specific reports included: 17 inches at Pulaski; 13 inches at Lacona and Harrisville; and 9 to 13 inches at Watertown.|After some diminishing of the activity Friday morning, a deep westerly flow set up again during the day with a band of intense snow setting up off Lake Erie over the lakeshore area near Dunkirk-Silver Creek. This band remained intense as it drifted north up the lake into the Buffalo South Towns by dark, then lifted quickly across the Buffalo metro area during the evening and then stalled in a weakened form up over Niagara county and Niagara Peninsula before dissipating Saturday morning. Specific snowfall reports included: 11 inches at Dunkirk; 10 inches at Mayville; 8 inches at Derby and Blasdell; and 7 inches in East Aurora.

A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Urban flooding in Rolla led to water running in a few homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive rain caused a few city streets in Ozark to flood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rare and widespread snowfall occurred across much of southeast and east central Louisiana, beginning early in the morning of December 11th and continuing until around the noon hour, as an unusually strong and cold upper level storm system moved across the region. The snow, which was occasionally heavy, affected all but some of the immediate coastal areas. The heaviest snow occurred over the Florida parishes of east central and southeast Louisiana from east of Baton Rouge to the Pearl River, and along and to the north of Interstate 12. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 6 inches were common in this area with 6 to 8 inch totals occurring in sections of Tangipahoa Parish. The weight of the snow resulted in widespread power outages and tree damage in areas that received the heavier snowfall amounts. Snowfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common across areas to the south and southwest of Lake Pontchartrain including the New Orleans metropolitan area.

A rare and widespread snowfall occurred across much of southeast and east central Louisiana, beginning early in the morning of December 11th and continuing until around the noon hour, as an unusually strong and cold upper level storm system moved across the region. The snow, which was occasionally heavy, affected all but some of the immediate coastal areas. The heaviest snow occurred over the Florida parishes of east central and southeast Louisiana from east of Baton Rouge to the Pearl River, and along and to the north of Interstate 12. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 6 inches were common in this area with 6 to 8 inch totals occurring in sections of Tangipahoa Parish. The weight of the snow resulted in widespread power outages and tree damage in areas that received the heavier snowfall amounts. Snowfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common across areas to the south and southwest of Lake Pontchartrain including the New Orleans metropolitan area.

A complex area of low pressure developed over the midsection of the nation and strengthened as it moved into the western Great Lakes region then into Quebec. Winds accompanying the system increased rapidly across the area ranging from 30 to 40 m.p.h. sustained readings with the strongest gusts downwind of Lakes Erie and Ontario. A peak gust of 75 m.p.h. was recorded at 8:21 a.m. EST at the Buffalo Airport. Close to 100,000 customers lost power during the storm and nearly 90,000 were without phone service. Downed trees damaged several structures and automobiles. The strong winds tore off roofs and shingles on many buildings. At the Buffalo Airport, wind gusts blew several jetways into the terminal building and the airport lost power during much of the storm. In Ripley, downed powerlines caused the closing of the eastbound lanes of the New York State Thruway. At Orchard Park, the wind tore a 2 feet by 50 feet section of the roof the Buffalo Bills field house. The wind picked up gravel and windows and windshields of numerous cars in the stadium parking lot were broken. Inside the stadium, the strong winds tilted both goal posts. Also near the stadium, a concession trailer was blown over with only minor injuries to the occupants reported. The Thousand Islands Bridge was closed for five hours after wind gusts flipped two southbound trucks.

Rainfall of up to an inch and a quarter combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the 60s  to melt a snowpack of four to eight inches which resulted in flooding on the creeks and streams of Western New York.|Cazenovia Creek at Ebenezer crested above its 10 flood stage at 13.0 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in West Seneca and near Cazenovia Park in South Buffalo.|Buffalo Creek at Gardenville crested above its 7 flood stage at 8.71 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding occurred in Elma and Gardenville.|Cayuga Creek at Lancaster crested above its 8 flood stage at 9.23 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in Marilla, Alden and Lancaster.|Tonawanda Creek at Batavia crested above its 9 flood stage at 11.71 feet at 10 a.m. on the 28th.|Tonawanda Creek at Rapids crested above its 12 flood stage at 14.56 feet at 9 a.m. on the 30th. Widespread flooding occurred from Batavia through Alabama, Clarence, Newstead, Akron and Amherst. Backwater flooding occurred on Ransom, Black, Beeman and Mud Creeks.|Black Creet at Churchville crested above its 6 flood stage at 7.87 feet at 7 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding extended from Chili to Churchville.|Oatka Creek at Garbutt crested above its 6 flood stage at 6.85 feet at 1 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding was reported in Garbutt and Scottsville.|Ellicott Creek at Williamsville crested above its 8 flood stage at 10.35 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding was reported along the creek in Bowmansville, Cheektowaga, Williamsville and Amherst.|Road, low-lying and basement flooding was reported along these creeks and some evacuations were ordered.

Heavy rain fell across northern Illinois during the early morning hours of December 27th.  Another round of heavy rain and thunderstorms moved across northern Illinois during the afternoon hours of December 27th.  Some of the thunderstorms produced severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two utility poles and several power lines were blown down on North Pine Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced a couple of small tornadoes in the Columbia CWA and a squall line also moved through and took down trees and powerlines across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm survey found shingles blow off a roof of a home and the owner said the roof briefly lifted up.  A few trees were also down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved across parts of northwest and west central Illinois during the mid evening hours of June 8 producing widespread tree damage, a few large hail stones, and heavy rain resulting in some isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds estimated to be 60 mph blew down some tree limbs in Little York, IL at 9:05 pm June 8.  The limbs were 4 to 6 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of storms as well as several discrete supercells affected north Texas.  Hail as large as softballs was reported as well as a brief tornado touchdown.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel-size hail was reported at the intersection of Highways 6 and 84.

A strong low moved south of the Aleutians producing strong east wind along with snow from the Kuskokwim Delta to the Pribilof Islands. The combination of wind and snow resulted in Blizzard conditions for these regions.

A strong low moved south of the Aleutians producing strong east wind along with snow from the Kuskokwim Delta to the Pribilof Islands. The combination of wind and snow resulted in Blizzard conditions for these regions.
Strong east to northeast wind combined with snow resulted in a Blizzard in the Pribilof Islands.

A tightening pressure gradient ahead of a powerful Pacific storm system produced strong winds in central Wyoming and in the Absaroka Range.  A sensor on Chief Joseph Pass commonly recorded sustained wind of 60 to 80 mph with a peak of 81 mph.  An anemometer along U.S. Highway 287 near Sweetwater Station measured sustained wind of 56 mph.  A peak gust of 73 mph was measured by NWS personnel traveling Wyoming Boulevard on the south side of Casper.

Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.

Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several tree branches and a few small trees toppled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure over the eastern Great Lakes combined with a developing low off the East Coast to produce a light to moderate snow across the state.  The greatest snow from the storm fell across northern Carroll County where 5 to 7 inches fell.  The remainder of the state generally received 2 to 5 inches of snow.

Well below normal temperatures caused a freeze-up jam to develop on the Sugar River at West Claremont, (flood stage 7.0 ft). The river briefly went above flood stage cresting at 7.2 ft, resulting in only minor flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice jam caused by a rapid freeze-up resulted in minor flooding on the Sugar River in West Claremont, (flood stage 7.0 ft), which crested at 7.2 ft.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure over the mid Mississippi Valley on the morning of the 19th moved rapidly eastward during the day and well off the East Coast by the morning of the 20th. The low brought heavy snow to the York and Cumberland, Counties where 5 to 9 inches of snow fell.

High winds developed near the Blue Ridge around sunrise, peaking in the mid to late morning, before tapering off during the afternoon. Numerous trees and power lines were blown down, with some scattered power outages.

High winds developed near the Blue Ridge around sunrise, peaking in the mid to late morning, before tapering off during the afternoon. Numerous trees and power lines were blown down, with some scattered power outages.

Low pressure moved out of the central Plains and moved across Pennsylvania. The low brought an eight to twelve inch blanket of snow to the entire region on the 19th. Across the western southern tier, snowfall amounts were slightly lower however, the snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet across that area. Some of the highest snowfall amounts included: 16 inches at Fairport; 15 inches at Youngstown; 14 inches at LaSalle; 13 inches at Medina; 12 inches at Getzville, Lockport, and North Tonawanda; 11 inches at Montezuma, Charlotte, Perinton, and Warsaw; 10 inches at Kenmore, Buffalo, Stafford, Pavilion, Lowville, Harrisville, Rochester, Niagara Falls, Wilson, Oswego, Walworth and Akron; 9 inches at West Seneca, Black River, Calcium, Hooker, Gorham, Phelps, and Palmyra. Innumerable automobile accidents were reported throughout the region as the roads became hard to navigate in the heavy snow and reduced visibilities. Schools shut down across the region and many municipalities suggested avoiding unnecessary travel if possible.

Strong south winds associated with an approaching front helped produce surf of 6 to 10 feet along the south-facing shores Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Lanai, Maui, and Kahoolawe. There were no reports of significant injuries or property damage.

A complex winter storm brought high winds and snow to northern and central Nevada. The high winds caused blowing and drifting of the snow which reduced visibilities to less than 1/4 mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought strong winds and snow to the Ruby Mountains and the East Humboldt Range. Four to six inches of new snow was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex winter storm brought high winds and snow to northern and central Nevada. The high winds caused blowing and drifting of the snow which reduced visibilities to less than 1/4 mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought strong winds and snow to southern Lander and southern Eureka counties. Frequent wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph occurred with this storm with occasional gusts of 45 to 55 mph. This reduced visibility to less than 1/4 mile at times in snow and blowing snow. Four inches of new snow fell in Austin and Eureka.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex winter storm brought high winds and snow to northern and central Nevada. The high winds caused blowing and drifting of the snow which reduced visibilities to less than 1/4 mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought strong winds and snow to extreme eastern Elko county. Frequent wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph occurred with this storm with occasional gusts of 45 to 55 mph. This reduced visibility to less than 1/4 mile at times in snow and blowing snow. A peak gust of 69 mph was |recorded at the Spring Gulch RAWS site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow but very cold artic airmass spilled southward into the Southern Plains into the Lower Mississippi Valley. This airmass resulted in surface temperatures hovering near to slightly below freezing across portions of northeast Texas.  A warm...moist airmass overran this shallow, colder air near the surface with light rain developing across the county. The light rain became freezing rain across portions of the region with ice accumulations below one quarter of an inch reported.  The ice collected on trees and power lines as well as elevated bridges and overpasses. There were no power disruptions but a few minor accidents were reported across portions of northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Icing was reported on bridges and overpasses on State Highway 82, State Highway 37 and U.S. 271.  Ice was also reported on the loop in Clarksville, Texas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow arctic airmass moved into the region a few days earlier resulting in near to slightly below freezing temperatures across much of northern Louisiana.  A warm...moist layer of air overran the shallower, colder air at the surface with patchy light drizzle and light rain falling across the region.  The drizzle and light rain became freezing drizzle and light freezing rain across much of northern Louisiana during the predawn hours of December 23rd.  The ice froze to elevated bridges and overpasses which in turn, resulted in several vehicle accidents.

A strong low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region.  Snow developed out of this system late in the day on November 30th, and continued through a good part of December 1st.  Snowfall totals of around a foot were common in a band arcing from just west of Traverse City, northeastward into Eastern Upper Michigan.  Trout Lake picked up 17 inches of snow, East Jordan had around 15 inches, and Interlochen right around a foot.

A low pressure trough moving through South Florida and a sea breeze boundary produced strong thunderstorms over Palm Beach County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Boynton Beach police observed a funnel cloud west of Congress Avenue on Boynton Beach Boulevard. The funnel came down about halfway to the ground before lifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued over most of the interior and southwest sections of South Florida during January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall during January led to the continuation of drought conditions across the area. Glades County was in an extreme drought (D3) status, while Hendry, western Palm Beach and northern Collier counties were in a severe drought (D2) status. ||Rainfall amounts during January ranged from 0.5 to 1.0 inches over coastal and inland Collier, Hendry and Glades counties to between 1.0 and 1.5 inches near the south and east shores of Lake Okeechobee. The level of Lake Okeechobee remained at just over 10 feet above sea level, which was over 4 feet below normal.

The storm that had been parked along the California coast finally moved inland on the 18th and created isolated high winds over the Central High Plains.

A powerful upper level disturbance with associated cold front pushed across the region the afternoon and evening of December 11. Over 2 inches of rain fell in many locations with several reports of minor urban flooding. One house was struck by lightning and burned to the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported one foot of water over the road near the intersection of East Millbrook and Quail Hollow roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful upper level disturbance with associated cold front pushed across the region the afternoon and evening of December 11. Over 2 inches of rain fell in many locations with several reports of minor urban flooding. One house was struck by lightning and burned to the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported three to six inches of water on the road near the intersection of Highway 111 and Highway 117 North.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first in a series of winter storms brought significant snowfall to portions of Northern Arizona from the afternoon of December 22 through early morning of December 23. The heaviest snow from this system fell across the Mogollon Rim and White Mountains with Flagstaff receiving 7 to 10 inches of new snow and the Arizona Snowbowl received 12 to 16 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to six inches of snow fell.  Highway 264 was icy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front swept across Deep South Texas and the Lower Rio Grande Valley during the overnight and early morning of December 9th and 10th, bringing periods of sustained gale force winds to the Laguna Madre and adjacent Gulf of Mexico waters out 20 nm, as well as a prolonged period of sustained winds of 30 mph with frequent gusts between above 45 mph, generally between 9 PM on the 9th and 6 AM on the 10th, most pronounced near the coast.||Behind the front, temperatures struggled through the 50s despite ample sunshine on the 10th, setting the stage for the first freeze of the young winter the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Clear skies and light winds allowed temperatures to plummet across mainly rural northern Hidalgo County during the morning of December 11.  At the Linn-San Manuel Mesowest (RAWS) observing station, part of the Lower Rio Grande Valley National Wildlife Refuge, the temperature fell to 30 degrees just after 7 AM.  While this location is just over the county line in extreme northwest Willacy County, interpolation between this location and the Falfurrias, TX (Brooks County) cooperative station argue for at least two hours of 32 degree F or lower readings, generally north of an Edinburg-Alton line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front swept across Deep South Texas and the Lower Rio Grande Valley during the overnight and early morning of December 9th and 10th, bringing periods of sustained gale force winds to the Laguna Madre and adjacent Gulf of Mexico waters out 20 nm, as well as a prolonged period of sustained winds of 30 mph with frequent gusts between above 45 mph, generally between 9 PM on the 9th and 6 AM on the 10th, most pronounced near the coast.||Behind the front, temperatures struggled through the 50s despite ample sunshine on the 10th, setting the stage for the first freeze of the young winter the following morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Clear skies and light winds allowed temperatures to plummet across mainly rural central and southern Jim Hogg County during the morning of December 11.  While temperatures at higher terrain, generally above 500 feet, may not have reached freezing, lower elevations likely fell to or below 32 for at least two hours just prior to sunrise, based on interpolation between similar cooperative observations at least a cooperative station (Brooks County, to the east), and one airport location (Zapata County, to the west).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell...with 6 to 11 inches of snow reported along and northeast of a Dodge to Norfolk to Neligh line.  Some of the heavier snow totals included around 11 inches at Walthill and near Battle Creek and around 10 inches near Norfolk and Wayne.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated between 1/4 and 1/3 of an inch over much of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from central Illinois to central Ohio, with heavy snow falling north of the track of the low.  Northern Michigan was grazed by the north end of the swath of heavy snow.  Six to nine inch accumulations were common, southeast of a line from Lake City to Harrisville.  McBain picked up around 9 inches of snow, while Gladwin and Sterling had around 8 inches.

Just two days after one storm system produced heavy snow in the higher elevations of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin, a second storm came through on a track slightly south of the first one. This storm produced heavy snow down to the desert floor over much of the Mojave Desert.  Snow was seen as low as 1500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured 11 inches of snow fell at Mountain Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough and associated cold front brought heavy snow.  Snowfall amounts in inches included 4 miles east of Pine Grove (6), Camp Sherman (7.5), 2 miles north northeast of Sunriver (7.5), 4 miles south southwest of Bend (6), 2 miles north northwest of Meacham (8), 2 miles northwest of Tollgate (8), Lucky Strike Snotel (6), Battle Mountain (10), Seneca (11), and 2 miles east southeast of Post (5).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were also estimated to be 75 mph with large tree limbs down as well.

A deepening area of low pressure moved across the Ohio valley and Pennsylvania before moving off the southern New England Coast during the afternoon of the 31st. Steady snow developed over the region and was accompanied by increasing northerly winds. Widespread snowfall amounts ranged from eight to fourteen inches during the eight hour event. The strong winds produced areas of blowing and drifting snow and resulted in significantly reduced visibilities. Some of the highest snowfall reports included: 14 inches at Walworth; 12 inches at Fairport; 11 inches at Lockport; 10 inches at Alden, Colden, Kenmore, Livonia, Penfield, and Warsaw; 9 inches at Sinclairville, Buffalo, Amherst, Clarence, Elma, Pavilion, Greece and Niagara Falls; and 8 inches at South Dayton, Montezuma, Avon, Mount Morris and Newark.

An arctic airmass combined with sufficient wind to produce extremely low wind chills across the Nebraska panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills around 40 degrees below zero were recorded near Harrisburg, NE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass combined with sufficient wind to produce extremely low wind chills across the Nebraska panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills from 30 to 35 degrees below zero were recorded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across Arkansas on the 9th, accompanied by numerous showers and thunderstorms. Colder air moved in quickly behind the front, with temperatures plunging more than 20 degrees within just a few hours after frontal passage. Lingering moisture behind the front, coupled with weak areas of low pressure aloft, brought some wintry precipitation to parts of northern Arkansas early on the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of light sleet, snow, and freezing rain caused slick spots to develop on some roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and squall line transited north Florida on Tuesday, February 26th, 2008.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report of two trees down 2 miles southeast of the town of Hampton. Report time has been adjusted based upon radar data as no storms were near Hampton at time of public report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and squall line transited north Florida on Tuesday, February 26th, 2008.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines down in northern part of the county near County Road 138 and State Road 47.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and squall line transited north Florida on Tuesday, February 26th, 2008.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees uprooted on State Road 121 north of Raiford.  Also there was debris in the road on State Road 238 near Raiford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to West Central Wisconsin, by the late evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree toppled on power line along 60th avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell...with 6 to 11 inches of snow reported along and northeast of a Dodge to Norfolk to Neligh line.  Some of the heavier snow totals included around 11 inches at Walthill and near Battle Creek and around 10 inches near Norfolk and Wayne.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and sleet accumulated between 1/2 and 3/4 inch over much of the county on 12/18. The precipitation changed over to snow around midnight on the 19th and around 1 inch of snow fell on top of the mixed ice and sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two periods of snow affected Northern Michigan.  On the 23rd, a pair of upper level disturbances brought 1 to 4 inches of snow to the area.  After a break in the pre-dawn hours, low pressure brought locally heavier snow to the region on the 24th.  Atlanta picked up 9 inches of snow, McBain 8 inches, and Leland 6 inches.
Strong winds prevailed across Western Kansas during the afternoon with a few peak gusts in the warning category.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 61 mph was recorded at the KSN weather lab station at the Deerfield middle school at 119 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deformation zone situated across Southern Idaho and Northern Nevada provided upslope conditions and a resultant four inches in the Twin Falls area on December 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The cooperative observer at KMVT in Twin Falls and trained spotters in Buhl and Filer reported that four inches of snow had fallen overnight.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent snow storm ripped through Southeast Oregon on December 19th bringing strong winds and four to six inches of snow to parts of Baker County. Many of the area roads experienced heavy drifting.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters in Baker City and Sumpter reported five to six inches of snow overnight. Area road conditions were bad due to blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent snow storm ripped through Southwest Idaho on December 19th bringing strong winds and six to twelve inches of snow to the West Central and Boise Mountains and the Camas Prairie. Many of the area roads experienced heavy drifting.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported six to eight inches around the Idaho City area and up to eleven inches near Garden Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent snow storm ripped through Southwest Idaho on December 19th bringing strong winds and six to twelve inches of snow to the West Central and Boise Mountains and the Camas Prairie. Many of the area roads experienced heavy drifting.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported eight to fourteen inches of snow. The heaviest concentration of snowfall was between the Donnelly and McCall areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent snow storm ripped through Southwest Idaho on December 19th bringing strong winds and six to twelve inches of snow to the West Central and Boise Mountains and the Camas Prairie. Many of the area roads experienced heavy drifting.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters in Fairfield and Blaine reported six to eight inches of snow overnight with considerable drifting due to strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms producing large hail and damaging winds moved across portions of South Central and Southeast Montana during the late afternoon hours of the 22nd and continued into the early morning hours of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Microburst winds were estimated at 60 to 70 mph on the south side of Billings. A mobile home roof was blown off and numerous six to eight inch tree limbs were blown down, along with a couple of eight to twelve inch limbs down with some minor damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm producing a severe wind gust moved through portions of the Paradise Valley in Park County during the early evening hours of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 59 mph was reported 9 miles east/southeast of Chico.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms packing damaging winds moved across Central and Southeast Montana during the evening hours of the 26th and the early morning hours of the 27th. The strongest winds were estimated at 80 mph across portions of Treasure County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 70 mph was estimated 5 miles south of Biddle. This resulted in a small trailer home being destroyed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alzada DOT reported a wind gust of 64 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 59 mph was reported at the National Weather Service office in Billings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong winds just off the surface periodically mixed down to the surface and created strong winds at times across parts of southeast Wyoming over a 3 day period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous wind gusts from 65 to 75 mph recorded along Interstate 25 at the Bordeaux interchange with a peak gust of 85 mph.  One tractor-trailer truck was blown over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong winds just off the surface periodically mixed down to the surface and created strong winds at times across parts of southeast Wyoming over a 3 day period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous wind gusts from 55 to 65 mph recorded along Interstate 25 with a peak gust of 66 mph.  Five tractor-trailer trucks were blown over between mile markers 2 and 6 southwest of Cheyenne, WY.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong wind gusts recorded along U.S. Highway 85 at the Gunbarrel site about 12 miles west of Albin, WY.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dense fog blanketed much of southern Illinois as milder south winds blew over cold, frozen ground. Visibility was reduced to one-quarter mile or less.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal squall line developed over central Alabama and extended South-southwestward into Louisiana.  This squall line moved across southeastern Georgia and northern Florida overnight on 2/17-18/2008.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management reported a tree down on power line at 569 Dupont Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management reported a cable line down at 77 Forest Hill Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept across the region with a strong line of showers and thunderstorms moving across the region with a pre-frontal squall line. A warm frontal boundary extended across Georgia from near Albany to Alma and then to Savannah with some severe weather developing along it. Upper level divergence was also fairly impressive based on water vapor satellite imagery and 250 mb winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported street flooding in the Waycross area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds affected much of the area behind a strong cold front. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph were common with gusts in the 50 to 60 mph range. Some damage was reported in the White Pigeon area from the strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sturgis Michigan AWOS unit recorded a wind gust to 58 mph.

Some of the heavier snow totals included around 11 inches at Walthill and near Battle Creek and around 10 inches near Norfolk and Wayne.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of freezing rain and sleet changed to snow during the evening hours of 12/18.  Although the freezing rain and sleet accumulation was under a quarter of an inch, snowfall of around 6 inches likely fell over much of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system dumped heavy snow on nearly all of southeastern Idaho starting on Sunday the 21st and continuing through Monday the 22nd.  More than a foot of snow was common in the mountains while 6 to 14 inches fell in the Snake River Plain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm brought heavy snow to the Eastern Magic Valley.  13 inches fell in Burley and 12 inches fell in Shoshone.  Amounts of greater than 8 inches were reported throughout the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system dumped heavy snow on nearly all of southeastern Idaho starting on Sunday the 21st and continuing through Monday the 22nd.  More than a foot of snow was common in the mountains while 6 to 14 inches fell in the Snake River Plain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snow fell at Howell Canyon with 9 inches at the Oxford Spring, Howell Canyon, and Bostetter SNOTEL sites.  Interstate 84 was closed at 11 am on the 22nd due to heavy snow and winds from mile post 222 to 275 or from the interstate 86 intersection to the Utah border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system dumped heavy snow on nearly all of southeastern Idaho starting on Sunday the 21st and continuing through Monday the 22nd.  More than a foot of snow was common in the mountains while 6 to 14 inches fell in the Snake River Plain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: SNOTEL sites reporting heavy snow were Wildhorse Divide at 13 inches, Somsen Ranch 15 inches, Sheep Mountain 14 inches, and Sedgwick Peak 14 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moving over the Rocky Mountains contributed to high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. Wind gusts in excess of 60 mph were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 77 mph was reported at Babb. Additionally, a wind gust to 80 mph was reported at East Glacier Park 1ENE (Two Medicine DOT site), a gust to 75 mphwas reported at Logan Pass in Glacier National Park, a gust to 58 mph was reported at Heart Butte.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moving over the Rocky Mountains contributed to high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. Wind gusts in excess of 60 mph were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 86 mph was reported at Dupuyer 9SW.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pacific moisture combined with arctic air to produce a winter storm along the Hi-Line. Snow and blowing snow reduced visibilities to less than one-quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 30 mph, visibilities less than one-quarter mile and 3 to 5 inches of snow was reported at Rudyard 27N.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pacific moisture combined with arctic air to produce a winter storm along the Hi-Line. Snow and blowing snow reduced visibilities to less than one-quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 30 mph, visibilitiies less than one-quarter mile and 5 to 8 inches of snow was reported at Chester. Snow drifts of 2 to 3 feet were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post cold-frontal wind chill values dropped to -20 to -30 across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  These bitter-cold wind chills were generated by west winds at 17 to 26 knots (20 to 30 mph) with gusts to 26 to 36 knots (30 to 41 mph).  Actual air temperatures were in the single digits above zero, or fell into that temperature range during this event.

An intense low pressure area approached the Northern California Coast on February 23rd bringing sporadic high winds and bouts of heavy rain to the San Francisco and Monterey Bay areas. A few thousand people lost power due to the high winds and several car accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds reached 46 mph at Pigeon Point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow developed over much of northwest Wisconsin, especially from the Bayfield Peninsula east into the Gogebic Range, during the midday hours of January 13, and persisted through late evening on January 14. Total snow accumulations ranged from 9 inches in Bayfield to about 20 inches in Gile.

Heavy lake effect snow developed over much of northwest Wisconsin, especially from the Bayfield Peninsula east into the Gogebic Range, during the midday hours of January 13, and persisted through late evening on January 14. Total snow accumulations ranged from 9 inches in Bayfield to about 20 inches in Gile.

Light snow developed across the Piedmont during mid-evening, and continued through much of the overnight hours. By mid-morning on the 17th, total accumulations ranged from around an inch south of I-85, to 3 inches or so along the I-40 corridor. Sleet and freezing rain mixed in with the snow before the event ended.

January saw a return to dry weather across western North Carolina.|Most observing stations across the region reported a rainfall deficit of 1 to 2 inches during the month, resulting in another month of exceptional drought conditions across most of the area. Water levels on area lakes remained within a foot or two of record low stages. However, rivers and streams remained somewhat recharged from the December rains, with streamflow on most waterways running 25 to 75 percent of normal.

A storm low southeast of New Zealand caused surf of 6 to 9 feet along the south facing shores of all the Hawaiian Islands.  No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

A large area of low pressure over the Great Lakes pushed a strong cold front across the region during the morning of January 30th. The strong pressure gradient along and behind the front produced wind gusts near 60 MPH in many locations across western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, eastern Ohio, and Garrett county Maryland. This produced numerous reports of trees and power lines down across the region.

A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down 3 miles east of Davis in an open field west of a farmstead and destroyed a 2 story barn.  Six by six supports from the barn where driven into the ground near the farm house.  The home was about 60 yards to the northeast of the barn and was heavily damaged by the tornado.  As the tornado travelled to the east, a couple of new homes sustained minor roof damage on Penrod Road.  It continued to the east northeast and damaged three additional machine sheds as well as numerous trees before lifting and dissipating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in an open field west of Illinois Route 104.  It damaged several trees in this location.  The tornado travelled to the east northeast.  It damaged the roof of one home just east of Illinois Route 104.  It then destroyed a large barn just south of County Road 1050N.  The debris field extended for a mile to the north northeast of the barn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down just west of County Road 2250th Street, north of N1025th Avenue. It damaged a machine shed and a mobile home in this location.  It travelled to the northeast and caused some additional tree damage before lifting and dissipating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds caused widespread damage in Vandalia.  Several windows were blown out around town. A large sign for a store was blown over and part of its roof was blown off. Another business had minor roof damage and a home had some siding damage. A local manufacturing plant had two 12 foot by 14 foot doors damaged and a 15 foot by 20 foot section of the metal wall blown away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the Midsouth during the afternoon and evening hours of December 27th, 2008. Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of the front. Some of the thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds knocked down power lines in Jackson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were blown down across Bunnell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked through the central Great Lakes on the 8th, and continued to slowly track into Ontario on the 9th. Southerly winds ahead of this low pressure allowed for many locations in northern Ohio to report record high temperatures in the 60s during the day on the 8th. The low pressure intensified rapidly as it moved over the Great Lakes during this time. A strong cold front extended from this low pressure, and tracked across the area during the mornning hours of the 9th. A line of showers and thunderstorms developed just ahead of the cold front causing some thunderstorm wind gust damage. Behind the cold front, the strong low pressure allowed for windy conditions to continue through the morning hours of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees, large limbs, and power poles were reported down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable moist atmosphere and slow moving cold front set the stage for the training of rain and thunderstorms across much of northern Indiana. In addition, a dense snowpack rapidly melted as a result of the warm temperatures and rainfall, resulting in rapid rises on river and streams as well as widespread problems with flooding of low areas and ditches. Rainfall amounts ranging from a couple inches to locally over 7 inches was reported, with the highest amounts in and around White county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads across Fulton county were at least partially, if not fully impassable with flood waters from low areas, creeks, streams and rivers. County officials closed all roads to general travel from the evening of January 8th to the morning hours of the 9th. Reports of a Chevy Tahoe in deep water with children trapped was received by dispatch centers in Fulton and Kosciusko counties around 750 am Tuesday morning. The vehicle was located on County Road 600 North between 825 and 900 East near the Fulton/Kosciusko county line. The driver of the vehicle, a 29 year old female, reported coming over the top of a hill and unknowningly drove into flowing water over 600 North. By the time she realized what was going on the vehicle stalled and was subsequently carried by nearly seven feet of water into an adjacent field. The driver was able to rescue three of the five children, ages four, one and three months. However, flood waters overtook the vehicle and two children, a two year old girl and five year old boy drowned in the SUV. Due to the fast current, a boat and front end loader were used in the rescue. A Mentone firefighter suffered minor injuries during the rescue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable moist atmosphere and slow moving cold front set the stage for the training of rain and thunderstorms across much of northern Indiana. In addition, a dense snowpack rapidly melted as a result of the warm temperatures and rainfall, resulting in rapid rises on river and streams as well as widespread problems with flooding of low areas and ditches. Rainfall amounts ranging from a couple inches to locally over 7 inches was reported, with the highest amounts in and around White county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding of many creeks, streams, low areas and small towns occurred as a result of anywhere from 5 to locally as much as 7 inches of rain across much of northern White county. Several inches of snow also rapidly melted, contributing to flooding. Portions of several towns, including Monon, Wolcott, Buffalo and Reynolds were under water, in some places over a foot deep. While the significant flooding subsided during the day of January 9th, numerous areas of standing water persisted well into the 10th. Exact damage figures are not available at this time, but are estimated around $250,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty west to northwest winds behind a cold front downed isolated trees, over turned a tractor trailer, and caused scaffolding to collapse, killing one person and injuring another in New York City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cinder block wall collapsed, causing minor damage to an adjacent building.

CZ_NAME: WEST JACKSON & WEST GRAND COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level jetstream brought very heavy snow to portions of the North-Central Mountains.  The Park and Medicine Bow Ranges received most of the heavy snow, with storm totals of 24 inches at Tower and 16 inches at the Columbine Snotel.  Storm totals elsewhere generally ranged from 4 to 8 inches.  Strong winds also accompanied the snow.  Peak gusts included:  71 mph at Mines Peak, 67 mph at Niwot Ridge, and 60 mph atop Wilkerson Pass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Park and Medicine Bow Ranges received most of the heavy snow, with storm totals of 24 inches at Tower and 16 inches at the Columbine Snotel.

CZ_NAME: S & SE GRAND / W CENTRAL & SW BOULDER / GILPIN / CLEAR CREEK / SUMMIT / N & W PARK COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another fast moving Pacific storm system brought strong winds and more snow to portions of the high country.  Additional snowfall was generally on the light side with accumulations ranging from 2 to 4 inches.  Strong winds caused most of the problem with extensive blowing and drifting snow.  Peak wind gusts included:  105 mph atop Niwot Ridge, 83 mph at Mines Peak, and 63 mph at Pickle Gulch.

A strong and progressive upper level winter storm moved into the Texas panhandle during the overnight hours Wednesday night, January 30th.  An area of snow developed in the Oklahoma panhandle very early Thursday, January 31st, 2008 and moved north into south central Kansas Thursday morning.  When the snow fell, it was heavy at times accompanied by north, gusty winds of 20 to 30 mph, which caused considerable blowing and drifting.  By 11am CST on the 31st, 4 to 5 inches of snow had fallen just east of Medicine Lodge in Barber County, with 2 to 3 inches just west and north of there in Comanche and Pratt counties.  Pratt, Comanche and Barber counties all reported poor driving conditions due to blowing and drifting of snow, with Barber County also reporting schools had closed due to poor road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong and progressive upper level winter storm moved into the Texas panhandle during the overnight hours Wednesday night, January 30th.  An area of snow developed in the Oklahoma panhandle very early Thursday, January 31st, 2008 and moved north into south central Kansas Thursday morning.  When the snow fell, it was heavy at times accompanied by north, gusty winds of 20 to 30 mph, which caused considerable blowing and drifting.  By 11am CST on the 31st, 4 to 5 inches of snow had fallen just east of Medicine Lodge in Barber County, with 2 to 3 inches just west and north of there in Comanche and Pratt counties.  Pratt, Comanche and Barber counties all reported poor driving conditions due to blowing and drifting of snow, with Barber County also reporting schools had closed due to poor road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm moved across the northern plains on Monday, January 28th, 2008, tightening up the surface pressure gradient across southwestern Kansas.  A small part of DDCs CWA experienced high winds during the late afternoon and early evening of the 28th.  A 40 mph sustained wind was reported from Hugoton in Stevens County at 1833 CST, with another from the same location at 2033 CST of 45 mph gusting to 55 mph.  At Liberal in Seward County, one gust of 60 mph occurred at 1955 CST, with a separate wind report from there of 40 mph gusting to 51 mph at 2115 CST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A sustained 40 mph wind was reported in Hugoton at 1630 CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the area Tuesday night with strong high pressure behind the front bringing an arctic airmass over the state on strong northerly flow. Freezing temperatures settled into Levy county Wednesday morning and then settled across the entire area for Thursday morning, with many locations seeing freezing temperatures for six or more hours. North winds of 10 to 15 mph Thursday morning also allowed wind chill values to fall to 15 to 20 degrees across the area. Temperatures moderated for Friday morning, but freezing temperatures were still felt across the Nature Coast for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing conditions were felt across much of the county, with the COOP station near Avon Park reaching a low of 28 degrees, and the COOP in Archbold reaching 29 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over upper Michigan continued to deepen as it tracked across the northern Great Lakes to Quebec. Winds increased to 25 to 40 mph with gusts measured to 75 mph.  Trees and power lines were downed by the strong winds. Utility companies reported tens of thousands of customers without power in locations scattered throughout region. Crews from Ohio, Connecticut and sections of eastern New York traveled to the area to help with power restoration which, in some cases, took several days. Several homes and automobiles were damaged by falling trees and limbs. The strong winds flipped five tractor trailers including ones on Route 12 in Denmark and on Route 81 between LaFargeville and Clayton. In Great Bend, the winds lifted a carport and deposited onto the roof of a home. Northwest Monroe County was particularly hart hit with four homes deemed uninhabitable. Several school districts closed or released students early because of the winds.

In early January, a powerful Pacific storm brought strong winds, heavy rainfall, flash flooding and winter storm conditions to Central and Southern California. Rainfall totals between January 4th and 6th ranged from 2 to 5 inches over coastal areas to 5 to 11 inches in the foothills and mountains. The heaviest rainfall fell over favored south-facing mountain slopes. The total amount of rainfall, combined with rainfall rates around 1 inch per hour, produced numerous reports of flooding as well as mud and debris flows. The mountains received significant snowfall, espeically at the resort levels where 12 to 24 inches of snow fell. Along with the intense precipitation, the storm brought some very strong and gusty southerly winds to the area. The strongest winds were reported across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties as well as all mountain areas. The winds knocked down trees and power lines, producing numerous power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported the intersection of Hidden Valley Lane and Ladera Lane was completely flooded which resulted in road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During December, drought conditions persisted across South Texas, and even intensified in some areas. By the end of December, extreme drought conditions existed across Goliad and Victoria counties. Severe drought conditions existed across Live Oak, Bee, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during December continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during the month, especially with the use of fireworks with the approach of New Years. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. Forage was sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during the month, especially with the use of fireworks with the approach of New Years. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

Total snowfall accumulations ranged from 10 inches at Finland to 26 inches along portions of the Gunflint Trail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down approximately 2.5 miles Southeast of downtown Becker, near the intersection of Highway 10 and 137th Street. It tracked East-Northeast for four miles. Damage included: broken trees, destroying a few sheds and causing minor house damage. The tornado dissipated just West of Eagle Lake, or about 3.5 miles North of Big Lake. In addition, just to the South of the tornado track, there was some straight line wind damage as well. This occurred most likely from a rear flank downdraft that accompanied the tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure track north along a cold front from the lower Mississippi River Valley during the day on the 29th and through the central Great Lakes region on the 30th. This area of low pressure intensified as it tracked north through the central Great Lakes from the afternoon on the 29th through the 30th as this low pressure moved into Canada. The cold front associated with this low pressure moved through the region during the early overnight hours into the 30th. Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of the cold front during the late evening on the 29th, but windy conditions continued through the overnight hours as the low pressure intensifed. Winds finally subsided during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were reported down across the county, especially in Massillon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across northwestern Pennsylvania on January 23rd.  Cold west to northwest behind this front caused lake effect snow showers to develop.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers developed early on January 24th behind a strong cold front.  Heavy snow was reported during the morning hours with the snow showers tapering off to flurries during the afternoon.  Visibilities during the middle portion of the morning were less than one half mile at times.  Six to eight inches of snow was reported south of Interstate 90 in Erie County.  Some accidents were reported.

Snowfall intensity began to increase during the mid and late evening. Snow continued to fall during the early morning hours across the southern mountains and foothills, and total accumulations of 2-4 inches were reached across much of the area shortly after midnight.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low east of Japan caused surf of 10 to 15 feet along the north facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; and 6 to 12 feet along the west-facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, and Oahu.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

January saw a return to dry weather across western North Carolina.|Most observing stations across the region reported a rainfall deficit of 1 to 2 inches during the month, resulting in another month of exceptional drought conditions across most of the area. Water levels on area lakes remained within a foot or two of record low stages. However, rivers and streams remained somewhat recharged from the December rains, with streamflow on most waterways running 25 to 75 percent of normal.

Water levels on area lakes remained within a foot or two of record low stages. However, rivers and streams remained somewhat recharged from the December rains, with streamflow on most waterways running 25 to 75 percent of normal.

A deepening low pressure system at the surface formed over central Kansas during the early morning hours of Thursday, January 10th.  This brought strong northwest winds of 30 to 35 mph to much of central Kansas for a 6 to 10 hour period.  A small band of snow developed in the Hays area (Ellis Co) about midnight Wednesday night.  Since this area had just received a light covering of snow the night before, this new snow had little surface to stick to and just blew across the surface.  Strong northwest winds resulted in blowing snow and near white-out conditions.  Several accidents were reported in and near Hays with cars sliding off the road, and multiple power outages were reported in both Hays and Victoria from downed power lines.   These low visibilities did not last too long (3-4 hours), but did lead to accidents and power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of low pressure over the Great Lakes pushed a strong cold front across the region during the morning of January 30th. The strong pressure gradient along and behind the front produced wind gusts near 60 MPH in many locations across western Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, eastern Ohio, and Garrett county Maryland. This produced numerous reports of trees and power lines down across the region.

A powerful cold front crosses western New York and was followed by very strong west to southwest winds. Sustained winds increased to 30 to 45 mph with gusts measured to 80 mph at the peak of the storm.  Trees and power lines were downed by the strong winds. Utility companies reported close to 100,000 customers without power in locations scattered throughout region. Several homes and automobiles were damaged by falling trees and limbs. On Grand Island, the roof a manufacturing company sustained significant damage. The Buffalo Airport was closed between 8:30 a.m. and noon with over half of its scheduled flights canceled for the day. In downtown Buffalo, a building from the 1850s that had been damaged in an earlier January windstorm, sustained further damage and was deemed unsafe and to be demolished. The New York State Thruway was closed from Henrietta to Depew because of blowing snow and whiteout conditions. Two tractor trailers were blown over on the Thruway. In Irondequoit, the steeple of a church was blown down.

Utility companies reported close to 100,000 customers without power in locations scattered throughout region. Several homes and automobiles were damaged by falling trees and limbs. On Grand Island, the roof a manufacturing company sustained significant damage. The Buffalo Airport was closed between 8:30 a.m. and noon with over half of its scheduled flights canceled for the day. In downtown Buffalo, a building from the 1850s that had been damaged in an earlier January windstorm, sustained further damage and was deemed unsafe and to be demolished. The New York State Thruway was closed from Henrietta to Depew because of blowing snow and whiteout conditions. Two tractor trailers were blown over on the Thruway. In Irondequoit, the steeple of a church was blown down.

A strong low pressure system moved into the Midsouth during the afternoon and evening hours of December 9th, 2008. Showers and thunderstorms developed over North Mississippi in advance of the system. Some thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds, hail and flash flooding.

A convective complex over Georgia initiated by a passing upper level short wave early in the day produced a large scale outflow boundary that advanced over our zones during the afternoon and early evening hours over a moist and unstable airmass. Outflows combined with a strong sea breeze collision near the east coast ignited scattered severe storms across the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down in both High Springs and Newberry around 430 pm local time from strong thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the northern Gulf of Mexico brought widespread precipitation to the region the evening of Friday, January 18th and the morning of Saturday, January 19th. The rain changed to snow over much of the area during the early morning hours of January 19th as the cold center of the strong disturbance moved across the region. Significant precipitation was still occurring along and south of the Interstate 20 corridor when the precipitation changed to snow, and accumulating snow then occurred in most locations east of the Mississippi River.||The heaviest snow appears to have fallen in the areas around Covington, Jefferson Davis, and western Jones Counties, where isolated amounts of 4 to 5 inches occurred. At the height of the snow, temperatures were able to fall to near freezing, and accumulations occurred on roadways resulting in a number of traffic accidents. Additionally, some power outages occurred in the heaviest snow band due to the weight of the wet snow on limbs and lines. However, most folks in the area enjoyed the rare snowfall and took full advantage of the opportunity to make snowmen and snow angels, or to go sledding on the nearest hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three inches of snow fell across the northern half of Marion County. The heaviest snow, around three inches, fell across the northern areas from the Bunker Hill to Improve Communities.
