EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second week of January 2008 was quite active with respect to severe weather. Two events impacted the region in a span of 3 days which produced several tornadoes, large hail and wind damage across the area. ||On January 10th a vigorous storm system developed over the southern portions of the Midwest and moved northeast towards the Ohio valley. A strong cold front swept across the area during the late morning into the afternoon hours and strong to severe thunderstorms developed out ahead of it. All of the ingredients for tornadic development came into place as warm Gulf moisture pushed northward into the area out ahead of the front. The thunderstorms developed in eastern Louisiana and quickly moved across central Mississippi during the late morning and afternoon hours. As the storms progressed eastward, good instability combined with very strong wind shear for supercell development east of the Mississippi River, with the storms reaching maximum intensity along and east of the interstate 55 corridor.||By far, the most damage was produced by a single supercell thunderstorm that moved from north of Vicksburg through north central and northeast Mississippi during the late morning and early afternoon hours. This single storm produced three strong tornadoes, all of which were rated as EF3 on the Enhanced Fujita tornado damage scale. The most significant damage occurred in Caledonia in Lowndes County, where a school gymnasium was destroyed along with a number of school buses and vehicles in the area.||A second supercell that organized near the Mississippi River in southwest Mississippi before midday tracked from Claiborne County, through the northern Jackson Metropolitan Area, and finally into Noxubee county in northeast Mississippi by mid afternoon. This storm was responsible for 5 different tornado touchdowns along its path, as well as many reports of high winds and hail.||The rest of the area saw a broken line of storms and other supercells ahead of the line. A mix of damaging winds and hail were reported through the rest of the afternoon before the system exited the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado occurred in a very rural area with tree damage the only observed damage. Where the tornado crossed Hunt Road, tree damage was significant, with hundreds of trees snapped and uprooted along with several power lines down.

Two events impacted the region in a span of 3 days which produced several tornadoes, large hail and wind damage across the area. ||On January 10th a vigorous storm system developed over the southern portions of the Midwest and moved northeast towards the Ohio valley. A strong cold front swept across the area during the late morning into the afternoon hours and strong to severe thunderstorms developed out ahead of it. All of the ingredients for tornadic development came into place as warm Gulf moisture pushed northward into the area out ahead of the front. The thunderstorms developed in eastern Louisiana and quickly moved across central Mississippi during the late morning and afternoon hours. As the storms progressed eastward, good instability combined with very strong wind shear for supercell development east of the Mississippi River, with the storms reaching maximum intensity along and east of the interstate 55 corridor.||By far, the most damage was produced by a single supercell thunderstorm that moved from north of Vicksburg through north central and northeast Mississippi during the late morning and early afternoon hours. This single storm produced three strong tornadoes, all of which were rated as EF3 on the Enhanced Fujita tornado damage scale. The most significant damage occurred in Caledonia in Lowndes County, where a school gymnasium was destroyed along with a number of school buses and vehicles in the area.||A second supercell that organized near the Mississippi River in southwest Mississippi before midday tracked from Claiborne County, through the northern Jackson Metropolitan Area, and finally into Noxubee county in northeast Mississippi by mid afternoon. This storm was responsible for 5 different tornado touchdowns along its path, as well as many reports of high winds and hail.||The rest of the area saw a broken line of storms and other supercells ahead of the line. A mix of damaging winds and hail were reported through the rest of the afternoon before the system exited the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level low enhanced sea breeze and outflow initiated convection over an unstable and moist airmass.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Clay Electric Line Supervisor in Keystone Heights reported widespread power line damage throughout his service area with the most significant damage in Florahome. Numerous trees were blown down on power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs and a small tree were blown down near the intersection of Highway 40 and Interstate 95.

CZ_NAME: FERNANDINA BEACH TO ST AUGUSTINE FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mayport Naval Station recorded a wind gust to 48 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and rapidly intensifying low pressure system moved from the Great Lakes across Ontario and western Quebec during the morning and early afternoon of January 9th. A very strong low-level wind field with southwest winds in excess of 70 mph just above the surface moved across northern New York during the late morning and early afternoon hours. ||Some of these strong winds translated down to the surface and caused scattered wind damage in the form of downed trees and scattered power outages across eastern Clinton and eastern Essex counties in New York.|Some recorded wind gusts included; 49 mph in Beekmantown, 46 mph in Peru and 45 mph at Plattsburgh (Clinton county).

A strong and rapidly intensifying low pressure system moved from the Great Lakes across Ontario and western Quebec during the morning and early afternoon of January 9th. A very strong low-level wind field with southwest winds in excess of 60 mph just above the surface moved across Vermont during the early afternoon hours. ||Some of these strong winds translated down to the surface and caused scattered wind damage in the form of downed trees and scattered power outages throughout Vermont. Some observed wind gusts included; 55 mph in Waitsfield (Washington county), 53 mph at Colchester Reef (Chittenden county) with 45 mph in Rutland (Rutland county) and Westford (Chittenden county).

An arctic cold front dropped south through the area during the day on the 19th. Northerly winds behind this front flowing over Lake Erie allowed for lake effect snow to develop through the daytime hours of the 19th. The lake effect snow continued into the 20th and tapered off on the 21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow began during the morning hours of the 19th and continued through the day. The lake effect snow persisted through the overnight and into the daytime hours of the 20th before coming to an end that night. The snow was light during the daytime of the 19th, with locations picking up between 1.0 and 4.0 inches by the evening. Lake effect snow was heaviest during the overnight hours into the 20th. On the morning of the 20th in just 12 hours Concord measured 8.1 inches and Painesville measured 6.3 inches. The snow continued that day and came to an end during the late evening and early overnight hours. By the evening, many locations throughout the county measured between 6.0 and 10.0 inches of snow. By the end of the event, Madison measured 11.0 inches, two spotters in Concord measured 11.9 inches and 15 inches, 8.2 inches in Mentor, and 7.2 inches in Kirtland. Many accidents were reported from this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front dropped south through the area during the day on the 19th. Northerly winds behind this front flowing over Lake Erie allowed for lake effect snow to develop through the daytime hours of the 19th. The lake effect snow continued into the 20th and tapered off on the 21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow began during the morning hours of the 19th and continued through the day. The snow was rather light during the day and by evening many locations only measured between 1.0 and 3.0 inches. The lake effect snow persisted through the overnight hours into the 20th, and was moderate to heavy at times overnight. By the morning of the 20th, snow reports just from the overnight hours indicate that Chardon picked up 9.0 inches, Hambden Township measured 7.6 inches and Montville measured 6.5 inches. The snow continued through much of the day on the 20th and ended that evening. Total snowfall measurements from this event include Chardon with 13.0 inches, Hambden with 12.3 inches, Montville measured 10.0 inches, and Thompson had 13.9 inches. Many accidents were reported from this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system lifted out of the Midwest and tracked just west of Buffalo to near Ottawa and Montreal. This is a very favorable track for high winds across much of Western New York as strong gusty winds are further enhanced by the funneling effects of Lakes Erie and Ontario. The strong winds developed during the evening hours and continued until early morning of the 25th. The highest gusts exceeded 60 miles per hour. The winds downed trees and power lines with tens of thousands left without power. Specific reported wind gusts included: 62 m.p.h. at Watertown Airport and Rochester Airport; 61 m.p.h. at Eden and Oswego; 60 m.p.h. at Java Center; 59 m.p.h. at Oswego Coast Guard; 58 m.p.h. at Dunkirk, Alden and Hamburg; 55 m.p.h. at Buffalo Airport and Canandaigua; 54 m.p.h. at Fulton; and 52 m.p.h. at Wellsville.

A deepening area of low pressure moved across the Ohio valley and Pennsylvania before moving off the southern New England Coast during the afternoon of the 31st. Steady snow developed over the region and was accompanied by increasing northerly winds. Widespread snowfall amounts ranged from eight to fourteen inches during the eight hour event. The strong winds produced areas of blowing and drifting snow and resulted in significantly reduced visibilities. Some of the highest snowfall reports included: 14 inches at Walworth; 12 inches at Fairport; 11 inches at Lockport; 10 inches at Alden, Colden, Kenmore, Livonia, Penfield, and Warsaw; 9 inches at Sinclairville, Buffalo, Amherst, Clarence, Elma, Pavilion, Greece and Niagara Falls; and 8 inches at South Dayton, Montezuma, Avon, Mount Morris and Newark.

CZ_NAME: KEY W TO DRY TORTUGAS WATERS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A narrow squall line moved eastward at 20 to 25 knots across the Florida Keys and adjacent coastal waters. Scattered wind gusts to gale force were measured as the squall line moved through.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 35 knots (40 mph) was measured at the Pulaski Shoal Light C-MAN station, 8 miles east northeast of Fort Jefferson National Monument.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 34 knots (39 mph) was measured at the Pulaski Shoal Light C-MAN station, 8 miles east northeast of Fort Jefferson National Monument.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions developed during the early morning of December 21st and continued through the early evening hours.  Many areas received new snowfall of 1 to 2 inches during the evening of December 20th.  This fresh snowfall was blown around by winds gusting to 40 mph, which caused visibilities to drop to near zero in many locations.

A powerful cold front crosses western New York and was followed by very strong west to southwest winds. Sustained winds increased to 30 to 45 mph with gusts measured to 80 mph at the peak of the storm.  Trees and power lines were downed by the strong winds. Utility companies reported close to 100,000 customers without power in locations scattered throughout region. Several homes and automobiles were damaged by falling trees and limbs. On Grand Island, the roof a manufacturing company sustained significant damage. The Buffalo Airport was closed between 8:30 a.m. and noon with over half of its scheduled flights canceled for the day. In downtown Buffalo, a building from the 1850s that had been damaged in an earlier January windstorm, sustained further damage and was deemed unsafe and to be demolished. The New York State Thruway was closed from Henrietta to Depew because of blowing snow and whiteout conditions. Two tractor trailers were blown over on the Thruway. In Irondequoit, the steeple of a church was blown down.

Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches in an area just west of the James River in southeast South Dakota during the predawn hours of January 23rd. The snowfall caused slippery travel and minor delays.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches, causing slippery travel conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches over the eastern two thirds of the county, causing slippery travel conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds blew some shingles off of three buildings in town.

CZ_NAME: INNER CHANNELS FROM KUPREANOF ISLAND TO ETOLIN ISLAND
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the twenty-ninth the arctic front was over the Panhandle with high pressure centered over the Yukon. This pattern caused some cold outflow through the Stikine river gap. On the thirtieth a frontal system moved near Dixon Entrance which caused warm moist air to briefly move over the arctic air in the Inner Channels.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The trained spotter at the forest service office in Petersburg measured 6.5 inches of new snow that fell from 0700 to 1220 on the thirtieth. Another spotter in Petersburg measured 7.5 inches of new snow from 0700 to 1500 on the thirtieth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved into the Midsouth during the afternoon and evening hours of December 9th, 2008. Showers and thunderstorms developed over North Mississippi in advance of the system. Some thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds, hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding across Tate County. Several roads were flooded as a result. In Senatobia, several streets in town were flooded as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved into the Midsouth during the afternoon and evening hours of December 9th, 2008. Showers and thunderstorms developed over North Mississippi in advance of the system. Some thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds, hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds damaged a barn 10 miles south of Pontotoc. In addition, trees and power lines were knocked down as well.

Showers and thunderstorms developed over North Mississippi in advance of the system. Some thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds, hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds blew the tops of trees off, 4 miles south of Houlka.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Marion County Sheriff officers reported trees down along Southeast 110th Street and the 475 intersection. The time of the damage was based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter estimated 60 mph wind gusts that downed 3 trees on Bypass Road on the west side of Homerville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm spotter reported television cable lines down in Argyle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cedar Ridge RV Park had several large trees down due to severe thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees that were blown down in Manor caused a brush fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Brantley County Emergency Operations Dispatch Center was inundated with calls due to downed trees and power lines from thunderstorm winds. Many downed lines caused small brush fires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of storms spread moderate to heavy snow across Southeast Oregon and Southwest Idaho. Strong, gusty winds also accompanied this storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of four to five inches of new snow in and around the Nampa and Caldwell areas including a report of seven inches near Marsing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong cold front, accompanied by developing low pressure, resulted in snow across much northern Indiana. While the highest amounts were only around 4 inches in the far northwestern part of the area, strong winds caused widespread blowing and drifting with white-out conditions at times. In addition, wind chills dropped into the 15 to 25 below zero range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm brought a wide variation in amounts to the county, ranging from around 11 inches in southeastern parts of the county, to 26 inches in New Carslie. The locally higher amounts were due to a combination of enhanced bands of both system and lake enhanced snow. Strong winds also created widespread blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong cold front, accompanied by developing low pressure, resulted in snow across much northern Indiana. While the highest amounts were only around 4 inches in the far northwestern part of the area, strong winds caused widespread blowing and drifting with white-out conditions at times. In addition, wind chills dropped into the 15 to 25 below zero range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm brought a wide variation in amounts to the county, ranging from around 12 inches in southeastern parts of the county, to 23.5 inches in Rolling Prairie. The locally higher amounts were due to a combination of enhanced bands of both system and lake enhanced snow. Strong winds also created widespread blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong cold front, accompanied by developing low pressure, resulted in snow across much northern Indiana. While the highest amounts were only around 4 inches in the far northwestern part of the area, strong winds caused widespread blowing and drifting with white-out conditions at times. In addition, wind chills dropped into the 15 to 25 below zero range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm brought 9 to 11 inches of snow across the county. Strong winds also created widespread blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong cold front, accompanied by developing low pressure, resulted in snow across much northern Indiana. While the highest amounts were only around 4 inches in the far northwestern part of the area, strong winds caused widespread blowing and drifting with white-out conditions at times. In addition, wind chills dropped into the 15 to 25 below zero range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm brought 6 to 9 inches of snow across the county. Strong winds also created widespread blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure track north along a cold front from the lower Mississippi River Valley during the day on the 29th and through the central Great Lakes region on the 30th. This area of low pressure intensified as it tracked north through the central Great Lakes from the afternoon on the 29th through the 30th as this low pressure moved into Canada. The cold front associated with this low pressure moved through the region during the early overnight hours into the 30th. Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of the cold front during the late evening on the 29th, but windy conditions continued through the overnight hours as the low pressure intensifed. Winds finally subsided during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were reported down countywide. Also, numerous road signs were blown away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure track north along a cold front from the lower Mississippi River Valley during the day on the 29th and through the central Great Lakes region on the 30th. This area of low pressure intensified as it tracked north through the central Great Lakes from the afternoon on the 29th through the 30th as this low pressure moved into Canada. The cold front associated with this low pressure moved through the region during the early overnight hours into the 30th. Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of the cold front during the late evening on the 29th, but windy conditions continued through the overnight hours as the low pressure intensifed. Winds finally subsided during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were reported down countywide. Also, numerous road signs were blown away from their poles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday evening, January 16th through Thursday, January 17th on a track southeast of the Morristown forecast area producing heavy mountain snowfall with some minor snow accumulation in the lower elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday evening, January 16th through Thursday, January 17th on a track southeast of the Morristown forecast area producing heavy mountain snowfall which totaled between 4 and 6 inches across this portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday evening, January 16th through Thursday, January 17th on a track southeast of the Morristown forecast area producing heavy mountain snowfall with some minor snow accumulation in the lower elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday evening, January 16th through Thursday, January 17th on a track southeast of the Morristown forecast area producing heavy mountain snowfall which totaled between 4 and 7 inches across this portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January saw a return to dry weather across western North Carolina.|Most observing stations across the region reported a rainfall deficit of 1 to 2 inches during the month, resulting in another month of exceptional drought conditions across most of the area. Water levels on area lakes remained within a foot or two of record low stages. However, rivers and streams remained somewhat recharged from the December rains, with streamflow on most waterways running 25 to 75 percent of normal.

A cold front moved through Oklahoma on the 29th. Behind the front, extremely strong wind gusts were reported over much of the area. Numerous locations reported wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph. A few wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph were reported in isolated locations. Minor damage was repored, but no injuries occurred. Monetary damages were estimated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The non-thunderstorm wind gust was reported at the National Weather Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Yet another series of Pacific storms brought heavy snow, high winds, and thunderstorms to parts of the Mojave Desert and Southern Great Basin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds lifted a trampoline into one set of power lines, and blew a tree down into another set of power lines.  Approximately 5,000 people were without power for one to two hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed over the Plains and moved east across the Great Lakes. The low brought a general light to moderate snowfall of four to six inches across the entire region. Over the higher elevations of the Chautauqua ridge, higher snow totals were reported. Eight inches fell in South Dayton while Stockton received twelve inches.

Low pressure developed over the Plains and moved east across the Great Lakes. The low brought a general light to moderate snowfall of four to six inches across the entire region. Over the higher elevations of the Chautauqua ridge, higher snow totals were reported. Eight inches fell in South Dayton while Stockton received twelve inches.

A powerful cold front crosses western New York and was followed by very strong west to southwest winds. Sustained winds increased to 30 to 45 mph with gusts measured to 80 mph at the peak of the storm.  Trees and power lines were downed by the strong winds. Utility companies reported close to 100,000 customers without power in locations scattered throughout region. Several homes and automobiles were damaged by falling trees and limbs. On Grand Island, the roof a manufacturing company sustained significant damage. The Buffalo Airport was closed between 8:30 a.m. and noon with over half of its scheduled flights canceled for the day. In downtown Buffalo, a building from the 1850s that had been damaged in an earlier January windstorm, sustained further damage and was deemed unsafe and to be demolished. The New York State Thruway was closed from Henrietta to Depew because of blowing snow and whiteout conditions. Two tractor trailers were blown over on the Thruway. In Irondequoit, the steeple of a church was blown down.

A storm off the California coast on the 4th and 5th finally moved inland on the 6th and reached the four corners area early on the 7th. This allowed for plenty of moisture to surge into New Mexico ahead of the storm. A long duration snow event occurred over the southern San Juan and Sangre De Cristo mountains with around two feet of snow. Six to 12 inches of snow was common over the western and central mountains, while 3 to 6 inches fell in the western valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to 9 inches of snow fell in the Sandia and Manzano mountains along with areas of blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm that deepened off the northern California coast on January 22nd and 23rd weakened as it moved inland on the 24th and crossed new Mexico on the 25th as a weak trough of low pressure. However, the storm was able to draw enough moisture into the state to produce light to moderate snowfall over primarily the northwest third of New Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of up to 4 inches around Farmington and Shiprock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad surface trough was nearly stationary over the forecast area as a short wave upper level trough traversed the region during the afternoon when instability was high. Widespread severe storms developed along the sea breezes and outflows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts downed several trees along the Alma Highway near Jamestown. A vehicle collided with one of the downed trees and emergency response officials were en-route to the accident just before 1 am EDT per the Ware County 911 Dispatch Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long wave upper level trough was over the western Atlantic and a weak surface trough lingered over the area. Storms fired in a highly unstable environment in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large limbs and power lines were blown down along Treasure Point Road and Doctors Lake Drive. Lightning struck a few power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability and abundant moisture combined with upper level forcing per a passing upper level trough enhanced convection along the sea breeze fronts in the late afternoon and early evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Clinch county officials received numerous reports of penny size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level low enhanced sea breeze and outflow initiated convection over an unstable and moist airmass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to penny size hail was reported east of downtown Ocala near 17th Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second week of January 2008 was quite active with respect to severe weather. Two events impacted the region in a span of 3 days which produced several tornadoes, large hail and wind damage across the area. ||On January 10th a vigorous storm system developed over the southern portions of the Midwest and moved northeast towards the Ohio valley. A strong cold front swept across the area during the late morning into the afternoon hours and strong to severe thunderstorms developed out ahead of it. All of the ingredients for tornadic development came into place as warm Gulf moisture pushed northward into the area out ahead of the front. The thunderstorms developed in eastern Louisiana and quickly moved across central Mississippi during the late morning and afternoon hours. As the storms progressed eastward, good instability combined with very strong wind shear for supercell development east of the Mississippi River, with the storms reaching maximum intensity along and east of the interstate 55 corridor.||By far, the most damage was produced by a single supercell thunderstorm that moved from north of Vicksburg through north central and northeast Mississippi during the late morning and early afternoon hours. This single storm produced three strong tornadoes, all of which were rated as EF3 on the Enhanced Fujita tornado damage scale. The most significant damage occurred in Caledonia in Lowndes County, where a school gymnasium was destroyed along with a number of school buses and vehicles in the area.||A second supercell that organized near the Mississippi River in southwest Mississippi before midday tracked from Claiborne County, through the northern Jackson Metropolitan Area, and finally into Noxubee county in northeast Mississippi by mid afternoon. This storm was responsible for 5 different tornado touchdowns along its path, as well as many reports of high winds and hail.||The rest of the area saw a broken line of storms and other supercells ahead of the line. A mix of damaging winds and hail were reported through the rest of the afternoon before the system exited the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swath of pea to penny sized hail continued to fall from the long lived supercell thunderstorm which was responsible for producing the two EF3 tornadoes across Holmes, Attala, and Choctaw Counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small ice storm occurred across the region on January 25 with freezing rain observed across the northern half of the service area. This occurred as a arctic high pressure settled over the Ohio Valley and shallow cold air filtered into region. While the cold air was moving in, an area of low pressure was taking shape across the northern Gulf of Mexico and helped to produce widespread light rain over the area. Across the northern portions of the forecast area, temperatures were below freezing when the light rain fell and good ice accumulations occurred for areas generally along and north of a line from Rayville Louisiana to Lexington Mississippi to West Point Mississippi. The icing was not very heavy, but problems occurred across the areas that did receive around a quarter inch of ice. Numerous accidents occurred from icing on bridges and overpasses with one fatality in Grenada County. Trees and power lines did accumulate some ice, but the ice was not heavy enough to cause much damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around one quarter inch of ice accumulated slowly through the day with icing being worst across area roads. Accidents were plentiful across the parish with some icing in trees and on power lines.

CZ_NAME: FERNANDINA BEACH TO ST AUGUSTINE FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 54 mph wind gust was measured at the St. Augustine Pier.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of powerful Pacific storms brought heavy precipitation and strong winds to southeast California and southern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bishop, CA ASOS recorded 4.00 of rain on January 4th.  This was an all-time one day rainfall record, breaking the previous record of 3.50 on February 24, 1969.  There was widespread minor flooding, but no major flooding was reported.

CZ_NAME: EASTERN SIERRA SLOPES OF INYO COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of powerful Pacific storms brought heavy precipitation and strong winds to southeast California and southern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer in Aspendell, CA (8500') recorded 34 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved down the Colorado River valley, producing locally strong north winds in its wake.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A gust of wind in Bullhead City picked up a patio roof and blew it into two houses.  The time of the event is an estimate.

CZ_NAME: EASTERN SIERRA SLOPES OF INYO COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of Pacific storms brought heavy snow to the eastern Sierra slopes, and strong winds to portions of southeast California and southern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer recorded 17 inches of snow in Aspendell (8500').

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked through the central Great Lakes on the 8th, and continued to slowly track into Ontario on the 9th. Southerly winds ahead of this low pressure allowed for many locations in northern Ohio to report record high temperatures in the 60s during the day on the 8th. The low pressure intensified rapidly as it moved over the Great Lakes during this time. A strong cold front extended from this low pressure, and tracked across the area during the mornning hours of the 9th. A line of showers and thunderstorms developed just ahead of the cold front causing some thunderstorm wind gust damage. Behind the cold front, the strong low pressure allowed for windy conditions to continue through the morning hours of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured a wind gust of 63 mph associated with a line of thunderstorms that moved through the area. No immediate damage was  noted with the severe winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable moist atmosphere and slow moving cold front set the stage for the training of rain and thunderstorms across much of northern Indiana. In addition, a dense snowpack rapidly melted as a result of the warm temperatures and rainfall, resulting in rapid rises on river and streams as well as widespread problems with flooding of low areas and ditches. Rainfall amounts ranging from a couple inches to locally over 7 inches was reported, with the highest amounts in and around White county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around one dozen roads were closed across the county, as well in Elkhart and Goshen as a result of either a foot or more of standing water on roadsway, or rising river levels. No mandatory evacuations were put in place. Several city and county parks were partially under water with damage to sidewalks and some retaining walls. No exact damage figures are available, but are estimated at $250,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable moist atmosphere and slow moving cold front set the stage for the training of rain and thunderstorms across much of northern Indiana. In addition, a dense snowpack rapidly melted as a result of the warm temperatures and rainfall, resulting in rapid rises on river and streams as well as widespread problems with flooding of low areas and ditches. Rainfall amounts ranging from a couple inches to locally over 7 inches was reported, with the highest amounts in and around White county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed or posted with high water signs across the county as a result of 1 to 3 inches of rain, as well as snow melt. Several residences and businesses were sandbagged as a precaution but no significant damage was reported. Damage is estimated at around $150,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable moist atmosphere and slow moving cold front set the stage for the training of rain and thunderstorms across much of northern Indiana. In addition, a dense snowpack rapidly melted as a result of the warm temperatures and rainfall, resulting in rapid rises on river and streams as well as widespread problems with flooding of low areas and ditches. Rainfall amounts ranging from a couple inches to locally over 7 inches was reported, with the highest amounts in and around White county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were either closed or had high water signs up for several days due to rainfall of 2 to 4 inches across the county. Several creeks and the Tippecanoe river also went over their banks, causing part of the flooding problems in addtion to creeks, ditches and low areas filling beyond capacity. No exact damage figures are available but are estimated at $200,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty west to northwest winds behind a cold front caused a building under construction to partially collapse.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A building under construction, near the Oxford Greens Housing Development, had a partial collapse along its south and east sides.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure track north along a cold front from the lower Mississippi River Valley during the day on the 29th and through the central Great Lakes region on the 30th. This area of low pressure intensified as it tracked north through the central Great Lakes from the afternoon on the 29th through the 30th as this low pressure moved into Canada. The cold front associated with this low pressure moved through the region during the early overnight hours into the 30th. Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of the cold front during the late evening on the 29th, but windy conditions continued through the overnight hours as the low pressure intensifed. Winds finally subsided during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees were reported down, one on the north side of the city and another on the south side of Marion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong disturbance aloft brought heavy snow, gusty winds and very cold temperatures to a large portion of North Central Montana. Snow amounts in excess of 6 inches, wind gusts in excess of 60 mph and wind chill readings colder than 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind chill reading of 43 degrees (F) below zero was reported at the Bowmans Corner DOT site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong disturbance aloft brought heavy snow, gusty winds and very cold temperatures to a large portion of North Central Montana. Snow amounts in excess of 6 inches, wind gusts in excess of 60 mph and wind chill readings colder than 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind chill reading of 47 degrees(F) below zero was reported at Hobson 6NW. Additionally, blowing snow caused road closures near Eddie's Corner.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of up to an inch and a quarter combined with unseasonably warm temperatures in the 60s  to melt a snowpack of four to eight inches which resulted in flooding on the creeks and streams of Western New York.|Cazenovia Creek at Ebenezer crested above its 10 flood stage at 13.0 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in West Seneca and near Cazenovia Park in South Buffalo.|Buffalo Creek at Gardenville crested above its 7 flood stage at 8.71 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding occurred in Elma and Gardenville.|Cayuga Creek at Lancaster crested above its 8 flood stage at 9.23 feet at 6 p.m. on the 27th. Flooding was reported in Marilla, Alden and Lancaster.|Tonawanda Creek at Batavia crested above its 9 flood stage at 11.71 feet at 10 a.m. on the 28th.|Tonawanda Creek at Rapids crested above its 12 flood stage at 14.56 feet at 9 a.m. on the 30th. Widespread flooding occurred from Batavia through Alabama, Clarence, Newstead, Akron and Amherst. Backwater flooding occurred on Ransom, Black, Beeman and Mud Creeks.|Black Creet at Churchville crested above its 6 flood stage at 7.87 feet at 7 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding extended from Chili to Churchville.|Oatka Creek at Garbutt crested above its 6 flood stage at 6.85 feet at 1 a.m. on the 29th. Flooding was reported in Garbutt and Scottsville.|Ellicott Creek at Williamsville crested above its 8 flood stage at 10.35 feet at 7 p.m. on the 28th. Flooding was reported along the creek in Bowmansville, Cheektowaga, Williamsville and Amherst.|Road, low-lying and basement flooding was reported along these creeks and some evacuations were ordered.

Many areas received new snowfall of 1 to 2 inches during the evening of December 20th.  This fresh snowfall was blown around by winds gusting to 40 mph, which caused visibilities to drop to near zero in many locations.

A combination of temperatures falling to 5 below to 10 below zero and winds of 20 to 30 mph caused wind chill readings to drop to 35 below zero across much of northern Illinois during the morning hours of December 21st.

Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches in an area just west of the James River in southeast South Dakota during the predawn hours of January 23rd. The snowfall caused slippery travel and minor delays.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches, causing slippery travel conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 2 to 4 inches over the northern part of the county, causing slippery travel conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulating 1 to 4 inches along and southeast of a Sioux City to Spencer line was accompanied by strong winds and considerable blowing snow. Numerous schools closed early or had classes cancelled for the day. The snow and blowing snow lasted from a little before daybreak into the middle part of the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulating 1 to 3 inches was accompanied by strong winds producing blowing snow. Resulting slippery travel conditions and low visibilities caused cancellation or early dismissal of classes at several schools.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A convective complex over Georgia initiated by a passing upper level short wave early in the day produced a large scale outflow boundary that advanced over our zones during the afternoon and early evening hours over a moist and unstable airmass. Outflows combined with a strong sea breeze collision near the east coast ignited scattered severe storms across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local television station meteorologist reported golf ball size hail and estimated wind gusts up to 60 mph near the St. Johns Town Center shopping complex.

Outflows combined with a strong sea breeze collision near the east coast ignited scattered severe storms across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported hail slightly smaller than golf ball size about 2 miles south of Marbon Road and San Jose Blvd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A convective complex over Georgia initiated by a passing upper level short wave early in the day produced a large scale outflow boundary that advanced over our zones during the afternoon and early evening hours over a moist and unstable airmass. Outflows combined with a strong sea breeze collision near the east coast ignited scattered severe storms across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported penny and golf ball size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure south of the area steered a prevailing moist southwest over the local area. A weak surface trough was over southeast Georgia. Storms developed along the sea breezes and interacted with the front to produce scattered severe storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered trees were blown down along U.S. Highway 301 between Bryceville and Baldwin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Steering flow from the southwest around 10-15 knots steered the west coast sea breeze inland early in the day over a moist and unstable airmass. Temperatures at 500 mb were -8 to -10 degrees Celcius which aided in strong instability and hail growth. Locally heavy rainfall was also expected due to training cells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down across the Jacksonville west side. One tree fell on a trailer home at the 9300 block of 103rd Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the northern Gulf of Mexico brought widespread precipitation to the region the evening of Friday, January 18th and the morning of Saturday, January 19th. The rain changed to snow over much of the area during the early morning hours of January 19th as the cold center of the strong disturbance moved across the region. Significant precipitation was still occurring along and south of the Interstate 20 corridor when the precipitation changed to snow, and accumulating snow then occurred in most locations east of the Mississippi River.||The heaviest snow appears to have fallen in the areas around Covington, Jefferson Davis, and western Jones Counties, where isolated amounts of 4 to 5 inches occurred. At the height of the snow, temperatures were able to fall to near freezing, and accumulations occurred on roadways resulting in a number of traffic accidents. Additionally, some power outages occurred in the heaviest snow band due to the weight of the wet snow on limbs and lines. However, most folks in the area enjoyed the rare snowfall and took full advantage of the opportunity to make snowmen and snow angels, or to go sledding on the nearest hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread two inches of snow fell across Franklin County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense winter storm brought high winds and heavy mountain snow to parts of Southwest Idaho and Southeast Oregon from January fourth through fifth. Wind gusts to ninety six miles per hour and six to eight inches of snow were reported in the mountains. Gusts to sixty four miles per hour including wind damage to trees and power lines were reported in the Treasure and Magic Valleys of Southwest Idaho.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Idaho Power reported power lines down near Caldwell, Greenleaf and Notus leaving thousands of customers without electricity. Local fire departments reported trees and power lines down in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked through the central Great Lakes on the 8th, and continued to slowly track into Ontario on the 9th. Southerly winds ahead of this low pressure allowed for many locations in northern Ohio to report record high temperatures in the 60s during the day on the 8th. The low pressure intensified rapidly as it moved over the Great Lakes during this time. A strong cold front extended from this low pressure, and tracked across the area during the mornning hours of the 9th. A line of showers and thunderstorms developed just ahead of the cold front causing some thunderstorm wind gust damage. Behind the cold front, the strong low pressure allowed for windy conditions to continue through the morning hours of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down during the thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked through the central Great Lakes on the 8th, and continued to slowly track into Ontario on the 9th. The low pressure intensified rapidly as it moved over the Great Lakes during this time. A line of showers and thunderstorms developed just ahead of the cold front causing some thunderstorm wind gust damage. Behind the cold front, the strong low pressure allowed for windy conditions to continue through the morning hours of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms tracked through the area during the early morning hours of the 9th. A public call was received describing significant damage in Berlin Heights about trampolines wrapped around trees, homes losing shingles, and pine trees snapped. A survey was conducted that morning, and it was found that severe winds blew apart a roof of a porch that was attached to the house. This portion of the roof consequently tore apart much of the roof structure on the front side of the home, and as the roof blew over the top of the house a chimney and attenna were also destroyed. During the survey, there was confirmation on other pine trees that were down, along with the trampolines destroyed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather observing equipment at the Lorain County Airport measured a wind gust of 65 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong cold front, accompanied by developing low pressure, resulted in snow across much northern Indiana. While the highest amounts were only around 4 inches in the far northwestern part of the area, strong winds caused widespread blowing and drifting with white-out conditions at times. In addition, wind chills dropped into the 15 to 25 below zero range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm brought 6 to 8 inches of snow across the county. Strong winds also created widespread blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed across the Piedmont during mid-evening, and continued through much of the overnight hours. By mid-morning on the 17th, total accumulations ranged from around an inch south of I-85, to 3 inches or so along the I-40 corridor. Sleet and freezing rain mixed in with the snow before the event ended.

A low pressure system moved northeast from the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday evening, January 16th through Thursday, January 17th on a track southeast of the Morristown forecast area producing heavy mountain snowfall with some minor snow accumulation in the lower elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Gulf of Mexico Wednesday evening, January 16th through Thursday, January 17th on a track southeast of the Morristown forecast area producing heavy mountain snowfall which totaled between 4 and 6 inches across this portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm low southeast of New Zealand caused surf of 6 to 9 feet along the south facing shores of all the Hawaiian Islands.  No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In early January, a powerful Pacific storm brought strong winds, heavy rainfall, flash flooding and winter storm conditions to Central and Southern California. Rainfall totals between January 4th and 6th ranged from 2 to 5 inches over coastal areas to 5 to 11 inches in the foothills and mountains. The heaviest rainfall fell over favored south-facing mountain slopes. The total amount of rainfall, combined with rainfall rates around 1 inch per hour, produced numerous reports of flooding as well as mud and debris flows. The mountains received significant snowfall, espeically at the resort levels where 12 to 24 inches of snow fell. Along with the intense precipitation, the storm brought some very strong and gusty southerly winds to the area. The strongest winds were reported across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties as well as all mountain areas. The winds knocked down trees and power lines, producing numerous power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty southeasterly winds affected the mountains of Los Angeles county. Various automated sensors reported wind gusts in excess of 60 mph. The strongest gusts reported were 74 mph at Grass Mountain and 64 mph at Camp Nine.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty southeasterly winds affected the mountains of Ventura county. Various automated sensors reported wind gusts in excess of 55 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of rain fell in a short amount of time on frozen ground causing flash flooding. Numerous roads in Waterloo were flooded with between 4 and 5 inches of water on several of those roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front crosses western New York and was followed by very strong west to southwest winds. Sustained winds increased to 30 to 45 mph with gusts measured to 80 mph at the peak of the storm.  Trees and power lines were downed by the strong winds. Utility companies reported close to 100,000 customers without power in locations scattered throughout region. Several homes and automobiles were damaged by falling trees and limbs. On Grand Island, the roof a manufacturing company sustained significant damage. The Buffalo Airport was closed between 8:30 a.m. and noon with over half of its scheduled flights canceled for the day. In downtown Buffalo, a building from the 1850s that had been damaged in an earlier January windstorm, sustained further damage and was deemed unsafe and to be demolished. The New York State Thruway was closed from Henrietta to Depew because of blowing snow and whiteout conditions. Two tractor trailers were blown over on the Thruway. In Irondequoit, the steeple of a church was blown down.

A strong cold front moved through the Midsouth during the afternoon and evening hours of December 27th, 2008. Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of the front. Some of the thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong gradient winds knocked down power lines across DeSoto County which caused widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the Midsouth during the afternoon and evening hours of December 27th, 2008. Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of the front. Some of the thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds knocked down trees and power lines west of Biggersville, near the intersection of County Road 534 and County Road 513.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of snow produced 6 to 10 inches across sections of northeast Nebraska, mainly west through north of Neligh.  The snow began Sunday morning January 20th and lasted into Monday evening the 21st.  Higher storm totals included between 10 and 11 inches at Orchard and around 8.5 inches in Bloomfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of between 10 and 11 inches was reported over the western sections of Antelope county over a 30 to 36 hour period ending late Monday evening January 21st.  Orchard reported 9.5 inches of snow by 800 am on the 21st, with another 1 to 1.5 inches estimated to have fallen later that day.  Neligh, farther to the southeast, reported just under 6 inches for the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level low enhanced sea breeze and outflow initiated convection over an unstable and moist airmass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail was reported about 1 mile south of Bell. The hail lasted about 10 minutes. Strong wind gusts were also observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level low enhanced sea breeze and outflow initiated convection over an unstable and moist airmass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported at Archer Road and NW 34th Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level low enhanced sea breeze and outflow initiated convection over an unstable and moist airmass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported near Satsuma.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level low enhanced sea breeze and outflow initiated convection over an unstable and moist airmass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported three inches of rain near the intersection of Southwest 75th Street and Southwest 24th Avenue over a period of one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were blown down on State Road 100, west of Bunnell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 77 mph and pea size hail were observed at the Flagler County Emergency Operations Center. One tree was blown down on the property.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter estimated wind gusts to 60 mph in the Grand Haven area of Palm Coast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the Great Lakes across southeast Canada on the 11th. An associated warm front lifted northeast across New England and delivered warmer, moist air above the surface (several thousand feet) that  traveled over sub-freezing temperatures at the surface. This produced light precipitation in the form of freezing rain along and east of the spine of the Green Mountains of Vermont during the morning of January 11th.||Although ice accumulations were minimal, freezing rain created hazardous driving conditions that resulted in numerous vehicle accidents from eastern Rutland and Windsor counties in southern Vermont to the Canadian border, including a fatal accident in Derby (Orleans county).

An arctic cold front moved across the eastern Great Lakes and northern New York during the late morning and early afternoon of January 19th. Meanwhile, ahead and along the arctic front, brisk and cold southwest winds traveled across a relatively mild Lake Ontario that produced a organized and stationary band of moderate lake effect snow which moved across northern St. Lawrence county. Light to moderate snow developed during the morning hours of the 19th and then shifted east of the area by the afternoon. Localized snowfall of 2 to 5 inches was reported in northern St. Lawrence county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured a wind gust of 64 mph as thunderstorms moved through the area. Numerous trees and power lines were also reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong disturbance aloft brought heavy snow, gusty winds and very cold temperatures to a large portion of North Central Montana. Snow amounts in excess of 6 inches, wind gusts in excess of 60 mph and wind chill readings colder than 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind chill reading of 43 degrees (F) below zero was reported at the Great Falls ASOS site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty west to northwest winds behind a cold front blew out isolated windows in high rise buildings in New York City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows were broken on the 22nd floor of the New York Times building and 52nd floor of the Bank of New York Building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain developed across the mountains during mid-evening and continued into the early morning hours. Roads became slick and hazardous, with a few traffic accidents reported. Ice accretion of up to 1/8 inch or so was reported, resulting in a few downed trees and power lines. During the early morning hours of February 1st, more significant icing developed, but that part of the event will be included in next month's Storm Data.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind chill reading of 42 degrees (F) below zero was reported at White Sulphur Springs 1SE.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine inches of snow was reported at the Yellowstone National Park Gate. Additionally, 7 inches of snow was reported at West Yellowstone and a wind gust to 64 mph was reported at Big Sky 7S.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorm in advance of a cold front produced large hail across portions of the Lower Maryland Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported at Crisfield marina.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low passing far north of the islands produced surf of 20 to 35 feet along the north facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; 10 to 20 feet along the west facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and the Big Island of Hawaii; and 6 to 12 feet along the east facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, and the Big Island.  The hazardous surf kept lifeguards busy on these isles with assisting and rescuing swimmers and surfers.  Water coming over the pavement closed a portion of Bayfront Highway in Hilo on the Big Island for a time on the 16th.  Water was crossing other shoreline roadways on these islands during this episode as well, though no significant disruption to traffic flow was noted.  No serious property damage or injuries were reported.

Dense fog blanketed much of southeast Missouri as milder south winds blew over cold, frozen ground. Visibility was reduced to one-quarter mile or less.
Strong south winds ahead of a developing low pressure system gusted to between 45 and 50 mph. The strong winds were from Carbondale to the Wabash Valley, including the Interstate 64 corridor.

A fast moving low pressure system moved through Southern New England bringing 4-10 inches of snow to the region. In addition, strong cold advection and pressure rises resulted in very cold temperatures, strong winds, and bitterly cold wind chills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of four to ten inches of snow were received.

CZ_NAME: LAGUNA MADRE FROM PORT OF BROWNSVILLE TO ARROYO COLORADO
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture lifted by west moving boundaries from weakening storms in the nearshore waters east of South Padre Island likely contributed to the development of a small storm just northeast of Laguna Heights.  A brief waterspout formed, according to witnesses, and quickly moved onshore as a weak tornado before dissipating.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A developing, brief strong thunderstorm produced a waterspout just northeast of Laguna Heights, which moved south southwest and reached land before quickly dissipating.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slowly developing coastal low pressure system brought snow to interior Massachusetts.
Unusual winter thunderstorms produced cloud to ground lightning strikes that knocked out power and damaged at least one home.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a house in Johnston blowing off vinyl siding and blowing out a basement window.  Several people were in the house at the time of the strike but none were injured.  No fire was started.  Several other locations were without power due to other lightning strikes in the area, including the Lincoln Mall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the northern Gulf of Mexico brought widespread precipitation to the region the evening of Friday, January 18th and the morning of Saturday, January 19th. The rain changed to snow over much of the area during the early morning hours of January 19th as the cold center of the strong disturbance moved across the region. Significant precipitation was still occurring along and south of the Interstate 20 corridor when the precipitation changed to snow, and accumulating snow then occurred in most locations east of the Mississippi River.||The heaviest snow appears to have fallen in the areas around Covington, Jefferson Davis, and western Jones Counties, where isolated amounts of 4 to 5 inches occurred. At the height of the snow, temperatures were able to fall to near freezing, and accumulations occurred on roadways resulting in a number of traffic accidents. Additionally, some power outages occurred in the heaviest snow band due to the weight of the wet snow on limbs and lines. However, most folks in the area enjoyed the rare snowfall and took full advantage of the opportunity to make snowmen and snow angels, or to go sledding on the nearest hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to two inches of snow fell across the southeast portion of Jefferson County. The heaviest snow fell around Union Church and was around two inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the northern Gulf of Mexico brought widespread precipitation to the region the evening of Friday, January 18th and the morning of Saturday, January 19th. The rain changed to snow over much of the area during the early morning hours of January 19th as the cold center of the strong disturbance moved across the region. Significant precipitation was still occurring along and south of the Interstate 20 corridor when the precipitation changed to snow, and accumulating snow then occurred in most locations east of the Mississippi River.||The heaviest snow appears to have fallen in the areas around Covington, Jefferson Davis, and western Jones Counties, where isolated amounts of 4 to 5 inches occurred. At the height of the snow, temperatures were able to fall to near freezing, and accumulations occurred on roadways resulting in a number of traffic accidents. Additionally, some power outages occurred in the heaviest snow band due to the weight of the wet snow on limbs and lines. However, most folks in the area enjoyed the rare snowfall and took full advantage of the opportunity to make snowmen and snow angels, or to go sledding on the nearest hill.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to two inches of snow fell across Adams County. The heaviest snow fell just to the east of Natchez heading into Franklin County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an area of low pressure progressed from the coast of the Gulf of Mexico to along the coast of North Carolina, associated wintry precipitation spread across the area from south to north. The precipitation began as snow and then transitioned to a brief period of sleet before ending as light freezing rain and freezing drizzle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts for the event include 6.0 inches in Glenvar, 5.0 inches in the City of Roanoke, 4.5 inches in Hollins and Vinton, and 4.3 inches in Cave Spring.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Steering flow from the southwest around 10-15 knots steered the west coast sea breeze inland early in the day over a moist and unstable airmass. Temperatures at 500 mb were -8 to -10 degrees Celcius which aided in strong instability and hail growth. Locally heavy rainfall was also expected due to training cells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Paines Prairie State Park reported trees down. The time of damage was based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny to dime size hail fell over central Palm Coast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 27 year old state park ranger died when a tree fell through the roof of his vehicle at Pudgy Road during a thunderstorm in Paines Prairie State Park.  He had stopped his car due to a downed tree crossing the road. A Significant Weather Alert was issued at 130 EDT which highlight wind gusts of 45-55 mph with possible minor damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability within a deep tropical moisture environment supported thunderstorm development along the sea breezes and outflows. A weak upper level short wave trough moved over the area from the Gulf of Mexico during the afternoon and evening which enhanced convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were blown down Live Oak.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked through the central Great Lakes on the 8th, and continued to slowly track into Ontario on the 9th. Southerly winds ahead of this low pressure allowed for many locations in northern Ohio to report record high temperatures in the 60s during the day on the 8th. The low pressure intensified rapidly as it moved over the Great Lakes during this time. A strong cold front extended from this low pressure, and tracked across the area during the mornning hours of the 9th. A line of showers and thunderstorms developed just ahead of the cold front causing some thunderstorm wind gust damage. Behind the cold front, the strong low pressure allowed for windy conditions to continue through the morning hours of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather observing equipment at the Burke Lakefront Airport measured a wind gust of 58 mph associated with a thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense winter storm brought high winds and heavy mountain snow to parts of Southwest Idaho and Southeast Oregon from January fourth through fifth. Wind gusts to ninety six miles per hour and six to eight inches of snow were reported in the mountains. Gusts to sixty four miles per hour including wind damage to trees and power lines were reported in the Treasure and Magic Valleys of Southwest Idaho.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twin Falls ASOS recorded sustained winds of forty five gusting to sixty four MPH.

Wind gusts to ninety six miles per hour and six to eight inches of snow were reported in the mountains. Gusts to sixty four miles per hour including wind damage to trees and power lines were reported in the Treasure and Magic Valleys of Southwest Idaho.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trail Gulch RAWS station at an elevation of 5700 feet recorded wind gusts to sixty eight MPH.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A retired NWS employee reported six inches of new snow in McCall and trained spotters and ski resorts around the area reported seven to eight inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flooding from December continued into the early portions of January along the Wabash River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along the Wabash River in Fountain County, including near Covington, due to heavy rain.  Flooding began on December 29th and continued into January.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure track north along a cold front from the lower Mississippi River Valley during the day on the 29th and through the central Great Lakes region on the 30th. This area of low pressure intensified as it tracked north through the central Great Lakes from the afternoon on the 29th through the 30th as this low pressure moved into Canada. The cold front associated with this low pressure moved through the region during the early overnight hours into the 30th. Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of the cold front during the late evening on the 29th, but windy conditions continued through the overnight hours as the low pressure intensifed. Winds finally subsided during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large trees and limbs were reported down countywide. Also, widespread power outages were reported.

Winds finally subsided during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down countywide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed across the Piedmont during mid-evening, and continued through much of the overnight hours. By mid-morning on the 17th, total accumulations ranged from around an inch south of I-85, to 3 inches or so along the I-40 corridor. Sleet and freezing rain mixed in with the snow before the event ended.

Light snow developed across the Upstate and Northwest Piedmont during mid-evening, and continued through much of the overnight hours. By mid-morning on the 17th, total accumulations ranged from 1 to 2 inches. Sleet and freezing rain mixed in with the snow before the event ended.

January saw a return to dry weather across western North Carolina.|Most observing stations across the region reported a rainfall deficit of 1 to 2 inches during the month, resulting in another month of exceptional drought conditions across most of the area. Water levels on area lakes remained within a foot or two of record low stages. However, rivers and streams remained somewhat recharged from the December rains, with streamflow on most waterways running 25 to 75 percent of normal.

A low northwest of the Aloha State generated surf of 12 to 18 feet along the north facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; and 6 to 12 feet along the west facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, and Molokai.  No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

CZ_NAME: EASTERN SIERRA SLOPES OF INYO COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of Pacific storms brought high winds and heavy snow to portions of southeast California and southern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 4 miles SW of Independence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of Pacific storms brought high winds and heavy snow to portions of southeast California and southern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred at Daggett (KDAG).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of rain fell in a short amount of time on frozen ground causing flash flooding.  Illinois Route 16 near Shipman was closed due to 2 to 3 feet of water over the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of rain fell in a short amount of time on frozen ground causing flash flooding.  About 3 miles east of Jerseyville, Illinois Route 16 was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of rain fell in a short amount of time on frozen ground causing flash flooding.  Several streets were flooded around Carondelet Park on the city's south side.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain began falling the evening of the 17th and continued into the early morning hours of the 18th. Ice accumulations were generally around one quarter of an inch with a few location approaching one half inch. There were scattered power outages reported across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulations across Adams County ranged from 1/4 inch in the Quincy area to nearly 4/10 of an inch in the Northeast corner. Tree limbs were down and there were scattered power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm off the California coast on the 4th and 5th finally moved inland on the 6th and reached the four corners area early on the 7th. This allowed for plenty of moisture to surge into New Mexico ahead of the storm. A long duration snow event occurred over the southern San Juan and Sangre De Cristo mountains with around two feet of snow. Six to 12 inches of snow was common over the western and central mountains, while 3 to 6 inches fell in the western valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Generally 3 to 6 inches of snow fell with some blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad surface trough was nearly stationary over the forecast area as a short wave upper level trough traversed the region during the afternoon when instability was high. Widespread severe storms developed along the sea breezes and outflows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported penny size hail along San Marco Road near the Fuller Warren Bridge and other areas of San Marco.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of snow produced 6 to 10 inches across sections of northeast Nebraska, mainly west through north of Neligh.  The snow began Sunday morning January 20th and lasted into Monday evening the 21st.  Higher storm totals included between 10 and 11 inches at Orchard and around 8.5 inches in Bloomfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of between 8 and 9 inches was estimated to have fallen over much of the county over a 30 to 36 hour period ending late Monday evening January 21st.  The estimations were based on Bloomfield and Crofton to the west and Sioux City to the east each reporting storm totals of around 8.5 to 9 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second week of January 2008 was quite active with respect to severe weather. Two events impacted the region in a span of 3 days which produced several tornadoes, large hail and wind damage across the area. ||On January 10th a vigorous storm system developed over the southern portions of the Midwest and moved northeast towards the Ohio valley. A strong cold front swept across the area during the late morning into the afternoon hours and strong to severe thunderstorms developed out ahead of it. All of the ingredients for tornadic development came into place as warm Gulf moisture pushed northward into the area out ahead of the front. The thunderstorms developed in eastern Louisiana and quickly moved across central Mississippi during the late morning and afternoon hours. As the storms progressed eastward, good instability combined with very strong wind shear for supercell development east of the Mississippi River, with the storms reaching maximum intensity along and east of the interstate 55 corridor.||By far, the most damage was produced by a single supercell thunderstorm that moved from north of Vicksburg through north central and northeast Mississippi during the late morning and early afternoon hours. This single storm produced three strong tornadoes, all of which were rated as EF3 on the Enhanced Fujita tornado damage scale. The most significant damage occurred in Caledonia in Lowndes County, where a school gymnasium was destroyed along with a number of school buses and vehicles in the area.||A second supercell that organized near the Mississippi River in southwest Mississippi before midday tracked from Claiborne County, through the northern Jackson Metropolitan Area, and finally into Noxubee county in northeast Mississippi by mid afternoon. This storm was responsible for 5 different tornado touchdowns along its path, as well as many reports of high winds and hail.||The rest of the area saw a broken line of storms and other supercells ahead of the line. A mix of damaging winds and hail were reported through the rest of the afternoon before the system exited the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large limbs were blown down along with a few power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This funnel cloud was observed by a Grand Gulf nuclear power plant employee.
