EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three inches of snow fell across the far northern portion of Forrest County. The heaviest snow, around three inches, fell around Rawls Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail fell at Favor Dykes State Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Flying J store employees estimated wind gusts of 50-60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down across Highway 252, about 1 mile south of Tarboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked through the central Great Lakes on the 8th, and continued to slowly track into Ontario on the 9th. Southerly winds ahead of this low pressure allowed for many locations in northern Ohio to report record high temperatures in the 60s during the day on the 8th. The low pressure intensified rapidly as it moved over the Great Lakes during this time. A strong cold front extended from this low pressure, and tracked across the area during the mornning hours of the 9th. A line of showers and thunderstorms developed just ahead of the cold front causing some thunderstorm wind gust damage. Behind the cold front, the strong low pressure allowed for windy conditions to continue through the morning hours of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree and several power poles were reported down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable moist atmosphere and slow moving cold front set the stage for the training of rain and thunderstorms across much of northern Indiana. In addition, a dense snowpack rapidly melted as a result of the warm temperatures and rainfall, resulting in rapid rises on river and streams as well as widespread problems with flooding of low areas and ditches. Rainfall amounts ranging from a couple inches to locally over 7 inches was reported, with the highest amounts in and around White county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded across mainly the northwestern part of the county, generally north of US 24 and west of State Route 25. A state of emergency was declared by county officials in these areas for about a 12 hour period, restricting travel to all but essential needs. Water was reported in many basements and covering driveways. Emergency officials did have to assist with several evacuations across the area. No exact damage figures are available, but is estimated at around $150,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable moist atmosphere and slow moving cold front set the stage for the training of rain and thunderstorms across much of northern Indiana. In addition, a dense snowpack rapidly melted as a result of the warm temperatures and rainfall, resulting in rapid rises on river and streams as well as widespread problems with flooding of low areas and ditches. Rainfall amounts ranging from a couple inches to locally over 7 inches was reported, with the highest amounts in and around White county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least 6 roads were temporarily closed, with many others posted with  high water signs, as ditches overflowed and low areas filled. A senior care center was threatened by flood waters coming out of a overflown retention pond. Sandbags were placed to help, but luckily no evacuations were needed. No exact damage figure were available, but are estimated at around $150,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonable moist atmosphere and slow moving cold front set the stage for the training of rain and thunderstorms across much of northern Indiana. In addition, a dense snowpack rapidly melted as a result of the warm temperatures and rainfall, resulting in rapid rises on river and streams as well as widespread problems with flooding of low areas and ditches. Rainfall amounts ranging from a couple inches to locally over 7 inches was reported, with the highest amounts in and around White county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County officials reported high water on some roadways both in the county and also in a few cities, including North Manchester and Roann. 2.7 inches of rain was observed near North Manchester. The Eastside Mobile Home Park next to the Eel river in North Manchester was evacuated as flood waters moved into the park and under trailers. Luckily, no water got into the trailers and residents were able to return home by Jan 11th. A rescue from a residence was needed in Roann to get 2 adults and a 5 month old child. No exact damage figures are available, but are estimated at $75,000, mainly for road repairs and some basement flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong disturbance aloft brought heavy snow, gusty winds and very cold temperatures to a large portion of North Central Montana. Snow amounts in excess of 6 inches, wind gusts in excess of 60 mph and wind chill readings colder than 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind chill reading of 40 degrees (F) below zero was reported at Cameron 5NNE. In addition to the cold, winds gusting in excess of 40 mph caused areas of blowing snow and reduced visibilities to less than 1 mile.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong disturbance aloft brought heavy snow, gusty winds and very cold temperatures to a large portion of North Central Montana. Snow amounts in excess of 6 inches, wind gusts in excess of 60 mph and wind chill readings colder than 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind chill reading of 53 degrees (F) below zero was reported at the Sweetgrass DOT site.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind chill reading of 43 degrees (F) below zero was reported at Lothair 3SE.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong disturbance aloft brought heavy snow, gusty winds and very cold temperatures to a large portion of North Central Montana. Snow amounts in excess of 6 inches, wind gusts in excess of 60 mph and wind chill readings colder than 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven inches of snow was reported at Heart Butte 14SW (the Badger Pass SNOTEL site - elevation 6900 feet). Additionally, a wind chill reading of 42 degrees (F) below zero was reported at Brady 2W.

CZ_NAME: S & SE GRAND / W CENTRAL & SW BOULDER / GILPIN / CLEAR CREEK / SUMMIT / N & W PARK COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow and very strong winds caused extensive blowing and drifting snow in the North-Central Mountains of Colorado.  Storm totals over the 2-day period included:  10 inches at Copper Mountain Ski Area, 8 inches at Breckenridge Ski Area, with 4 inches at Arapahoe Basin and Bear Lake State Park.  Peak wind gusts during the event included:  85 mph atop Loveland Pass, 70 mph at Berthoud Pass, and 55 mph at Copper Mountain.

Freezing rain developed across the mountains during mid-evening and continued past midnight. Roads became slick and hazardous, with a few traffic accidents reported. During the early morning hours of February 1st, more significant icing developed, but that part of the event will be included in next month's Storm Data.

Freezing rain developed across the mountains during mid-evening and continued past midnight. Roads became slick and hazardous, with a few traffic accidents reported. During the early morning hours of February 1st, more significant icing developed, but that part of the event will be included in next month's Storm Data.

A strong and progressive upper level winter storm moved into the Texas panhandle during the overnight hours Wednesday night, January 30th.  An area of snow developed in the Oklahoma panhandle very early Thursday, January 31st, 2008 and moved north into south central Kansas Thursday morning.  When the snow fell, it was heavy at times accompanied by north, gusty winds of 20 to 30 mph, which caused considerable blowing and drifting.  By 11am CST on the 31st, 4 to 5 inches of snow had fallen just east of Medicine Lodge in Barber County, with 2 to 3 inches just west and north of there in Comanche and Pratt counties.  Pratt, Comanche and Barber counties all reported poor driving conditions due to blowing and drifting of snow, with Barber County also reporting schools had closed due to poor road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong and progressive upper level winter storm moved into the Texas panhandle during the overnight hours Wednesday night, January 30th.  An area of snow developed in the Oklahoma panhandle very early Thursday, January 31st, 2008 and moved north into south central Kansas Thursday morning.  When the snow fell, it was heavy at times accompanied by north, gusty winds of 20 to 30 mph, which caused considerable blowing and drifting.  By 11am CST on the 31st, 4 to 5 inches of snow had fallen just east of Medicine Lodge in Barber County, with 2 to 3 inches just west and north of there in Comanche and Pratt counties.  Pratt, Comanche and Barber counties all reported poor driving conditions due to blowing and drifting of snow, with Barber County also reporting schools had closed due to poor road conditions.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree limb fell through a home one mile east of Starke on State Road 100 due to thunderstorm winds. Another tree limb fell through the roof at the Pine Forest Apartments in Starke. At the time of the damage report, over 1,000 people were without power in the Starke area due to damaged power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of five to eight inches of snow were received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a brief thaw, a strong cold front blasted Arctic air back into Northern Michigan.  Wind gusts behind the front reached 65 mph in Ossineke, and 63 mph in Charlevoix.  The cold air rushing in over the Great Lakes resulted in 1 to 3 inches of snow in much of Eastern Upper and Northwest Lower Michigan.  The snow and wind resulted in near-blizzard conditions for a few hours on the morning of the 28th.  Visibilities of a half-mile or less were common.

A potent supercell developed during the afternoon and moved eastward along a cold front.  This storm was responsible for hail as large as baseballs as it moved across Jack, Stephens, Palo Pinto, Parker, and Tarrant Counties.  A squall line developed along the southward moving cold front later that evening, producing a few reports of thunderstorm winds and large hail.
There was a severe weather outbreak on Thursday, January 8, 2008 that caused some wind damage in Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down on U.S. Highway 412 West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There was a severe weather outbreak on Thursday, January 8, 2008 that caused some wind damage in Middle Tennessee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down, and one road was blocked.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There was a severe weather outbreak on Thursday, January 8, 2008 that caused some wind damage in Middle Tennessee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The drought continued to affect areas in the eastern part of Middle Tennessee in January 2008 despite recent rains in December 2007 and January 2008. Conditions in the western part of Middle Tennessee have shown a lessening of the drought.

Low pressure tracked through the central Great Lakes on the 8th, and continued to slowly track into Ontario on the 9th. Southerly winds ahead of this low pressure allowed for many locations in northern Ohio to report record high temperatures in the 60s during the day on the 8th. The low pressure intensified rapidly as it moved over the Great Lakes during this time. A strong cold front extended from this low pressure, and tracked across the area during the mornning hours of the 9th. A line of showers and thunderstorms developed just ahead of the cold front causing some thunderstorm wind gust damage. Behind the cold front, the strong low pressure allowed for windy conditions to continue through the morning hours of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 65 mph was measured by a trained spotter. Also, trees and large limbs were reported down from the thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds increased significantly behind the passage of a cold front. Wind gusts were mainly in the 50 to 55 mph range with occasional gusts around 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High wind gusts caused trees to be blown down across the county.  Damage amounts are estimates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds increased significantly behind the passage of a cold front. Wind gusts were mainly in the 50 to 55 mph range with occasional gusts around 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Laurel Springs, trees were blown down near route 18.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense winter storm brought high winds and heavy mountain snow to parts of Southwest Idaho and Southeast Oregon from January fourth through fifth. Wind gusts to ninety six miles per hour and six to eight inches of snow were reported in the mountains. Gusts to sixty four miles per hour including wind damage to trees and power lines were reported in the Treasure and Magic Valleys of Southwest Idaho.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rome, Oregon ASOS recorded a wind gust of sixty nine MPH and several RAWS stations reported winds over sixty MPH including a sustained wind of sixty three and a gust to ninety six MPH at Riddle Mountain RAWS.

Gusts to sixty four miles per hour including wind damage to trees and power lines were reported in the Treasure and Magic Valleys of Southwest Idaho.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flagstaff Hill RAWS station at an elevation of 3945 feet and Morgan Mountain RAWS station at 4200 feet recorded wind gusts to sixty MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense winter storm brought high winds and heavy mountain snow to parts of Southwest Idaho and Southeast Oregon from January fourth through fifth. Wind gusts to ninety six miles per hour and six to eight inches of snow were reported in the mountains. Gusts to sixty four miles per hour including wind damage to trees and power lines were reported in the Treasure and Magic Valleys of Southwest Idaho.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter near Garden Valley reported six and one half inches of new snow while Bogus Basin Ski Resort reported sustained winds of fifty six gusting to seventy five MPH. Many sites found it difficult to measure the true snowfall during the event due to blowing and drifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front raced across Illinois during the afternoon hours of January 29th.  Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of the front, producing damaging wind gusts and large hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure track north along a cold front from the lower Mississippi River Valley during the day on the 29th and through the central Great Lakes region on the 30th. This area of low pressure intensified as it tracked north through the central Great Lakes from the afternoon on the 29th through the 30th as this low pressure moved into Canada. The cold front associated with this low pressure moved through the region during the early overnight hours into the 30th. Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of the cold front during the late evening on the 29th, but windy conditions continued through the overnight hours as the low pressure intensifed. Winds finally subsided during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous power lines were reported down across the county, especially in the City of Painesville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong cold front, accompanied by developing low pressure, resulted in snow across much of far southern Lower Michigan. While the highest amounts were only around 4 inches, strong winds caused widespread blowing and drifting with white-out conditions at times. In addition, wind chills dropped into the 15 to 25 below zero range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported just over 4 inches of snow in Berrien Springs, along with whiteout conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another arctic boundary moved across the Great Lakes, with unseaonably warm air ahead of it. This set the stage for a narrow line of thunderstorms that produced isolated wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 38 foot 5th wheel trailer was rolled by the strong winds. Branches were also reported down in parts of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another arctic boundary moved across the Great Lakes, with unseaonably warm air ahead of it. This set the stage for a narrow line of thunderstorms that produced isolated wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven power poles were reported blown down southeast of Van Wert by emergency management officials.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A blast of arctic air flowed over the relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan to allow for the development of lake effect snow showers. One band in particular dropped heavy snow across portions of Berrien county. Brisk winds also caused area of blowing and drifting as well as wind chills around 20 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in the Stevensville area reported a storm total accumulation of 8.6 inches, with nearly 6 inches of this falling within a 6 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another strong cold front, accompanied by developing low pressure, resulted in snow across much northern Indiana. While the highest amounts were only around 4 inches in the far northwestern part of the area, strong winds caused widespread blowing and drifting with white-out conditions at times. In addition, wind chills dropped into the 15 to 25 below zero range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm brought 6 to 9 inches of snow to much of the county with isolated higer amounts in the northern part of the county where around 11 inches was measured at the Nationa Weather Service office just north of North Webster. Strong winds also created widespread blowing and drifting snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January saw a return to dry weather across western North Carolina.|Most observing stations across the region reported a rainfall deficit of 1 to 2 inches during the month, resulting in another month of exceptional drought conditions across most of the area. Water levels on area lakes remained within a foot or two of record low stages. However, rivers and streams remained somewhat recharged from the December rains, with streamflow on most waterways running 25 to 75 percent of normal.

January saw a return to dry weather across western North Carolina.|Most observing stations across the region reported a rainfall deficit of 1 to 2 inches during the month, resulting in another month of exceptional drought conditions across most of the area. Water levels on area lakes remained within a foot or two of record low stages. However, rivers and streams remained somewhat recharged from the December rains, with streamflow on most waterways running 25 to 75 percent of normal.

In early January, a powerful Pacific storm brought strong winds, heavy rainfall, flash flooding and winter storm conditions to Central and Southern California. Rainfall totals between January 4th and 6th ranged from 2 to 5 inches over coastal areas to 5 to 11 inches in the foothills and mountains. The heaviest rainfall fell over favored south-facing mountain slopes. The total amount of rainfall, combined with rainfall rates around 1 inch per hour, produced numerous reports of flooding as well as mud and debris flows. The mountains received significant snowfall, espeically at the resort levels where 12 to 24 inches of snow fell. Along with the intense precipitation, the storm brought some very strong and gusty southerly winds to the area. The strongest winds were reported across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties as well as all mountain areas. The winds knocked down trees and power lines, producing numerous power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind tower on Tranquilla Peak reported southeasterly winds gusting over 85 mph.

CZ_NAME: EASTERN SIERRA SLOPES OF INYO COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of Pacific storms brought high winds and heavy snow to portions of southeast California and southern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer recorded 12 inches of snow in Aspendell (8500').  High winds also occurred during the event, with a peak gust of 72 mph at 0432 PST on the 3rd.  The wind piled the snow into drifts six to seven feet high.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds caused damage in the Ash-Meadows National Wildlife Refuge 15 miles NW of Pahrump.  12 inch diameter fruit trees were blown over, 12 inch diameter limbs were snapped off elm trees, 8-9 inch diameter pine trees were bent over, and 100 square feet of roofing blew off a home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small ice storm occurred across the region on January 25 with freezing rain observed across the northern half of the service area. This occurred as a arctic high pressure settled over the Ohio Valley and shallow cold air filtered into region. While the cold air was moving in, an area of low pressure was taking shape across the northern Gulf of Mexico and helped to produce widespread light rain over the area. Across the northern portions of the forecast area, temperatures were below freezing when the light rain fell and good ice accumulations occurred for areas generally along and north of a line from Rayville Louisiana to Lexington Mississippi to West Point Mississippi. The icing was not very heavy, but problems occurred across the areas that did receive around a quarter inch of ice. Numerous accidents occurred from icing on bridges and overpasses with one fatality in Grenada County. Trees and power lines did accumulate some ice, but the ice was not heavy enough to cause much damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around one quarter inch of ice accumulated slowly through the day with icing being worst across area roads. Accidents were plentiful across the parish with some icing in trees and on power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the Great Lakes across southeast Canada on the 11th. An associated warm front lifted northeast across New England and delivered warmer, moist air above the surface (several thousand feet) that  traveled over sub-freezing temperatures at the surface. This produced light precipitation in the form of freezing rain along and east of the spine of the Green Mountains of Vermont during the morning of January 11th.||Although ice accumulations were minimal, freezing rain created hazardous driving conditions that resulted in numerous vehicle accidents from eastern Rutland and Windsor counties in southern Vermont to the Canadian border, including a fatal accident in Derby (Orleans county).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across northwestern Pennsylvania on January 23rd.  Cold west to northwest behind this front caused lake effect snow showers to develop.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers developed early on January 24th behind a strong cold front.  Heavy snow was reported during the morning hours with the snow showers tapering off to flurries during the afternoon.  Visibilities during the middle portion of the morning were less than one half mile at times.  As much as 12 inches of snow was reported along and north of Interstate 90.  Officially, 9.9 inches of snow was recorded at Erie International Airport between midnight and 1 pm.  Some accidents were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought heavy snow, areas of blowing snow and gusty winds to the Rocky Mountain Front. Snow accumulations in excess of 10 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eleven inches of snow was reported at the Copper Camp SNOTEL site (elevation 6950 feet).

Freezing rain developed across the mountains during mid-evening and continued past midnight. Roads became slick and hazardous, with a few traffic accidents reported. Ice accretion of up to 1/8 inch or so was reported, resulting in a few downed trees and power lines. During the early morning hours of February 1st, more significant icing developed, but that part of the event will be included in next month's Storm Data.

A trough of low pressure off the Western U.S. coast helped transport abundant moisture into Southeast Arizona. Heavy rainfall occurred in the mountains causing flooding in the Catalinas and stream flooding in Greenlee County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Blue River crested 4.5 feet above Bankfull stage due to heavy rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swift water rescue took place in the Tanque Verde wash near North Wentworth Road and East Speedway Blvd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low passing far north of the islands produced surf of 20 to 35 feet along the north facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; 10 to 20 feet along the west facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, and the Big Island of Hawaii; and 6 to 12 feet along the east facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, and the Big Island.  The hazardous surf kept lifeguards busy on these isles with assisting and rescuing swimmers and surfers.  Water coming over the pavement closed a portion of Bayfront Highway in Hilo on the Big Island for a time on the 16th.  Water was crossing other shoreline roadways on these islands during this episode as well, though no significant disruption to traffic flow was noted.  No serious property damage or injuries were reported.

A strong and progressive upper level winter storm moved into the Texas panhandle during the overnight hours Wednesday night, January 30th.  An area of snow developed in the Oklahoma panhandle very early Thursday, January 31st, 2008 and moved north into south central Kansas Thursday morning.  When the snow fell, it was heavy at times accompanied by north, gusty winds of 20 to 30 mph, which caused considerable blowing and drifting.  By 11am CST on the 31st, 4 to 5 inches of snow had fallen just east of Medicine Lodge in Barber County, with 2 to 3 inches just west and north of there in Comanche and Pratt counties.  Pratt, Comanche and Barber counties all reported poor driving conditions due to blowing and drifting of snow, with Barber County also reporting schools had closed due to poor road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong and progressive upper level winter storm moved into the Texas panhandle during the overnight hours Wednesday night, January 30th.  An area of snow developed in the Oklahoma panhandle very early Thursday, January 31st, 2008 and moved north into south central Kansas Thursday morning.  When the snow fell, it was heavy at times accompanied by north, gusty winds of 20 to 30 mph, which caused considerable blowing and drifting.  By 11am CST on the 31st, 4 to 5 inches of snow had fallen just east of Medicine Lodge in Barber County, with 2 to 3 inches just west and north of there in Comanche and Pratt counties.  Pratt, Comanche and Barber counties all reported poor driving conditions due to blowing and drifting of snow, with Barber County also reporting schools had closed due to poor road conditions.

Rainfall totals between January 4th and 6th ranged from 2 to 5 inches over coastal areas to 5 to 11 inches in the foothills and mountains. The heaviest rainfall fell over favored south-facing mountain slopes. The total amount of rainfall, combined with rainfall rates around 1 inch per hour, produced numerous reports of flooding as well as mud and debris flows. The mountains received significant snowfall, espeically at the resort levels where 12 to 24 inches of snow fell. Along with the intense precipitation, the storm brought some very strong and gusty southerly winds to the area. The strongest winds were reported across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties as well as all mountain areas. The winds knocked down trees and power lines, producing numerous power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mud and debris flow developed around the Barham Burn area. Forest Lawn Drive was closed due to over one foot of mud and debris.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were down along College Drive in Orange Park.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were down near Kingsley Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent supercell developed during the afternoon and moved eastward along a cold front.  This storm was responsible for hail as large as baseballs as it moved across Jack, Stephens, Palo Pinto, Parker, and Tarrant Counties.  A squall line developed along the southward moving cold front later that evening, producing a few reports of thunderstorm winds and large hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pacific moisture combined with arctic air to produce a winter storm along the Hi-Line. Snow and blowing snow reduced visibilities to less than one-quarter mile at times.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 30 mph, visibilities to less than one-quarter mile and 8 inches of snow was reported at Chinook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked through the central Great Lakes on the 8th, and continued to slowly track into Ontario on the 9th. Southerly winds ahead of this low pressure allowed for many locations in northern Ohio to report record high temperatures in the 60s during the day on the 8th. The low pressure intensified rapidly as it moved over the Great Lakes during this time. A strong cold front extended from this low pressure, and tracked across the area during the mornning hours of the 9th. A line of showers and thunderstorms developed just ahead of the cold front causing some thunderstorm wind gust damage. Behind the cold front, the strong low pressure allowed for windy conditions to continue through the morning hours of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down countywide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure track north along a cold front from the lower Mississippi River Valley during the day on the 29th and through the central Great Lakes region on the 30th. This area of low pressure intensified as it tracked north through the central Great Lakes from the afternoon on the 29th through the 30th as this low pressure moved into Canada. The cold front associated with this low pressure moved through the region during the early overnight hours into the 30th. Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of the cold front during the late evening on the 29th, but windy conditions continued through the overnight hours as the low pressure intensifed. Winds finally subsided during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down countywide. A particularly hard hit area of the county was north of Mount Gilead in the town of Iberia were numerous power lines were reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow began during the early evening hours and began to increase in intensity during the mid and late evening. Total accumulations of 2-4 inches were reached across much of the area shortly after midnight. Snow began changing to sleet and freezing rain across the foothills of South Carolina during the pre-dawn hours, producing a light glaze of ice on top of the snow before precipitation changed to rain and tapered off.

CZ_NAME: SAN LUIS OBISPO COUNTY INTERIOR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In early January, a powerful Pacific storm brought strong winds, heavy rainfall, flash flooding and winter storm conditions to Central and Southern California. Rainfall totals between January 4th and 6th ranged from 2 to 5 inches over coastal areas to 5 to 11 inches in the foothills and mountains. The heaviest rainfall fell over favored south-facing mountain slopes. The total amount of rainfall, combined with rainfall rates around 1 inch per hour, produced numerous reports of flooding as well as mud and debris flows. The mountains received significant snowfall, espeically at the resort levels where 12 to 24 inches of snow fell. Along with the intense precipitation, the storm brought some very strong and gusty southerly winds to the area. The strongest winds were reported across San Luis Obispo and Santa Barbara counties as well as all mountain areas. The winds knocked down trees and power lines, producing numerous power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An automated sensor in Atascadero reported sustained winds of 43 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In early January, a powerful Pacific storm brought strong winds, heavy rainfall, flash flooding and winter storm conditions to Central and Southern California. Rainfall totals between January 4th and 6th ranged from 2 to 5 inches over coastal areas to 5 to 11 inches in the foothills and mountains. The heaviest rainfall fell over favored south-facing mountain slopes. The total amount of rainfall, combined with rainfall rates around 1 inch per hour, produced numerous reports of flooding as well as mud and debris flows. EVENT_NARRATIVE: In New Cuyama, strong southeasterly winds knocked down several power poles and closed down Highway 166 for several hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region...triggering showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms became severe with large hail, damaging winds, tornadoes and flash flooding reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down on State Highway HH west of U.S. 61 damaging some trees in the area.  The tornado travelled to the east and damaged two small apartment complexes in addition to signs and trees along U.S. 61. It continued to the east, crossing New London Gravel Road causing additional tree damage before lifting and dissipating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful cold front crosses western New York and was followed by very strong west to southwest winds. Sustained winds increased to 30 to 45 mph with gusts measured to 80 mph at the peak of the storm.  Trees and power lines were downed by the strong winds. Utility companies reported close to 100,000 customers without power in locations scattered throughout region. Several homes and automobiles were damaged by falling trees and limbs. On Grand Island, the roof a manufacturing company sustained significant damage. The Buffalo Airport was closed between 8:30 a.m. and noon with over half of its scheduled flights canceled for the day. In downtown Buffalo, a building from the 1850s that had been damaged in an earlier January windstorm, sustained further damage and was deemed unsafe and to be demolished. The New York State Thruway was closed from Henrietta to Depew because of blowing snow and whiteout conditions. Two tractor trailers were blown over on the Thruway. In Irondequoit, the steeple of a church was blown down.

A strong cold front moved through the Midsouth during the afternoon and evening hours of December 27th, 2008. Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of the front. Some of the thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding near Downtown Memphis. Mississippi Boulevard and Crump Boulevard was flooded as a result.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the Midsouth during the afternoon and evening hours of December 27th, 2008. Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of the front. Some of the thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds knocked down two trees in Millsfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching surface front over Georgia, passing upper level energy per an upper level trough digging over the eastern seaboard and high atmospheric moisture and instability fueled numerous severe storms in the afternoon and evening along the sea breezes and resultant storm outflows under a prevailing southwest flow regime.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down on power lines in rural Nassau county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the Great Lakes across southeast Canada on the 11th. An associated warm front lifted northeast across New England and delivered warmer, moist air above the surface (several thousand feet) that  traveled over sub-freezing temperatures at the surface. This produced light precipitation in the form of freezing rain along and east of the spine of the Green Mountains of Vermont during the morning of January 11th.||Although ice accumulations were minimal, freezing rain created hazardous driving conditions that resulted in numerous vehicle accidents from eastern Rutland and Windsor counties in southern Vermont to the Canadian border, including a fatal accident in Derby (Orleans county).

A storm system brought heavy snow, areas of blowing snow and gusty winds to the Rocky Mountain Front. Snow accumulations in excess of 10 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snow was reported at Babb 18WSW (the Flattop Mountain SNOTEL site). Elevation 6900 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong disturbance aloft brought heavy snow, gusty winds and very cold temperatures to a large portion of North Central Montana. Snow amounts in excess of 6 inches, wind gusts in excess of 60 mph and wind chill readings colder than 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snow was reported at Dell 22SW (Beagle Springs SNOTEL site - elevation 8850 feet).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fourteen inches of snow was reported at Babb 12W (the Many Glacier SNOTEL site - elevation 4900 feet). Additionally, sixteen inches of snow was reported at Babb 18W (the Flattop Mountain SNOTEL site - elevation 6300 feet).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind chill reading of 52 degrees (F) below zero was reported at the Cut Bank ASOS site.

CZ_NAME: S & E JACKSON / LARIMER / N & NE GRAND / NW BOULDER COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level jetstream brought very heavy snow to portions of the North-Central Mountains.  The Park and Medicine Bow Ranges received most of the heavy snow, with storm totals of 24 inches at Tower and 16 inches at the Columbine Snotel.  Storm totals elsewhere generally ranged from 4 to 8 inches.  Strong winds also accompanied the snow.  Peak gusts included:  71 mph at Mines Peak, 67 mph at Niwot Ridge, and 60 mph atop Wilkerson Pass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm totals generally ranged from 4 to 8 inches. Strong winds also accompanied the snow. A peak wind gust to 67 mph were recorded at Niwot Ridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain developed across the mountains during mid-evening and continued into the early morning hours. Roads became slick and hazardous, with a few traffic accidents reported. Ice accretion of up to 1/8 inch or so was reported, resulting in a few downed trees and power lines. During the early morning hours of February 1st, more significant icing developed, but that part of the event will be included in next month's Storm Data.
A cold front moving southward across west Texas, resulted in high wind gusts across portions of the Guadalupe and Davis Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northeast winds behind a cold front gusted to above high wind criteria during the morning hours of January 16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving southward across west Texas, resulted in high wind gusts across portions of the Guadalupe and Davis Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds late Wednesday into the early morning hours on Thursday reached high wind criteria.  A peak sustained wind of 45 mph was reported just before midnight at Guadalupe Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface low pressure located over eastern portions of New Mexico aided in winds briefly reaching high wind thresholds over portions of the Guadalupe Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds briefly gusted above high wind criteria at Guadalupe Pass during the afternoon of January 21.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the area Tuesday night with strong high pressure behind the front bringing an arctic airmass over the state on strong northerly flow. Freezing temperatures settled into Levy county Wednesday morning and then settled across the entire area for Thursday morning, with many locations seeing freezing temperatures for six or more hours. North winds of 10 to 15 mph Thursday morning also allowed wind chill values to fall to 15 to 20 degrees across the area. Temperatures moderated for Friday morning, but freezing temperatures were still felt across the Nature Coast for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing conditions were felt across much of the county, with the COOP station in Venice reaching a low of 29 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A billboard and a one foot diameter tree blew down in the southwest part of the Las Vegas Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred 1 mile ESE of Red Rock Canyon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The following damage occurred in the northern part of the Las Vegas Valley: two large signs were snapped at their bases and blown down, a large pine tree was knocked over, and a billboard was blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 7 inches of snow fell at Hualapai Mountain Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained at near 30 mph with gusts around 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 1 to 3 inches to produce areas of blowing snow, with brief visibilities near a quarter mile in places. The strong winds and temperatures falling to around zero produced wind chill readings of 20 to 25 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained near 30 mph with gusts around 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 1 to 3 inches to produce blowing snow, with brief visibilities around a quarter mile in places. Temperatures falling to near zero combined with the strong winds to produce wind chill readings of 20 to 25 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued over most of the interior and southwest sections of South Florida during January.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall during January led to the continuation of drought conditions across the area. Glades County was in an extreme drought (D3) status, while Hendry, western Palm Beach and northern Collier counties were in a severe drought (D2) status. ||Rainfall amounts during January ranged from 0.5 to 1.0 inches over coastal and inland Collier, Hendry and Glades counties to between 1.0 and 1.5 inches near the south and east shores of Lake Okeechobee. The level of Lake Okeechobee remained at just over 10 feet above sea level, which was over 4 feet below normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A sharp cold front crossed Central Pennsylvania during the early morning hours of the 30th. Strong westerly wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph developed in the wake of the frontal passage, toppling trees and bringing down wires across portions of the western and northern mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cambria County 911 center reported trees down throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down across County Road 4. Several other trees toppled in town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shed blown over and grain bin blown off foundation on 100th St. two miles West of Highway 15.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful upper level disturbance with associated cold front pushed across the region the afternoon and evening of December 11. Over 2 inches of rain fell in many locations with several reports of minor urban flooding. One house was struck by lightning and burned to the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man ran off the road and into a ditch which was full of water. The vehicle was carried downstream and the man had to be rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful upper level disturbance with associated cold front pushed across the region the afternoon and evening of December 11. Over 2 inches of rain fell in many locations with several reports of minor urban flooding. One house was struck by lightning and burned to the ground.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a home in Chapel Hill and caught fire. The house burned to the ground when the lightning got into the gas lines of the home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong winds occurred over wind favored areas of extreme southeast Wyoming.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous gusts around 60 mph were recorded along Interstate 25 north and southwest of Cheyenne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong winds occurred over wind favored areas of extreme southeast Wyoming.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous gusts from 60 to 70 mph were recorded over parts of the area with a peak gust of 78 mph recorded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very strong winds occurred over wind favored areas of extreme southeast Wyoming.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous gusts from 60 to 65 mph were recorded along Interstate 25 at the Bordeaux interchange with a peak gust of 68 mph recorded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong non-thunderstorm wind gusts were prevalent behind a strong cold front which moved through the region during the afternoon hours.  Wind gusts as high as 45 mph were reported which downed large limbs and a few trees, resulting in isolated power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shingles were blown off a roof of the Laquinta Inn at Benton and Old Minden Roads.  Four windshields were broken out by debris.  A door was blown off the entrance of the hotel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought between 1 and 3 inches of snow to areas north of the I-70 corridor on December 16th.  Further south, patchy freezing drizzle created icy road conditions south of I-70...where numerous traffic accidents were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man was killed when the vehicle he was driving slid into a retention pond.  The accident happened at the chemical plant complex in Mapleton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds blew across portions of southeast Wyoming with the worst conditions along Interstate 80 from near Walcott Junction to near Arlington, where ground blizzard conditions resulted in near zero visibilities in some spots and necessitated the closure of roads in that area for a time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some gusts from 70 to 80 mph recorded along Interstate 25 at the Bordeaux interchange.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front triggered upslope snow showers along and west of the Allegheny Front in West Virginia beginning during the late morning of the 1st and lasting into the early morning hours of the 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 3.0 inches in Mount Storm and 1.5 inches in Bayard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front triggered upslope snow showers along and west of the Allegheny Front in West Virginia beginning during the late morning of the 1st and lasting into the early morning hours of the 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow totaled up to 2.0 inches in Circleville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell...with 6 to 11 inches of snow reported along and northeast of a Dodge to Norfolk to Neligh line.  Some of the heavier snow totals included around 11 inches at Walthill and near Battle Creek and around 10 inches near Norfolk and Wayne.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated between 1/4 and 1/3 of an inch over much of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the area in the early morning hours with a weak squall line traveling just ahead of the front. The line produced two areas of minor straight line wind damage with wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight mobile homes received minor damage to lanais and carports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the area late in the evening on 12/1 and through the early morning hours on 12/2. Cold air settled into the Nature Coast through the day on 12/2 and allowed for several hours of sub-freezing temperatures on the morning of 12/3. ||Levy County experienced several hours of sub-freezing temperatures with lows from 27 to 31 degrees across the county. The lowest temperature of 27 degrees occurred at the cooperative station six miles southeast of Chiefland. ||Citrus County experienced over 9 hours of sub-freezing temperatures in some locations, with the lowest temperature of 25 degrees occurring at a mesonet station near Inverness.||Hernando County also had over 9 hours of sub-freezing temperatures with the lowest temperature of 24 degrees occurring at the FAWN station in Brooksville.||Sumter County had lows ranging from 28 to 32 degrees, with the lowest temperature of 28 degrees occurring at the cooperative station in Bushnell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Levy County experienced several hours of sub-freezing temperatures with lows from 27 to 31 degrees across the county. The lowest temperature of 27 degrees occurred at the cooperative station six miles southeast of Chiefland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Just two days after one storm system produced heavy snow in the higher elevations of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin, a second storm came through on a track slightly south of the first one. This storm produced heavy snow down to the desert floor over much of the Mojave Desert.  Snow was seen as low as 1500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured 6.5 inches of snow fell at Barstow. State Highway 247 was closed for a time because snow plows could not keep up.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Just two days after one storm system produced heavy snow in the higher elevations of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin, a second storm came through on a track slightly south of the first one. This storm produced heavy snow down to the desert floor over much of the Mojave Desert.  Snow was seen as low as 1500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured 16 inches of snow fell at Mount Charleston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Just two days after one storm system produced heavy snow in the higher elevations of the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin, a second storm came through on a track slightly south of the first one. This storm produced heavy snow down to the desert floor over much of the Mojave Desert.  Snow was seen as low as 1500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell over much of the southeast half of the Las Vegas Valley.  The highest total was 8 inches, measured on the south side of Henderson. Many cars slid off roads, and others were abandoned at the bottoms of hills.  At an apartment complex, a large carport collapsed under the weight of the snow, damaging several vehicles parked underneath.  Many trees were bent down to the ground, or snapped in two due to the weight of the snow, blocking roads.  The Clark County School District closed schools due to snow for the first time in 30 years.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm and associated cold front traversed the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin, bringing heavy snow to the higher elevations and high winds to the lower elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust occurred at the Kingman airport.

As a result, the D2 drought classification also ended.||For the whole month of December, precipitation totals were mostly between 4 and 5.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through southeast Idaho during the evening and morning of the 12th and 13th and brought with it heavy snow and strong winds.  Heavy snow fell in high elevations, with strong winds causing power outages to 15,000 people in Bingham County on the morning of the 13th.  Although heavy snow did not fall in the Snake River Plain, 30 to 40 minor accidents occurred on icy roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snow was reported at the Oxford Spring SNOTEL site.  Twelve inches was also reported in Malad City.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of snow combined with strong winds closed area roads and schools around Twin Falls and Jerome.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dense fog blanketed much of southern Illinois as milder south winds blew over cold, frozen ground. Visibility was reduced to one-quarter mile or less.

Another major winter storm reached the central California Interior during the afternoon of December 16th. This storm dropped south along the coast, and as a result had a stronger impact on the Kern County mountains and desert than on the Sierra Nevada north of Kings Canyon. In the Kern desert, California City had 6 inches of new snow, and Rosamond received 2 inches. In the Kern County mountains, a foot of snow fell at Alpine Mountain. Rain that developed over San Luis Obispo and Monterey Counties during the afternoon of the 16th moved into the west side of the San Joaquin Valley, and actually produced light snowfall at Harris Ranch.||As the storm crossed southern California and into Arizona, skies cleared over the central California interior. In the central and southern San Joaquin Valley, temperatures fell into the mid 20s during the morning of December 18th. The lowest temperatures were recorded in Merced and western Fresno Counties, where durations below 28 degrees were as much as 5 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper tracked through the region on Saturday, December 6th. Light snow accompanied this system, with generally light accumulations reported. However, the light snow was enough to create icy roads with 1 fatal accident in Jay County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed early on Saturday, December 6th, and continued through the day. Snowfall accumulations were light, generally less than an inch across the region. However, the light snow was enough to create hazardous driving conditions and icy roadways with 1 fatality reported. A man was killed when his car slid off the road, striking a tree in Richland Township. The accident occurred on Indiana 67, south and west of County Road 700 West. The accident occurred at 11:21 am on December 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line raced through southeast Ohio at 50 to 60 mph during the late night hours.  The line was weakening, compared to earlier that night and further to the southwest.  However, trees were still blown down.

A strong Pacific storm system dumped heavy snow on nearly all of southeastern Idaho starting on Sunday the 21st and continuing through Monday the 22nd.  More than a foot of snow was common in the mountains while 6 to 14 inches fell in the Snake River Plain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emigrant Summit SNOTEL reported 11 inches of snowfall.

CZ_NAME: BIG AND LITTLE WOOD RIVER REGION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Pacific storm system dumped heavy snow on nearly all of southeastern Idaho starting on Sunday the 21st and continuing through Monday the 22nd.  More than a foot of snow was common in the mountains while 6 to 14 inches fell in the Snake River Plain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 9 inches of snow at Ketchum, 10 inches were reported 9 miles northeast of Carey.  15 inches were reported 5 miles west southwest of Gannett, and 10 inches were reported in Bellevue.  Selected SNOTEL amounts were:  9 inches at Swede Peak, 9 inches at Hyndman, 15 inches at Garfield Ranger Station, 15 inches at Galena Summit, 15 inches at Galena Lodge, 18 inches at Dollarhide, 9 inches at Chocolate Gulch, and 18 inches at Lost Wood Divide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The season's most severe lake effect event to date followed the passage of a sharp front early on Sunday the 21st. Winds turned southwest and increased to 30 to 40 mph with higher gusts by early afternoon over the west and almost as strong by late Sunday afternoon east of Lake Ontario. The strong winds inhibited single band formation, but resulted in a broad 20-30 mile wide area of lake snows northeast of Lake Erie right across the Buffalo metro area during the afternoon, which gradually settled south across the city and nearby southern suburbs in the evening. The winds created whiteouts and near blizzard conditions at times, with drifts commonly three feet across the entire Buffalo metro area. An upper air disturbance crossed around 3 a.m. on Monday the 22nd and bands shifted south where they remained in a weakened form across southern Erie and northern Chautauqua and Cattaraugus counties during the day Monday before drifting north and weakening Monday night.  Off Lake Ontario, a similar scenario ensued, but about 4 to 6 hours later. The main activity was over Jefferson and northern Lewis counties Sunday afternoon and night, gradually shifting south across Oswego county Monday and settling across the Syracuse area later Monday before shifting north and weakening Tuesday morning.  Snowfall amounts were close to a foot across metro Buffalo with a bit more in a strip from Hamburg to West Seneca to Elma to Batavia. Six inches fell up into far southern Niagara County, and even Rochester caught three inches as the band extended that far east for a time Sunday evening. Off Ontario the heaviest amounts fell from central Jefferson to northern Lewis counties, although a narrow area of a foot also was recorded in the Syracuse area and far southern Oswego County as the band stalled Monday.  The strong winds and frigid temperatures combined with the heavy snow to create the worst whiteout conditions and drifting in the Buffalo area in several years. Activities were ground to a halt with several major highways closed, including the I-90 NYS Thruway. Numerous automobile accidents were reported, including a fatal crash in Cambria.

A deepening storm system lifted out of the Midwest and tracked just west of Buffalo to near Ottawa and Montreal. This is a very favorable track for high winds across much of Western New York as strong gusty winds are further enhanced by the funneling effects of Lakes Erie and Ontario. The strong winds developed during the evening hours and continued until early morning of the 25th. The highest gusts exceeded 60 miles per hour. The winds downed trees and power lines with tens of thousands left without power. Specific reported wind gusts included: 62 m.p.h. at Watertown Airport and Rochester Airport; 61 m.p.h. at Eden and Oswego; 60 m.p.h. at Java Center; 59 m.p.h. at Oswego Coast Guard; 58 m.p.h. at Dunkirk, Alden and Hamburg; 55 m.p.h. at Buffalo Airport and Canandaigua; 54 m.p.h. at Fulton; and 52 m.p.h. at Wellsville.

Post cold-frontal wind chill values dropped to -20 to -30 across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  These bitter-cold wind chills were generated by west winds at 17 to 26 knots (20 to 30 mph) with gusts to 26 to 36 knots (30 to 41 mph).  Actual air temperatures were in the single digits above zero, or fell into that temperature range during this event.

A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds gusts damaged the roof of an outbuilding.  There was also a tree knocked over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power poles were knocked down from severe thunderstorm winds gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained at near 30 mph with gusts around 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 1 to 3 inches to produce areas of blowing snow, with brief visibilities near a quarter mile in places. The strong winds and temperatures falling to around zero produced wind chill readings of 20 to 25 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds sustained near 30 mph with gusts around 40 mph combined with existing snow cover and new snowfall of 1 to 3 inches to produce blowing snow, with brief visibilities around a quarter mile in places. Temperatures falling to near zero combined with the strong winds to produce wind chill readings of 20 to 25 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure weakened as it crossed the Great Lakes on the morning of the 21st as a second area of low pressure developed off the North Carolina coast.  The coastal low intensified rapidly as it moved northeast along the East Coast to Nova Scotia by the morning of the 22nd. The coastal low brought heavy snow to the entire state with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 15 inches in coastal areas to 20 to 30 inches in the mountains.  Eustis reported a total of 41 inches of snow from the storm.

Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inch diameter tree downed at the intersection of County Rd 40 and County Road 28, one mile West of Spencer Brook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushing into an unseasonably warm and moist airmass across central Illinois produced a round of severe thunderstorms on December 27th.  With a very strong mid-level jet streak in place across the Midwest, the storms were able to tap into this energy and produce widespread damaging winds in excess of 60 mph.  In addtion, heavy rainfall falling on partially frozen ground led to flash flooding in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Unanchored outdoor displays were blown off a hardware store parking lot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved from the Central Plains to Southern Lower Michigan, producing heavy snow north of the track of the low.  In Northern Michigan, the heavier snow fell near and southeast of a line from Manistee to Alpena.  Total accumulations of 10 to 14 inches were common near Gladwin, West Branch, Hale, and Black River.

In Northern Michigan, the heavier snow fell near and southeast of a line from Manistee to Alpena.  Total accumulations of 10 to 14 inches were common near Gladwin, West Branch, Hale, and Black River.
An area of low pressure combined with cold air to trigger snow near the Allegheny front in Virginia. The snow started on the afternoon of the 6th and lasted through the morning of the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 1.5 inches in Monterey, and 4.0 inches in Seneca Rocks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure combined with cold air to trigger snow across locations along and west of the Allegheny front in eastern West Virginia.  The snow started on the afternoon of the 6th and lasted through the morning of the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 6.0 inches 6 miles west-southwest of Cherry Grove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure tracked along a stationary front over Virginia on the 10th bringing a soaking rain. An isolated report of flooding did occur from the steady rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 737 was closed both eastbound and westbound due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of light snow occurred across Iowa.  An Arctic airmass was in place over the state as southwest winds drew warmer and more moist air over the area.  Low pressure formed over Kansas during the day on the 21st and lifted northeast across southeast Iowa.  The Topeka, KS sounding from 12z on the 21st showed the 850 mb temperature had warmed to 0 C. with a southwest wind at 63 kts.  As a result, there was a brief period of freezing rain over the southeast third of the state on the afternoon and early evening of the 21st.  Elsewhere, an extended period of light snow produced 4 to 8 inch snow amounts over about the north half of the state.  Snow over the south was limited by the passage of the upper air dry slot.  A small area of heavy snow occurred over the northwest part of the CWA.  Pocahontas received 10 inches of snow in a 24 hour period.  Travel problems were limited however as the snow was very light and fluffy in nature.

Two low pressure systems combined with a slow moving cold front produced widespread and sustained snow and freezing rain.  Snowfall in inches included Bickleton (8), 4 miles west of College Place (6.8), Richland (8), 3 miles northeast of College Place (8), 1 mile north of Prosser (7), 1 miles north northwest of Kennewick (6), Hanford (8.1), 11 miles west of Glenwood (19), north White Salmon (15), 1 mile north northwest of Glenwood (14), 3 miles southeast of BZ Corner (15), Trout Lake (20).  Freezing rain accumulations included 1/2 inch 5 miles south of Eltopia and 5 miles west of College Place, 1/4 inch at Kennewick, Wishram, and 6 miles north northwest of Walla Walla.

A cold front moved through the area late in the evening on 12/1 and through the early morning hours on 12/2. Cold air settled into the Nature Coast through the day on 12/2 and allowed for several hours of sub-freezing temperatures on the morning of 12/3. ||Levy County experienced several hours of sub-freezing temperatures with lows from 27 to 31 degrees across the county. The lowest temperature of 27 degrees occurred at the cooperative station six miles southeast of Chiefland. ||Citrus County experienced over 9 hours of sub-freezing temperatures in some locations, with the lowest temperature of 25 degrees occurring at a mesonet station near Inverness.||Hernando County also had over 9 hours of sub-freezing temperatures with the lowest temperature of 24 degrees occurring at the FAWN station in Brooksville.||Sumter County had lows ranging from 28 to 32 degrees, with the lowest temperature of 28 degrees occurring at the cooperative station in Bushnell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hernando County experienced over 9 hours of sub-freezing temperatures with the lowest temperature of 24 degrees occurring at the FAWN station in Brooksville. This location also experienced temperatures at or below 27 degrees for 5 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A gulf low pressure system lifted through the deep south and pushed a cold front through the area. A strong and fast moving squall line developed ahead of the cold front, bringing winds of 40 to 50 mph as it moved through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A sheet metal roof was torn off of a porch of a local residence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved out of the central Plains and moved across Pennsylvania. The low brought an eight to twelve inch blanket of snow to the entire region on the 19th. Across the western southern tier, snowfall amounts were slightly lower however, the snow mixed with freezing rain and sleet across that area. Some of the highest snowfall amounts included: 16 inches at Fairport; 15 inches at Youngstown; 14 inches at LaSalle; 13 inches at Medina; 12 inches at Getzville, Lockport, and North Tonawanda; 11 inches at Montezuma, Charlotte, Perinton, and Warsaw; 10 inches at Kenmore, Buffalo, Stafford, Pavilion, Lowville, Harrisville, Rochester, Niagara Falls, Wilson, Oswego, Walworth and Akron; 9 inches at West Seneca, Black River, Calcium, Hooker, Gorham, Phelps, and Palmyra. Innumerable automobile accidents were reported throughout the region as the roads became hard to navigate in the heavy snow and reduced visibilities. Schools shut down across the region and many municipalities suggested avoiding unnecessary travel if possible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving low pressure system tracking across the Ohio Valley pulled a strong cold front through the Southern Appalachians during the morning of the 31st. Wind damage was widespread and extended into the foothill counties.

CZ_NAME: WEST SLOPES NORTHERN CASCADES AND PASSES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in the Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell at Mt. baker--18 inches in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Behind a departing low, an upper-level ridge over the eastern Pacific built into California, bringing more stratus and patchy dense fog during the morning of December 8th. A weak upper-level disturbance moved over the central California interior, bringing light rain to the central and southern San Joaquin Valley; a few hundredths of an inch fell at Fresno. High pressure rebuilt over the central California interior, bringing more dense fog to the central and southern San Joaquin Valley.  The worst dense fog conditions were prevalent during much of the overnight and morning hours on December 9, 10, 11, and 12, when visibilities were lowered to near zero in some areas due to very dense fog.

A fast moving low pressure system moved through Southern New England bringing 4-10 inches of snow to the region.  In addition, strong cold advection and pressure rises resulted in very cold temperatures, strong winds, and bitterly cold wind chills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of four to seven inches of snow across Tolland County were received.

CZ_NAME: EAST SLOPES OF THE CENTRAL CASCADES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of moist upper level disturbances combined with upslope flow brought heavy snow to the east slopes of the central Washington Cascades.  Snowfall amounts in inches included 7 miles north northwest of Easton (8) and 5 miles east of Easton (10).

Heavy snow and strong winds occurred in the mountains of Idaho.  Strong winds and drifting closed highway 32 from Ashton to Tetonia in the Upper Snake Highlands and highway 47 was closed from Ashton to Bear Gulch.  Sugar Salem and Fremont County schools were closed on the 19th.  One to two feet of snow fell in the central mountains and Upper Snake River Highlands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell above 7,000 feet in the Sawtooth Mountains.  15 inches fell at Bear Canyon, 12 inches at Stinckney Mill, 20 inches at Smiley Mountain and 12 inches at Mill Creek.

Northwest winds sustained around 30 mph, with gusts over 40 mph, combined with recent heavy and loose snow cover and generally light new snowfall to cause frequent visibilities near zero in blowing snow. Drifting snow closed several roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northwest winds sustained at 30 mph with gusts to over 40 mph combined with heavy loose snow cover to produce widespread visibilities of a quarter mile or less in blowing snow. Drifting snow blocked several roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across Arkansas on the 9th, accompanied by numerous showers and thunderstorms. Colder air moved in quickly behind the front, with temperatures plunging more than 20 degrees within just a few hours after frontal passage. Lingering moisture behind the front, coupled with weak areas of low pressure aloft, brought some wintry precipitation to parts of northern Arkansas early on the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of light sleet, snow, and freezing rain caused slick spots to develop on some roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very cold air just before Christmas was replaced by near record high temperatures in the 60s and 70s on the 26th. This was ahead of a storm system riding a southwest wind flow aloft toward Arkansas. Ahead of the system, the atmosphere became rather unstable. A cold front moving through the Plains tapped into this unstable air, and a line of thunderstorms resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A roof was blown off a mobile home on Waterplant Road in Dardanelle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two periods of snow affected Northern Michigan.  On the 23rd, a pair of upper level disturbances brought 1 to 4 inches of snow to the area.  After a break in the pre-dawn hours, low pressure brought locally heavier snow to the region on the 24th.  Atlanta picked up 9 inches of snow, McBain 8 inches, and Leland 6 inches.

After a brief thaw, a strong cold front blasted Arctic air back into Northern Michigan.  Wind gusts behind the front reached 65 mph in Ossineke, and 63 mph in Charlevoix.  The cold air rushing in over the Great Lakes resulted in 1 to 3 inches of snow in much of Eastern Upper and Northwest Lower Michigan.  The snow and wind resulted in near-blizzard conditions for a few hours on the morning of the 28th.  Visibilities of a half-mile or less were common.

A squall line raced through southeast Ohio at 50 to 60 mph during the late night hours.  The line was weakening, compared to earlier that night and further to the southwest.  However, trees were still blown down.

A weakening squall line, during the late night hours, was still strong enough to cause wind gusts in the 55 to 65 mph range.  Trees were blown down, along with some damage to a few buildings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were knocked down around the community of Pea Ridge.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of a roof was blown off a building.

Severe thunderstorms packing hail and strong winds moved across portions of South Central Montana during the late evening hours of the 4th.

A deepening storm system lifted out of the Midwest and tracked just west of Buffalo to near Ottawa and Montreal. This is a very favorable track for high winds across much of Western New York as strong gusty winds are further enhanced by the funneling effects of Lakes Erie and Ontario. The strong winds developed during the evening hours and continued until early morning of the 25th. The highest gusts exceeded 60 miles per hour. The winds downed trees and power lines with tens of thousands left without power. Specific reported wind gusts included: 62 m.p.h. at Watertown Airport and Rochester Airport; 61 m.p.h. at Eden and Oswego; 60 m.p.h. at Java Center; 59 m.p.h. at Oswego Coast Guard; 58 m.p.h. at Dunkirk, Alden and Hamburg; 55 m.p.h. at Buffalo Airport and Canandaigua; 54 m.p.h. at Fulton; and 52 m.p.h. at Wellsville.

A strong cold front crossed the region during the morning hours. Winds shifted to the southwest and increased rapidly. The combination of the wind shift, rapid strengthening of the wind speed and the long fetch up the length of Lake Erie produced a seiche on the lake. Water levels rose over six and a half feet in about three hours time. The Lake Erie water level crested at Buffalo at 8.1 feet, just above its eight foot flood stage. Flooding was reported along the lake shore from Angola to Buffalo.

A deepening area of low pressure moved across the Ohio valley and Pennsylvania before moving off the southern New England Coast during the afternoon of the 31st. Steady snow developed over the region and was accompanied by increasing northerly winds. Widespread snowfall amounts ranged from eight to fourteen inches during the eight hour event. The strong winds produced areas of blowing and drifting snow and resulted in significantly reduced visibilities. Some of the highest snowfall reports included: 14 inches at Walworth; 12 inches at Fairport; 11 inches at Lockport; 10 inches at Alden, Colden, Kenmore, Livonia, Penfield, and Warsaw; 9 inches at Sinclairville, Buffalo, Amherst, Clarence, Elma, Pavilion, Greece and Niagara Falls; and 8 inches at South Dayton, Montezuma, Avon, Mount Morris and Newark.

A large squall line of thunderstorms impacted all locations of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks.  Several locations experienced severe weather, mainly in the form of damaging straight line winds.  However, two brief tornadoes occurred in McDonald and Barry counties.  Meanwhile, there were a few observations of large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm wind gusts completely destroyed a shed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were knocked over and damaged from severe thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept across the region with a strong line of showers and thunderstorms moving across the region with a pre-frontal squall line. A warm frontal boundary extended across Georgia from near Albany to Alma and then to Savannah with some severe weather developing along it. Upper level divergence was also fairly impressive based on water vapor satellite imagery and 250 mb winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported heavy rainfall with street flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure weakened as it crossed the Great Lakes on the morning of the 21st as a second area of low pressure developed off the North Carolina coast.  The coastal low intensified rapidly as it moved northeast along the East Coast to Nova Scotia by the morning of the 22nd. The coastal low brought heavy snow to the entire state with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 15 inches in coastal areas to 20 to 30 inches in the mountains.  Eustis reported a total of 41 inches of snow from the storm.

A large tree fell on a home near Cashiers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level system moved from the southwestern United States across the plains tapping gulf moisture as it moved near eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  With Arctic air in place across the area...the moisture and forcing from the system produced freezing rain and sleet over southeast and east central Nebraska and southwest Iowa and heavy snow over northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.  Freezing rain accumulations of 1/4 to 1/3 inch were common from far southeast Nebraska into far southwest Iowa, with 1/2 to 3/4 inch sleet mixed with freezing rain accumulations common just north of there including the Lincoln and Omaha areas.  Farther north and northwest the precipitation was mostly snow...although some sleet also fell...with 6 to 11 inches of snow reported along and northeast of a Dodge to Norfolk to Neligh line.  Some of the heavier snow totals included around 11 inches at Walthill and near Battle Creek and around 10 inches near Norfolk and Wayne.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated around a quarter of inch over much of the county.  The freezing rain was mixed with a little sleet.

In Northern Michigan, the heavier snow fell near and southeast of a line from Manistee to Alpena.  Total accumulations of 10 to 14 inches were common near Gladwin, West Branch, Hale, and Black River.

A Pacific storm pushed moisture over cold air in the Mojave Desert and southern Great Basin, producing significant snow as low as 3000 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured 6.5 inches of snow fell at Diamond M Ranch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two low pressure systems combined with a slow moving cold front produced widespread and sustained snow and freezing rain.  Snowfall in inches included Bickleton (8), 4 miles west of College Place (6.8), Richland (8), 3 miles northeast of College Place (8), 1 mile north of Prosser (7), 1 miles north northwest of Kennewick (6), Hanford (8.1), 11 miles west of Glenwood (19), north White Salmon (15), 1 mile north northwest of Glenwood (14), 3 miles southeast of BZ Corner (15), Trout Lake (20).  Freezing rain accumulations included 1/2 inch 5 miles south of Eltopia and 5 miles west of College Place, 1/4 inch at Kennewick, Wishram, and 6 miles north northwest of Walla Walla.

A sharp cold front crossed Central Pennsylvania during the early morning hours of the 30th. Strong westerly wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph developed in the wake of the frontal passage, toppling trees and bringing down wires across portions of the western and northern mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: PennDot reported trees and wires down across Cameron County.
