A bridge flooded along Highway J three miles east of Conway. A section of Highway FF was flooded between highways T and 133. Brush Creek north of Morgan flooded all low areas near its channel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow to much of east central and southeast Illinois on the 21st.  Most of the accumulations were minor, but four tenths of an inch of ice accumulated from the freezing rain over Clay county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four tenths of an inch of ice accumulation was reported from freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure lifted north from the Tennessee valley and spread initially snow, then a mix of snow, freezing rain and sleet, across parts of the region. Snowfalls ranged from five to eleven inches followed by a couple inches of sleet or a coating of ice.

A complex weather situation was in place during the overnight hours of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.  A warm front was positioned to the south of Iowa.  Meanwhile, a secondary cold front dropped into the north central  U.S. and stretched from eastern Montana into southern Minnesota.  The upper flow was northwest and quite conducive for MCS development as considerable moisture transport took place over Iowa.  Initially, an area of thunderstorms formed over south central Iowa.  The storms remained below severe limits as they tracked east-southeast out of the CWA.  A strong thunderstorm complex developed over western South Dakota during the night and propagated southeast, along with the upper air northwest flow, into Iowa.  The MCS became linear in nature as it moved out of northwest Iowa into the central sections of the state.  Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in several counties, with urban street flooding along the length of the line.  Rainfall rates of one to two inches in one half hour or less were reported.  A few areas received 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Appanoose County was quite hard hit with water flowing over the roads two feet deep.  The main severe mode of the system was the high winds.  There were numerous reports of 60 to 70 MPH winds.  The entire length of the line produced 40 to 50 MPH winds however.  Hail was somewhat limited as the freezing level was over 14,000 feet.  Following the passage of the line, high winds became a problem as a wake low developed.  Winds gusted to 58 MPH in Story County at Colo and wind damage was reported in Polk County at Bondurant.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Big Creek at Blairstown crested at 23.02 feet, or 3.02 feet above flood stage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Blackwater River near Blue Lick crested at 26.34 feet, or 2.34 feet above flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system moved from the southwest United States and into the southern plains during the day. A very unstable airmass was noted across the four state region with abundant low level wind shear and deep layer shear in the mid levels of the atmosphere. A dry line moved into southeast Oklahoma and northeast Texas by late afternoon with scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms developing ahead of the dry line across the region. Thunderstorms produced strong and damaging wind gusts along with large hail across most of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail fell on Hwy 344 west, 2 miles east of Hwy 155.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 8-9, a winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall. The build up of snow on the mountains caused it to become unstable and produce avalanches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two avalanches were reported along Highway 12. The first, at mile marker 133.79, covered the highway with 3 to 4 feet of debris and snow. The second, at mile marker 132.48, covered the highway with 23 feet of snow, large trees and debris.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced a band of 6-10 inches of snow from extreme eastern Colorado into northwest Kansas and southwest Nebraska.  Cheyenne county Colorado received 6-7 inches of snow in the eastern half of the county from Kit Carson to Cheyenne Wells and Arapahoe.

A low pressure system tracked from the Great Lakes on Wednesday December 24th, to off the northern New England coast by Thursday morning on December 25th. ||Strong winds developed immediately ahead of, and with a cold frontal passage Wednesday night, and persisted into Thursday morning. Wind gusts reached 40 to 55 mph, with the strongest winds occurring across the higher elevations of the western Berkshires.

Heavy rainfall, combined with snowmelt led to isolated minor flooding in east central Ulster County during Thursday December 25th. The water levels gradually receded by Monday morning on December 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of heavy rain and snowmelt led to isolated minor flooding of Springtown Road, between Kleine Kill Drive, and Dug Road in New Paltz, forcing this portion of the road to be closed.||The road was closed at approximately 1530 LST on December 25th, and reopened by 0700 LST on December 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked east from northern Pennsylvania to just south of Long Island during Wednesday, December 31st, before intensifying rapidly and moving northeast off the New England coast by Thursday morning on January 1st.||As this low moved east, a swath of moderate snowfall fell across southern Vermont, with amounts ranging from 4 to 8 inches. The heaviest snow coincided with the morning commute, creating treacherous travel conditions, and forcing many businesses to close, or have delayed openings. Most schools were already closed for the Holiday break.

A strong low pressure system brought snow to the Northern Great Lakes region.  Locally heavy snow developed in parts of Northwest Lower Michigan on the evening of the 30th, with Lake Ann picking up 13 inches of snow by morning of the 1st.  However, for most of the region, the heaviest snow fell on the 1st.  Thus, a more complete disucssion of this event will be contained in Storm Data for December 2008.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds knocked down several trees just to the north of Wadesboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another month of below normal rainfall resulted in a persistence of severe to exceptional drought conditions over much of Upstate South Carolina through November. Slight improvements in well water levels continued across the area. Most rivers and major streams continued to flow at less than 10 percent of normal. Voluntary water restrictions continued in most areas, with a few areas continuing to institute mandatory restrictions.

A deepening upper level trough over the southeast region lifted a deep plume of tropical moisture over the forecast area. A strong low level 850 mb jet of 50-55 knots was in place. Backing winds advected instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico across North Florida which coincided with the passing of a second pre-frontal squall line as it tracked across North Florida and Southeast Georgia in the afternoon. Low level storm relative helicities increased to 200-350 M2/S2. Widespread severe storms developed across the forecast area during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An oak tree was blown down at the Harbor Pines Apartments on Harbor Pines Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An inverted trough of low pressure at the surface moved through the state during the early morning of the 20th into the day on the 20th. At the same time, a strong low pressure deepened in the upper atmosphere over and just northeast of the state.  The combination drew down Arctic air into the central U.S. A tight pressure gradient developed between the developing low to the east and Arctic high pressure to the northwest.  Winds increased on the 20th, and continued through most of the day on the 21st.  Sustained wind speeds were in the 25 to 35 MPH range, with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH.  Very little snow fell with the inverted trough, generally an inch or two, however antecedent snow cover was quite high with 7 to 12 inches common.  The winds caused whiteout conditions for an extended period of time as the snow that was loose blew in open areas.  Much of the deeper snow had crusted over, so blizzard conditions were somewhat sporadic and not as widespread as would normally be expected.  The first and second order reporting stations did not meet blizzard criteria outside of occasionally, however law enforcement officials reported visibility frequently reduced to between 10 and 100 feet in open areas.  Travel was therefore not recommended across all of the northern part of Iowa north of U.S. Highway 30.  Roads drifted shut quickly and snowplows were taken off of several roads during the height of the storm.  In addition to the wind, temperatures fell below zero, resulting in dangerous wind chill indices in the -30 to -40 F. range.

Severe thunderstorms moved out of eastern New Hampshire and into western Maine during the early afternoon of June 17th. As in New Hampshire, these storms were almost exclusively large hail producers with numerous reports of 1 to 1.75 inch hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced .88 inch hail which covered the ground in Cornish.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced 1 inch hail in West Newfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated at 60 mph were recorded.  Central dispatch reported that numerous trees and power lines were blown down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: November brought several rain events to southern California, but not enough to have an impact on the drought. The statewide drought declaration made in early June continues. A water shortage emergency (stage 1) remains in effect for San Diego with a call for voluntary water conservation, however, no water shortages have been reported. Mandatory cutbacks have already started for some farmers in San Diego County, and could be extended to others by early next year. ||The USDA granted a Secretarial Disaster Designation for the county of San Diego, Orange, and Riverside due to agricultural losses cause by drought. Emergency, low interest loans have been made available to family-sized farms and ranches. Losses to range lands have been qualified at greater than 40%.||This resulted in D1 (Moderate Drought) classification by the U.S. Drought Monitor for Orange County, and D2 (Severe Drought) classification for the rest of the CWA.

An extended period of offshore winds affected Southern California. North to northeast wind gusts in excess of 65 MPH were reported in some areas. The strong winds, combined with very dry conditions, helped fuel two significant wildfires. The Tea Fire, near Montecito in Santa Barbara county, burned 1,940 acres. The Sayre Fire, north of Sylmar in Los Angeles county, burned 11,262 acres. Both fires produced significant loss of residences.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds affected the foothill areas south of the Santa Ynez range in southern Santa Barbara county. The RAWS sensor at Montecito reported sustained winds between 40 and 55 MPH with gusts as high as 72 MPH.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty north to northeast winds affected the mountains of Los Angeles county. The RAWS sensor at Warm Springs reported north to northeast winds gusting to 60 MPH while the RAWS sensor at Chilao reported north to northeast winds gusts to 59 MPH.

CZ_NAME: COASTAL NORTH BAY INCLUDING POINT REYES NATIONAL SEASHORE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High Surf and dangerous rip currents buffeted the North Bay Coast, resulting in the death of a young woman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 19 year old woman entered the water at Portuguese Beach in Sonoma Coast State Park after her fiance jumped in to retrieve their dog. She got swept up in a fierce rip current and was swept away to her death. The fiance and dog survived.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a warm front over east central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon hours of February 5th.  Many of the thunderstorms on either side of the front produced heavy rains and flooding.  The storms to the south of the warm front also produced damaging winds and hail, especially along and south of the I-70 corridor.  The flooding produced numerous road closures across the region, while the winds produced primarily tree, power line and power pole damage.  However, several structures received minor, mainly roofing damage and one mobile home was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex weather situation was in place during the overnight hours of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.  A warm front was positioned to the south of Iowa.  Meanwhile, a secondary cold front dropped into the north central  U.S. and stretched from eastern Montana into southern Minnesota.  The upper flow was northwest and quite conducive for MCS development as considerable moisture transport took place over Iowa.  Initially, an area of thunderstorms formed over south central Iowa.  The storms remained below severe limits as they tracked east-southeast out of the CWA.  A strong thunderstorm complex developed over western South Dakota during the night and propagated southeast, along with the upper air northwest flow, into Iowa.  The MCS became linear in nature as it moved out of northwest Iowa into the central sections of the state.  Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in several counties, with urban street flooding along the length of the line.  Rainfall rates of one to two inches in one half hour or less were reported.  A few areas received 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Appanoose County was quite hard hit with water flowing over the roads two feet deep.  The main severe mode of the system was the high winds.  There were numerous reports of 60 to 70 MPH winds.  The entire length of the line produced 40 to 50 MPH winds however.  Hail was somewhat limited as the freezing level was over 14,000 feet.  Following the passage of the line, high winds became a problem as a wake low developed.  Winds gusted to 58 MPH in Story County at Colo and wind damage was reported in Polk County at Bondurant.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across Western Montana and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West Glacier received 7.5 inches, Marias Pass received 7 inches, and Swan Lake received 6 inches of new snowfall accumulations from this event. In addition, gusty winds to 35 mph were observed along the US Highway 12 corridor between Essex and Marias Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across Western Montana and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Whitefish received 8 inches and Bigfork received 6 inches of new snowfall accumulations. In addition, winds across the Flathead and Mission valleys gusted between 21 mph and 31 mph throughout the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across Western Montana and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe weather spotters and automated weather stations reported between 6 and 10.5 inches of new snowfall accumulations along the Interstate 90 corridor between Saint Regis and Lookout Pass. In addition, wind gusts in the valleys and at Lookout Pass ranged between 21 mph and 31 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system moved from the southwest United States and into the southern plains during the day. A very unstable airmass was noted across the four state region with abundant low level wind shear and deep layer shear in the mid levels of the atmosphere. A dry line moved into southeast Oklahoma and northeast Texas by late afternoon with scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms developing ahead of the dry line across the region. Thunderstorms produced strong and damaging wind gusts along with large hail across most of the region.

Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values hovered around 25 below zero on the morning of the 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values plunged into the 25 to 35 below zero range during the period.  Ewen-Trout Creek Schools closed on the 16th due to the bitter cold.

In fact, drought conditions actually worsened in some areas, with portions of the central North Carolina mountains deteriorating to exceptional drought conditions late in the month. Slight improvements in well water levels continued across the area. Most rivers and major streams continued to flow at less than 10 percent of normal.  Voluntary water restrictions continued in most areas, with a few areas continuing to institute mandatory restrictions.

An upper level trough moving into the Mid Atlantic and Northeast, skirted just north of central North Carolina on the afternoon of August 2nd. The trough passage was close enough to trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms during peak heating. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding across portions of the western Piedmont, the Sandhills, and the southern Coastal Plain of North Carolina.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An air conditioning unit was blown off a building in Wadesboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong trough of low pressure in the upper atmosphere moved into the southwest U.S. late on the 17th and early on the 18th.  The system was very fast moving with a strong jet of 165 kts streaming up the east side of the trough.  A short wave ejected out of the trough and raced northeast through the central U.S., reaching Illinois by the morning of the 19th.  Low pressure at the surface formed over western Kansas during the afternoon of the 18th. It moved to northeast Kansas by evening, and to near Burlington, IA by sunrise on the 19th.  A strong low level jet pushed moisture over a polar airmass that was in place over Iowa.  In addition, the atmosphere became quite unstable for December over the state, resulting in the development of thunderstorms over a large part of Iowa during the overnight hours of the 18th into the 19th.  Temperatures over southern Iowa remained in the 20s through the event, though the cold layer was quite shallow.  Temperatures aloft rose well above freezing, thus most of the precipitation that fell came in the form of freezing rain.  The freezing rain turned to sleet and snow briefly before ending.  Heavy ice accumulations occurred over southern Iowa, especially the southwest and southeast parts of the DSM CWA.  Ice accrual reached one half inch over Davis County, and around 0.6 inches in Adams Counties for the heaviest amounts.  Most of the area received between 0.25 and 0.4 inches of ice.  Spotty power outages were reported, however much of the power problems were mitigated by efforts the previous summer with tree trimming by the power utilities. Roads became very icy with all roads 100% ice covered.  Nearly all schools and many activities were cancelled for the 19th due to the ice.

A deepening upper level trough over the southeast region lifted a deep plume of tropical moisture over the forecast area. A strong low level 850 mb jet of 50-55 knots was in place. Backing winds advected instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico across North Florida which coincided with the passing of a second pre-frontal squall line as it tracked across North Florida and Southeast Georgia in the afternoon. Low level storm relative helicities increased to 200-350 M2/S2. Widespread severe storms developed across the forecast area during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated at 60 mph. The winds destroyed a pump house which supplied water for the main house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave that brought strong winds to the coast moved inland, bringing strong westerlies to the Cascades of southwest Washington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds estimated based on observed wind gusts at White Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall, fueled by a tropical moisture source that had origins in the west Pacific, drenched the region over the course of a few days. This heavy rainfall caused flooding along multiple rivers in northwest Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trask River Road at milepost 7.5 was reported closed due to high water.  The was caused by the heavy rain that fell over the Coast Range, that resulted in the flooding of the Trask River.  A woman driving a car was stuck in the high water along the road, but was rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall, fueled by a tropical moisture source that had origins in the west Pacific, drenched the region over the course of a few days. This heavy rainfall caused flooding along multiple rivers in northwest Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains over the Willapa Hills drained into the Grays River, raising the river out of it's banks. This combined with high tides brought flooding to areas in Wahkiakum county, especially around the town of Rosburg.  Flooding in the area closed local roads as well as some evacuations of people from their homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the state during the early morning hours of the 27th.  Temperatures fell from the 50s into the upper 20s to low 30s within an hour or two.  The cold air was very shallow with warm air continuing to stream into the state.  A large area of thunderstorms developed on the cold side of the cold frontal boundary.  The rain fell into the cold air at the surface, resulting in widespread glazing across much of the southeast half of the Des Moines CWA as temperatures had fallen into the 20s by the time the thunderstorms moved through.  Ice accumulated quite quickly with one quarter inch amounts quite widespread.  Spotty one half inch amounts were reported over parts of central, south central, and southeast Iowa as thunderstorms produced heavier rainfall in those areas.  Scattered power outages were reported across the area and roadways became treacherous due to the icing.  Overall, damage was not all that extensive as the areas that received half inch amounts of ice were relatively small.

Persistent dry weather over the summer into the fall has resulted in severe drought conditions across the Northwest Hill Country.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe Drought conditions (D2) which began in September continued into October.  Range and pasture conditions were extremely poor due to the dry conditions.  Supplemental feeding of livestock has also increased. Stock tank levels continued to drop.  The dry weather has also created fire weather concerns.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area tracekd across east Texas and western Louisiana, creating up to 8 inches of rainfall. This resulted in some flash flooding in the Jasper, TX area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several homes on Second Street had water enter them after as much as eight inches of rain fell in a short time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 60 mph brought down several trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low off of Prince William Sound produced snow and gusty north wind over the Western Prince William Sound region that resulted in blizzard conditions in northern Resurrection Bay.

A strong upper atmospheric low pressure system moved from south central Canada to the Great Lakes during the night of December 20th into the morning of December 21st. At the surface, the primary low associated with this upper level feature moved into the Great Lakes and weakened on the  21st. Meanwhile, a secondary coastal low developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast during the morning of the 21st and tracked into the Gulf of Maine during that evening.||Snow overspread Vermont around daybreak on the 21st and fell heavy at times during the late morning and early afternoon hours before dissipating during the evening. Snowfall accumulations of 6 to 10 inches were common across western Vermont with 10 to 18 inches across central and eastern Vermont. Some specific snowfall totals include; 18 inches in Marshfield (Washington), St. Johnsbury (Caledonia county), Rochester (Windsor county) and Randolph Center (Orange county) with 15 inches in Moretown and Waterbury Center (Washington county), North Promfret (Windsor county), Island Pond (Essex county). ||This was the second significant snowfall within 36 hours which led to additional vehicle accidents and exhausted snow removal resources. Snowfall totals in excess of 24 inches within 36 hours led to blocked ventilation pipes and some carbon monoxide injuries as well as a few collapsed small farm structures due to the weight of the snow.

Snowfall totals in excess of 24 inches within 36 hours led to blocked ventilation pipes and some carbon monoxide injuries as well as a few collapsed small farm structures due to the weight of the snow.

A strong cold front crossed the eastern Great Lakes late Saturday and early Sunday (16th) and was immediately followed by a strong westerly lake effect event. Initially, very heavy snow was restricted to the higher elevations of Chautauqua and Cattaraugus counties. Over 20 inches fell by late Sunday night along the ridge tops. East of Lake Ontario, similar activity began on the Tug Hill Sunday morning, with amounts topping a foot by early Monday. A secondary trough crossed the area late Monday and disrupted the lake snows, with winds veering sharply to the north-northwest for Monday night and Tuesday. Multiple bands off Lake Ontario set up later Tuesday and Tuesday night which gradually weakened during Wednesday morning. This second phase brought up to a foot over Cayuga County.  Total snowfall ranged from two feet over the Chautauqua ridge with a maximum of near 30 in Ellicottville and South Dayton. Other reports included: 24 at Hinsdale, 23 at Mayville, and 15 at Jamestown. To the east, the Tug Hill received upwards of two feet during the first phase on the westerly flow with a maximum of 28 at West Leyden. Other eastern Lake Ontario reports included: 27 at Constableville and 15 at Highmarket. The second phase brought 14 to Fairhaven and 11 at Oswego.

Lake effect snows developed on Thursday (20th) as a west to northwest flow set up off Lake Erie and brought narrow streamers of heavy snow into Chautauqua County. Several inches fell during the afternoon. Meanwhile, a weak secondary front and wind shift dropped south across New York and set up from near Erie across Pennsylvania to near Philadelphia. A band of heavy snow set up along this convergence line, fed at its western end by Lake Erie. This band dropped just to the south of Chautauqua County during the evening, after 6 to 8 inch totals. Winds turned north-northeasterly and another band set up from Dunkirk to Ripley which became heavy overnight and early Friday morning as winds backed to north-northwest. Six to twelve inches fell during this phase along the lakeshore. The flow turned strong northwest later Friday and remained so through Saturday. This flow was unusually cold for November but very dry, so multiple bands formed off Lake Ontario and continued for 36 to 48 hours. Total snowfall for the entire event exceeded a foot over most of Chautauqua County. Eight to fourteen inches fell for the period from Wayne to Oswego counties. Specific snowfall reports included: 18 at Mayville, 16 at Westfield, 14 at Jamestown and West Monroe; 12 inches at Cherry Hill; 11 at Dunkirk; 10 at Ripley, Oswego and Palymra; and 8 at Cato.
Heavy rain caused localized flooding over portions of north-central Pennsylvania during the evening of February 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flooding in and around Genesee, with reports of several small streams out of their banks, and a number of flooded basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant ice accretion occurred across the northern tier of central Pennsylvania as a broad area of precipitation overran a shallow sub-freezing airmass entrenched near the surface. Ice accumulations ranged from one-quarter to one inch (thickness) and brought down numerous trees and power lines. Several power outages were also reported across north-central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Utility Company in Warren County reported numerous power lines down across the northern portion of the county. COOP observer near Sugar Grove reported one-quarter inch ice accretion on trees and structures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant ice accretion occurred across the northern tier of central Pennsylvania as a broad area of precipitation overran a shallow sub-freezing airmass entrenched near the surface. Ice accumulations ranged from one-quarter to one inch (thickness) and brought down numerous trees and power lines. Several power outages were also reported across north-central Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Kane reported one-quarter inch ice accretion on trees and power lines. McKean County 911 center along with PennDot reported numerous trees and power lines down county-wide. Total ice accumulations ranged from one-quarter to one-half inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low that developed off of New Zealand moving east generated heavy swells resulting in high surf that impacted the south shores of the Samoan Islands from February 07th through February 11th.  No significant damages were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High Surf Advisories were posted for all south facing shores of the island of Tutuila. No damage or life lost was reported.

A low pressure system moved into the western Great Lakes on the 14th, along an arctic cold front.  Most of the associated snow in Northern Michigan was light, but a narrow band of heavy snow impacted parts of Central Lower Michigan.  Manistee picked up a foot of snow, while Wellston received almost ten inches.

An upper level disturbance crossing Colorado on February 8th tightened the mid level pressure gradient, which mixed down to the surface, resulting in isolated high winds in Los Alamos and near Ruidoso.

An upper level disturbance crossing Colorado on February 8th tightened the mid level pressure gradient, which mixed down to the surface, resulting in isolated high winds in Los Alamos and near Ruidoso.
On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across Western Montana and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe weather spotters reported between 9 and 11 inches of new snowfall accumulations in the areas surrounding Hamilton. In addition, wind gusts between 22 mph and 32 mph were observed across the Bitterroot Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across Western Montana and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lolo Pass received 6 to 7 inches of new snowfall accumulations in a 12 hour period. Lost Trail Pass received 10 to 12 inches of new snowfall accumulations during the entire event. In addition, gusty winds between 23 and 37 mph were observed throughout the mountains during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather observers in Pierce and Elk River reported 8 to 12 inches of new snowfall accumulations. In addition, nearby automated weather stations reported wind gusts between 20 mph and 29 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The weather observer at Powell reported 9 inches of new snowfall accumulations. The automated weather station at Lolo Pass reported 6 inches of new snowfall accumulations. In addition, nearby automated weather stations reported wind gusts to 29 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed in the wake of a cold front and became heavy at times for the northwest wind snowbelts from the 3rd into the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Ironwood measured 12 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow developed in the wake of a cold front and became heavy at times for the northwest wind snowbelts from the 3rd into the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Rockland measured eight inches of snow in 12 hours and a storm total snowfall of 19.1 inches ending on the evening of the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure traveled from the Great Lakes across New England during February 5th. Snow overspread Vermont just after Midnight on the 5th and mixed with sleet and freezing rain around dawn before ending around midday. Combined snow and sleet accumulations across central and eastern Vermont was 3 to 6 inches. Some specific snowfall totals include; 6 inches in Brookfield and Randolph Center (Orange county), Woodstock and White River Junction (Windsor county) with 5 inches in Worcester (Washington county), Bethel (Windsor county), Chelsea (Orange county) and 4 inches in St. Johnsbury (Caledonia county), Island Pond (Essex county), Eden and Morrisville (Lamoille county).

On February 6th, two areas of low pressure traveled along a boundary, previously left by a storm on February 5th. The first low traveled across New York and New England during the morning of February 6th and the next system moved along the southern New England coast during the night of the 6th into the morning hours of the 7th. ||Snow overspread northern New York during the early morning hours of the 6th and tapered off to scattered snow showers by midday. Meanwhile, another area of low pressure moved toward the region during the evening with another period of steady snow that continued into the early morning hours of the 7th. ||Storm total snowfall across the St. Lawrence River Valley was 4 to 7 inches.

Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values dropped between 25 and 30 below zero on the morning of the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values plummeted to 25 to 30 below zero on the morning of the 16th as Marquette area schools closed due to the cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary low pressure trough over central Lake Superior focused heavy lake effect snow showers over Keweenaw County on the 17th into the morning of the 18th. As the trough sagged slowly south...heavy lake effect snow then became focused over north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th into the morning of 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lake Linden observer measured 6 inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary low pressure trough over central Lake Superior focused heavy lake effect snow showers over Keweenaw County on the 17th into the morning of the 18th. As the trough sagged slowly south...heavy lake effect snow then became focused over north central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th into the morning of 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 12 inches of lake effect snow in Deerton. Most of the snow fell during the afternoon and evening of the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough moving into the Mid Atlantic and Northeast, skirted just north of central North Carolina on the afternoon of August 2nd. The trough passage was close enough to trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms during peak heating. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding across portions of the western Piedmont, the Sandhills, and the southern Coastal Plain of North Carolina.

An upper level trough moving into the Mid Atlantic and Northeast, skirted just north of central North Carolina on the afternoon of August 2nd. The trough passage was close enough to trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms during peak heating. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding across portions of the western Piedmont, the Sandhills, and the southern Coastal Plain of North Carolina.

Another month of below normal rainfall resulted in a persistence of severe to exceptional drought conditions over much of Upstate South Carolina through November. Slight improvements in well water levels continued across the area. Most rivers and major streams continued to flow at less than 10 percent of normal. Voluntary water restrictions continued in most areas, with a few areas continuing to institute mandatory restrictions.

A broad mean layer trough was over the southeast region with a ridge axis across central Florida. An active southwest flow regime tracked the west coast sea breeze inland during the afternoon where it merged with the east coast in the late afternoon and early evening across eastern Florida. High instability and a passing upper level short wave enhanced a few severe storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down on power lines near Salt Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad mean layer trough was over the southeast region with a ridge axis across central Florida. An active southwest flow regime tracked the west coast sea breeze inland during the afternoon where it merged with the east coast in the late afternoon and early evening across eastern Florida. High instability and a passing upper level short wave enhanced a few severe storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down on power lines in Astor Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening upper level trough over the southeast region lifted a deep plume of tropical moisture over the forecast area. A strong low level 850 mb jet of 50-55 knots was in place. Backing winds advected instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico across North Florida which coincided with the passing of a second pre-frontal squall line as it tracked across North Florida and Southeast Georgia in the afternoon. Low level storm relative helicities increased to 200-350 M2/S2. Widespread severe storms developed across the forecast area during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a pool house near the Clinch County Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening upper level trough over the southeast region lifted a deep plume of tropical moisture over the forecast area. A strong low level 850 mb jet of 50-55 knots was in place. Backing winds advected instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico across North Florida which coincided with the passing of a second pre-frontal squall line as it tracked across North Florida and Southeast Georgia in the afternoon. Low level storm relative helicities increased to 200-350 M2/S2. Widespread severe storms developed across the forecast area during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were blown down on power lines from Fargo to 4 miles north of Fargo along Highway 441. The time of damage was based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An inverted trough of low pressure at the surface moved through the state during the early morning of the 20th into the day on the 20th. At the same time, a strong low pressure deepened in the upper atmosphere over and just northeast of the state.  The combination drew down Arctic air into the central U.S. A tight pressure gradient developed between the developing low to the east and Arctic high pressure to the northwest.  Winds increased on the 20th, and continued through most of the day on the 21st.  Sustained wind speeds were in the 25 to 35 MPH range, with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH.  Very little snow fell with the inverted trough, generally an inch or two, however antecedent snow cover was quite high with 7 to 12 inches common.  The winds caused whiteout conditions for an extended period of time as the snow that was loose blew in open areas.  Much of the deeper snow had crusted over, so blizzard conditions were somewhat sporadic and not as widespread as would normally be expected.  The first and second order reporting stations did not meet blizzard criteria outside of occasionally, however law enforcement officials reported visibility frequently reduced to between 10 and 100 feet in open areas.  Travel was therefore not recommended across all of the northern part of Iowa north of U.S. Highway 30.  Roads drifted shut quickly and snowplows were taken off of several roads during the height of the storm.  In addition to the wind, temperatures fell below zero, resulting in dangerous wind chill indices in the -30 to -40 F. range.

An intense trough associated with a low pressure system west of Manua had meandered over the islands on a period of 12 days. A strong high pressure system south of the islands persisted throughout the period. This had prohibited the low pressure system west of Manua to move southward and allowing the trough to meander over the islands for such period. The episode occurred on the 19th to the 30th of November. The average precipitation recorded at the Pago Pago WSO for the period was above 0.50 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous cumulonimbus embedded within the trough were moving southeast along the trough axis on the 28th of November. The Pago Pago WSO recored 1.21 inches of precipitation in less than 30 minutes. Mayors of various villages reported overflow of streams on roads and low lying areas. Debris and pot-holes were the major damages reported by the Department of Public Works. No other damages were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The surface pressure gradient behind a cold front resulted in gusty northwest winds around midnight.  An isolated gust of 59 mph occurred with frontal passage, while most wind gusts remained around 45-50 mph.
Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds in portions of western Maine on the afternoon and evening of June 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm downed trees and power lines in Industry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds in portions of western Maine on the afternoon and evening of June 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm downed trees and power lines in Starks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm downed trees and power lines in the town of New Portland.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm downed trees and wires just north of Bingham.

During December, drought conditions persisted across South Texas, and even intensified in some areas. By the end of December, extreme drought conditions existed across Goliad and Victoria counties. Severe drought conditions existed across Live Oak, Bee, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during December continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during the month, especially with the use of fireworks with the approach of New Years. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During December, drought conditions persisted across South Texas, and even intensified in some areas. By the end of December, extreme drought conditions existed across Goliad and Victoria counties. Severe drought conditions existed across Live Oak, Bee, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during December continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during the month, especially with the use of fireworks with the approach of New Years. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Occurred one mile West of Elk River golf club.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.

A rare early December heavy snow event unfolded across the south starting late on the 10th and really ramping up on the 11th. An upper level low deepened across the northern gulf and produced a swath of snow from southeast Texas, Louisiana, and into Mississippi. This was an unusual snow because temperatures ranged from 32 to 35 degrees where the snow fell. The upper low provided its own cold air and that was enough to allow rain to change to snow, especially where precipitation was heavy. Snowfall amounts ranged from a trace to 9 inches across our service area. The heaviest snow fell within an axis from McComb to Morton Mississippi. Areas that did receive more than 2 or 3 inches had trees and power lines down from the weight of the snow which resulted in many power outages. Roads were slick as well because of the fast accumulation and slushy conditions. Numerous accidents occurred from the hazardous road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sleet began just around 630am quickly changing over to snow before 7 across the eastern half of the county. By 830 moderate had begun to fall across the area with accumulations quickly adding up especially across portions of the county. Around 9 over 2 inches had occurred with moderate to heavy snow still falling with some locations quickly approaching 3 inches by 930. By 11 the community of Hazlehurst in the central part of the county had reported 3 inches with the town of crystal springs further to the north just over 2 inches by noon. Moderate to heavy snow continued to fall across the eastern half of the county for another hour with all winter precipitation coming to an end around 115pm. Total accumulations ranged from a trace in the west to over 4 inches across the eastern half of the county. Large tree branches and some trees came down due to the weight of the snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe (D2) drought conditions continued through November across southern Price county. The lack of significant precipitation this month led to the persistence of the drought conditions.

A broad and weak trough extending from the northeast caribbean northward into the Atlantic...combined with daytime heating and local orographic effects to produce heavy rain across the southwestern sections of Puerto Rico. Radar estimated 2 to 4 inches mainly over the municipalities of Yauco and Sabana Grande.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: River Rio Loco in Yauco was reported out of its banks and flooding areas along the river between Yauco and Sabana Grande.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Six to 12 inches of snow fell in the snowbelt of Iron County. Hurley measured 7 of snow, Whitecap Ski Resort near Upson reported 8 and Gile had 9.5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to 12 inches of lake effect snow fell over the northern half of Iron County. Hurley measured 7 of snow, Whitecap Ski Resort near Upson reported 8, and Gile had 9.5 of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass combined with a strong shortwave moving in from the northwest produced numerous severe thunderstorms across the southern Piedmont and the Sandhills of central North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm knocked a tree onto a house just northeast of Oakboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass combined with a strong shortwave moving in from the northwest produced numerous severe thunderstorms across the southern Piedmont and the Sandhills of central North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell thunderstorm downed trees onto several homes in downtown Fayetteville in the area of Pearl Street and Bragg Boulevard. Other trees were downed on Morganton Road, blocking part of Devane Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front and a potent upper level trough moved into an unstable airmass over central North Carolina during the evening of August 10th. Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed and some of them became severe. There were numerous reports of downed trees and up to quarter size hail. Torrential rains also caused flash flooding in Cumberland and Sampson counties during the early morning hours of August 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three separate farmers in northwestern Alamance County reported significant tobacco crop damage due to penny size hail, including 40 acres and and 25 acres destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front and a potent upper level trough moved into an unstable airmass over central North Carolina during the evening of August 10th. Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed and some of them became severe. There were numerous reports of downed trees and up to quarter size hail. Torrential rains also caused flash flooding in Cumberland and Sampson counties during the early morning hours of August 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on Highway 501 north of Laurinburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low that developed off of New Zealand moving east generated heavy swells resulting in high surf that impacted the south shores of the Samoan Islands from February 07th through February 11th.  No significant damages were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High Surf Advisories were posted for all south facing shores of the island of Tutuila. No damage or life lost was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast and moved up the east coast southeast of Nantucket producing snow, rain, and ice across Southern New England. Widespread two to four inch rainfall amounts resulted in small stream and poor drainage flooding as well as some minor river flooding. In addition, there was some minor wind damage from strong northeast winds, especially along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 114 near Greenville Road was flooded in Cranston.  Also, Natick and Wilbur Avenues and Fletcher Streets were impassable due to flooding and the Meshanicut Valley construction site was washed out.  The Natick Avenue bridge was closed to all traffic because of severe erosion caused by the heavy rain.  Several basements were flooded in Scituate.  In addition, Route 116 near the reservoir was flooded with 18 inches of water flowing over the road.  In Johnston, severe erosion on the sides of the Plainfield Pike was reported with 12 inches of water flooding portions of the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over the North Slope and moderate low pressure over the Gulf of Alaska created moderate winds near the Alaska-Canada border, and with cold temperatures this resulted in a period of Extreme Wind Chill, as reported by the Remote Automated Weather Station at Eagle, where the Wind Chill reach -70 F. Sustained Wind speeds were 20 to 30 mph during the event. Event continued into March.

A storm along the Pacific northwest coast moved south and strengthened into a closed low over northern Baja California on the 14th. The storm moved east on the 15th and crossed extreme southern New Mexico on the 16th. The result was a band of significant snowfall, primarily across east central New Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A general area of 3 to 7 inches of snow fell over the northern portions of the Central High Plains, including southeast Santa Fe county and southwest San Miguel county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm along the Pacific northwest coast moved south and strengthened into a closed low over northern Baja California on the 14th. The storm moved east on the 15th and crossed extreme southern New Mexico on the 16th. The result was a band of significant snowfall, primarily across east central New Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to 6 inches of snow fell over Guadalupe county early on the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm along the Pacific northwest coast moved south and strengthened into a closed low over northern Baja California on the 14th. The storm moved east on the 15th and crossed extreme southern New Mexico on the 16th. The result was a band of significant snowfall, primarily across east central New Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of snow was reported in far northwest De Baca county on the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of storms crossed New Mexico on the 25th, bringing high winds to several locations from late on the 24th through the morning of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Las Vegas ASOS also reported a sustained wind speed of 43 mph at 1053pm on the 24th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of storms crossed New Mexico on the 25th, bringing high winds to several locations from late on the 24th through the morning of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cannon AFB ASOS also reported a sustained wind speed of 40 mph at 855am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system moved from the southwest United States and into the southern plains during the day.  A very unstable airmass was noted across the four state region with abundant low level wind shear and deep layer shear in the mid levels of the atmosphere. A dry line moved into southeast Oklahoma and northeast Texas by late afternoon with scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms developing ahead of the dry line across the region.  Thunderstorms produced strong and damaging wind gusts along with large hail across most of the region.
An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters from Traunik to Trenary and east to Melstrand reported whiteout conditions in heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow along with frequent wind gusts to 35 mph or greater on the 6th.  At least a foot of snow was reported at Traunik and Melstrand during the blizzard event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were extrapolated over northern Schoolcraft County on the 6th due to the blizzard conditions reported near Shingleton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front blasted portions of Upper Michigan with blizzard to near-blizzard conditions and occasional heavy snow on the 6th and 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Occasional whiteout conditions were reported across the county as winds gusted over 30 mph at times. The spotter five miles west of Houghton reported 6 inches of snow in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands dropped locally heavy snow from Rockland and Mass City to Twin Lakes on the 11th and 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Rockland and Mass City reported eight inches of snow in the 12-hour period ending at 9 pm on the 11th. The spotter in Rockland reported four inches of snow between 530 pm and 9 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands dropped locally heavy snow from Rockland and Mass City to Twin Lakes on the 11th and 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Twin Lakes measured 9.5 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mohawk observer reported whiteout conditions throughout the day.  Keweenaw County schools were closed on the 15th due to the blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure lifted north from the Tennessee valley and spread initially snow, then a mix of snow, freezing rain and sleet, across parts of the region. Snowfalls ranged from five to eleven inches followed by a couple inches of sleet or a coating of ice.

Thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a warm front over east central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon hours of February 5th.  Many of the thunderstorms on either side of the front produced heavy rains and flooding.  The storms to the south of the warm front also produced damaging winds and hail, especially along and south of the I-70 corridor.  The flooding produced numerous road closures across the region, while the winds produced primarily tree, power line and power pole damage.  However, several structures received minor, mainly roofing damage and one mobile home was destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Salt Fork River was over its banks near Sidney.  Also, many streets in Sidney had over a foot of water flowing across them, causing multiple stalled cars.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low pressure system combined with surface temperatures near the freezing mark resulted in  the development of severe thunderstorms across the Big Country that produced large hail.  At times, the large hail occurred simultaneously with the freezing rain.
An arctic cold front dropped out of Canada southward into central Montana accompanied by strong winds and a period of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds, snow and blowing snow accompanied a cold frontal passage. This created icy road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving storm system crossed the area on February 7th, bringing some reports of high winds and heavy snow, mainly to higher elevations of Central Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 58 mph were accompanied by snow and blowing snow at mesowest observation site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving storm system crossed the area on February 7th, bringing some reports of high winds and heavy snow, mainly to higher elevations of Central Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten inches of snow fell over an 18 hour period at Copper Camp Snotel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system produced strong winds on February 7th over much of Central Montana, with one severe wind gust at the Helena Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe wind gust observed at Helena Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system, travelling across southern Alberta, generated strong winds over much of Central Montana on February 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds of 40 mph measured at Denton DOT wind sensor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough moving into the Mid Atlantic and Northeast, skirted just north of central North Carolina on the afternoon of August 2nd. The trough passage was close enough to trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms during peak heating. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding across portions of the western Piedmont, the Sandhills, and the southern Coastal Plain of North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was knocked down onto Conrad Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough moving into the Mid Atlantic and Northeast, skirted just north of central North Carolina on the afternoon of August 2nd. The trough passage was close enough to trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms during peak heating. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding across portions of the western Piedmont, the Sandhills, and the southern Coastal Plain of North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two 40 to 50 foot white pine trees were snapped off about a third of the way off the ground just west of Winston-Salem.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough moving into the Mid Atlantic and Northeast, skirted just north of central North Carolina on the afternoon of August 2nd. The trough passage was close enough to trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms during peak heating. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding across portions of the western Piedmont, the Sandhills, and the southern Coastal Plain of North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and power lines were downed across northern Davidson County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening upper level trough over the southeast region lifted a deep plume of tropical moisture over the forecast area. A strong low level 850 mb jet of 50-55 knots was in place. Backing winds advected instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico across North Florida which coincided with the passing of a second pre-frontal squall line as it tracked across North Florida and Southeast Georgia in the afternoon. Low level storm relative helicities increased to 200-350 M2/S2. Widespread severe storms developed across the forecast area during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A retired NWS employee reported a billboard was destroyed near Mariners Village about 6 miles east of Interstate 95 near Highway 40. The time of damage was based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Arctic air mass was retreating northeastward out of the region. Strong mid-level warm advection and a weak disturbance in southwest flow provided support for light precipitation. Temperatures were still below freezing when the precipitation initially tracked across far northwest Georgia.  Brief showers of moderate to heavy sleet fell across Dade, Walker, and Whitfield counties during the mid and late morning hours on the 23rd.  Some roads, especially in Dade county, became slick and hazardous for a few hours during the morning, especially Georgia Highway 136 and roads in the Lookout Mountain area.  A couple of traffic accidents occurred as a result of the slick roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Dade County 911 Center reported some sleet and ice accumulation on Georgia Highway 136 and in the Lookout Mountain area.  A couple of accidents occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Arctic air mass was retreating northeastward out of the region. Strong mid-level warm advection and a weak disturbance in southwest flow provided support for light precipitation. Temperatures were still below freezing when the precipitation initially tracked across far northwest Georgia.  Brief showers of moderate to heavy sleet fell across Dade, Walker, and Whitfield counties during the mid and late morning hours on the 23rd.  Some roads, especially in Dade county, became slick and hazardous for a few hours during the morning, especially Georgia Highway 136 and roads in the Lookout Mountain area.  A couple of traffic accidents occurred as a result of the slick roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Whitfield County 911 Center reported that sleet fell off and on during the mid and late morning hours.  Brief heavy sleet showers were observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the state during the early morning hours of the 27th.  Temperatures fell from the 50s into the upper 20s to low 30s within an hour or two.  The cold air was very shallow with warm air continuing to stream into the state.  A large area of thunderstorms developed on the cold side of the cold frontal boundary.  The rain fell into the cold air at the surface, resulting in widespread glazing across much of the southeast half of the Des Moines CWA as temperatures had fallen into the 20s by the time the thunderstorms moved through.  Ice accumulated quite quickly with one quarter inch amounts quite widespread.  Spotty one half inch amounts were reported over parts of central, south central, and southeast Iowa as thunderstorms produced heavier rainfall in those areas.  Scattered power outages were reported across the area and roadways became treacherous due to the icing.  Overall, damage was not all that extensive as the areas that received half inch amounts of ice were relatively small.

Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds in portions of western Maine on the afternoon and evening of June 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm downed trees and wires just north of Cornville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved out of eastern New Hampshire and into western Maine during the early afternoon of June 17th. As in New Hampshire, these storms were almost exclusively large hail producers with numerous reports of 1 to 1.75 inch hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced 1 inch hail in West Baldwin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved out of eastern New Hampshire and into western Maine during the early afternoon of June 17th. As in New Hampshire, these storms were almost exclusively large hail producers with numerous reports of 1 to 1.75 inch hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced 1 inch hail in Eustis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved out of eastern New Hampshire and into western Maine during the early afternoon of June 17th. As in New Hampshire, these storms were almost exclusively large hail producers with numerous reports of 1 to 1.75 inch hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A COOP observer reported 1 inch hail in Eustis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southwestern lower Michigan experienced a mix of precipitation from the afternoon of December the 8th through the 9th. Due to warmer temperatures farther south near the I-94 corridor, precipitation was mainly rain with some freezing rain across that area. ||The first burst of precipitation spread northeast over southwest lower Michigan during the early evening hours of the 8th. Near the I-94 corridor freezing rain in the evening changed to rain overnight as warmer air was transported north into the region. Approximately 5 to 8 inches of new snow fell north of a Muskegon to Mount Pleasant line by early Tuesday morning.||Another upper disturbance approached Southwest Lower Michigan during the day of Tuesday the 9th while a cold front moved slowly southeast across the area. Many areas saw a change from rain or freezing rain to snow immediately behind the front. However, this snow only lasted a couple hours at most spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to eight inches of snow along with a little bit of sleet and freezing rain was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: November brought several rain events to southern California, but not enough to have an impact on the drought. The statewide drought declaration made in early June continues. A water shortage emergency (stage 1) remains in effect for San Diego with a call for voluntary water conservation, however, no water shortages have been reported. Mandatory cutbacks have already started for some farmers in San Diego County, and could be extended to others by early next year. ||The USDA granted a Secretarial Disaster Designation for the county of San Diego, Orange, and Riverside due to agricultural losses cause by drought. Emergency, low interest loans have been made available to family-sized farms and ranches. Losses to range lands have been qualified at greater than 40%.||This resulted in D1 (Moderate Drought) classification by the U.S. Drought Monitor for Orange County, and D2 (Severe Drought) classification for the rest of the CWA.

Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.
A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Utility poles were snapped and street lights were blown down near the intersection of US Highway 1 and US Highway 82.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were blown down at the NOAA Weather Radio transmitter site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A utility company reported a several trees down between Nahunta and Waynesville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down near highway 301 with power outages to 100 customers reported by the local utility company.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A power line was reported down near North View Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A church steeple was blown off at intersection of Red Oak Road and Highway 203. Reports were also received of power lines and trees down at the intersection of Red Oak Road and Reese Road. Also small out buildings were blown over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A several power lines were blown down and minor structure damage occurred to a building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another month of below normal rainfall resulted in a persistence of severe to exceptional drought conditions over northeast Georgia through November. Slight improvements in well water levels continued across the area. Most rivers and major streams continued to flow at less than 10 percent of normal.  Voluntary water restrictions continued in most areas, with a few areas continuing to institute mandatory restrictions.

A strong trough of low pressure in the upper atmosphere moved into the southwest U.S. late on the 17th and early on the 18th.  The system was very fast moving with a strong jet of 165 kts streaming up the east side of the trough.  A short wave ejected out of the trough and raced northeast through the central U.S., reaching Illinois by the morning of the 19th.  Low pressure at the surface formed over western Kansas during the afternoon of the 18th. It moved to northeast Kansas by evening, and to near Burlington, IA by sunrise on the 19th.  A strong low level jet pushed moisture over a polar airmass that was in place over Iowa.  In addition, the atmosphere became quite unstable for December over the state, resulting in the development of thunderstorms over a large part of Iowa during the overnight hours of the 18th into the 19th.  Temperatures over southern Iowa remained in the 20s through the event, though the cold layer was quite shallow.  Temperatures aloft rose well above freezing, thus most of the precipitation that fell came in the form of freezing rain.  The freezing rain turned to sleet and snow briefly before ending.  Heavy ice accumulations occurred over southern Iowa, especially the southwest and southeast parts of the DSM CWA.  Ice accrual reached one half inch over Davis County, and around 0.6 inches in Adams Counties for the heaviest amounts.  Most of the area received between 0.25 and 0.4 inches of ice.  Spotty power outages were reported, however much of the power problems were mitigated by efforts the previous summer with tree trimming by the power utilities. Roads became very icy with all roads 100% ice covered.  Nearly all schools and many activities were cancelled for the 19th due to the ice.

An inverted trough of low pressure at the surface moved through the state during the early morning of the 20th into the day on the 20th. At the same time, a strong low pressure deepened in the upper atmosphere over and just northeast of the state.  The combination drew down Arctic air into the central U.S. A tight pressure gradient developed between the developing low to the east and Arctic high pressure to the northwest.  Winds increased on the 20th, and continued through most of the day on the 21st.  Sustained wind speeds were in the 25 to 35 MPH range, with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH.  Very little snow fell with the inverted trough, generally an inch or two, however antecedent snow cover was quite high with 7 to 12 inches common.  The winds caused whiteout conditions for an extended period of time as the snow that was loose blew in open areas.  Much of the deeper snow had crusted over, so blizzard conditions were somewhat sporadic and not as widespread as would normally be expected.  The first and second order reporting stations did not meet blizzard criteria outside of occasionally, however law enforcement officials reported visibility frequently reduced to between 10 and 100 feet in open areas.  Travel was therefore not recommended across all of the northern part of Iowa north of U.S. Highway 30.  Roads drifted shut quickly and snowplows were taken off of several roads during the height of the storm.  In addition to the wind, temperatures fell below zero, resulting in dangerous wind chill indices in the -30 to -40 F. range.

A complex weather situation was in place during the overnight hours of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.  A warm front was positioned to the south of Iowa.  Meanwhile, a secondary cold front dropped into the north central  U.S. and stretched from eastern Montana into southern Minnesota.  The upper flow was northwest and quite conducive for MCS development as considerable moisture transport took place over Iowa.  Initially, an area of thunderstorms formed over south central Iowa.  The storms remained below severe limits as they tracked east-southeast out of the CWA.  A strong thunderstorm complex developed over western South Dakota during the night and propagated southeast, along with the upper air northwest flow, into Iowa.  The MCS became linear in nature as it moved out of northwest Iowa into the central sections of the state.  Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in several counties, with urban street flooding along the length of the line.  Rainfall rates of one to two inches in one half hour or less were reported.  A few areas received 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Appanoose County was quite hard hit with water flowing over the roads two feet deep.  The main severe mode of the system was the high winds.  There were numerous reports of 60 to 70 MPH winds.  The entire length of the line produced 40 to 50 MPH winds however.  Hail was somewhat limited as the freezing level was over 14,000 feet.  Following the passage of the line, high winds became a problem as a wake low developed.  Winds gusted to 58 MPH in Story County at Colo and wind damage was reported in Polk County at Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Raccoon River was flooding over Highway 169.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Additional heavy rainfall on the 25th and 26th continued to add problems to an already waterlogged state.  For the most part, the rain fell over parts of central into the southern parts of Iowa.  This renewed flooding along rivers across the south, however the flooding was considerably less than that experienced earlier in the month.  Damage for the most part was additional agricultural damage.
Early evening thunderstorms on the 6th downed several trees and power lines across portions of Worth and Lee counties in southwest Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were down near the intersection of State Roads 32 and 33.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early evening thunderstorms on the 6th downed several trees and power lines across portions of Worth and Lee counties in southwest Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were down near Philema Road and State Road 32.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure lifted north from the Tennessee valley and spread initially snow, then a mix of snow, freezing rain and sleet, across parts of the region. Snowfalls ranged from five to eleven inches followed by a couple inches of sleet or a coating of ice.

Low pressure lifted north from the Tennessee valley and spread initially snow, then a mix of snow, freezing rain and sleet, across parts of the region. Snowfalls ranged from five to eleven inches followed by a couple inches of sleet or a coating of ice.

Bands of lake snows developed by mid to late afternoon of the 10th east of Lake Ontario and became intense Sunday night and most of Monday. The bands started across northern Oswego county and the Tug Hill, edged southward into central Oswego county for much of Monday before lifting north a bit again Monday night and shutting down overnight into Tuesday morning. This event was exacerbated by very strong winds Sunday night into Monday morning which resulted in many whiteouts and road closures, including I-81. The State University of New York at Oswego cancelled classes on Monday the 11th. This was the most severe lake effect event of the 07-08 winter season in regard to winds, visibilities and frigid temperatures which were just above zero, with wind chills of -20, dangerous conditions. Specific snowfalls reported: 41 inches at Minetto, 26 inches at Mexico, 24 inches at Oswego, 20 inches at Pulaski, and 17 inches Boonville.
