A fast moving storm system brought high winds to portions of the Northern Rocky Mountain Front on February 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe wind gust measured at Two Medicine DOT wind sensor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong trough of low pressure in the upper atmosphere moved into the southwest U.S. late on the 17th and early on the 18th.  The system was very fast moving with a strong jet of 165 kts streaming up the east side of the trough.  A short wave ejected out of the trough and raced northeast through the central U.S., reaching Illinois by the morning of the 19th.  Low pressure at the surface formed over western Kansas during the afternoon of the 18th. It moved to northeast Kansas by evening, and to near Burlington, IA by sunrise on the 19th.  A strong low level jet pushed moisture over a polar airmass that was in place over Iowa.  In addition, the atmosphere became quite unstable for December over the state, resulting in the development of thunderstorms over a large part of Iowa during the overnight hours of the 18th into the 19th.  Temperatures over southern Iowa remained in the 20s through the event, though the cold layer was quite shallow.  Temperatures aloft rose well above freezing, thus most of the precipitation that fell came in the form of freezing rain.  The freezing rain turned to sleet and snow briefly before ending.  Heavy ice accumulations occurred over southern Iowa, especially the southwest and southeast parts of the DSM CWA.  Ice accrual reached one half inch over Davis County, and around 0.6 inches in Adams Counties for the heaviest amounts.  Most of the area received between 0.25 and 0.4 inches of ice.  Spotty power outages were reported, however much of the power problems were mitigated by efforts the previous summer with tree trimming by the power utilities. Roads became very icy with all roads 100% ice covered.  Nearly all schools and many activities were cancelled for the 19th due to the ice.

An inverted trough of low pressure at the surface moved through the state during the early morning of the 20th into the day on the 20th. At the same time, a strong low pressure deepened in the upper atmosphere over and just northeast of the state.  The combination drew down Arctic air into the central U.S. A tight pressure gradient developed between the developing low to the east and Arctic high pressure to the northwest.  Winds increased on the 20th, and continued through most of the day on the 21st.  Sustained wind speeds were in the 25 to 35 MPH range, with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH.  Very little snow fell with the inverted trough, generally an inch or two, however antecedent snow cover was quite high with 7 to 12 inches common.  The winds caused whiteout conditions for an extended period of time as the snow that was loose blew in open areas.  Much of the deeper snow had crusted over, so blizzard conditions were somewhat sporadic and not as widespread as would normally be expected.  The first and second order reporting stations did not meet blizzard criteria outside of occasionally, however law enforcement officials reported visibility frequently reduced to between 10 and 100 feet in open areas.  Travel was therefore not recommended across all of the northern part of Iowa north of U.S. Highway 30.  Roads drifted shut quickly and snowplows were taken off of several roads during the height of the storm.  In addition to the wind, temperatures fell below zero, resulting in dangerous wind chill indices in the -30 to -40 F. range.

An Arctic air mass was retreating northeastward out of the region. Strong mid-level warm advection and a weak disturbance in southwest flow provided support for light precipitation. Temperatures were still below freezing when the precipitation initially tracked across far northwest Georgia.  Brief showers of moderate to heavy sleet fell across Dade, Walker, and Whitfield counties during the mid and late morning hours on the 23rd.  Some roads, especially in Dade county, became slick and hazardous for a few hours during the morning, especially Georgia Highway 136 and roads in the Lookout Mountain area.  A couple of traffic accidents occurred as a result of the slick roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Walker County 911 Center reported that some sleet was observed in the northern and western parts of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave and frontal system brought strong winds to the coast of northwest Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds were reported in Garibaldi, with recorded sustained winds of 36 kt as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave and frontal system brought strong winds to the coast of northwest Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds were reported in Waldport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved through portions of northern and central New Hampshire during the late afternoon of June 10th. These storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm downed trees and power lines in Hanover.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved through portions of northern and central New Hampshire during the late afternoon of June 10th. These storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm downed trees and power lines in the town of Lyme.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds in portions of western Maine on the afternoon and evening of June 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced 1.25 inch hail in Harrison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds in portions of western Maine on the afternoon and evening of June 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced 1 inch hail in Bryant Pond.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the state during the early morning hours of the 27th.  Temperatures fell from the 50s into the upper 20s to low 30s within an hour or two.  The cold air was very shallow with warm air continuing to stream into the state.  A large area of thunderstorms developed on the cold side of the cold frontal boundary.  The rain fell into the cold air at the surface, resulting in widespread glazing across much of the southeast half of the Des Moines CWA as temperatures had fallen into the 20s by the time the thunderstorms moved through.  Ice accumulated quite quickly with one quarter inch amounts quite widespread.  Spotty one half inch amounts were reported over parts of central, south central, and southeast Iowa as thunderstorms produced heavier rainfall in those areas.  Scattered power outages were reported across the area and roadways became treacherous due to the icing.  Overall, damage was not all that extensive as the areas that received half inch amounts of ice were relatively small.

A sharp cold front brought an abrupt change to colder conditions and the season's first lake effect episode. As is usually the case in early season events, elevation played a major role in snowfall accumulations. As colder air filtered in, winds began to veer more westerly, and rain mixed with and turned to wet snow during the late afternoon and evening of the 9th. Wet snow then fell at varying rates though most of the day Monday (10th) across the higher elevations of the southern tier before ending Monday evening.  Total snowfall off Lake Erie topped out in the 8 to 12 inch range along the Chautauqua Ridge and gradually dropped off to the east and southeast. Specific snowfall reports included:  11 at Mayville, 10 at Stockton, 9 at Sinclairville, and 8 at Ellicottville. Off Lake Ontario, a similar scenario played out, but several hours later. Snow began in earnest late Sunday night and continued until near midnight Monday night, but it was mainly focused on the Tug Hill and central Lewis County. Heavy amounts were restricted to the central and northern Tug Hill with over a foot reported, but only 5 inches fell in the valley at Lowville. Specific reports included: 14 at Hooker, 6 at Highmarket, and 5 at Lowville.

A strong low pressure system produced very windy conditions across southwestern lower Michigan on December the 28th.  The highest wind gusts occurred mainly before sunrise, however very gusty conditions persisted well into the afternoon.  Hundreds of thousands of people across the state lost power at least temporarily due to high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated at 60 mph were recorded in Ottawa county.  Several trees and power lines were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper atmospheric low pressure system moved from south central Canada to the Great Lakes during the night of December 20th into the morning of December 21st. At the surface, the primary low associated with this upper level feature moved into the Great Lakes and weakened on the  21st. Meanwhile, a secondary coastal low developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast during the morning of the 21st and tracked into the Gulf of Maine during that evening.||Snow overspread Vermont around daybreak on the 21st and fell heavy at times during the late morning and early afternoon hours before dissipating during the evening. Snowfall accumulations of 6 to 10 inches were common across western Vermont with 10 to 18 inches across central and eastern Vermont. Some specific snowfall totals include; 18 inches in Marshfield (Washington), St. Johnsbury (Caledonia county), Rochester (Windsor county) and Randolph Center (Orange county) with 15 inches in Moretown and Waterbury Center (Washington county), North Promfret (Windsor county), Island Pond (Essex county). ||This was the second significant snowfall within 36 hours which led to additional vehicle accidents and exhausted snow removal resources. Snowfall totals in excess of 24 inches within 36 hours led to blocked ventilation pipes and some carbon monoxide injuries as well as a few collapsed small farm structures due to the weight of the snow.

A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind lifted partially off of a large distribution center building on Peggy Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure developed just south of North Carolina during the early morning hours of November 5th. The low pressure system moved northeast along the North Carolina coast during the day. This low produced very heavy rain and strong gusty winds along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain of 5 to 7 inches produced flooding on Highway 12 between Oregon Inlet and Avon. Water up to 8 inches deep reported on the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought snow to the Northern Great Lakes region.  Locally heavy snow developed in parts of Northwest Lower Michigan on the evening of the 30th, with Lake Ann picking up 13 inches of snow by morning of the 1st.  However, for most of the region, the heaviest snow fell on the 1st.  Thus, a more complete disucssion of this event will be contained in Storm Data for December 2008.
Subfreezing temperatures combined with sparse low level moisture to produce isolated incidences of freezing rain in eastern Kentucky on December 26.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain was reported in Booneville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Subfreezing temperatures combined with sparse low level moisture to produce isolated incidences of freezing rain in eastern Kentucky on December 26.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain was reported in Sandy Hook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tightening pressure gradient ahead of an approaching cold front led to strong, gusty winds across Eastern Kentucky on December 9th. Many wind gusts between 45 and 50 mph were reported. These winds brought down a few trees in McCreary County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed numerous trees and power lines in and around Whitley City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tightening pressure gradient ahead of an approaching cold front led to strong, gusty winds across Eastern Kentucky on December 9th. Many wind gusts between 45 and 50 mph were reported. These winds brought down a few trees in McCreary County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees at least 6 inches in diameter were broken off by strong winds 20 to 30 feet above the ground. Wrist sized branches were also broken off trees by the wind. Numerous power outages were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow fell mainly across the higher elevations of the northern mountains from late morning through the afternoon. Accumulations were mainly confined to the higher peaks, where up to 3 inches was reported. The valleys saw little more than a dusting.

Tropical Storm Fay moved north out of Caribbean Sea, then cut across south and central Florida into the Atlantic Ocean. Fay then slowly curved west and made landfall in the vicinity for Flagler Beach and Daytona Beach on Aug 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Fay made landfall well south of the Georgia coast with strong winds, high tides, high surf and heavy rainfall impacting Glynn and Camden Counties. Heavy rainfall spread inland as Fay moved west causing some flooding across portions of interior southeast Georgia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms impacted southern Missouri with large hail, damaging winds, and a couple of tornadoes.  The two tornadoes were confirmed by a National Weather Service storm survey over Douglas County, including northern sections of the city of Ava.

A few clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms impacted southern Missouri with large hail, damaging winds, and a couple of tornadoes.  The two tornadoes were confirmed by a National Weather Service storm survey over Douglas County, including northern sections of the city of Ava.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts downed several tree limbs.

A strong northerly wind event produced gusty winds across the mountains of Santa Barbara, Ventura and Los Angeles counties and the south coast of Santa Barbara county. Wind gusts in excess of 70 MPH were reported in some locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty north winds affected the mountains of Ventura county near the  Interstate 5 corridor. North winds gusting in excess of 60 MPH were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of offshore winds affected Southern California. North to northeast wind gusts in excess of 65 MPH were reported in some areas. The strong winds, combined with very dry conditions, helped fuel two significant wildfires. The Tea Fire, near Montecito in Santa Barbara county, burned 1,940 acres. The Sayre Fire, north of Sylmar in Los Angeles county, burned 11,262 acres. Both fires produced significant loss of residences.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds affected the Santa Ynez range in southern Santa Barbara county. The RAWS sensor at Montecito reported sustained winds between 40 and 55 MPH with gusts as high as 72 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three men drowned from rip currents at Panama City Beach on August 3 and 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Georgia man and his two daughters were rescued from the surf by the Panama City Beach police.  The girls survived, however the man later died at a local hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Three men drowned from rip currents at Panama City Beach on August 3 and 4.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An Alabama man and histwo children becmae distressed in the surf, and the children's grandfather went into the water to assist them.  The grandfather got caught up in the strong current.  Beach Surf and Rescue personnel and nearby beach vendors were able to rescue all four victims.  However, paramedics were unable to revive the father, and the grandfather was taken to a local hospital and later released.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms on the 7th dropped penny to golfball hail in near Tallahassee and produced wind damage north of Madison.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a power line and snapped the utility pole across State Road 145 and Persimmon Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms on the 7th produced a few reports of damaging winds in Houston County and lightning damage to some property in Henry County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms on the 7th produced a few reports of damaging winds in Houston County and lightning damage to some property in Henry County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck two house trailers.  Fire from the trailers spread to a nearby vehicle and grass field.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Butte Falls woman died early Wednesday 11/12/2008 when her minivan veered off Butte Falls Highway and struck a tree. Jackson County deputies identified the woman as Juanita Mae Moore, 66, of Broad Street.||A passing driver spotted the single-vehicle crash in the 11000 block of the highway leading to and from Butte Falls at 7:39 a.m.||Moore's 2003 Pontiac Montana had left the road and hit a tree about 150 feet from the pavement.  The pavement was wet and a light fog blanketed the area of the crash.||The weather was probably a contributing factor, said Sheriff Mike Winters.

The pavement was wet and a light fog blanketed the area of the crash.||The weather was probably a contributing factor, said Sheriff Mike Winters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Marginally severe thunderstorms, mainly producing hail up to the size of quarters, also caused flash flooding in several areas.  A slow moving frontal system was positioned over southern Missouri, allowing for unusual amounts of moisture and modest instability to develop along and south of this feature.  Mostly non-severe thunderstorms developed at random over southern Missouri.  However, two tornadic supercells approached south central Missouri from Arkansas, but failed to produce tornadoes within the Springfield, Missouri county warning area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads became impassable from flash flooding on the eastern edge of Rolla.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread excessive rainfall impacted almost all of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks during the overnight period of 16 February into 17 February.  Widespread rainfall amounts of one to three and a half inches fell.  The heaviest amounts fell over the upper White River Basin as three and a half inches were observed near Table Rock Lake.  Meanwhile areas of the Osage Plains from southeast Kansas in to west central Missouri measured around an inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous county roads in Howell County experienced flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread excessive rainfall impacted almost all of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks during the overnight period of 16 February into 17 February.  Widespread rainfall amounts of one to three and a half inches fell.  The heaviest amounts fell over the upper White River Basin as three and a half inches were observed near Table Rock Lake.  Meanwhile areas of the Osage Plains from southeast Kansas in to west central Missouri measured around an inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding occurred over county roads and low water crossings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread excessive rainfall impacted almost all of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks during the overnight period of 16 February into 17 February. Meanwhile areas of the Osage Plains from southeast Kansas in to west central Missouri measured around an inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A section of Highway M three miles east of Highway AH experienced flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex weather situation was in place during the overnight hours of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.  A warm front was positioned to the south of Iowa.  Meanwhile, a secondary cold front dropped into the north central  U.S. and stretched from eastern Montana into southern Minnesota.  The upper flow was northwest and quite conducive for MCS development as considerable moisture transport took place over Iowa.  Initially, an area of thunderstorms formed over south central Iowa.  The storms remained below severe limits as they tracked east-southeast out of the CWA.  A strong thunderstorm complex developed over western South Dakota during the night and propagated southeast, along with the upper air northwest flow, into Iowa.  The MCS became linear in nature as it moved out of northwest Iowa into the central sections of the state.  Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in several counties, with urban street flooding along the length of the line.  Rainfall rates of one to two inches in one half hour or less were reported.  A few areas received 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Appanoose County was quite hard hit with water flowing over the roads two feet deep.  The main severe mode of the system was the high winds.  There were numerous reports of 60 to 70 MPH winds.  The entire length of the line produced 40 to 50 MPH winds however.  Hail was somewhat limited as the freezing level was over 14,000 feet.  Following the passage of the line, high winds became a problem as a wake low developed.  Winds gusted to 58 MPH in Story County at Colo and wind damage was reported in Polk County at Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding was reported in Ottumwa.  A number of intersections and low lying areas were under water, including the intersection of Jefferson and Main.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The police department in Grangeville reported whiteout conditions across the Camas Prairie througout the night. In addition, the automated weather station in Grangeville reported wind gusts to 62 mph. US Highway 95 was closed to travel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 6-8, a persistant winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Idaho Department of Transportation reported 10 to 12 inches of new snowfall accumulations along US Highway 93 between Gibbonsville and Lost Trail Pass. In addition, automated weather stations across Eastern Lemhi County reported wind gusts between 28 mph and 45 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds in portions of western Maine on the afternoon and evening of June 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced 0.88 inch hail just west of Bryant Pond.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced damaging winds which brought down several large limbs on a trailer in Mexico.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southwestern lower Michigan experienced a mix of precipitation from the afternoon of December the 8th through the 9th. Due to warmer temperatures farther south near the I-94 corridor, precipitation was mainly rain with some freezing rain across that area. ||The first burst of precipitation spread northeast over southwest lower Michigan during the early evening hours of the 8th. Near the I-94 corridor freezing rain in the evening changed to rain overnight as warmer air was transported north into the region. Approximately 5 to 8 inches of new snow fell north of a Muskegon to Mount Pleasant line by early Tuesday morning.||Another upper disturbance approached Southwest Lower Michigan during the day of Tuesday the 9th while a cold front moved slowly southeast across the area. Many areas saw a change from rain or freezing rain to snow immediately behind the front. However, this snow only lasted a couple hours at most spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to twelve inches of snow was reported.

As colder air filtered in, winds began to veer more westerly, and rain mixed with and turned to wet snow during the late afternoon and evening of the 9th. Wet snow then fell at varying rates though most of the day Monday (10th) across the higher elevations of the southern tier before ending Monday evening.  Total snowfall off Lake Erie topped out in the 8 to 12 inch range along the Chautauqua Ridge and gradually dropped off to the east and southeast. Specific snowfall reports included:  11 at Mayville, 10 at Stockton, 9 at Sinclairville, and 8 at Ellicottville. Off Lake Ontario, a similar scenario played out, but several hours later. Snow began in earnest late Sunday night and continued until near midnight Monday night, but it was mainly focused on the Tug Hill and central Lewis County. Heavy amounts were restricted to the central and northern Tug Hill with over a foot reported, but only 5 inches fell in the valley at Lowville. Specific reports included: 14 at Hooker, 6 at Highmarket, and 5 at Lowville.

Another lake effect event got underway early on Friday 28th in the wake of another weak frontal passage. Off Lake Ontario, the activity focused on the Tug Hill, developing during the morning Friday and continuing through the evening before gradually shifting southward as winds veered early Saturday morning. The activity ended by midday Saturday. Heaviest snows fell across interior northern Oswego county and southern Lewis county where a foot or so fell. Specific reports included: 12 at Redfield and 11 at Highmarket.
Seventy flights were either delayed, diverted, or canceled due to a prolonged period of dense fog at Lindbergh Field.

November brought several rain events to southern California, but not enough to have an impact on the drought. The statewide drought declaration made in early June continues. A water shortage emergency (stage 1) remains in effect for San Diego with a call for voluntary water conservation, however, no water shortages have been reported. Mandatory cutbacks have already started for some farmers in San Diego County, and could be extended to others by early next year. ||The USDA granted a Secretarial Disaster Designation for the county of San Diego, Orange, and Riverside due to agricultural losses cause by drought. Emergency, low interest loans have been made available to family-sized farms and ranches. Losses to range lands have been qualified at greater than 40%.||This resulted in D1 (Moderate Drought) classification by the U.S. Drought Monitor for Orange County, and D2 (Severe Drought) classification for the rest of the CWA.

During November, drought conditions expanded southwest across South Texas. By the end of November, severe drought conditions existed across Bee, Goliad, Victoria, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, Live Oak, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties by the end of November. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during November continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was becoming sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during November. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

By the end of November, severe drought conditions existed across Bee, Goliad, Victoria, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, Live Oak, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties by the end of November. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during November continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was becoming sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during November. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.

Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.

A rare early December heavy snow event unfolded across the south starting late on the 10th and really ramping up on the 11th. An upper level low deepened across the northern gulf and produced a swath of snow from southeast Texas, Louisiana, and into Mississippi. This was an unusual snow because temperatures ranged from 32 to 35 degrees where the snow fell. The upper low provided its own cold air and that was enough to allow rain to change to snow, especially where precipitation was heavy. Snowfall amounts ranged from a trace to 9 inches across our service area. The heaviest snow fell within an axis from McComb to Morton Mississippi. Areas that did receive more than 2 or 3 inches had trees and power lines down from the weight of the snow which resulted in many power outages. Roads were slick as well because of the fast accumulation and slushy conditions. Numerous accidents occurred from the hazardous road conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rain began to change over to sleet around 533am. Light sleet than continued till shortly after 8 before changing back over to rain. Between 720 and 8 light snow mixed with sleet at times with only a few tenths accumulations across southern portions of the county. Total sleet accumulations of up to an inch were reported across the county.

By 1130 am he reported that the snow had accumulated to one half inch and the snowfall intensity had increased. By 101 pm the public reported|that an estimated 3 inches had fallen three miles south of madden. The snow intensity gradually decreased during|the afternoon and exited the region by 830 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another month of below normal rainfall resulted in a persistence of severe to exceptional drought conditions over much of Upstate South Carolina through November. Slight improvements in well water levels continued across the area. Most rivers and major streams continued to flow at less than 10 percent of normal. Voluntary water restrictions continued in most areas, with a few areas continuing to institute mandatory restrictions.

Strong winds developed ahead of an approaching cold front on December 24th. Winds gusted between 40 and 50 mph at times. These winds were enough to bring down a few trees and tree limbs across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large limbs were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain fell across portions of Eastern Kentucky late in the afternoon into the evening hours of December 23rd. Light precipitation started out as sleet, freezing rain, and rain during the afternoon hours. By late afternoon, the precipitation had increased in coverage and intensity, and changed over to freezing rain and rain. Arctic air that had been over the area over the previous couple of days allowed for surface temperatures to remain at or below freezing, even as air temperatures rose to near or slightly above freezing. This created very hazardous travel conditions across the area, with numerous accidents reported. Traffic was backed up on the Mountain Parkway due to accidents caused by icy roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain caused icy roads and several car accidents around the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough moving into the Mid Atlantic and Northeast, skirted just north of central North Carolina on the afternoon of August 2nd. The trough passage was close enough to trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms during peak heating. Some of the storms became severe, producing large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding across portions of the western Piedmont, the Sandhills, and the southern Coastal Plain of North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree was reported down across Arrington Bridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass combined with a strong shortwave moving in from the northwest produced numerous severe thunderstorms across the southern Piedmont and the Sandhills of central North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced a swath of quarter to golf ball size hail across southwest Anson county. One such report of large hail was received near Camden Church Road five miles east northeast of White Store.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass combined with a strong shortwave moving in from the northwest produced numerous severe thunderstorms across the southern Piedmont and the Sandhills of central North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported to the south southwest of Laurinburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very unstable airmass combined with a strong shortwave moving in from the northwest produced numerous severe thunderstorms across the southern Piedmont and the Sandhills of central North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds downed a tree across Highway 117 near Arrington Bridge Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms impacted southern Missouri with large hail, damaging winds, and a couple of tornadoes.  The two tornadoes were confirmed by a National Weather Service storm survey over Douglas County, including northern sections of the city of Ava.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorm wind gusts downed several trees while causing minor damage to an outbuilding at the intersection of Highway J and Highway N.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weather system moved across northwest Kansas producing freezing rain and light snow. Numerous accidents were reported on Interstate 70 in Sherman and Thomas counties as a result of ice accumulations up to 1/8.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain resulted in numerous traffic accidents in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed across Logan and Gove counties around daybreak, producing marginally severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to penny sized hail covered the sidewalk.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed across Logan and Gove counties around daybreak, producing marginally severe hail.
Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon, producing marginally severe hail across Gove and Wichita counties in Kansas.

Thunderstorms developed across western Nebraska and western Kansas during the late afternoon hours.  Numerous hail reports were received from the stronger storms, the largest being golf ball sized hail in Rawlins county, KS.

Thunderstorms developed across western Nebraska and western Kansas during the late afternoon hours.  Numerous hail reports were received from the stronger storms, the largest being golf ball sized hail in Rawlins county, KS.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported dime to quarter size hail that lasted approximately 15 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across eastern Colorado and western Kansas early in the afternoon and moved east and southeast. Numerous hail reports were received, some up to 2 inches in diameter. Several tornadoes occurred in western Kansas, all over open fields.

During December, drought conditions persisted across South Texas, and even intensified in some areas. By the end of December, extreme drought conditions existed across Goliad and Victoria counties. Severe drought conditions existed across Live Oak, Bee, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during December continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during the month, especially with the use of fireworks with the approach of New Years. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds blew tree limbs onto electrical lines, which then ignited fires near Sherman.  A home and other buildings were destroyed and another home damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed power lines and trees across the county sparking  several grass fires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large plate glass window at a bank broke due to strong winds.  Power  outages occurred as power lines were tossed by the wind.  A few small structures were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large wildfire fanned by 40 MPH winds burned more than 1,000 acres north of Hico near Purvis.  No structures were known to have been lost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed across the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds blew several trees down, damaging houses and outbuildings.  Power outages were reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front was slowly moving to the north across Missouri and Illinois. Dense fog formed north of the front reducing visibilities to near zero in many locations.  Several major accidents were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several accidents occurred over Macoupin county due to the dense fog. Around 815 am, a semi hauling steel pipe crashed into a train at the crossing on Illinois Route 4 near Lamb Road.  The truck burst into flames, but the driver was able to escape from the truck.  He sustained moderate burns and was transported to a local hospital.  Also, a two car accident occurred on Illinois Route 108 near the intersection with Standard City Road, just east of Carlinville.  Two occupants sustained minor injuries and were transported to a local hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal band hung over parts of the Bay Area bringing intense rainfall for several hours. The hardest hit areas were the coastal sections of Marin, San Francisco and San Mateo Counties. Rainfall amounts in some of these areas topped over 3 during Friday January 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Neighborhoods in Moss Landing and Montara were flooded and some cars submerged after several hours of drenching heavy rains. Rising flood waters along Pescadero Creek Road foreced about 18 residents out of their homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal band hung over parts of the Bay Area bringing intense rainfall for several hours. The hardest hit areas were the coastal sections of Marin, San Francisco and San Mateo Counties. Rainfall amounts in some of these areas topped over 3 during Friday January 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Ross Valley of Marin County. The Corte Madera Creek near Ross went over its 19 foot flood stage during the evening of January 26th. Evacuations were ordered around San Anselmo and Fairfax and Ross were put on alert.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal band hung over parts of the Bay Area bringing intense rainfall for several hours. The hardest hit areas were the coastal sections of Marin, San Francisco and San Mateo Counties. Rainfall amounts in some of these areas topped over 3 during Friday January 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rain caused flash flooding around Petaluma late Friday night, January 26th. The Petaluma River near Corona Road went over its flood stage of 25.5 feet reaching nearly 30 feet. At least a dozen homes were flooded as were several businesses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced large hail in southwest Maine droppping a brief period of .75 inch hail near Shapleigh.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced .75 inch hail in Shapleigh.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of slow moving showers and thunderstorms produced up to 6 inches of rain in 3 hours resulting in flash flooding in several towns in southeast New Hampshire. Numerous roads were inundated by small streams and many were washed out. Several cars were trapped in rising water in Laconia and several homes were also damaged. Damage was also extensive in Meredith and New Hampton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Laconia area washing out several roads and damaging cars and homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread excessive rainfall impacted almost all of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks during the overnight period of 16 February into 17 February.  Widespread rainfall amounts of one to three and a half inches fell.  The heaviest amounts fell over the upper White River Basin as three and a half inches were observed near Table Rock Lake.  Meanwhile areas of the Osage Plains from southeast Kansas in to west central Missouri measured around an inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A low water crossing on Highway HH two miles north of Highway 64 experienced flash flooding and was impassable to motorists.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a warm front over east central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon hours of February 5th.  Many of the thunderstorms on either side of the front produced heavy rains and flooding.  The storms to the south of the warm front also produced damaging winds and hail, especially along and south of the I-70 corridor.  The flooding produced numerous road closures across the region, while the winds produced primarily tree, power line and power pole damage.  However, several structures received minor, mainly roofing damage and one mobile home was destroyed.

Many of the thunderstorms on either side of the front produced heavy rains and flooding.  The storms to the south of the warm front also produced damaging winds and hail, especially along and south of the I-70 corridor.  The flooding produced numerous road closures across the region, while the winds produced primarily tree, power line and power pole damage.  However, several structures received minor, mainly roofing damage and one mobile home was destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding closed 9th Street in Mattoon between Stinson Avenue and Old State Road.  One vehicle stalled in the high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many streets were flooded on the west side of Effingham.  One vehicle become stuck in high water near the Little Wabash River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex weather situation was in place during the overnight hours of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.  A warm front was positioned to the south of Iowa.  Meanwhile, a secondary cold front dropped into the north central  U.S. and stretched from eastern Montana into southern Minnesota.  The upper flow was northwest and quite conducive for MCS development as considerable moisture transport took place over Iowa.  Initially, an area of thunderstorms formed over south central Iowa.  The storms remained below severe limits as they tracked east-southeast out of the CWA.  A strong thunderstorm complex developed over western South Dakota during the night and propagated southeast, along with the upper air northwest flow, into Iowa.  The MCS became linear in nature as it moved out of northwest Iowa into the central sections of the state.  Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in several counties, with urban street flooding along the length of the line.  Rainfall rates of one to two inches in one half hour or less were reported.  A few areas received 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Appanoose County was quite hard hit with water flowing over the roads two feet deep.  The main severe mode of the system was the high winds.  There were numerous reports of 60 to 70 MPH winds.  The entire length of the line produced 40 to 50 MPH winds however.  Hail was somewhat limited as the freezing level was over 14,000 feet.  Following the passage of the line, high winds became a problem as a wake low developed.  Winds gusted to 58 MPH in Story County at Colo and wind damage was reported in Polk County at Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree damage was reported with 10 to 12 inch limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across southwest Louisiana, producing severe thunderstorms with large hail and damaging winds.
A strong cold front moved across southwest Louisiana, producing severe thunderstorms with large hail and damaging winds.

On February 8-9, another winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather observers in Elk River and Pierce reported 12 inches and 8 inches of new snowfall accumulations, respectively. In addition, several automated weather stations nearby reported wind gusts between 23 mph and 29 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 8-9, another winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Idaho Department of Transportation closed US Highway 95 to emergency travel only over the Whitebird grade due to whiteout conditions. In addition, 6 to 8 inches of new snowfall accumulations were received in Cottonwood.

CZ_NAME: LOWER HELLS CANYON / SALMON RIVER REGION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 8-9, another winter storm moved east across North Central Idaho and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Idaho Department of Transportation closed US Highway 95 to emergency travel only over the Whitebird grade due to whiteout conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 8 and 9, another winter storm moved east across Western Montana and produced heavy snowfall and gusty winds in many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Automated weather stations in the Glacier National Park area reported wind gusts to 25 mph and wind chills that were between -20 degrees and -27 degrees. In addition, a weather observer in Essex reported 6 inches of new snowfall accumulations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On February 13 and 14, a narrow north to south oriented band of snow positioned itself over the U.S. Highway 93 corridor between Ronan and Arlee. Heavy snowfall amounts were observed along this route.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to eight inches of new snowfall accumulations were received along the U.S. Highway 93 route between Saint Ignatius and Arlee during this period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer eight miles southwest of Ontonagon measured 11 inches of snow in the 24-hour period ending at 7 am on the 15th. West winds gusting over 30 mph caused reduced visibility in blowing snow as well. Schools were closed in Ontonagon on the 15th due to the harsh winter conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the state during the early morning hours of the 27th.  Temperatures fell from the 50s into the upper 20s to low 30s within an hour or two.  The cold air was very shallow with warm air continuing to stream into the state.  A large area of thunderstorms developed on the cold side of the cold frontal boundary.  The rain fell into the cold air at the surface, resulting in widespread glazing across much of the southeast half of the Des Moines CWA as temperatures had fallen into the 20s by the time the thunderstorms moved through.  Ice accumulated quite quickly with one quarter inch amounts quite widespread.  Spotty one half inch amounts were reported over parts of central, south central, and southeast Iowa as thunderstorms produced heavier rainfall in those areas.  Scattered power outages were reported across the area and roadways became treacherous due to the icing.  Overall, damage was not all that extensive as the areas that received half inch amounts of ice were relatively small.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms that produced damaging winds and large hail at inland locations earlier in the evening also produced strong winds over Lake Michigan.

Southwestern lower Michigan experienced a mix of precipitation from the afternoon of December the 8th through the 9th. Due to warmer temperatures farther south near the I-94 corridor, precipitation was mainly rain with some freezing rain across that area. ||The first burst of precipitation spread northeast over southwest lower Michigan during the early evening hours of the 8th. Near the I-94 corridor freezing rain in the evening changed to rain overnight as warmer air was transported north into the region. Approximately 5 to 8 inches of new snow fell north of a Muskegon to Mount Pleasant line by early Tuesday morning.||Another upper disturbance approached Southwest Lower Michigan during the day of Tuesday the 9th while a cold front moved slowly southeast across the area. Many areas saw a change from rain or freezing rain to snow immediately behind the front. However, this snow only lasted a couple hours at most spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to ten inches of snow along with a little bit of sleet and freezing rain was reported.

Ice accretion ranged from one tenth to one quarter of an inch, although locally greater amounts of just under one half of an inch were reported across the higher elevations. Since this light wintry mix occurred on a busy travel day, the Sunday after Thanksgiving Day, the impact to travelers was high. ||Numerous minor accidents were reported, especially during the afternoon and evening hours.

A developing low pressure system along the northern Gulf Coast on Saturday November 29th traveled north into the lower Ohio Valley by Sunday morning on November 30th, and then strengthened upon reaching the eastern Great Lakes by Monday morning on December 1st. ||A warm front associated with this system approached from the south during Sunday, producing a widespread light mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain. The precipitation began during the midday hours across western Massachusetts, and eventually changed to plain rain by Sunday evening. ||Snow and sleet amounts were light, generally 1 to 2 inches. Ice accretion ranged from one tenth to one quarter of an inch, although locally greater amounts of just under one half of an inch were reported across the higher elevations. Since this light wintry mix occurred on a busy travel day, the Sunday after Thanksgiving Day, the impact to travelers was high. ||Numerous minor accidents were reported, especially during the afternoon and evening hours.
A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down along path of storm. Vinyl fencing blown down with some shingles ripped off a roof. Two trampolines were  blown a considerable distance.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another month of below normal rainfall resulted in a persistence of severe to exceptional drought conditions over much of Upstate South Carolina through November. Slight improvements in well water levels continued across the area. Most rivers and major streams continued to flow at less than 10 percent of normal. Voluntary water restrictions continued in most areas, with a few areas continuing to institute mandatory restrictions.

A very unstable airmass combined with a strong shortwave moving in from the northwest produced numerous severe thunderstorms across the southern Piedmont and the Sandhills of central North Carolina.
A very unstable airmass combined with a strong shortwave moving in from the northwest produced numerous severe thunderstorms across the southern Piedmont and the Sandhills of central North Carolina.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cumberland County 911 reported several trees down near Autryville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong trough of low pressure in the upper atmosphere moved into the southwest U.S. late on the 17th and early on the 18th.  The system was very fast moving with a strong jet of 165 kts streaming up the east side of the trough.  A short wave ejected out of the trough and raced northeast through the central U.S., reaching Illinois by the morning of the 19th.  Low pressure at the surface formed over western Kansas during the afternoon of the 18th. It moved to northeast Kansas by evening, and to near Burlington, IA by sunrise on the 19th.  A strong low level jet pushed moisture over a polar airmass that was in place over Iowa.  In addition, the atmosphere became quite unstable for December over the state, resulting in the development of thunderstorms over a large part of Iowa during the overnight hours of the 18th into the 19th.  Temperatures over southern Iowa remained in the 20s through the event, though the cold layer was quite shallow.  Temperatures aloft rose well above freezing, thus most of the precipitation that fell came in the form of freezing rain.  The freezing rain turned to sleet and snow briefly before ending.  Heavy ice accumulations occurred over southern Iowa, especially the southwest and southeast parts of the DSM CWA.  Ice accrual reached one half inch over Davis County, and around 0.6 inches in Adams Counties for the heaviest amounts.  Most of the area received between 0.25 and 0.4 inches of ice.  Spotty power outages were reported, however much of the power problems were mitigated by efforts the previous summer with tree trimming by the power utilities. Roads became very icy with all roads 100% ice covered.  Nearly all schools and many activities were cancelled for the 19th due to the ice.

Thunderstorms developed across eastern Colorado and western Kansas early in the afternoon and moved east and southeast. Numerous hail reports were received, some up to 2 inches in diameter. Several tornadoes occurred in western Kansas, all over open fields.
Supercell thunderstorms produced up to tea cup size hail over portions of northwest Kansas.
Supercell thunderstorms produced up to tea cup size hail over portions of northwest Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement officer measured hail up to 3.5 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved out of eastern New Hampshire and into western Maine during the early afternoon of June 17th. As in New Hampshire, these storms were almost exclusively large hail producers with numerous reports of 1 to 1.75 inch hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced 1.75 inch hail in Limerick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved out of eastern New Hampshire and into western Maine during the early afternoon of June 17th. As in New Hampshire, these storms were almost exclusively large hail producers with numerous reports of 1 to 1.75 inch hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced .75 inch hail in North Waterboro.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced .88 inch hail in Limerick.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced 1.25 inch hail in Limington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.

Strong low pressure developed just south of North Carolina during the early morning hours of November 5th. The low pressure system moved northeast along the North Carolina coast during the day. This low produced very heavy rain and strong gusty winds along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS wind instrument measured peak gust of 68 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front was approaching eastern North Carolina during the early morning hours of November 15 2008. South to southwest winds ahead of the front pushed warm and unstable air across the region. Scattered thunderstorms moved northeast across the inland portions of eastern North Carolina during the early morning hours. One of the thunderstorms produced a EF1 tornado in Martin County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado touched down near the intersection of Alternate Highway 64 and Jenkins Road. The tornado moved northeast about 2 miles before lifting. The tornado was about 50 yards wide and was estimated at EF1 intensity. A chapel and two abandoned mobile homes were severely damaged near Highway 64. Several outbuildings and a greenhouse were severely damaged or destroyed near a farm on Claude Green Road. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over Michigan on the afternoon of the 2nd ahead of a cold front.  These storms consolidated into a bow echo which moved rapidly eastward through southern Michigan and into Lake Erie near sunset.  The southern flank of this bow echo stalled across northwestern Ohio, with several rounds of thunderstorm redevelopment bringing heavy rainfall, flash flooding, and isolated severe weather to the Toledo area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over Michigan on the afternoon of the 2nd ahead of a cold front.  These storms consolidated into a bow echo which moved rapidly eastward through southern Michigan and into Lake Erie near sunset.  The southern flank of this bow echo stalled across northwestern Ohio, with several rounds of thunderstorm redevelopment bringing heavy rainfall, flash flooding, and isolated severe weather to the Toledo area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed several large tree limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system moved through the Central Plains spreading severe thunderstorms across South Central Kansas and snow to Central Kansas. Several severe thunderstorms moved across Sedgwick County with hail up to the size of quarters reported during the morning hours of February 5th. As the storm tapped into colder air on heavy snow fell from Russell through Chase counties. The storm produced upwards of 6 inches in that swath with lesser amounts across South Central and Southeast Kansas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Marginally severe thunderstorms, mainly producing hail up to the size of quarters, also caused flash flooding in several areas.  A slow moving frontal system was positioned over southern Missouri, allowing for unusual amounts of moisture and modest instability to develop along and south of this feature.  Mostly non-severe thunderstorms developed at random over southern Missouri.  However, two tornadic supercells approached south central Missouri from Arkansas, but failed to produce tornadoes within the Springfield, Missouri county warning area.

An area of slow moving showers and thunderstorms produced up to 6 inches of rain in 3 hours resulting in flash flooding in several towns in southeast New Hampshire. Numerous roads were inundated by small streams and many were washed out. Several cars were trapped in rising water in Laconia and several homes were also damaged. Damage was also extensive in Meredith and New Hampton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding and several road washouts in the New Hampton area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large scale ascent increased over the southeast during the overnight hours as a large upper trough over the central plains moved east towards the region. A 50 to 60 knot southerly low-level jet raced eastward ahead of the main trough, spreading Gulf of Mexico moisture north into the Carolinas. Organized convection developed in the coastal plain region as the airmass became increasingly unstable as surface dew points rose into the lower to middle 60s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported by local law enforcement on Harnett Dunn Highway between Old Crow Road and Denning Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Large scale ascent increased over the southeast during the overnight hours as a large upper trough over the central plains moved east towards the region. A 50 to 60 knot southerly low-level jet raced eastward ahead of the main trough, spreading Gulf of Mexico moisture north into the Carolinas. Organized convection developed in the coastal plain region as the airmass became increasingly unstable as surface dew points rose into the lower to middle 60s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported minor damage to vehicles from half dollar size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late evening hours of February 13th several bands of snow showers moved across the Northwest Piedmont resulting in periods of moderate to heavy snow for a few hours. Between one to three inches of snow fell in many locations between 6pm and midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between a half to one inch of snow fell across Davidson County mainly from Lexington north to Thomasville and the Forsyth county line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a warm front over east central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon hours of February 5th.  Many of the thunderstorms on either side of the front produced heavy rains and flooding.  The storms to the south of the warm front also produced damaging winds and hail, especially along and south of the I-70 corridor.  The flooding produced numerous road closures across the region, while the winds produced primarily tree, power line and power pole damage.  However, several structures received minor, mainly roofing damage and one mobile home was destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were flooded in Shelby county.  Two vehicles drove into flooded roadways and were swept into ditches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across southwest Louisiana, producing severe thunderstorms with large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: After radar analysis and a storm survey, this storm was determined to be a land spout tornado. Two 75 foot tall ham radio towers were blown down with one falling on the roof of a residence. A fence with concrete posts in the ground was blown over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across southwest Louisiana, producing severe thunderstorms with large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Another land spout tornado briefly touched down. Minor damage occurred at the Teche Oil Company where an overhead door was blown out and a carport was damaged. Four vehicles were damaged when the carport fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across southwest Louisiana, producing severe thunderstorms with large hail and damaging winds.
As a cold front moved across the region, thunderstorms briefly became severe and produced large hail.
As a cold front moved across the region, thunderstorms briefly became severe and produced large hail.
As a low pressure system moved across the region, some thunderstorms became severe and produced damaging wind gusts and large hail.
Another in a series of storms crossed New Mexico on the 25th, bringing high winds to several locations from late on the 24th through the morning of the 25th.
A squall line with severe weather and several tornadoes moved across north Florida and southeast Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 4 inch diameter tree was blown down on the Laura Walker Golf Course. The time of event was estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line with severe weather and several tornadoes moved across north Florida and southeast Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five public reports of a tornado received by Emergency Management nine miles west of Waynesville at Turkey Ridge. There was damage to at least one home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills reported by the Houghton County Airport ASOS were around 25 below zero on the morning of the 16th. The Houghton-Keweenaw County Schools were on a two-hour delay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observations indicated wind chill values of 20 to 25 below zero across much of the county during the morning of the 16th.  Keweenaw County Schools were on a two-hour delay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured inches of snow in less than 18 hours. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing of snow and reduced visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer near the Alger County measured eight inches of snow during the event. Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph caused considerable blowing of snow and reduced visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong Arctic cold front caused blizzard to near-blizzard conditions over western Upper Michigan on the 15th. Dangerously cold wind chills also developed on the 15th and 16th with the arrival of colder air in the wake of the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values hovered around 25 below zero on the morning of the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A sharp cold front brought an abrupt change to colder conditions and the season's first lake effect episode. As is usually the case in early season events, elevation played a major role in snowfall accumulations. As colder air filtered in, winds began to veer more westerly, and rain mixed with and turned to wet snow during the late afternoon and evening of the 9th. Wet snow then fell at varying rates though most of the day Monday (10th) across the higher elevations of the southern tier before ending Monday evening.  Total snowfall off Lake Erie topped out in the 8 to 12 inch range along the Chautauqua Ridge and gradually dropped off to the east and southeast. Specific snowfall reports included:  11 at Mayville, 10 at Stockton, 9 at Sinclairville, and 8 at Ellicottville. Off Lake Ontario, a similar scenario played out, but several hours later. Snow began in earnest late Sunday night and continued until near midnight Monday night, but it was mainly focused on the Tug Hill and central Lewis County. Heavy amounts were restricted to the central and northern Tug Hill with over a foot reported, but only 5 inches fell in the valley at Lowville. Specific reports included: 14 at Hooker, 6 at Highmarket, and 5 at Lowville.

Abundant low level moisture trapped under drier air aloft resulted in periods of widespread dense fog across portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd through the morning of the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog reported throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During November, drought conditions expanded southwest across South Texas. By the end of November, severe drought conditions existed across Bee, Goliad, Victoria, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, Live Oak, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties by the end of November. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during November continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was becoming sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during November. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during November continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was becoming sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during November. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm frontal boundary across West Central Wisconsin provided the support for scattered severe thunderstorms across the region on this date.

Instability ahead of a cold front which moved from the Central Dakotas on the morning of the 11th, to the Eastern half of Minnesota by the early evening hours, was the prime ingredient for scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms across the region, during this period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail occurred near intersection of County Rd. 210 and County Rd. 11.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper atmospheric low pressure system moved from south central Canada to the Great Lakes during the night of December 20th into the morning of December 21st. At the surface, the primary low associated with this upper level feature moved into the Great Lakes and weakened on the  21st. Meanwhile, a secondary coastal low developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast during the morning of the 21st and tracked into the Gulf of Maine during that evening.||Snow overspread Vermont around daybreak on the 21st and fell heavy at times during the late morning and early afternoon hours before dissipating during the evening. Snowfall accumulations of 6 to 10 inches were common across western Vermont with 10 to 18 inches across central and eastern Vermont. Some specific snowfall totals include; 18 inches in Marshfield (Washington), St. Johnsbury (Caledonia county), Rochester (Windsor county) and Randolph Center (Orange county) with 15 inches in Moretown and Waterbury Center (Washington county), North Promfret (Windsor county), Island Pond (Essex county). ||This was the second significant snowfall within 36 hours which led to additional vehicle accidents and exhausted snow removal resources. Snowfall totals in excess of 24 inches within 36 hours led to blocked ventilation pipes and some carbon monoxide injuries as well as a few collapsed small farm structures due to the weight of the snow.

A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Central dispatch relayed a report of trees down in the City of Douglas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved east across north Florida over night on Wednesday 12/10 and during the day on Thursday 12/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement relayed a report of a roof blown off an old building and a tree down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought snow to the Northern Great Lakes region.  Locally heavy snow developed in parts of Northwest Lower Michigan on the evening of the 30th, with Lake Ann picking up 13 inches of snow by morning of the 1st.  However, for most of the region, the heaviest snow fell on the 1st.  Thus, a more complete disucssion of this event will be contained in Storm Data for December 2008.

A deepening upper level trough over the southeast region lifted a deep plume of tropical moisture over the forecast area. A strong low level 850 mb jet of 50-55 knots was in place. Backing winds advected instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico across North Florida which coincided with the passing of a second pre-frontal squall line as it tracked across North Florida and Southeast Georgia in the afternoon. Low level storm relative helicities increased to 200-350 M2/S2. Widespread severe storms developed across the forecast area during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell on a trailer home and injured two residents inside. The victims were taken to the local hospital. The extent of their injuries was unknown.

Backing winds advected instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico across North Florida which coincided with the passing of a second pre-frontal squall line as it tracked across North Florida and Southeast Georgia in the afternoon. Low level storm relative helicities increased to 200-350 M2/S2. Widespread severe storms developed across the forecast area during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported widespread wind damage across Sugarmill Plantation including downed trees and limbs, fence damage and roof damage. He heard of a report of a roof blown off of a construction trailer at a local school.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A retired NWS employee reported a large oak tree and power lines were blown down off of Osborne Road. The time of the event was based on radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak deformation zone was over the area which created weak steering flow for storms. High instability and moderate moisture fueled afternoon and evening storms that formed along the sea breezes and outflows.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Fargo reported several trees were blown down at his residence when the storm passed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An inverted trough of low pressure at the surface moved through the state during the early morning of the 20th into the day on the 20th. At the same time, a strong low pressure deepened in the upper atmosphere over and just northeast of the state.  The combination drew down Arctic air into the central U.S. A tight pressure gradient developed between the developing low to the east and Arctic high pressure to the northwest.  Winds increased on the 20th, and continued through most of the day on the 21st.  Sustained wind speeds were in the 25 to 35 MPH range, with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH.  Very little snow fell with the inverted trough, generally an inch or two, however antecedent snow cover was quite high with 7 to 12 inches common.  The winds caused whiteout conditions for an extended period of time as the snow that was loose blew in open areas.  Much of the deeper snow had crusted over, so blizzard conditions were somewhat sporadic and not as widespread as would normally be expected.  The first and second order reporting stations did not meet blizzard criteria outside of occasionally, however law enforcement officials reported visibility frequently reduced to between 10 and 100 feet in open areas.  Travel was therefore not recommended across all of the northern part of Iowa north of U.S. Highway 30.  Roads drifted shut quickly and snowplows were taken off of several roads during the height of the storm.  In addition to the wind, temperatures fell below zero, resulting in dangerous wind chill indices in the -30 to -40 F. range.

An inverted trough of low pressure at the surface moved through the state during the early morning of the 20th into the day on the 20th. At the same time, a strong low pressure deepened in the upper atmosphere over and just northeast of the state.  The combination drew down Arctic air into the central U.S. A tight pressure gradient developed between the developing low to the east and Arctic high pressure to the northwest.  Winds increased on the 20th, and continued through most of the day on the 21st.  Sustained wind speeds were in the 25 to 35 MPH range, with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH.  Very little snow fell with the inverted trough, generally an inch or two, however antecedent snow cover was quite high with 7 to 12 inches common.  The winds caused whiteout conditions for an extended period of time as the snow that was loose blew in open areas.  Much of the deeper snow had crusted over, so blizzard conditions were somewhat sporadic and not as widespread as would normally be expected.  The first and second order reporting stations did not meet blizzard criteria outside of occasionally, however law enforcement officials reported visibility frequently reduced to between 10 and 100 feet in open areas.  Travel was therefore not recommended across all of the northern part of Iowa north of U.S. Highway 30.  Roads drifted shut quickly and snowplows were taken off of several roads during the height of the storm.  In addition to the wind, temperatures fell below zero, resulting in dangerous wind chill indices in the -30 to -40 F. range.

Severe thunderstorms moved out of eastern New Hampshire and into western Maine during the early afternoon of June 17th. As in New Hampshire, these storms were almost exclusively large hail producers with numerous reports of 1 to 1.75 inch hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced .88 inch hail in Hollis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense hurricane force storm moved into the western Bering Sea Sunday January 13th. As the storm approached the region the western Aleutians, hurricane force wind blew through the Aleutian Islands. Snow combined with the strong wind created blizzard conditions in the eastern Aleutians and Pribilof Islands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Satellite estimated wind of 60 KT with this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain fell across portions of Eastern Kentucky late in the afternoon into the evening hours of December 23rd. Light precipitation started out as sleet, freezing rain, and rain during the afternoon hours. By late afternoon, the precipitation had increased in coverage and intensity, and changed over to freezing rain and rain. Arctic air that had been over the area over the previous couple of days allowed for surface temperatures to remain at or below freezing, even as air temperatures rose to near or slightly above freezing. This created very hazardous travel conditions across the area, with numerous accidents reported. Traffic was backed up on the Mountain Parkway due to accidents caused by icy roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A glaze of ice was occurring from freezing rain on exposed surfaces at the National Weather Service Office.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Marginally severe thunderstorms, mainly producing hail up to the size of quarters, also caused flash flooding in several areas.  A slow moving frontal system was positioned over southern Missouri, allowing for unusual amounts of moisture and modest instability to develop along and south of this feature.  Mostly non-severe thunderstorms developed at random over southern Missouri.  However, two tornadic supercells approached south central Missouri from Arkansas, but failed to produce tornadoes within the Springfield, Missouri county warning area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two sections of Highway 215 east of Pleasant Hope became inundated with flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between one to three inches of snow fell across Forsyth County with the heavier amounts north of Winston Salem.
