EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex weather situation was in place during the overnight hours of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.  A warm front was positioned to the south of Iowa.  Meanwhile, a secondary cold front dropped into the north central  U.S. and stretched from eastern Montana into southern Minnesota.  The upper flow was northwest and quite conducive for MCS development as considerable moisture transport took place over Iowa.  Initially, an area of thunderstorms formed over south central Iowa.  The storms remained below severe limits as they tracked east-southeast out of the CWA.  A strong thunderstorm complex developed over western South Dakota during the night and propagated southeast, along with the upper air northwest flow, into Iowa.  The MCS became linear in nature as it moved out of northwest Iowa into the central sections of the state.  Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in several counties, with urban street flooding along the length of the line.  Rainfall rates of one to two inches in one half hour or less were reported.  A few areas received 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Appanoose County was quite hard hit with water flowing over the roads two feet deep.  The main severe mode of the system was the high winds.  There were numerous reports of 60 to 70 MPH winds.  The entire length of the line produced 40 to 50 MPH winds however.  Hail was somewhat limited as the freezing level was over 14,000 feet.  Following the passage of the line, high winds became a problem as a wake low developed.  Winds gusted to 58 MPH in Story County at Colo and wind damage was reported in Polk County at Bondurant.

Very cold air with temperatures dropping to near 20 below zero was accompanied by wind speeds of 10 to 25 mph. These cold temperatures and winds drove wind chill readings down to 35 to 45 degrees below zero in southwest Minnesota from the night of February 19th through the morning of February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds of 10 to 25 mph accompanied by temperatures dropping to near 20 below zero lowered wind chill readings to the 35 to 45 below zero range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm lifted from the southern plains into the Ohio Valley from January 31st into February 1st.  This storm produced heavy snow, at least 6 inches, across much of central Illinois.  The accumulating snow began during the afternoon hours of the 31st and ended during the morning hours of the 1st.  The heaviest band of snow extended from Springfield, to Decatur, to Rantoul, where 9 to 12 inches of snow fell. The maximum snowfall amount was 12.9 inches in Springfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought up to 2 inches of sleet accumulation to the southern third of Randolph County. A half inch to one inch fell across the rest of the county.

Up to five inches of sleet accumulated across parts of Southeast Missouri. Southern Reynolds and Madison County picked up about 5 inches of sleet with amounts in counties to the north ranging from 2 to 4 inches. There were numerous traffic accidents reported across the area. Many schools across the area were closed for the rest of the week.

A cold front moved southeast across Iowa during the afternoon of the 27th.  The initial surface wind shift line had passed, however the cold front aloft lagged the wind shift by at least 150 miles. The airmass became unstable by afternoon with CAPE values in the 2000 to 3000 J/kg range, and lifted indices between -4 and -7 C.  The atmosphere became more sheared as the afternoon progressed, with 30 to 45 kts of effective shear by late afternoon.  Available downdraft CAPE was 700 to 900 J/kg, with cape available in the -10 to -30 C. layer of the atmosphere between 300 and 400 J/kg.  Initially, a scattered line of thunderstorms formed over eastern parts of Nebraska and South Dakota.  The line became more solidified as it moved into Iowa.  A few rogue cells developed ahead of the line, and became severe.  One of them produced baseball size hail southwest of Earlham in Madison County.  For the most part, the storms produced hail in the three quarter to one inch diameter size.  The storms produced gusty winds in most areas.  There were several reports of winds around 60 MPH or so with the stronger storms.  Most of the wind damage was limited to trees and power lines.  A beta bow element moved through Cass County, destroying a machine shed there as high winds tore it apart.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds of 60 MPH were breaking 6 inch diameter tree limbs.  Heavy rain was reducing visibility to one quarter of a mile or less.

Record and near record setting cold air poured into eastern North Dakota and Northwest Minnesota Tuesday (February 19th) and Tuesday night. The combination of moderate northerly winds of 15 mph to 25 mph with the very cold temperatures produced wind chills of 40 to 50 degrees below zero.
A strong cold front approaching the region from the west along with adequate surface based instability resulted in the development of numerous showers and thunderstorms across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained weather spotter reported penny size hail 6 miles southeast of Hinesville, Georgia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved north from the Gulf Coast and into the Ohio Valley, then redeveloped over the Mid Atlantic states. A wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain affected Central Pennsylvania with significant ice accumulations ranging from a quarter to one-half inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lancaster ASOS recorded over a quarter inch of precipitation as  freezing rain and sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Depression Fay stalled over southern Mississippi on the 25th, and produced severe thunderstorms which spawned a few tornadoes and damaging winds in southeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near the intersection of County Roads 19 and 15, about three miles northwest of Skipperville.  Several trees were uprooted and a barn was heavily damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Depression Fay stalled over southern Mississippi on the 25th, and produced severe thunderstorms which spawned a few tornadoes and damaging winds in southeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down just south of Gordon.  A mobile home along East County Road 8 was destroyed when an uprooted tree crashed on top of it.  There were several trees with their tops snapped off along the tornado's short path.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado, spawned by a rainband from Tropical Storm Fay on the 23rd, briefly touched down in a wooded area in Jefferson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down briefly in a wooded area.  There was a short narrow swath of pine trees with their tops snapped off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dry line developed over north central Texas on the afternoon of February 25th and began moving eastward in conjunction with an upper level trough moving through the mid-Mississippi Valley. Moderate lapse rates and lift associated with the dry line helped spur a line of storms in the late afternoon hours over northeast Texas and southwestern Arkansas. The storms marched eastward throughout the evening and produced hail mainly under 1 inch in many locations across east Texas, southern Arkansas, and northwest Louisiana with some wind damage reported in southern Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail reported by local restaurant.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved north from the Gulf Coast and into the Ohio Valley, then redeveloped over the Mid Atlantic states. A wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain affected Central Pennsylvania with significant ice accumulations ranging from a quarter to one-half inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP observer in Buffalo Mills measured between a quarter and one-half inch ice accretion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across the region during the afternoon hours on January 29th, 2008.  Several reports of large hail and damaging winds were reported.
A strong cold front moved across the region during the afternoon hours on January 29th, 2008.  Several reports of large hail and damaging winds were reported.

A period of rain and mild temperatures over melting snow pack cause an extended period of dense fog across much of central and southeast Illinois.  Numerous school closures and vehicular accidents occurred as a result of the dense fog.  One accident resulted in a fatality in Vermilion county.

Strong low pressure system moved from the Tennessee Valley of Alabama northeast to the Central Appalachians with widespread wind damage occurring across the county warning area in convection which formed just ahead of system cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree was reported down in Pound.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Up to five inches of sleet accumulated across parts of Southeast Missouri. Southern Reynolds and Madison County picked up about 5 inches of sleet with amounts in counties to the north ranging from 2 to 4 inches. There were numerous traffic accidents reported across the area. Many schools across the area were closed for the rest of the week.

A strong dry line developed over north central Texas on the afternoon of February 25th and began moving eastward in conjunction with an upper level trough moving through the mid-Mississippi Valley. Moderate lapse rates and lift associated with the dry line helped spur a line of storms in the late afternoon hours over northeast Texas and southwestern Arkansas. The storms marched eastward throughout the evening and produced hail mainly under 1 inch in many locations across east Texas, southern Arkansas, and northwest Louisiana with some wind damage reported in southern Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was reported in the North Highlands area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong dry line developed over north central Texas on the afternoon of February 25th and began moving eastward in conjunction with an upper level trough moving through the mid-Mississippi Valley. Moderate lapse rates and lift associated with the dry line helped spur a line of storms in the late afternoon hours over northeast Texas and southwestern Arkansas. The storms marched eastward throughout the evening and produced hail mainly under 1 inch in many locations across east Texas, southern Arkansas, and northwest Louisiana with some wind damage reported in southern Arkansas.

A strong upper level storm system moved from the southwest United States and into the southern plains during the day. A very unstable airmass was noted across the four state region with abundant low level wind shear and deep layer shear in the mid levels of the atmosphere. A dry line moved into southeast Oklahoma and northeast Texas by late afternoon with scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms developing ahead of the dry line across the region. Thunderstorms produced strong and damaging wind gusts along with large hail across most of the region.

Record and near record setting cold air poured into eastern North Dakota and Northwest Minnesota Tuesday (February 19th) and Tuesday night. The combination of moderate northerly winds of 15 mph to 25 mph with the very cold temperatures produced wind chills of 40 to 50 degrees below zero.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sullivan County emergency management reported over a quarter inch of ice from freezing rain and sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved north from the Gulf Coast and into the Ohio Valley, then redeveloped over the Mid Atlantic states. A wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain affected Central Pennsylvania with significant ice accumulations ranging from a quarter to one-half inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP observer in Lock Haven measured over one quarter inch of ice accretion from freezing rain and sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An ice storm occurred across the middle and lower Susquehanna valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported a quarter inch of ice accumulation in Hughesville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused localized flooding over portions of north-central Pennsylvania during the evening of February 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flooding over portions of Potter County. Emergency Management reported flooding along portions of the Allegheny River near Roulette, and the First Fork of Sinnemahoning Creek was out of its banks near Costello.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracked along the I-95 corridor while high pressure to the northeast fed cold surface temperatures into Southern New England. Combined with warm temperatures in the upper atmosphere, this resulted in freezing rain and/or sleet across much of the area. In addition, a strong cold front moved through late in the afternoon, resulting in strong winds along the south coast, Cape Cod, and the islands.  Icy roads indirectly contributed to a fatal accident in Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car began skidding sideways while on a curve in the road and was struck by a loaded flatbed tow truck.  The truck driver tried to avoid the accident, but because of the icy roads was unable to move quickly.  The driver of the car was killed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracked along the I-95 corridor while high pressure to the northeast fed cold surface temperatures into Southern New England.  Combined with warm temperatures in the upper atmosphere, this resulted in freezing rain and/or sleet across much of the area.  In addition, a strong cold front moved through late in the afternoon, resulting in strong winds along the south coast, Cape Cod, and the islands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Automated Surface Observing Station at Nantucket Memorial Airport (KACK) recorded a wind gust of 62 mph.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storm tides associated with Fay as it moved into the Florida Panhandle ranged from two to four feet along the Big Bend coastline during the morning of the 24th.  No beach erosion was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm tides peaked at three feet along the coast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late afternoon thunderstorm on the 25th spawned a weak tornado which briefly touched down in Jackson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down briefly in an open field.  No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Fay made its fourth landfall on Saturday, August 23rd near Carrabelle, Florida, then continued on a steady westward path across the Florida Panhandle. Intense rain bands, which trained over the same locations during the afternoon and evening hours, producing extremely high rainfall rates and subsequent flash flooding across portions of southwest and south central Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads and low lying areas were flooded, including portions of State Highway 91 between Colquitt and Cooktown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Fay made its fourth landfall on Saturday, August 23rd near Carrabelle, Florida, then continued on a steady westward path across the Florida Panhandle. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads and low lying areas were flooded, including portions of U.S. Highway 221 and State Highway 333 south of Quitman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large above-ground pool was lifted and thrown against a mobile home.  Windows were broken out at the home and the pool was twisted and destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and large tree limbs were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trailer overturned near Lake Ray Roberts Dam due to strong winds.  The winds also caused arcing power lines which sparked several small fires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front approaching from the west in combination with a significant influx of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico and Atlantic resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms developing across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Colleton County Warning Point reported that several trees were blown down near Hillio Court and along Round O Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front approaching from the west in combination with a significant influx of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico and Atlantic resulted in numerous showers and thunderstorms developing across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Maple tree that was 2 feet in diameter and 30 feet tall was reported to have broken off 3 feet above the ground on Old Cherry Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted northward into southeast Georgia, allowing temperatures to climb close to 80 degrees with dewpoints in the upper 60s along the Altamaha River.  The frontal boundary served as a focusing mechanism for thunderstorms to develop.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported by the general public and relayed by the local media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow accompanied by 40-50 mph winds resulted in whiteout conditions for a time across the Tri-State region during the day. Snowfall totals ranged from one to two inches while visibilities of near zero to 1/4 mile in falling and blowing snow occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility was reported to be less than one quarter of a mile with moderate snow.  Snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches occurred.

There were numerous traffic accidents reported across the area. Many schools across the area were closed for the rest of the week.

A light coating of freezing rain and sleet fell during the morning of February 11, 2008 resulting in numerous traffic accidents and injuries. At least 130 accidents were reported in Boone County resulting in 35 injuries. One death occurred in a traffic accident in Warren County on I-70 near mile marker 191.

High winds affected much of Southern New England as an arctic front moved through the area.  Winds gusted as high as 67 mph in Woonsocket, Rhode Island and downed tree limbs and wires across much of Rhode Island.

A low pressure system developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast and moved up the east coast southeast of Nantucket producing snow, rain, and ice across Southern New England. Widespread two to four inch rainfall amounts resulted in small stream and poor drainage flooding as well as some minor river flooding. In addition, there was some minor wind damage from strong northeast winds, especially along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over two and a half inches of rain fell in the Providence area causing the roof of an auto body shop to collapse.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast and moved up the east coast southeast of Nantucket producing snow, rain, and ice across Southern New England. Widespread two to four inch rainfall amounts resulted in small stream and poor drainage flooding as well as some minor river flooding. In addition, there was some minor wind damage from strong northeast winds, especially along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several backyards were under six inches of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across Southern New England resulting in strong, gusty winds. Trees, branches, and wires were downed by the winds resulting in power outages in some areas.

A cold front moved southeast across Iowa during the afternoon of the 27th.  The initial surface wind shift line had passed, however the cold front aloft lagged the wind shift by at least 150 miles. The airmass became unstable by afternoon with CAPE values in the 2000 to 3000 J/kg range, and lifted indices between -4 and -7 C.  The atmosphere became more sheared as the afternoon progressed, with 30 to 45 kts of effective shear by late afternoon.  Available downdraft CAPE was 700 to 900 J/kg, with cape available in the -10 to -30 C. layer of the atmosphere between 300 and 400 J/kg.  Initially, a scattered line of thunderstorms formed over eastern parts of Nebraska and South Dakota.  The line became more solidified as it moved into Iowa.  A few rogue cells developed ahead of the line, and became severe.  One of them produced baseball size hail southwest of Earlham in Madison County.  For the most part, the storms produced hail in the three quarter to one inch diameter size.  The storms produced gusty winds in most areas.  There were several reports of winds around 60 MPH or so with the stronger storms.  Most of the wind damage was limited to trees and power lines.  A beta bow element moved through Cass County, destroying a machine shed there as high winds tore it apart.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured wind gust reported by amateur radio operator.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds blew signs, branches, and metal roofs down across the county.  The ceiling of the Grand Saline Elementary School was damaged when the wind entered an open door and lifted it up.  The ceiling then collapsed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fires in southwestern Tarrant County burned several hundred acres.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A sustained wind speed of 40 MPH was recorded in Mesquite.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Signs were blown down and some light property damage occurred as a strong cold front blew through the area.  Wind damage to roofs, barns, and outbuildings was common.  The Rogers-Wade building in downtown Paris lost its roof and suffered structural damage.  Power outages were reported in Blossom.  The Paris observation reported 41.4 MPH sustained early in the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alliance Airport reported a sustained wind of 41 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved into the western Great Lakes on the 14th, along an arctic cold front.  Most of the associated snow in Northern Michigan was light, but a narrow band of heavy snow impacted parts of Central Lower Michigan.  Manistee picked up a foot of snow, while Wellston received almost ten inches.

A strong storm system moved through the Central Plains spreading severe thunderstorms across South Central Kansas and snow to Central Kansas. Several severe thunderstorms moved across Sedgwick County with hail up to the size of quarters reported during the morning hours of February 5th. As the storm tapped into colder air on heavy snow fell from Russell through Chase counties. The storm produced upwards of 6 inches in that swath with lesser amounts across South Central and Southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ellsworth County law enforcement officials estimated that 6 inches of snow had fallen in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm that deepened off the northern California coast on January 22nd and 23rd weakened as it moved inland on the 24th and crossed new Mexico on the 25th as a weak trough of low pressure. However, the storm was able to draw enough moisture into the state to produce light to moderate snowfall over primarily the northwest third of New Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of up to 4 inches fell below 7500 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm along the west coast helped increase winds in the mid levels of the atmosphere on the 27th, leading to an isolated strong wind gust at the Sierra Blanca Airport near Ruidoso.

An area of slow moving showers and thunderstorms produced up to 6 inches of rain in 3 hours resulting in flash flooding in several towns in southeast New Hampshire. Numerous roads were inundated by small streams and many were washed out. Several cars were trapped in rising water in Laconia and several homes were also damaged. Damage was also extensive in Meredith and New Hampton.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in Meredith washing out several roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line with severe weather and several tornadoes moved across north Florida and southeast Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A local utility company reported several trees down on power lines west of Interstate 95. The times were estimated by radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line with severe weather and several tornadoes moved across north Florida and southeast Georgia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wayne County Emergency Management reported a 200 yard wide and one half mile long tornado track crossing Post Road and Boones Branch Road south of Mount Pleasant. Hundreds of trees were snapped by the event with the Road Department sent to clear the roadways. Several garages were damaged with the tornado path transiting between several homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure built in across southeast Georgia resulting in downed trees and power lines in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down near Mose Johnson lane. Additionally other trees were reported down on power lines with some power outages reported the intersection of Lonnie Road and Highway 441 near Pearson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure built in across southeast Georgia resulting in downed trees and power lines in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down across Ten Mile Highway. A second tree was down in a yard on Kelly Davis Road off of Spring Branch Church Road about 4 miles north of Baxley. A third tree was reported down on a power line on Bethel Church Road off Highway 144 about 10 miles northeast of Baxley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure built into the area with strong winds fanning several wildfires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several brush fires closed a portion of Moncrief Road to Old Kings. Several mobile homes in the area were reported as being compromised but the fire was reported as under control by 900 pm EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm lifted from the southern plains into the Ohio Valley from January 31st into February 1st.  This storm produced heavy snow, at least 6 inches, across much of central Illinois.  The accumulating snow began during the afternoon hours of the 31st and ended during the morning hours of the 1st.  The heaviest band of snow extended from Springfield, to Decatur, to Rantoul, where 9 to 12 inches of snow fell. The maximum snowfall amount was 12.9 inches in Springfield.

A cold front moved southeast across Iowa during the afternoon of the 27th.  The initial surface wind shift line had passed, however the cold front aloft lagged the wind shift by at least 150 miles. The airmass became unstable by afternoon with CAPE values in the 2000 to 3000 J/kg range, and lifted indices between -4 and -7 C.  The atmosphere became more sheared as the afternoon progressed, with 30 to 45 kts of effective shear by late afternoon.  Available downdraft CAPE was 700 to 900 J/kg, with cape available in the -10 to -30 C. layer of the atmosphere between 300 and 400 J/kg.  Initially, a scattered line of thunderstorms formed over eastern parts of Nebraska and South Dakota.  The line became more solidified as it moved into Iowa.  A few rogue cells developed ahead of the line, and became severe.  One of them produced baseball size hail southwest of Earlham in Madison County.  For the most part, the storms produced hail in the three quarter to one inch diameter size.  The storms produced gusty winds in most areas.  There were several reports of winds around 60 MPH or so with the stronger storms.  Most of the wind damage was limited to trees and power lines.  A beta bow element moved through Cass County, destroying a machine shed there as high winds tore it apart.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small amount of penny size hail fell along with 40 MPH winds.

Very cold air with temperatures dropping to around 15 below zero was accompanied by wind speeds of 10 to 25 mph. These cold temperatures and winds drove wind chill readings down to the 35 to 40 degree below zero range in most of northwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds of 10 to 25 mph accompanied by temperatures dropping to around 15 below zero lowered wind chill readings to the 35 to 40 below zero range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved north from the Gulf Coast and into the Ohio Valley, then redeveloped over the Mid Atlantic states. A wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain affected Central Pennsylvania with significant ice accumulations ranging from a quarter to one-half inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP observer in Altoona measured between a quarter and one-half inch ice accretion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved north from the Gulf Coast and into the Ohio Valley, then redeveloped over the Mid Atlantic states. A wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain affected Central Pennsylvania with significant ice accumulations ranging from a quarter to one-half inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Johnstown ASOS reported a quarter to one-half inch of precipitation falling as freezing rain. The heavy ice accretion brought down trees in Ashville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of rain and mild temperatures over melting snow pack cause an extended period of dense fog across much of central and southeast Illinois.  Numerous school closures and vehicular accidents occurred as a result of the dense fog.  One accident resulted in a fatality in Vermilion county.

A period of rain and mild temperatures over melting snow pack cause an extended period of dense fog across much of central and southeast Illinois.  Numerous school closures and vehicular accidents occurred as a result of the dense fog.  One accident resulted in a fatality in Vermilion county.

A warm front lifted northward into southeast Georgia, allowing temperatures to climb close to 80 degrees with dewpoints in the upper 60s along the Altamaha River.  The frontal boundary served as a focusing mechanism for thunderstorms to develop.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to half dollar size hail was reported by the general public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system moved from the southwest United States and into the southern plains during the day. A very unstable airmass was noted across the four state region with abundant low level wind shear and deep layer shear in the mid levels of the atmosphere. A dry line moved into southeast Oklahoma and northeast Texas by late afternoon with scattered to numerous severe thunderstorms developing ahead of the dry line across the region. Thunderstorms produced strong and damaging wind gusts along with large hail across most of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff's office reporting trees and power lines downed on the west side of Detroit, Texas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow accompanied by 40-50 mph winds resulted in whiteout conditions for a time across the Tri-State region during the day. Snowfall totals ranged from one to two inches while visibilities of near zero to 1/4 mile in falling and blowing snow occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported visibility reduced to 900 feet with light snow and winds  of 40 to 50 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light snow accompanied by 40-50 mph winds resulted in whiteout conditions for a time across the Tri-State region during the day. Snowfall totals ranged from one to two inches while visibilities of near zero to 1/4 mile in falling and blowing snow occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported visibility reduced to less than one quarter of a mile with light snow and winds of 40 to 50 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm system that helped spawn killer tornadoes over the Tennessee Valley brought areas of heavy snow and blowing snow to southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  The system tracked from the Texas panhandle to the lower great lakes region and pulled up 50 and 60 degree surface dew points into southeast Missouri and southern Illinois.||Snow from this system began around sunrise Tuesday morning February 5th and lasted until mid morning on the 6th.  Around 6 inches of snow fell over much of Montgomery county, and north winds that frequently gusted over 25 mph caused significant blowing and drifting snow.  Some schools across the area were closed on the 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Red Oak reported around 6 inches of snow from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Marginally severe thunderstorms, mainly producing hail up to the size of quarters, also caused flash flooding in several areas.  A slow moving frontal system was positioned over southern Missouri, allowing for unusual amounts of moisture and modest instability to develop along and south of this feature.  Mostly non-severe thunderstorms developed at random over southern Missouri.  However, two tornadic supercells approached south central Missouri from Arkansas, but failed to produce tornadoes within the Springfield, Missouri county warning area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 08/16/08 ignited a round of wildfires across southwest Oregon. The Lonesome Complex fires consisted of the Middle Fork, Lonesome, and Bessie Rock fires. As of 09/01/08, all but the Middle Fork fires were contained. The Middle Fork fire was still burning when the last update was issued on 10/09/08.  At that time, the size of the fire was 21175 acres and the was 90% contained. The estimated containment date was 10/15/08.  No update on expenditures was available, but as of 09/01/08, 17.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 08/16/08 ignited a round of wildfires across southwest Oregon. The Lonesome Complex fires consisted of the Middle Fork, Lonesome, and Bessie Rock fires. As of 09/01/08, all but the Middle Fork fires were contained. The Middle Fork fire was still burning when the last update was issued on 10/09/08. At that time, the size of the fire was 21175 acres and the was 90% contained. The estimated containment date was 10/15/08. No update on expenditures was available, but as of 09/01/08, 17.7 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding in Somerst County. Old Kelly Dam Road was washed out near the intersection of Golden Road.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding which washed out the Old Kelly Dam Road near the intersection of Golden Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a home in Newcastle and ignited a fire that destroyed the residence.
Lightning struck a building used to store hay and ignited a fire that caused major damage to the wooden structure.

Lightning struck a nearby tree and then followed a gas line into a home in Salem where it ignited a fire.  The fire casued damage to the basement and first floor, however a sprinkler system limited damage on the upper floor.

A weakening upper-level low, along with a strong Polar Jet over California, brought periods of light to moderate rain, mountain snow, and strong winds over the Christmas holiday. Rainfall amounts ranged from one-quarter to one-half inch at the lower elevations, and one to two and one-half inches in the coastal slopes. No significant snowfall was reported. High winds downed trees and power lines in Encinitas, Palm Desert, and Palm Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 89 MPH was measured by the Burns Canyon RAWS. Wind gusts greater than 58 MPH lasted for 5 hours, with sustained winds as high as 59 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weakening upper-level low, along with a strong Polar Jet over California, brought periods of light to moderate rain, mountain snow, and strong winds over the Christmas holiday. Rainfall amounts ranged from one-quarter to one-half inch at the lower elevations, and one to two and one-half inches in the coastal slopes. No significant snowfall was reported. High winds downed trees and power lines in Encinitas, Palm Desert, and Palm Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 58 MPH was measured by the Ranger Peak RAWS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of lake snows developed by mid to late afternoon of the 10th east of Lake Ontario and became intense Sunday night and most of Monday. The bands started across northern Oswego county and the Tug Hill, edged southward into central Oswego county for much of Monday before lifting north a bit again Monday night and shutting down overnight into Tuesday morning. This event was exacerbated by very strong winds Sunday night into Monday morning which resulted in many whiteouts and road closures, including I-81. The State University of New York at Oswego cancelled classes on Monday the 11th. This was the most severe lake effect event of the 07-08 winter season in regard to winds, visibilities and frigid temperatures which were just above zero, with wind chills of -20, dangerous conditions. Specific snowfalls reported: 41 inches at Minetto, 26 inches at Mexico, 24 inches at Oswego, 20 inches at Pulaski, and 17 inches Boonville.

A west to northwest flow of arctic air was just enough to result in lake snows from Wayne to Oswego counties late on Friday the 15th to early Saturday the 16th. The snows were scattered during Friday afternoon but consolidated into a single band which persistent much of the night from Wolcott to Syracuse. The activity broke apart and drifted north by late Saturday morning.  Snow totals were around six inches in Oswego and Northern Cayuga counties, but up to a foot feel in northeast Wayne County.

A surge of arctic air followed a secondary cold front which crossed the area Monday night the 18th and soon set off lake effect snows off both Lakes Erie and Ontario. |The Lake Ontario activity began Tuesday midday over Jefferson County but soon settled slowly southward as the winds veered to westerly later in the day. The band settled southward across most of Oswego county Tuesday night before lifting north to the Oswego-Jefferson county line early Wednesday and remained there much of the day before lifting north again. Some minor activity redeveloped on a northwest flow Wednesday night further south and west over Wayne County. Total accumulations were a foot or less over most areas due to the transition of the band, but a narrow area of northern Oswego County around Lacona and Pulaski saw accumulations of three to four feet. Specific snowfall reports included: 49 inches at Pulaski, 22 inches at Sandy Creek, 19 inches at Lacona, 16 inches at Mexico and 9 inches at Highmarket.|The activity off Erie was most interesting and was highly subject to locations of open water. Although the lake was mostly ice covered, a warm spell and brisk southwest winds opened up an area of open water along the south shore of the lake. Snow showers developed during the afternoon hours but were more of a cellular nature due to the late February sun. This turned into an intense single band during Tuesday evening which extended across Lackawanna to Depew and Darien with 1-2 inch per hour rates. A few more bands developed and dissipated overnight into Wednesday morning with one final band giving several inches to East Aurora and Wales Wednesday morning. Total accumulations ranged up to a foot or a little more just southeast of Buffalo in Depew and Elma, but the gradient was sharp with 4 inches at the Buffalo Airport and only 1-2 inches in Amherst. Specific snowfall reports included: 14 inches at Elma, 13 inches at South Wales and Depew, 11 inches at East Aurora and 10 inches at West Seneca.

Low pressure moved from southern Pennsylvania to southern New England and spread a blanket of snow across the western southern tier and Finger Lakes regions of New York. Area-wide, snowfalls of eight to twelve inches were reported. Several automobile accidents were blamed on wintry conditions.
Arctic air combined with gusty winds produced wind chill values of ten to twenty degrees below zero from the evening of the 10th through the early morning on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bitterly cold temperatures combined with brisk west-northwest winds produced wind chills of ten to twenty degrees below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region, triggering showers and thunderstorms.  Some of the storms were severe with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding.  There were also two brief tornado touchdowns in Marion county Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three inches of rain fell over portions of Crawford county during the evening of February 5th. Several roads around the Steelville area had over a foot of water flowing over them.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system moved north from the Gulf Coast and into the Ohio Valley, then redeveloped over the Mid Atlantic states. A wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain affected Central Pennsylvania with significant ice accumulations ranging from a quarter to one-half inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Williamsport ASOS recorded over a quarter inch of precipitation as freezing rain and sleet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across the region during the afternoon hours on January 29th, 2008.  Several reports of large hail and damaging winds were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds gusting to 54 mph were associated with the passage of a cold front.  In Centralia, one building sustained minor roof damage.  Countywide numerous tree limbs and power lines were knocked down.  Two miles north of Salem near mile marker 119 on Interstate 57, a semi was blown over.  No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved across the region during the afternoon hours on January 29th, 2008.  Several reports of large hail and damaging winds were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds associated with the passage of a cold front, knocked down several power lines onto Illinois Route 4 about 2 miles south of Sparta.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The long standing drought continued through the month, with conditions improving one drought category by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal rainfall for the month helped to improve overall drought conditions.  The United States Drought Monitor improved drought classifications from Extreme(D3) to Severe(D2), with a classification of Moderate(D1) for coastal counties. Streamflows around the area also improved by the end of the month, with flows at or just below normal for the time of year.

CZ_NAME: EDISTO BEACH SC TO SAVANNAH GA OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted northward into southeast Georgia, allowing temperatures to climb close to 80 degrees with dewpoints in the upper 60s along the Altamaha River. The frontal boundary served as a focusing mechanism for thunderstorms to develop that eventually pushed in the Atlantic Coastal Waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 39 mph or 34 knots was reported by a Mesonet station on Hilton Head Island.

Lightning from a thunderstorm event on 08/17/08 ignited another round of wildfires across southwest Oregon. The Rattle Fire was initially part of the North Fork Complex, but the other fires were suppressed. The last update on this fire was issued on 10/07/08.  At that time, the size of the fire was 19775 acres and was 90% contained.  The estimated containment date was 10/30/08. No update on expenditures was available, but as of 08/31/08, 1.9 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

No update on expenditures was available, but as of 08/31/08, 1.9 million dollars had been spent on firefighting efforts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fireworks caused at least one fire on New Year's Day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fireworks caused a fire along CR 600 in Burleson that burned 3 acres and destroyed a barn that was filled with lumber.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were dozens of reports of damage due to strong winds as a powerful low pressure system and cold front moved through the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The McKinney ASOS recorded a peak wind gust of 59 miles an hour at 10:50 AM CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light coating of freezing rain and sleet fell during the morning of February 11, 2008 resulting in numerous traffic accidents and injuries. At least 130 accidents were reported in Boone County resulting in 35 injuries. One death occurred in a traffic accident in Warren County on I-70 near mile marker 191.

Widespread excessive rainfall impacted almost all of extreme southeast Kansas and the Missouri Ozarks during the overnight period of 16 February into 17 February.  Widespread rainfall amounts of one to three and a half inches fell.  The heaviest amounts fell over the upper White River Basin as three and a half inches were observed near Table Rock Lake.  Meanwhile areas of the Osage Plains from southeast Kansas in to west central Missouri measured around an inch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A section of County Road 627 five miles north of Dixon experienced flash flooding and was impassable to motorists.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure traveled from the Great Lakes across New England during February 5th. Snow overspread Vermont just after Midnight on the 5th and mixed with sleet and freezing rain around dawn before ending around midday. Combined snow and sleet accumulations across central and eastern Vermont was 3 to 6 inches. Some specific snowfall totals include; 6 inches in Brookfield and Randolph Center (Orange county), Woodstock and White River Junction (Windsor county) with 5 inches in Worcester (Washington county), Bethel (Windsor county), Chelsea (Orange county) and 4 inches in St. Johnsbury (Caledonia county), Island Pond (Essex county), Eden and Morrisville (Lamoille county).

Low pressure moved from southern Pennsylvania to southern New England and spread a blanket of snow across the western southern tier and Finger Lakes regions of New York. Area-wide, snowfalls of eight to twelve inches were reported. Several automobile accidents were blamed on wintry conditions.

A complex weather situation was in place during the overnight hours of the 2nd into the morning of the 3rd.  A warm front was positioned to the south of Iowa.  Meanwhile, a secondary cold front dropped into the north central  U.S. and stretched from eastern Montana into southern Minnesota.  The upper flow was northwest and quite conducive for MCS development as considerable moisture transport took place over Iowa.  Initially, an area of thunderstorms formed over south central Iowa.  The storms remained below severe limits as they tracked east-southeast out of the CWA.  A strong thunderstorm complex developed over western South Dakota during the night and propagated southeast, along with the upper air northwest flow, into Iowa.  The MCS became linear in nature as it moved out of northwest Iowa into the central sections of the state.  Very heavy rainfall resulted in flash flooding in several counties, with urban street flooding along the length of the line.  Rainfall rates of one to two inches in one half hour or less were reported.  A few areas received 2 to 3 inches of rain.  Appanoose County was quite hard hit with water flowing over the roads two feet deep.  The main severe mode of the system was the high winds.  There were numerous reports of 60 to 70 MPH winds.  The entire length of the line produced 40 to 50 MPH winds however.  Hail was somewhat limited as the freezing level was over 14,000 feet.  Following the passage of the line, high winds became a problem as a wake low developed.  Winds gusted to 58 MPH in Story County at Colo and wind damage was reported in Polk County at Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fifty to 60 MPH winds were reported with minor tree damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front slid across the region...triggering numerous thunderstorms...so of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downburst winds caused considerable damage to numerous trees and tree limbs from half a mile to 1.5 miles south of Nebo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front slid across the region...triggering numerous thunderstorms...so of which became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down just west of the intersection of Route A and Route Y, about 5.5 miles south of Mount Sterling, along the west bank of Crider Creek.  The tornado moved to the north northeast across the creek, dissipating in a nearby field.  Damage only consisted of a several uprooted trees, as well as some snapped trees and tree limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved southeast across Iowa during the afternoon of the 27th.  The initial surface wind shift line had passed, however the cold front aloft lagged the wind shift by at least 150 miles. The airmass became unstable by afternoon with CAPE values in the 2000 to 3000 J/kg range, and lifted indices between -4 and -7 C.  The atmosphere became more sheared as the afternoon progressed, with 30 to 45 kts of effective shear by late afternoon.  Available downdraft CAPE was 700 to 900 J/kg, with cape available in the -10 to -30 C. layer of the atmosphere between 300 and 400 J/kg.  Initially, a scattered line of thunderstorms formed over eastern parts of Nebraska and South Dakota.  The line became more solidified as it moved into Iowa.  A few rogue cells developed ahead of the line, and became severe.  One of them produced baseball size hail southwest of Earlham in Madison County.  For the most part, the storms produced hail in the three quarter to one inch diameter size.  The storms produced gusty winds in most areas.  There were several reports of winds around 60 MPH or so with the stronger storms.  Most of the wind damage was limited to trees and power lines.  A beta bow element moved through Cass County, destroying a machine shed there as high winds tore it apart.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball to baseball size hail was reported, along with 30 to 40 MPH winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region, triggering showers and thunderstorms.  Some of the storms were severe with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding.  There were also two brief tornado touchdowns in Marion county Illinois.

A strong cold front moved through the region, triggering showers and thunderstorms.  Some of the storms were severe with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding.  There were also two brief tornado touchdowns in Marion county Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of rain fell over portions of Macoupin county during the evening hours of February 5th.  The viaduct on Illinois Route 16 in Shipman was flooded and viaducts on the north and south sides of Carlinville on Illinois Route 4 were flooded. Also, water was reported over several roads including Enslow Road just northeast of Standard City.  Briar Creek on the east side of Carlinville overflowed its banks, causing minor flooding on several streets in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region, triggering showers and thunderstorms.  Some of the storms were severe with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding.  There were also two brief tornado touchdowns in Marion county Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three inches of rain fell over portions of Montgomery county during the afternoon and evening hours on February 5th.  Six to eight inches of water was over Illinois Route 127 just west of Raymond.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region, triggering showers and thunderstorms.  Some of the storms were severe with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding.  There were also two brief tornado touchdowns in Marion county Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds blew in two large barn doors on a farm 5 miles west of Ashley. Further north the winds blew down several power lines in the Hoyleton area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region, triggering showers and thunderstorms.  Some of the storms were severe with large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding.  There were also two brief tornado touchdowns in Marion county Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second tornado briefly touched down at the same time about a mile south of Illinois Route 161 on Medlin Road.  A machine shed sustained major damage with the north, west and south faces of the shed buckled and collapsed.  An attached awning was completely upturned and thrown to the southeast.  Also, the entire roof was lifted and thrown 100 yards to the southeast.

About twin inches of snow fell across parts of Monroe, St. Clair, Randolph, and Marion counties in Illinois. There were some auto accidents reported across the area.

Marginally severe thunderstorms, mainly producing hail up to the size of quarters, also caused flash flooding in several areas.  A slow moving frontal system was positioned over southern Missouri, allowing for unusual amounts of moisture and modest instability to develop along and south of this feature.  Mostly non-severe thunderstorms developed at random over southern Missouri.  However, two tornadic supercells approached south central Missouri from Arkansas, but failed to produce tornadoes within the Springfield, Missouri county warning area.

Thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a warm front over east central and southeast Illinois during the afternoon hours of February 5th.  Many of the thunderstorms on either side of the front produced heavy rains and flooding.  The storms to the south of the warm front also produced damaging winds and hail, especially along and south of the I-70 corridor.  The flooding produced numerous road closures across the region, while the winds produced primarily tree, power line and power pole damage.  However, several structures received minor, mainly roofing damage and one mobile home was destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were flooded in Moultrie county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense storm moved across the Aleutians into the Bering Sea producing hurricane force wind along the Aleutians then Blizzard conditions across the Pribilof Islands to the Bering Sea Coast on the 23rd and 24th.

A strong trough of low pressure in the upper atmosphere moved into the southwest U.S. late on the 17th and early on the 18th.  The system was very fast moving with a strong jet of 165 kts streaming up the east side of the trough.  A short wave ejected out of the trough and raced northeast through the central U.S., reaching Illinois by the morning of the 19th.  Low pressure at the surface formed over western Kansas during the afternoon of the 18th. It moved to northeast Kansas by evening, and to near Burlington, IA by sunrise on the 19th.  A strong low level jet pushed moisture over a polar airmass that was in place over Iowa.  In addition, the atmosphere became quite unstable for December over the state, resulting in the development of thunderstorms over a large part of Iowa during the overnight hours of the 18th into the 19th.  Temperatures over southern Iowa remained in the 20s through the event, though the cold layer was quite shallow.  Temperatures aloft rose well above freezing, thus most of the precipitation that fell came in the form of freezing rain.  The freezing rain turned to sleet and snow briefly before ending.  Heavy ice accumulations occurred over southern Iowa, especially the southwest and southeast parts of the DSM CWA.  Ice accrual reached one half inch over Davis County, and around 0.6 inches in Adams Counties for the heaviest amounts.  Most of the area received between 0.25 and 0.4 inches of ice.  Spotty power outages were reported, however much of the power problems were mitigated by efforts the previous summer with tree trimming by the power utilities. Roads became very icy with all roads 100% ice covered.  Nearly all schools and many activities were cancelled for the 19th due to the ice.

An inverted trough of low pressure at the surface moved through the state during the early morning of the 20th into the day on the 20th. At the same time, a strong low pressure deepened in the upper atmosphere over and just northeast of the state.  The combination drew down Arctic air into the central U.S. A tight pressure gradient developed between the developing low to the east and Arctic high pressure to the northwest.  Winds increased on the 20th, and continued through most of the day on the 21st.  Sustained wind speeds were in the 25 to 35 MPH range, with gusts of 40 to 50 MPH.  Very little snow fell with the inverted trough, generally an inch or two, however antecedent snow cover was quite high with 7 to 12 inches common.  The winds caused whiteout conditions for an extended period of time as the snow that was loose blew in open areas.  Much of the deeper snow had crusted over, so blizzard conditions were somewhat sporadic and not as widespread as would normally be expected.  The first and second order reporting stations did not meet blizzard criteria outside of occasionally, however law enforcement officials reported visibility frequently reduced to between 10 and 100 feet in open areas.  Travel was therefore not recommended across all of the northern part of Iowa north of U.S. Highway 30.  Roads drifted shut quickly and snowplows were taken off of several roads during the height of the storm.  In addition to the wind, temperatures fell below zero, resulting in dangerous wind chill indices in the -30 to -40 F. range.

With abundant ground moisture, dense fog developed over parts of the central and southern San Joaquin Valley during the early morning of the 27th. The fog lifted into a stratus layer during the afternoon and evening, keeping the Valley free on dense fog the night of the 27th-28th. Dense fog did redevelop just before daybreak on the 29th, lasting into the late morning. November ended on a foggy note in the central and south Valley, with dense fog developing shortly after midnight on the 30th and persisting through midday.

A few clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms impacted southern Missouri with large hail, damaging winds, and a couple of tornadoes.  The two tornadoes were confirmed by a National Weather Service storm survey over Douglas County, including northern sections of the city of Ava.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down from thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved east across northern Ohio during the afternoon of July 26th.  Severe thunderstorms developed along this front.  Large hail was reported with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a few trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved east across northern Ohio during the afternoon of July 26th.  Severe thunderstorms developed along this front.  Large hail was reported with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought heavy, wet snow to portions of Eastern Kentucky on the evening of December 11th. The snow occurred as colder air moved in behind the departing storm system. Earlier in the day, rain, and some freezing rain, fell across the area. A quick change to snow occurred in the evening. The heavy wet snow stuck to trees, weighing them down and causing many to snap.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least four inches of snow fell in northern Owsley County near the Lee County border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex storm system brought a wintry mix of precipitation fell across Eastern Kentucky on December 15th into the 16th. The heaviest precipitation fell mainly along and north of the Mountain Parkway, where freezing rain, sleet, and snow created hazardous travel conditions. A warm front moved north across the area late on the 16th, changing the precipitation to all rain from south to north.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to a half inch of sleet and freezing rain created major travel problems through Bath County.  Interstate 64 was closed for several hours due to accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a low pressure system tracking east across northern New York State, and a second low pressure rapidly developing across the Canadian Maritimes created a tight pressure gradient across much of eastern New York and western New England during Sunday afternoon and evening, December 7th. This tight pressure gradient led to strong west to northwest winds, with sustained speeds of 15 to 30 mph, and gusts of up to 55 mph.||These strong winds led to some downed tree limbs, and subsequent scattered power outages across the region Sunday afternoon and evening.

During November, drought conditions expanded southwest across South Texas. By the end of November, severe drought conditions existed across Bee, Goliad, Victoria, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, Live Oak, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties by the end of November. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during November continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was becoming sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during November. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During November, drought conditions expanded southwest across South Texas. By the end of November, severe drought conditions existed across Bee, Goliad, Victoria, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, Live Oak, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties by the end of November. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during November continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was becoming sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during November. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low to mid level low pressure trough meandering across the northeast Caribbean and adjacent Atlantic, helped to maintain abundant tropical moisture and very weak winds over the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding was reported in the flood plain of river Cibuco, along road 620, at Barrio Fatima.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Canadian air mass plunged southeast into the Central Plains during the late morning and afternoon hours of October 26th as temperatures in the 30s and 40s replaced 60s to around 70 which were observed the previous afternoon.  The cold air was ushered into the region on northwest winds that were sustained at 30 to 35 mph with gusts of 45 to 55 mph.  A few wind gusts reached high wind criteria of 58 mph or greater for a brief period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts reaching 59 mph were measured by Dept. of Roads wind equipment near Cedar Rapids.  Wind gusts of this magnitude were recorded for around a 3 hour period from 1pm through 4pm CDT.  The winds were the result of Canadian air spilling southeast across the plains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant early-season winter storm brought significant precipitation and wind to Central and Southern California. Rainfall totals across the forecast area ranged between 1 and 3 inches. Along with the rainfall totals, the rainfall rates were high enough to produce mud and debris flows near some burn areas. In the mountains, significant winter storm conditions were reported. Snowfall totals between 10 and 16 inches were reported. In addition, winds gusting to around 55 mph produce areas of reduced visibilities in snow and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bands of showers produced intense rainfall rates in and around the Gap Fire burn area. The West Camino Cielo sensor reported 1.47 inches of rainfall in one hour. With such intense rainfall rates, mud and debris flows were reported. Fortunately, areas affected by the mud and debris flows were protected by a fence. Behind the fence, up to 6 feet of mud and debris was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant early-season winter storm brought significant precipitation and wind to Central and Southern California. Rainfall totals across the forecast area ranged between 1 and 3 inches. Along with the rainfall totals, the rainfall rates were high enough to produce mud and debris flows near some burn areas. In the mountains, significant winter storm conditions were reported. Snowfall totals between 10 and 16 inches were reported. In addition, winds gusting to around 55 mph produce areas of reduced visibilities in snow and blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bands of showers produced intense rainfall rates across the Tea Fire burn area. Rainfall rates in excess of 0.50 inches per hours were reported. The intense showers produced mud and debris flows which forced the closure of East Mountain Drive south of the burn scar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A extremely cold early-season storm heavy snow and strong winds to the mountains and deserts of Los Angeles county. Cold air associated with the storm dropped snow levels down to around 1500 feet. With such low snow levels, significant snowfall accumulations were reported across the Antelope Valley where elevations are around 2500 feet. In addition to the snowfall, very strong northeast winds gusting to between 35 and 55 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A very cold early-season storm brought heavy snow and gusty northeast winds to the Antelope Valley. With snow levels down to around 1500 feet, all areas across the Antelope Valley received significant snowfall. Llano reported 22 inches of snowfall while Lake Los Angeles and Palmdale reported between 8 and 10 inches of snowfall. Along with the snowfall, northeast winds gusting to around 35 mph were reported. Numerous roadways across the Antelope Valley were closed due to winter storm conditions.

A fast moving line of convective showers accompanied a strong cold front. The showers were moving east and northeast around 50 to 55 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were knocked down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below average rainfall allowed for Severe (D2) and Extreme (D3) drought to continue across much of northwest North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The month began with a Severe (D2) drought across the far southwest portion of the county and Moderate (D1) across the remainder of the county.  On June 10th, conditions had worsened across all but the northeast part of the county to a Severe (D2) drought.  On June 17th, all of the county was categorized as being in a Severe (D2) drought.  This category of drought continued through the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly developing storm system moved over the southern plains, with moderate to heavy snowfall occurring in southern and southeast Oklahoma. Although temperatures began the morning in the middle to upper 30s, temperatures quickly cooled into the lower 30s as moderate to heavy snowfall began. The storm system continued its intensification as it moved  into eastern Oklahoma and western Arkansas, with the snowfall intensity also increasing. Snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches were common over the southeast third of Oklahoma, with locally higher amounts of 10 inches. As expected with the heavy snowfall, traffic on area roadways was significantly slowed, with a few minor accidents. Monetary damages were estimated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three inches of snow was measured in Coleman, with 3.1 inches measured in Tishomingo.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust to 68 mph was reported at Babb. Additionally, wind gusts to 78 mph and 59 mph were reported at the DOT site at Two Medicine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak surface low developed across the Great Lakes on December 16th and moved into northern New York by the morning of December 17th. A secondary low formed south of New England during the early morning hours of December 17th and moved east of New England by the evening.||Snow overspread Vermont after midnight on the 17th and accumulated 3 to 6 inches before tapering to snow showers and ending by early afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the state during the early morning hours of the 27th.  Temperatures fell from the 50s into the upper 20s to low 30s within an hour or two.  The cold air was very shallow with warm air continuing to stream into the state.  A large area of thunderstorms developed on the cold side of the cold frontal boundary.  The rain fell into the cold air at the surface, resulting in widespread glazing across much of the southeast half of the Des Moines CWA as temperatures had fallen into the 20s by the time the thunderstorms moved through.  Ice accumulated quite quickly with one quarter inch amounts quite widespread.  Spotty one half inch amounts were reported over parts of central, south central, and southeast Iowa as thunderstorms produced heavier rainfall in those areas.  Scattered power outages were reported across the area and roadways became treacherous due to the icing.  Overall, damage was not all that extensive as the areas that received half inch amounts of ice were relatively small.

Snowfall amounts in inches included 3.5 miles northeast of Dallesport(8), Wishram(6), 3 miles east southeast of Kittitas(6), 5 miles north northwest of Ellensburg(4), Toppenish(4), Yakima(4.8), 5 miles west of Kennewick(4.5), Connell(6), 4 miles east northeast of Dixie(6), Walla Walla(5), Touchet SnoTel(13.5), Ski Bluewood(10), Naches(8), 3 miles northwest of Cle Elum(10.5), 3 miles southeast of BZ Corner(9.5), Snowden(10).

During November, drought conditions expanded southwest across South Texas. By the end of November, severe drought conditions existed across Bee, Goliad, Victoria, Refugio, Aransas, and San Patricio counties. Moderate drought existed across Calhoun, Live Oak, McMullen, La Salle, Nueces, northern Jim Wells and northern Duval counties by the end of November. Abnormally dry conditions were observed across Webb, Kleberg, southern Jim Wells and southern Duval counties. (per the U.S. Drought Monitor:  http://www.drought.unl.edu/dm/monitor.html)||The primary impacts of the drought during November continued to be agricultural in drought counties. Forage was becoming sparse and the supplemental feeding of hay to livestock continued.  The fire danger threat also increased during November. In addition, reservoir levels continued a gradual fall. Rivers and creeks in the rainfall deficit areas continued a slow fall, and were below baseflow.
